LaBoeuf is more of a side character, despite having his own reasons for wanting to find the killer. Still, he does eventually prove to have a purpose in the movie.All in all, this is not a masterpiece (certainly not the Coen brothers' best movie), but I still recommend it. Jeff Bridges almost chills your bones as the gruff Cogburn, staying focused on his business while maintaining a rather sordid lifestyle. Matt Damon didn't catch my attention as much, but a lot of praise should go to newcomer Hailee Steinfeld as the brave, young Mattie. There's nothing "cute" about this girl.So, while this might not be the best movie, I still encourage you to see it. Also starring Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper.

Short and sweet on this one... I am a huge John Wayne fan and as such this movie pales in comparison just a little for me, however it is a good movie, a good story, well-acted and Directed. I only ask you see the original John Wayne version and then watch Jeff Bridges as Rooster.Good Solid movie and a credit to the Western genre. A side note I had a bag of Cape Cod BBQ chips while I watched this movie and I enjoyed them both.

reviews.review_title: It was good but not sure why they bothered
reviews.content: Just got back form the movie. It was very good but didn't add anything. I'd heard the Cohens have said they were making a movie about the book, not a re-make of the movie. There are some differences, but not many, the 1969 movie was pretty close to the book too. I think the changes from the novel in the original movie were good and made sense. Matt Damon and Haliee Steinfeld are an improvement on Glen Campbell and Kim Darby but Jeff Bridges, who I like, is in no way a John Wayne. Bridges wisely doesn't try to do anything like Wayne, it's a completely original performance and it's pretty good. However, you can't watch that character and that story and not think about John Wayne. I don't think the pacing or soundtrack is as good as the original. There was more comedy in the first version and also, surprisingly, I think the violence was better too. Also, the country and photography was better in the first. Upon reflection, I guess I just wish they'd made some other western, maybe "The Law at Renaldo", that was a good book that hasn't been filmed.

Young Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) recruits U.S. Marshal Reuben 'Rooster' Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to help her hunt down Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), the scoundrel who robbed and murdered her father. Tagging along is LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), a Texas Ranger who is hunting Chaney for the murder of a Texas senator (and his dog). The Coen brothers bring a muted version of their distinctive style to this version of Charles Portis' novel and the result is an excellent revisionist Western, with a classic anti-hero in Cogburn, who likes to 'pull a cork' and condones the occasional extrajudicial killing when it's called for. Bridges is great as the tough, often drunk 'one-eyed fat man' as is 14-year old Steinfeld as the tenacious (and sometimes vexatious) girl who is searching for 'frontier justice'. The cinematography is excellent and the film has an authentic feel for time and place although I found the dialogue at times to be a bit 'stagy' (especially Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper) who sounded a bit like a character from HBO's 'Deadwood' (2004) without the imaginative profanity). All in all, an excellent version of a great Western story and a worthy successor the 1969 version, for which John Wayne finally won an Academy Award (and undeserving of its own Oscar snub (10 nominations, 0 wins)).

Can't really discuss "True Grit" without comparing versions, but the Coen brothers have succeeded in making an engaging movie (not to mention Western)and their version is an improvement in a couple of ways. Casting, first and foremost, and Hailee Steinfeld, surrounded by veteran performers, manages to steal the movie. I can't speak highly enough of her ability to hold her own. And the back-and-forth between Bridges and Damon is hilarious. It's a great group of actors.This movie also has the superior payoff; bittersweet, to be sure, but bursting with sentiment. When all is said and done, this version is much better at hitting on the actual meaning of the film's title.7/10

Hands down the worst thing I've seen by the C Bros, to the point I wondered if someone else was behind the camera. The story is generic, the characters are painfully annoying and overdone. The dialogue is campy. It's just not very good. Bad film. Bad script. Etc...I disliked the film the whole time I was watching it, especially the young actress playing the "spunky" female protagonist. She was particularly insufferable to listen to and watch. She overacted all her lines.There is some cool action sequences but other than that there is nothing worth viewing here. You can't enjoy a film just because it's a western and just because it's by the Coen Brothers. That won't cut it with me. It has to actually be good, and this isn't.Please avoid.

reviews.review_title: Coen Brothers' re-make has impressive cinematography and set design but plot is nothing to write home about
reviews.content: I have to disagree with Rene Rodriguez of the Miami Herald who downgraded 'True Grit' slightly because of what she terms "the prevailing lack of Coen-ness in the movie." In fact, that's precisely why the movie worked a lot better than many of their previous offerings (usually involving trashing one of their prototypical straw man anti-heroes as well as reveling in their ubiquitous 'glass is half-empty' philosophy of life). The Coens have been quoted as saying that they approached the True Grit source material quite reverently, based on Charles Portis' 1968 novel, "with its emphasis on adventure and quest." As usual the Coen cinematography and set design is excellent, creating a much better look to the old west, than the way it was depicted in the first True Grit vehicle, starring John Wayne. Except for the ending and a greater emphasis on Mattie Ross (focusing on the clever 14 year old, as the story's main protagonist), both versions pretty much followed the main plot points as found in the novel.I found this 'True Grit' to be mildly interesting but often slow-moving. It takes quite a while before 14 year old Mattie conscripts Rooster Cogburn, the 'meanest' US Marshall in the west, who will eventually track down Chaney, the man who killed her father. Joining them along the way is LaBouef, the Texas Ranger played by Matt Damon, who is also seeking Chaney for the killing of a Texas State Senator. When Mattie objects to LaBouef and Cogburn agreeing to bring Chaney back to Texas and not to her hometown to stand trial for the murder of her father, she receives a whipping from LeBouef. Cogburn intervenes, preventing LaBouef from inflicting additional punishment, and he then leaves.Although one of the strong suits of the film is the dialogue which features interesting local references, it's often hard to understand much of it, as Jeff Bridges has a tendency to mumble his words. The Coen brothers are determined to make this True Grit more 'grittier' and play up the violence. Cogburn is not politically correct when he gruffly tosses two Native Americans off a porch as he looks for an outlaw, Ned Pepper, and his gang, who are reportedly traveling with Chaney. When he finds two outlaws, Quincey and Moon, in an empty dugout, Quincey cuts off Moon's fingers and stabs him in the chest, to prevent him from talking, with Cogburn forced then to dispose of Quincey.Most of the rest of 'True Grit' is perfunctory. Ned shows up with his gang and Cogburn kills some of them with his shotgun, saving LeBouef in the process (who showed up earlier, right before the gang comes on the scene). Eventually, Mattie is kidnapped by Chaney, Cogburn kills most of Ned's gang, but is saved at the last moment by LaBouef, who shoots Ned, from a cliff, 400 yards away. Oh yes, Mattie eventually kills Chaney but falls into what looks like an abandoned mine, only to be saved by Cogburn after she's bitten by a rattlesnake.True Grit has its moments, but there are really few surprises overall, in this average tale of a teenager's desire for vengeance. Much of the conflict stems from the tension between the perspicacious Mattie and Cogburn, who is often befuddled by the tenacity of such a female. It works occasionally because it's nice to see such a macho character as Cogburn, get his comeuppance. But Cogburn is also such a one-note character, that the machinations between the two principals, begins to grow tiresome. As for the plot, it's basically a tale of the good guys dispatching the bad guys (with antagonists who aren't particularly interesting). The film might have worked a bit better if we arrived at the climax a bit sooner.The Coen Brothers did well in adding on the ending which is found in the novel but not in the 1968 film. We see Maddie (sans an arm due to the snake bite) now as a grown woman, looking for Cogburn, but tragically misses him by only three days (Cogburn, employed at a circus, dies right before Maddie can find him). After all the excitement, Maddie ironically turns out to be a spinster, in her adulthood (no CGI effects here folks; the Coens actually did a nationwide search and found a one-armed woman, who could play the part). Perhaps True Grit's main problem is that it's based on source material that has quite a bit of realistic dialogue but no real twists and turns in the plot. I liked Hailee Steinfeld as the new Maddie, as she provides a more 'serious' approach than the Kim Darby version in 1968. As for Jeff Bridges, some have said he's guilty of overacting; I leave further evaluations for the pundits, although again, I think he could have done better in annunciating his lines a bit better. Damon fails to bring anything distinctive to the thankless part of LaBouef.In the end, True Grit pretty much is an average western, featuring better than usual dialogue as well as a great deal of impressive cinematography. For once the Coen brothers decide not to stand above the fray and expect to be congratulated for shooting down one of their usual straw men. This time, they've done an honest job in attempting to adapt someone else's material. Not all of it works but one can say it's mighty nice to look at—and that's no small feat.

reviews.review_title: One of you is gonna have to be the caller. I will tell you what to say. I will do all the other parts myself.
reviews.content: There has never been a more John Wayne role than Rooster Cogburn in Henry Hathaway's True Grit. It was the old western relic at his most uninhibited and unashamed, sporting an effectively hammy eye-patch that I surmise Wayne might have just grabbed on his way through the wardrobe department. Audiences lapped it up because the traditional conservative figure descended into self-parody, and Wayne embraced every bit of the tough-loving, no-nonsense hardman of the west. Consider the final 'showdown' of the film, where Cogburn leans into his horse, pistol in one hand, rifle in the other (he holds the reins with his teeth), and charges at the four goons across the plain. No one but Wayne himself could ever sell the audaciousness of a four-on-one shootout posed like a medieval joust, and Bridges, who has been bumbling about for most of the remake, doesn't have the self-imposed gravitas and hardness to make it meaningful or dramatic. The original was a tale of two heads clashing - Cogburn, the stubborn old rooster, and Mattie Ross, the equally stubborn young hen, and how neither of them gave up any ground. It was only through the story and journey that they learnt to get along and even care for one another. But the power imbalance of this relationship in the remake means we don't get the same clashes. Bridges has no grit, taking a leaf out of his Lebowski instead of Wayne's numerous collections of weathered hardmen. His introduction is reminiscent of the stoner hero; squatting in the outhouse, grumbling about his 'business' being interrupted, playing off the straight-laced Ross. A similar scene is staged mostly for humour and the viewer's benefit - Bridges tossing up bread into the sky and being outdrawn by LaBoeuf, but not before spluttering and falling unceremoniously from his saddle. In these moments the character does nothing but service a joke, but because Bridges never goes beyond them, he doesn't earn his final redemption. Wayne's bravado of violence and self-importance was a facade that lent itself to each postured moment where he dominated the screen. Wayne didn't simply utter dialogue, he strutted and growled through his entire body and eyes, and until Ross we understand that nobody had ever challenged him on it. Bridges' version, on the other hand, mumbles through most of his lines, and shrinks rather than rising to the occasion. There is no narrative process where he is gradually humbled and stripped of his outward persona, and therefore no payoff. In LaBoeuf there is also an interesting transformation. Glen Campbell was a country singer first and actor second, and there is little comparison to Damon, but he plays his role well. The character is an archetype plucked straight from Texas, a sort of larger than life cowboy, a straight shooter for truth and justice. It's a bit role that requires a very specific type of character, one that is humourless and uptight, and Damon doesn't fit the mould. Watch how he has to strain and clench his jaw to keep within the character's parameters. In fact all of the original cast were tightly held by the same formal, literal prose from Charles Portis' novel - the kind of speech which forgoes contractions and gets straight to the point. The Coens, unsurprisingly, render this comedic and twist it into their traditionally deadpan deliveries. "If you want to kiss him it will be all right," recites the undertaker to a grieving Ross in the beginning. Steinfeld is the only one who makes this dialogue work in a remake burdened by the Coens' familiar post-modern irony, subversion and outlandish signposting. Some obvious examples: the bear-head costume, how a hanged man's last words are cut off, the cackling midget of Pepper's gang. Most egregiously, in how the violence is stylised and then played for laughs - see how the camera casually pans down to the chopped-off digits after the dramatic shooting, and then is loudly interrupted by Bridges' "GOD DANG IT". Kim Darby was good in the original, with the impetuosity of a teacher's pet who always got her way and a motor mouth to back up her actions. She wielding the phrase 'Lawyer Daggett' like a magical spell and practically bullied older men into giving her what she wanted. Steinfeld is even better. She is younger, yet does not recall the brashness of Darby - she's not the teacher's pet but the teacher herself, shamelessly scolding adults and criminals like misbehaving schoolchildren that would dare deny her the justice she deserves. She nails my favourite part of the film where Ross squeezes between the two bounty hunters arguing, and reduces them to grumpy children wanting to hear a bedtime story: "Would you two like to hear the story of the Midnight caller?" Steinfeld pulls this off with a nervous smile about her, not only because of the simmering hostility in the air but also because she is opening up a bit of herself beyond that initial persona, and hinting at an underlying kindness and childishness that the west would see as a weakness and gobble up immediately. The Coens know this, so they cut straight to her tuckered up in blankets upon a horse, and expose her for the brave little girl she really is. They also bring back the original ending of the novel where an older Ross reminisces on how both men, much like the west, faded into obscurity and how she singularly held onto that time in her memory. I would love to presume that the Coens are using layers of history to meditate on the nature of legend, myth, storytelling - how the truth is usually funnier and harsher than the stories they form - but a glance seems to confirm that it is merely them not being able to resist their usual trademarks. But they have never really been able to hold back from this, except perhaps in No Country.

True Grit is based upon the novel of the same name by Charles Portis. Many who will go to see it will also recall that it was a film in 1969 which starred John Wayne and won him an Oscar for the same character that this time around, Jeff Bridges will most likely get an Academy Award nomination for playing. The film takes place in the late 1800's to early 1900's and is about a determined and fiery young woman named Mattie Ross, who goes into town to settle her late father's affairs. She vows to get even with the man who shot her father dead and decides to look for a marshal to bring him down. Mattie comes across the cantankerous and moody Rooster Cogburn and decides that he is the right man for the job. After some persuasion, Rooster agrees and the two of them are off on a manhunt to bring back the killer of her father, whether dead, or alive. I would like to start off by saying that I have never seen the popular 1969 film version of True Grit and I have also never read the novel on which both films were based. As any fan of films can tell you, John Wayne was and still after his death is one of the most popular movie stars of all time. People loved the westerns that he starred in and he had a lot of loyal fans. To some of those fans remaking, or doing a new version on one of his films, let alone the film that won him his Oscar should not be touched and I could see where some of those fans may not even want to see this new version. As, I said, having never seen the original version, I can not truthfully make any comparisons between the two. However, I did find myself immensely enjoying this new version. Westerns are not normally my favourite genre because I find that they can get pretty formulaic and clichéd, but I felt this version of True Grit did everything right. It gives us a very entertaining story that is not only filled with a lot of entertainment, good character study, humour and some well played out action scenes, but it also is done with a lot of craft and care and the film comes off looking like a beauty. The story itself, I think is further enhanced by the great characters and how well and developed they are. The relationship between the crotchety Rooster and the determined and spitfire Mattie, is actually a joy to watch because their screen relationship is so good between one another because of their great conversations and even when they are saying nothing at all the performances by Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld are perfect. They will definitely both be up for acting Oscars for this film and both are well deserved nominations. The rest of the cast is all very good here as well, including even the minor characters. The mood of the film was at times atmospheric with beautiful cinematography and art and set decoration and at other times it is grim, at others full of action and there is even some true laugh out loud moments in the film. The editing and direction are tight and well on display here and it is put together perfectly. This is definitely a film where the entire cast and crew gives there all and the result is fantastic. I loved True Grit for the great screen chemistry between Bridges and Steinfeld, their relationship as well as the words they exchange with one another and the fact that they really do care for one another. The story itself is intriguing and we want to keep watching as a viewer to see what will happen and at times it is really exciting. The action scenes are well shot and played fairly low key, so nothing is over the top, or ridiculous looking. As well as the great performances and look and feel of the film, this is the type of film that critics will love and the average moviegoer will love as well. True Grit did everything right and turned out, so much better than I thought it would be, to the point where I would call it one of the best films of 2010 and worthy of any and all Oscar nominations it is up for.

True Grit crackles and pops across the sweeping vistas of the Wild West, a time where the frontier actually existed, where young girls could pursue their father's killer in the name of revenge, and a time where a U.S. Marshall could be judge, jury, and executioner without any real appeal. The Coen Brothers have crafted a Western adventure that is everything a great Western should be, and something that many Westerns have lacked. They take us back to a simpler time, where men roamed the wilderness, where it was either good or bad, scoundrel or coward, and it is this simplicity that makes True Grit the superb cinematic achievement that it is.Fourteen-year-old Mattie Ross's father was murdered by the coward Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Mattie (newcomer Hailee Steinfeld) recruits U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to hunt Chaney down and bring him to justice, but here's the catch, Mattie must accompany Cogburn across the wilderness to exact her revenge upon Chaney. Along the way there are electrifying gunfights, beautiful landscapes, and a self-promoting Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), who often teams up with Mattie and Rooster. The hunt is on.Writer/directors Joel and Ethan Coen make a sentimental film to a time long lost, without feeling at all sentimental, but being a work in memory of the time. Throughout the entire film, the Coens keep it pure and simple, and simplicity is the thing that makes this movie excel. There are no complex narrative structures or crazy frills and whistles, the movie does not innovate in these areas, but just does so well with what already exists. The cinematography from Roger Deakins is simply marvelous. Never is there an unnecessary camera movement or hand-held camera work to add some grit, but rather the cinematography is always precise and captures the essence of simplicity. Helping aid the simplicity, the score from Carter Burwell, adapted from four old 1800s hymns, is never obtrusive, always played purely, effectively, and reminiscent of what an 1800s church service might have felt like with just a couple twenty people and an organ to sing to.The Coen Brothers' script sizzles with their trademark comedic flare, and it is through the humor that comes simply from the characters being themselves that creates a camaraderie between Mattie, Cogburn, and LaBeouf. Everyone is not as they seem in this movie. Mattie, contrary to her appearance, is a tough girl who will trek the wilderness to hunt down a killer, but she is also a compassionate person who sees things in others that no one else sees. Mattie sees beyond Cogburn's gruff exterior, and becomes his spunky sidekick, knowing that he is a man of heart who will carry her across the plains to save her life. Not only that, Mattie comes to believe in LaBeouf more than he does in himself, that he is a greater Ranger than both he and Cogburn give him credit for. But what makes their camaraderie work are the performances of the actors. Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon deliver as one would expect, but the scene stealer is always thirteen-year-old Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie. Steinfeld is a firecracker whose emotions are pure, innocent, and straight-to-the-point. Nothing in her performance ever seems over-thought, but just natural, and the tears of her seeing a horse put down or her fear when she falls into a pit of rattlesnakes, is true to human nature.Never have I been more enthralled by a Wild West adventure than I was by the Coens' True Grit. Their simplistic view of a simpler time takes one back as a viewer to those times of their simplistic childhood, where we idolized heroes, and despised the villains. We were Mattie, and for a few hours, the Coens allow us to remember what it was like to be her.I give True Grit a 10 out of 10!

reviews.review_title: It's different but just as good as the original (IMO)...
reviews.content: Having seen, and loved, the original 1969 version of this story starring John Wayne I was intrigued to see the Coen Brothers' take on it. As is usually the case with these things, it didn't show at my local cinema and so I waited patiently for it to appear on TV. As you can probably guess, it put in an appearance this week and I'm very pleased to report its well worth a look. I will tell you why after this brief summary.Fourteen year old Mattie Ross has been sent to claim the body of her dead father, shot by a man employed by him called Tom Chaney. Now Chaney had run for the 'Indian Territory' after the event which makes him the responsibility of the U.S. Marshall's service. To this end, Mattie engages U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn to bring Chaney to justice. A Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf, is also interested in finding Chaney as he had shot a Senator while down there. Cogburn and LaBoeuf plan to find Chaney on their own and bring him to justice in Texas, but they hadn't bargained for the tenacity of the young Mattie Ross. We follow them into the 'Indian Territory' in their pursuit of the fugitive who they believe to be running with one Lucky Ned Pepper. I will leave it there or the Spoiler Police (Western's Division) will be sending Cogburn after me (again).Nicely shot, but with a much 'starker' feel to it than the original; it also lacks the majesty of the surroundings that the original had. Having said that, this doesn't detract too much from the story which is very well written and performed. And on that subject, we have to give praise to Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn who, despite a rather mumbled performance, does really well! Also worthy of note were both Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross and Matt Damon as LaBoeuf who both put in great performances also. Honourable mentions must also go to Josh Brolin as Tom Chaney and Barry Pepper as Lucky Ned Pepper.Much has been made of the dialogue and how it more closely matches the original novel. Well, yes it does, but then again the 1969 version wasn't a million miles away from it either. There are, however, some interesting, and welcome, additions and alterations to the narrative that weren't included in the original. I really liked these and they gave the film a little extra that I wasn't expecting. Now I have to talk about the performance of Hailee Steinfeld; while quite different to Kim Darby's 1969 performance, I found the character grew on me as it went on. I believe Kim Darby was quite a bit older when she made the film and I think is shows in her slightly more polished performance. That's not to take anything away from Hailee Steinfeld, she's a fine actress and I hope this performance brings her much success in the future. Over all, I like both films but the Coen's version slightly has the edge (at the moment). Worth a watch Hell yes!... Recommended.My score: 8.2/10.IMDb Score: 7.8/10 (based on 106,408 votes at the time of going to press).Rotten Tomatoes 'Tomatometer' Score: 96/100 (based on 248 reviews counted at the time of going to press).Rotten Tomatoes 'Audience' Score: 86/100 (based on 108,965 user ratings counted at the time of going to press).

When I hear of a remake of a film wherein I was fond of the original, I am not usually eager to see it. But after watching this film last night (industry screener copy), I wish the Coen Brothers would remake a few more films. Their version of True Grit is an engrossing masterpiece. The main adjective that describes the viewing experience is...immersive. I have rarely felt so incredibly immersed in a world and a subject matter. Every detail of every performance is simultaneously both quotidian and extraordinary. Every detail of the world depicted on film makes me feel like I'm there.And the script -- the dialogue is colorful yet plain speaking, mundane yet deep. If I keep describing the film in contradictions, I guess it's because it's rare that a film can give us a glimpse of the contradiction that is life. There are odd bursts of humor -- the kind that happens in real life. Perhaps because the sudden violence that is depicted seems so real, the humor is all the more appreciated. By the characters themselves as well as the viewing audience. The direction is brilliant -- the Coen Brothers at their best. And the cast is uniformly brilliant, even the smallest bit player. Jeff Bridges, Josh Brolin, Matt Damon -- all a joy to watch. But the young actress Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie is perhaps the most notable simply because it's her first movie, her first starring role. What a debut! She has an intensity that leaps off the screen effortlessly and makes us care about her plight from the first second we see her.Forgive the hagiographic nature of this review -- but this movie is just that good. The most satisfying movie-going experience in years. In an age with a relentless onslaught of those horrid comic book superhero movies and bland romantic comedies alleviated only by the pretentious dreary indies and headache-inducing 3d pap thrown in the mix, it's a relief to see a movie so well crafted as this. It pulls you in from the beginning and doesn't let go till the credits roll. Thanks Coen Brothers, for writing this and directing it and picking such a great cast and crew. Thanks for reminding me why the movies were invented.

reviews.review_title: A Western film, the only one worth mentioning in the last 3 years
reviews.content: Mattie Ross' (Hailee Steinfeld) father has been murdered. She wants the man who killed him, Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) to be shot dead. To do this, she enlists the help of Deputy Marshal Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges).Cogburn is a barely functioning alcoholic, but still mighty good with a gun. He accepts her offer of $100 to hunt down the man who killed her father. He is joined by a Texas Ranger named La Boeuf (Matt Damon). Mattie accompanies them on their hunt, because she doesn't trust either of them.The rest of the story is the group's exploits in attempting to find the man who killed Mattie's father. That is just about it. There isn't a twist, there isn't a lot on the film's mind, and it's just a well-told adventure story in a western setting. Since this is a Coen brothers film, that also means that the adventure will be compelling and the characters will be interesting. The movie will also be of high quality, this we can almost be sure of before even viewing it."True Grit" is adapted from the 1968 novel of the same name. The novel had already been made into a film one year later in 1969. That film starred John Wayne, and won him the Academy Award for Best Actor. The Coen brothers have stated that they wanted their film to be more faithful to the novel than the 1969 film, and that they were not just reimagining that film.Whether or not their claim is true or not is something that is hard to discern. The story doesn't really have much to alter about it, and the genre is already set in stone. In fact, this is really the first time that the Coen brothers have stuck to their genre so rigorously. They adhere to most of the standards of the Western genre, not pushing any boundaries or taking any risks.There are only two things that actually make "True Grit" stand out from the other quality movies that are out nowadays, or the great Westerns that were made years past. The first way is differentiates itself is in the humor that it contains. The way that the Coen brothers have written their adaptation makes it humorous, while keeping a fairly dark tone. There are many funny situations and moments in dialogue, breaking up the dark moments with ones of humor.The second way that it is different is the fact that it is a Western. There haven't been many of those lately, so having one come out automatically makes "True Grit" stand out. The last big Western film to come out was 2007's 3:10 to Yuma, itself a critical success. Having a lack of competition will certainly help "True Grit" at the box office.Also helping it out is the fact that it features great acting performances. Despite the big names included in the cast like Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon, the lead of the film is actually 14-year-old Hailee Steinfeld. The story is told from her point of view, and she does a good job of carrying it. Selected from more than 15 000 auditions, Steinfeld won the role. This must have been created some anxiety from the filmmakers, as she hadn't starred in any large-scale production before. Nonetheless, the risk paid off, and she delivers an impressive performance. Her character is far more mature than many you would expect, being able to negotiate with several businessmen and get her way.Also great are the performances by Bridges and Damon. While they don't get as much attention as Steinfeld, they are perfect for their roles. Bridges job as an alcoholic, half-functioning U.S. Marshal is always entertaining, and Damon always seems like he's having fun, no matter what is happening in the story at the time.The story mixes a mystery with adventure, finding a good balance between the two. Characters have to look for clues regarding Chaney's whereabouts. They ride horses everywhere, and engage in shootouts. Characters travel great distances across the Wild West. There is a good sense of adventure that is given, and there is enough action to keep the audience's attention.The characters all have depth and they develop throughout "True Grit". We are given reason to care about Mattie right away, as her character is one to be empathized with. Her father's murder gives her motivation. We also end up caring about the other characters, especially that of Cogburn. We want to see him overcome all of his issues by the end of the film. We have that hope throughout, and it helps keep our attention during the slower moments."True Grit" is a good film that will get attention mostly because it is a new Western film, something that there have been few of as of late. It has an interesting story, great acting and the Coen brothers' unique style of humor. It's genuinely funny, and stays entertaining throughout. "True Grit" is a well-made film that may inspire similar films to be made in the near future. It's a great Western film, something we haven't had much of lately, and that will allow it to be a success. It's definitely worth a watch, so give it one.

I've never been a fan of westerns, but my father is a big John Wayne fan. He and I watched this film in theaters together, and by the time the credits rolled I was mind blown.
This film is truly amazing. The acting from Bridges, Damon and STIENFELD is incredible. The story is quite beautiful yet dark and heartbreaking at the same time.All in all, highly recommended for any western fans, especially Cohen brothers fans.

reviews.review_title: Neat Western with an outstanding performance by Jeff Bridges
reviews.content:

The plot is very Western like and interesting to follow for most parts.

reviews.review_title: "Come see a fat old man some time..."
reviews.content: So sayeth John Wayne at the end of the original "True Grit" back in 1969. Bridges character is portrayed no less gritty than Wayne's Cogburn, and is in fact given a nice sheen with his mean as a opossum in a cellar attitude. Bridges pulls no punches with his interpretation of Cogburn, and is not straddled by a larger than life reputation that accompanied Wayne with nearly all of his roles.So it is that we get to see not Wayne, not Bridges, but Cogburn himself in perhaps a purer form as intended by the author. There's a lot to praise in this film. First off, it's not an action piece. It's a good old fashioned Western with six shooters, horses, bandits, vendettas, rattlers, and everything that goes with it. There're ancient forces at work here; predator and prey, law and order, right and wrong. This stuff courses through this film.There aren't a lot of quick witted zingers, but there's good portioned humor scattered throughout, usually in the form of a wry observation, or other commentary that's peculiar prima facia, but otherwise a kind of truism worthy only of a US Marshal or Texas Ranger.It's a film that's respectably shot, decently acted, though there are no deep moments of tears, anger or other emotions. This is the old west. People have feelings, but they're secondary to survival in a world where those who've gone astray can pack a rifle or six-shooter, and spread their misery. They need to be dealt with, and it falls to the tin-star to bring them in.Look, I'll be honest here, I liked this film. But, compared to the high-glossed super-sexed action tripe that people seem to love so much today, I simply don't know if people are ready for this kind of film. One that goes back to basics; bear your pain (suck-it-up) and forge onward to see that right is done in the face of wrong. It will not look pretty at first, but the beauty is in seeing that justice, the law, has addressed the evil in men's hearts. I'm not sure the younger audience will except non-sexy film making.The shots are basic. They are functional. Again, this is old fashioned film making. This is not quick cut MTV shaky cam BS mixed in with a hyper bass track that makes your heart skip a beat. Nor is the content in the film white washed nor over played in terms of the times the characters inhabited. We have people dressed in the attire of the time, and living, thinking and speaking the way people did then. My grand parents and their grand parents and so forth. To live here, you must have true grit.I think of my own horse and firearm days, and no, they weren't anything like this, but I did camp out under the stars, fire different types of pistols and rifles, rode horses, hiked up in the coldest of the Rocky Mountains and trudged across deserts, and I could certainly get a sense for the characters and their surroundings.My final note is on the cast; superb. Bridges does an excellent job, as I mentioned before, as do all the rest who surround him. There isn't a single miscast here, and everyone does their job with great authority and execution.If movies weren't so expensive, I'd go see it again. In the meantime, give it a chance.

reviews.review_title: Slow, powerful western movie with a focus on dialog
reviews.content: A slow wild west story, it starts off as a narration by the protagonist, who recounts her experience while she was a 14 year old girl. Her father was murdered by one of his employees, Tom Cheney (Josh Brolin). She finds out that the law is moving slowly in delivering justice, and takes it on her own hand to hire an experienced tracker to hunt him down and bring him to justice.She hires Rooster Coogan (Jeff Bridges), a one eyed drunkard sheriff who was reputed to kill more than arrest. They are also joined by Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) who is also chasing Tom Cheney for crimes in Texas, for which a substantial reward is still pending.The movie is gripping, and the performances were very powerful. However, for some reason, I thought the 1969 John Wayne version had a better story - the story is slightly different towards the end. But I don't remember that all too well, so maybe I'm wrong.In any case, it's a pretty good movie to watch, if you're into the realistic, gritty, slow westerns, like 'Unforgiven'... (I use that for comparison, but Unforgiven is the better movie by leagues and miles.)

Sure, some John Wayne fans will stubbornly refuse to admit what is plainly visible in this remake of the original made in 1969. They'll say it's a travesty to remake John Wayne's Oscar winning movie..blah, blah, blah. but don't believe them. That's bias and sour grapes talking.This new effort is so obviously superior to the original that I am shocked to admit it. I watched the original a week before seeing the new version and must admit that although it was pleasant enough, the original has not aged as well as many other classic westerns. I believe the reason for this is Henry Hathaway's uneven direction, Elmer Bernstein's uncharacteristically weak musical score and Glen Campbell's horrible casting as La Boeuf. I enjoyed John Wayne, Kim Darby and Robert Duvall in the original but Wayne and Darby never really made an obvious emotional connection in the original. (In fact John Wayne commented on his low opinion of Kim Darby's acting skills after the movie was released.) By comparison Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfield hit it off in this new effort in a way I'm convinced John Wayne would have admired greatly. I personally place much of the blame for this with Hathaway not the actors. Despite John Wayne's criticism of Kim Darby I don't think they were out acted as much as Hathaway out-directed by the Coen's. This takes nothing away from the actors in the new version. Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and Hailee Steinfeld were absolutely fantastic, with Hailee Stanfield edging out the fantastic performance by Jeff Bridges. The overall direction, pacing, art direction, cinematography, music and casting all come together in away they simply did not in the original. It really is an amazing tribute to the Coen's collaborative genius. One thing I particularly appreciate that I'm sure many more conventional movie goers will not like is the ending, but then I hate syrupy happy ending in movies like this. (It's sooo Hollywood.) This is a darker movie with a more realistic feel to it, so the remake appropriately has a darker, more believable ending. Is it really hard to imagine that a woman as forthright and independent as Mattie Ross, minus her left arm, wouldn't be married? Is it hard to imagine that after being bitten by a rattlesnake and a days ride from help that she might lose her arm. Wake up people, Rooster Cogburn didn't ride her up to Johns Hopkins.If you like fairy tale westerns, with unrealistic happy endings, stick with the1969 version. If you like something a bit more realistic and poignant, go for the remake. The movie's named "True Grit" afterall.

reviews.review_title: To all those who hated this, take a second look...
reviews.content: I will admit, the first time i saw this movie on opening day I actually hated it for some reason(I really don't remember). But after seeing the trailer again and realizing that i actually fell asleep the first time and possibly missed the good parts, I decided to take a second look. My opinion had majorly changed. the plot is all about a young girl wanting to avenge her father,hires a marshal and a Texas ranger to aid her on her quest. PROS:-the performances are excellent for the genre and newcomer Hailee Steinfeld was fantastic and hopefully will get an award for her performance -the dialogue was witty and will well written and kept my attention -a treat for some horror fans, Jarlath Conroy makes a brief cameo which was fun -the soundtrack is very good and keeps the western on life support-the action pretty suspenseful and keeps the movie goingCONS: - the movie takes way too long to get to the point and it just drags to the good stuffOverall,the movie is a good thrill ride and brings us back to a time when westerns were fun,but it can get boring at times. be sure to take a caffeine pill or a can of monster before you go. I give this movie a 9. Thanks for reading. have a good day.:)

First off, I never saw the older version with John Wayne, so please don't expect me to comment about that at all. As far as this version with Jeff Bridges in the role that Wayne originally played, I thought it was pretty much half-baked.The plot is a very straightforward revenge-Western, with the twist being that it's a young girl who wants to "get this killin' done" to borrow a phrase from Dylan. It's reasonably hard-boiled and dry, with a couple good action scenes. There were two big problems that I had with the movie. First of all, I want to smack Joel and Ethan Coen and tell them that it's OK to use contractions. If the entire "style" of the piece hangs up such a thread, then it's probably not a very worthwhile style. Basically, if you have not yet seen this movie and you are reading my comments despite the spoiler warning, expect that every character in this movie talks like Commander Data on Star Trek. No matter what part of the country they come from or how drunk they are, they will not say won't. And I thought it was a bit.... gosh I hardly dare to use the word on the IMDb but maybe.... pretentious? The other thing was the whole ending, which I guess is where the generalized spoiler warning comes into effect. I thought as soon as Hailee shot Chaney and he turned into a CGI and she suddenly hurtled backwards down a mineshaft, all of a sudden it was a Roadrunner/Willie Coyote film and it was just utterly horrible, the entire rest of the film. Actually we can rewind... even the whole climactic showdown with Bridges against Barry Pepper (whose character's named, oddly enough, is Ned Pepper) and his gang was pretty underwhelming, with Bridges not really summoning anything special and with poor Pepper, one of our best working character actors, without enough screen time in the film to establish a memorable villain, it's kind of an anticlimax. And then with Josh Brolin popping up like a monster in a horror movie, and the rattlesnakes, I mean it's just too much for me.The acting is uniformly excellent. Matt Damon is coming along excellently as a star and managed to hold the screen with Bridges. Bridges himself is the star of the show and he knows it, but a generous and spontaneous performer here as always. Brolin didn't manage to do anything memorable except another enactment of his malignant buffoon routine, but he's good at that. Barry Pepper, again despite very limited time, was as impressive as always at conveying a character more complex than the scenario surrounding him. His performance seemed right out of a Boetticher film, quite a bit like Richard Boone in "The Tall T"... he's a leader of bad men who's just intelligent and wise enough to know how much of a better man (or in this case, girl) his enemies are than his "friends." I like the movie but I didn't find it compelling and I thought the conclusion was corny. I don't know if they were trying to stay true to the book, but it didn't work for me at all.

reviews.review_title: The Dude follows the Duke and Mattie Ross is a revelation.
reviews.content: It is my opinion that many of the people who go to see the Coen Brothers' re-imagination of True Grit will have little to no knowledge of the original version from 1969 starring John Wayne. Indeed, both follow the Charles Portis novel well while the Coens follow the plot more truly, sticking to much of the dialogue as well as certain story lines left out of the Wayne film.Regardless, this is a film that stands on its own, primarily because of the very strong acting. Jeff Bridges, always associated with his character from the Coens' 1998 classic The Big Lebowski, really gets under the skin of Rooster Cogburn, a curmudgeon of a federal marshal who is hired by the strong-willed and determined 14 year-old daughter of a recently murdered man to avenge his murder. The young girl, Mattie Ross, is played by newcomer Hallie Steinfeld, who is without a doubt a revelation of an actress, one so young yet so intelligently fierce in her performance, she stands nose-to-nose with every other actor in the film, who are needless to say great in their own right.Aside from the marvelous and immensely watchable Steinfeld, the Coens have put together an incredible cast, boasted by Bridges' method performance along with Matt Damon as the pompous Texas Ranger La Beouf, Josh Brolin as the vile and cutthroat Tom Chaney, and Barry Pepper as the infamous Lucky Ned Pepper. As with nearly all Coen films, the supporting cast is perfect, every single small role and extra filled just right to accentuate the main cast.This is much more of a straight up genre picture than the Coens have ever done, particularly in the Western form. That being the case, True Grit is not the instant masterpiece No Country for Old Men was, but it still has the immaculate quality of film making expected by the Coens every time out. Roger Deakins' photography is breathtakingly beautiful and sublime, Carter Burwell's score is minimalisticly aesthetic and the Coens write, direct and edit so perfectly, you forget to look for flaws or missteps and simply fall into this rather charming story of the relationship between a young girl and older man who somehow meet in the middle, rekindling the very thing that brought them together initially: a father-daughter relationship.This is perhaps the "nicest" Coen Brothers film ever, although given their past dark material that isn't saying much. It follows along smoothly, never stopping to include certain passages or characters unnecessary to the real story. Some may feel unmoved by it, but I find it hard to believe many people will leave feeling any remorse or empathy for Mattie Ross. She is a wonderful character, and Steinfeld's performance only enhances the beauty and majesty of this film. The true grit belongs to her and we admire how much she has as well as how she attains it.

reviews.review_title: True Academy Awards....Jeff Bridges, Hailee Steinfeld
reviews.content: My wife and I see over 100 movies a year, having been in the business and now retired. WE DO NOT READ ANY REVIEWS BY ANYONE. WE TRY TO TELL OUR FRIENDS THAT A CRITIC IS ONE PERSON, HE OR SHE IS NOT US. Critics are also a dying breed as newspapers disappear.Therefore, our critique is not biased and based on actually seeing the movie in a theatre. Many critics see the movies 5 at a time in a viewing room.Not a real atmosphere to gauge audience reaction. How can you review a movie without the real deal? What a terrific movie. Jeff Bridges is at is usual top of the game fantastic. He is one of our best and yet unrecognized actors for about 35 years.Contrast Jeff with Hailee Steinfeld, 14 yrs old never acted before, this girl is super fantastic in this movie. She will be a superstar. Her poise is that of a 20+ years in the business actress.She simply blew us away with her acting. Academy Award consideration for the movie and the stars.

The Brothers Coen have made an excellent movie again. It's very well directed, very well acted and its action has great dramatic intensity in almost every moment. Jeff Bridges is simply five stars in his role as Rooster Coqburn the old US Marshall. And sceneries, landscapes and views in general reproduce with great realism the wild west of the second half of 19th century with all its violence and lawlessness. A 14 year old girl (Hailee Steinfeld) is strongly determined against all odds to pursue and catch the man who killed her father and ran away to join a bandit gang in the Indian Territory, with the purpose of killing him or bringing him to justice. After hard bargaining she managed to hire an old US Marshall for that purpose and makes him with great obstinacy of hers, to accept her company and help to perform that just task. Later a Texas Ranger joins them since he is also chasing the same man for the murder of a senator. Despite the fact of dealing with those characters and despite her indomitable will and determination the young girl reveals herself to be very well-bred always calling the marshall as Marshall and the Ranger as Mr. LaBoeuf and behaving nicely most of the time. The story develops itself in several intensely dramatic moments since the chase is not peaceful at all and passes through several violent scenes riveting the viewer's attention till the very end. This is indeed one of the best westerns of the history of cinema.

reviews.review_title: True grit in the voice of a 14 year old........A great adventure when you are on the kill for vengeance
reviews.content: An amazing movie by Ethan Coen and Joel Coen and no one's surprised as they make their way to the nominations for the Academy this time as well. Although I personally didn't like No country for old men and I was a bit reluctant to go for another one of their flick but I was really taken by surprise when I actually found the movie quite interesting and brilliant. No country for old men had left me with a sour taste (yeah I am talking about the ending) although the movie was quite brilliant as I recall it now but True grit has certainly something more of a true grit in it.What really worked apart from the obvious brilliant direction was Mattie Ross's (Hailee Steinfeld) boldness and Rooster Cogburn's (Jeff Bridges) true grit. Matt Damon did his part as LaBoeuf the Texas Ranger who follows them on their hunt completing the trio hunting down Tom Chaney(Josh Brolin) who has murdered Mattie's father and absconded. Mattie is looking for revenge and hires Rooster Cogburn to hunt down Tom Chaney and punish him for his deed. Albeit LaBoeuf is already on the hunt for Tom Chaney and wants him hanged in his own town and there is a bit of a contradiction of opinions between the three of them. The drama is well portrayed as everyone wants a piece of Tom Chaney and LaBoeuf and Rooster are busy proving who's the best in getting a Bulls eye. Rooster is after a guy named Lucky Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper) and is in for the kill for his reasons.The flick is a marvellous depiction of the life of Mattie who is looking for vengeance, who is just 14 years old and still can do a lot about getting her job done because of her bravery, presence of mind and skills.It is a worth watch and I'd rate the movie 8.5 on 10 and recommend everyone to go for it.

reviews.review_title: Another fine movie from one of the most talented duos in the business.
reviews.content: (EDIT: Bumping my original review up from 7 stars to 8 after seeing it again. The writing of the Coen Brothers shines as always with repeated viewings, and the characters are even more endearing and memorable.)"I knew the marshal long ago. We too had lively times."A surprisingly funny (maybe not so surprising, this is a Coen Brothers movie), poignant, rousing adventure of a western. Beautifully shot, and with excellent performances from all the main cast members. This isn'tas complex as the typical Coen flick, but there's no reason for it to be. True Grit succeeds admirably at being an entertaining movie with a brisk pace. I haven't seen a better ending in quite a while, this film is about true grit in more ways than one. I can't compare it to the original movie (yet to watch it) or the novel (haven't read it), but this version more than stands on its own, and any fan of westerns, the Coens, or good movies in general should see it.

reviews.review_title: Jeff Bridges Steps Into John Wayne's Shoes
reviews.content: The brothers Joel and Ethan Coen must have taken a lot of heat for daring to remake (or rework, depending on how you look at it) the classic 1969 Henry Hathaway-directed western TRUE GRIT, which gave John Wayne the sole Oscar of his career. But the end result, with Jeff Bridges, no stranger to westerns he (RANCHO DELUXE; BAD COMPANY; WILD BILL), in the role that the Duke cemented forever in people's minds, is no slouch of a film either.Once again, a teenager named Mattie Ross (here played by Hailee Steinfield, in the role Kim Darby had) hires the crusty, whiskey-drinking Cogburn (Bridges) to hunt down Tom Cheney (Josh Brolin, taking over for Jeff Corey), the man who killed her father, as well as Brolin's gang, headed up by "Lucky" Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper, in the role Robert Duvall parlayed in '69). Matt Damon, meanwhile, tags along as LaBeouf, the greenhorn Texas Ranger (played by Glen Campbell) who proves he, like the feisty Mattie, shows some "true grit" of his own to stand up to Bridges' hard-charging marshal. The film, though somewhat longer than an audience weaned on headache-inducing 3D and MTV-inspired montage editing might like, moves at a fairly fast pace, thanks to Bridges' salty performance as Cogburn, and the Coen Brothers' eye for period dialog, set design, and music (provided by the Coens' regular composer Carter Burwell). And Steinfield gives a great and marvelously unruffled performance as Mattie--a role that probably ought to earn her at least an Oscar nomination.It's never easy for Hollywood to do remakes of anything, especially not Westerns, particularly those where John Wayne was involved; but the Coens' effort at reworking TRUE GRIT doesn't disappoint. If Bridges' performance as Rooster Cogburn doesn't necessarily outshine the Duke's, it is not out of lack of trying; he just gives a different, but equally valid, portrayal. Many of the original film's most famous lines are repeated almost verbatim (including the always-memorable "Fill your hand, you son-of-a-b**ch!"). In the end, it may very well get people to ask why Hollywood went stone-cold on the Western, even after it proved its worth in recent times with films like UNFORGIVEN, TOMBSTONE, and OPEN RANGE. When made with the kind of care and authenticity shown here, along with solid performances from all concerned, the Western can still show the kind of "true grit" that the Coens' film, like the Henry Hathaway/John Wayne epic before it, showed.

First of all, I went in thinking the worst, as I am a big fan of the original, and remakes almost always are HORRIBLE. As I sat down, I opened my mind, cleared it, and gave it an honest look. In the beginning I felt it had hope, but very shortly after, I kept wondering... What did he say?. Through the whole movie, I couldn't understand half of what Jeff Bridges was saying!. And the sound was so LOUD! it was almost painful, before you got adjusted to it. I mean , I love Jeff, he is one of my all time favorite actors, but he clearly was still a little stuck in his last roll a bit (Crazy Heart) except here, you can't understand him. (by the way, Crazy heart was.... OK)As always, the filming of movies today...it's so amazing. They can make crap smell good, because they have such great equipment and technology. That, and the fact that they also produce such garbage at the same time, they make what movies that DO come out fairly well, to appear far better than they really are. The color, the music, the sound, the graphics, can be very good, but what they miss a lot is, there are other elements you need... to make a "Great Movie".John Wayne (aka Rooster Cogburn) had a way about him that made you love him. In this version, Rooster is a bum, someone I wouldn't want buried next to me, for sure! I wouldn't even want to know the guy. Josh Brolin was a JOKE!. He looked foolish trying to copy the dialogue from the original that I don't even want to talk about it, it's so bad. Hailee Steinfeld was...OK, Barry Pepper sounded amazingly like Robert Duval and played his part VERY well. Matt Damon also did very well, but then again, he had Glen Campbell's old part, and well, doesn't take much to do better than Glen Campbell.I'm not suggesting they should make remakes exactly word for word what the original was, but the rule generally is, if you aren't going to make it better (or at least just as good), then please, PLEASE... don't make it at all.The end was a major league disappointment and that made the movie a disappointment even more so. If you are a fan of the Original, Don't buy this movie, borrow it if you must see it.By the way.... I just heard on the TV, as I write this, that this movie has been nominated for 10 Academy Awards....WOW!...there is something very wrong in Hollywood, or they made a lot of crap last year.

reviews.review_title: True Grit (2010) - Jeff Bridges is the New John Wayne!
reviews.content: Joel Coen and Ethan Coen comes back with a remake of John Wayne's classic hit that awarded him an Oscar. This is the very first time in their history of filmmaking, that the Coen brothers have ever done a western film. The story of True Grit follows Mattie Ross seeking revenge on Tom Chaney, the man who killed her father, with the help of Rooster Cogburn and Labeouf, Texas Ranger. First of all, I know this film does not relate to traditional Coen films. The type of movies from the Coens are dark comedies, well-written dramas, and sometimes bloody. But "True Grit" is the first Coen film that only had little of that, and does not fit traditionally. But I still enjoyed the movie, and the cast is incredible. Jeff Bridges helped recreate John Wayne's Oscar-winning performance of a drunk U.S. Marshal who never shut up. There's also Matt Damon as a Texas ranger, Josh Brolin as a coward, and even 14-year-old Hailee Steinfeld, who portrayed an awesome performance in this movie, where she spent her whole life and soul to find the man guilty of killing her father. And her Best Supporting Actress nomination is so deserving. But she was placed in the supporting category, when having more scenes than anyone else in the whole movie. This film had its moments of great writing and talented casting, but "True Grit" handles less Coen brothers tradition, but most scenes are completely epic, and the ending follows revenge, punishment, and retribution. "True Grit", in my review, "An epic adventure, but not the same piece of material".

reviews.review_title: I can't believe anyone liked this
reviews.content: I did not watch this movie when it first came out because I loved the original with John Wayne. Several friends said it was good, and so when I saw that it was available on Netflix I ordered it. I knew that several Academy Award nominations had been won by this film, especially for the acting, and that Jeff Bridges had actually won best actor. I was doubtful, but I was ready to watch this with an open mind. I was shocked that anyone could compare this favorably to the original. John Wayne's Rooster Cogburn was someone who Mattie could count on, drunk or not. Jeff Bridges' Rooster Cogburn was just a drunk. His ultimate rescue of Mattie seemed out of character. Glen Campbell's LeBoeuf, while not a stellar piece of acting, was fun and entertaining. Matt Damon's LeBoeuf was just boring. Nothing about his performance stands out. In fact I found this whole movie boring. I found myself yawning and hoping that something would happen soon. There was never a dull moment in the original. The only reason I gave this movie 2 stars was because I enjoyed the music during the ending credits.

reviews.review_title: One of my few perfect reviews. Compare with the original
reviews.content: I loved the original "True Grit", a movie that I would give a solid 9 rating to it. But it had so many fails that I like the remake so much better I should be allowed to give an 11 by comparison. Movies, by their nature, are contrived stories. The degree to which that contraption makes us feel it's real adds to the quality of the movie. The dialog feels so skewed and awkward to modern thinking, but fits with my understanding of language and dialog of the time period that I quickly grew to love every line of it.The decades between provide some beautiful technical changes. In "Deliverance" the filmographer had to underexpose to produce night scenes. In this film the night scenes beautifully capture moonlit nights in ways so rarely seen.Perhaps the best part of this film is the presentation that 19th century civilization was as both sophisticated as we are, but as primitive as we can be.This is nearly perfect a western as they come.

The book and the 1969 original set very high standards for this Coen Brothers' Western drama, but as high as the standards were set, the Coen Brothers managed achieve the goals or better yet exceeded them. True Grit is about a drunken US Marshal and a cocky Texas Ranger helping a stubborn 14 year-old finding her father's murderer. Rooster (Jeff Bridges) was offered $50 to find the murderer for Mattie, played by newcomer Hailee Steinfeld. Meanwhile, Texas Ranger Le Boeuf (Matt Damon) was offered a reward to find the same guy who also killed a Senator. Conflicting each other on the journey and finally catching the bad guy Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), the three each developed their character skillfully. Jeff Bridges playing last year Crazy Heart's Bad Blake only with a gun and an eyepatch. Matt Damon used his own personal style to play this cocky but humorous Texas Ranger. Hailee Steinfeld played a stubborn 14 year-old who's determined to find Tom Chaney and bring him to hang. Though expected performances from both Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon, newcomer Hailee Stenfeld was as good as her castmates. The one thing I kept in mind while going in this film was that Bridges and Damon are going to give applausable performances and Hailee Steinfeld was getting nominated for some major awards. But when I was finished, I didn't see what all the buzz was about. Sure, Steinfield was good, but compared to Bridges and Damon, she sure didn't have much. I have to say though, beating thousands of other girls for this role is impressive, but I'm sure other Hollywood stars had to do that as well. Even though I find her not as great as I hoped, she still delivered well. The directors are the two and only Coen Brothers. With ten Oscar nominations and four wins for each Joel and Ethan Coen, they are Hollywood's most wanted in directing dark Western dramas. Well known for their latest work "A Serious Man" and "No Country For Old Men', True Grit is another fine addition to their long and impressive resume. Directed with true grit and impressive performances, True Grit outsmarts the original and simply entertaining. OscarBuzz: Best Picture (good chance), Best Director (good chance), Best Actor (Jeff Bridges, better chance), Best Supporting Actor (Matt Damon, a chance at a nod), Best Supporting Actress (Hailee Steinfeld, a chance at a nod), Best Adapted Screenplay (Coen Brothers, better chance)

reviews.review_title: Terrible remake of a classic Western
reviews.content: If you've seen the original True Grit, you'll be sorely disappointed with this new version. It's boring, the acting is awful, especially Jeff Bridges, the scenery is not spectacular at all, I really don't know why they bothered to remake this film, it's just a waste of time.Honestly, I have no idea why it's got so many glowing reviews.The *only* good thing about this movie, is the 14 year old actress, she's excellent as Mattie.I had to create this account on IMDb just to write this, because reading the other reviews was too much to bear.Avoid this film at all costs!

reviews.review_title: Best Western in years and certainly the most original in decades
reviews.content: A terrific effort- respectful of the novel in a way that Hollywood movies almost never are, with a wonderful primary cast and a large number of character actors who all do a great job. I'm an old (63)Texan who's watched a lot (dozens and dozens)of Westerns set in Texas, set in Arizona, set in Mexico, New Mexico, you name it- and they all, oddly, looked exactly like they were set in southern California. This movie was filmed in the Texas Hill Country, and the scenery is perfectly in accord with much of south eastern Oklahoma and Arkansas. There are scenes in scrub timber and on rocky hillsides that are perfectly beautiful and quite fresh to the Great American Western.I am astonished by the number of reviewers who rate this movie as inferior to the film starring John Wayne. You know, there's a reason nobody ever tapped Wayne for an Old Vic revival of King Lear. In any film Wayne ever made, the script, the story, the other actors were all there in secondary importance to the great Wayne, and no one watching the film ever was allowed to forget it - the movie belonged to John Wayne. He played the same character over and over and over again, he played him at age 30 and age 65, in all kinds of settings, but he was the same guy. Wayne was hugely popular and is still, but he was never much of an actor. He was a movie star. The film he made of True Grit was a John Wayne movie.In contrast, the Coen Brothers movie was cast with accomplished, versatile actors playing realistic characters from a brief but distinct period of American history, respectfully and skillfully adapted from a marvelously original novel. The only reason I didn't give it ten stars is that I believe the highest rating should be reserved for relatively few films.

reviews.review_title: The Coens did not misfire, but not a true epic
reviews.content: TRUE GRITThe Coen Brothers decided to be "west" "ern" "boys" and rounded up a western in their redux of the John Wayne starring classic "True Grit". When I first heard that the Coens were going to tackle this gritty tale of a western young teen Mattie Ross who hires a vociferous & alcoholic U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn to extinguish the outlaw who killed her father, I thought that it was a risky move because it's not within their quirky recipe of movie-making. But I was wrong, because Joel and Ethan Coen did an admirable job in incorporating a straight-arrow narrative approach to their "True Grit" that differed in style from their past films; not that there is anything wrong with their past films, these brothers from the same mother definitely know how to saddle up a good movie. John Wayne played Cogburn in the 1969 original, which is resurrected in a sound but overrated performance in the Coens' version by Jeff Bridges. Before you gun me down for criticizing the thespian master Bridges, let me just hit on some bullet points why Jeff's starring performance as Rooster Cogburn was not as good as many think it is.  It did have a certain amount of authentic enigma on the pathos of the Rooster character on what led him to run whiskeys dry every day, but I think his drinking ways left with him with a speech impediment because half the time Bridges' Rooster sounded like Karl Childers of "Sling Blade". MMM! HMM!  I am not trying to state this like an acting standoff between The Duke vs. The Dude, but I think the Duke played Cogburn with more of a respectful tone to the character than The Dude.  Hey, I am one of Jeff Bridges' biggest fans, but I think he was a bit too one-dimensional in his Rooster show here.  My last bullet states "what do I know?" Why? Because Bridges will most probably be nominated for a Best Actor Academy Award for his performance in "True Grit". Now, I do give my full support to the impressive supporting performances of "True Grit". Matt Damon proves yet again that he has acting depth with his charismatic performance as LaBouef (pronounced La Beef), the Texas Ranger who is also in a quest to capture the outlaw Tom Chaney. I have no beef with Damon's work here which ranged from comedic to heroic in authentic fashion. But the grittiest performance of "True Grit" comes in the form of newcomer Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross. She stood her ground acting opposite the likes of Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon, and Josh Brolin. This Seinfeld, I mean Steinfeld, is not about nothing! She will blow you away with her screen presence and the vivid dynamics she brought to the Mattie character within her determination, brilliance, and focus. Forget campaigning her for a Best Supporting Actress Oscar nomination, try Best Actress! She is in every darn scene of the movie, Hello!!! I will give Brolin some credit for his showy performance as the ruthless Chaney, but I fall preference to the other outlaw in "True Grit", that would be the Lucky Ned Pepper played with sure magnetism by who else but Barry Pepper. Ned is a Pepper, Barry is a Pepper, wouldn't you like to act like a Pepper too! Barry Pepper has been one of the most underrated actors for years, and hopefully his luck will change and be more recognized for his consistent acting efforts. We are talking about a Coen movie, so with it there is always stunning cinematography in the hands of the camera maestro Roger Deakins. And here is no different, did you Roger that? The Duke of Deakins shines again with his scenic cinematography to another Coens' pic. The Coens screenplay contribution to "True Grit" was a treat, even though I could not hear half of the words that Bridges' Rooster was rambling about. I preferred how the Cones directed this "True Grit" tale by paying homage to the original novel and on how it perpetuated its tribute to the western genre. "True Grit" gets my true recommendation, and I am sure I will enjoy it more in its second viewing; Hopefully, this time with subtitles so I can fully understand those Rooster verbal calls. **** Good

I've really come to expect more from the Coen bros. I've almost invariably enjoyed their previous films, finding them very witty, sharp, and pervaded with dark humor. This film relies heavily on a pronounced dichotomy between fast-paced banter and typical "Hollywood" resolutions; there seems to be a nice story build-up to a place of despair, in which they realize the trail has gone cold and the spectator can feel the emptiness in any further pursuits. After this the movie spirals into a formulaic approach to story-telling; there seems to be a time constraint in which they need to crank out the remaining details listed in the script. The bad guy is miraculously found, the little girl avenges her father after being saved at the last second (more than once) by the deus ex machina of screenwriters (blatantly spitting in the face of real life, which has no such piety.. human life is ballast at most, but essentially useless)... I find it hard to believe that anyone who has some degree of familiarity with cinema still finds relief in having the hero come through virtually unscathed (her losing her arm doesn't change the direction of this diatribe). It's sad... I had high hopes for the performance of Jeff Bridges, but he wasn't able to provide enough contrast to the role to be convincing. We'll see what the directors come up with next, but this one did not deliver.

After watching a movie that so many thought was great, Inception, I was thrilled to watch one which is truly great, True Grit. The problem with Inception is that it deals with animation known as "special Effects" and they control the entire movie. I frankly couldn't have cared less what happened to anyone in that movie for it wasn't "real." But True Grit grabbed me immediately and made me care. From the very beginning I care what happens to the daughter whose father has been killed. I care about Rooster. I even care about her valiant horse who dies in the end. The people came alive for me and jumped into my life. The dynamics of the action, the camera shots, the acting, the cinematography and the score are all brilliant. it's movie making at its best. They had a tale to tell and they did it with breath taking élan.

reviews.review_title: Feels less like a Coen brothers movie, but that can be forgiven, since the film is highly entertaining, and Steinfeld is exceptional.
reviews.content: The first movie of 2011 I decided to see was True Grit, Joel and Ethan Coen's take on the novel by Charles Portis.Set in the 1800's, the film centers on headstrong 14 year old Mattie Ross (Played terrifically by newcomer Hailee Steinfeld), a girl who seeks the help of a ruthless, alcoholic, and old-fashioned U.S. Marshal named Rooster Cogburn (Played by Jeff Bridges), so that she may find, and bring to justice Tom Chaney, a man who shot, and killed her father in cold blood. Joining their group is a Texas Ranger named LaBoeuf (Played by Matt Damon), who also wants to see Chaney hanged for a previous murder, rather than Mattie's father's.To be honest, the film feels less like a film by the Coens than most of their other movies, but a decision like that is for the better, as the film channels the classic westerns of Hollywood, ranging from the spaghetti westerns of Leone, to the other great western of the Coens, No Country for Old Men. But the film is not entirely without their personal stamp. As you'd expect, it's neatly structured, evenly paced, thoughtfully worded, and also so funny. For instance, Tom Chaney is built up to be such a rough and evil man, but upon his introduction, he comes off as somewhat comical.The cast is also impressive, specifically that of Steinfeld, who gives a natural performance balanced out by her sharp wit, and emotional timing. Pardon the cliché, but a star is born. Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon are also fun to watch in their respective roles of Cogburn and LaBoeuf, while Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper make great use of their relatively small roles.The film is also beautiful, sporting an involving sound mix, impressive production and costume design by Jess Gonchor and Mary Zophres, and especially great cinematography by the man, the legend, Roger Deakins.***1/2 out of ****

reviews.review_title: Rooster Cogburn, ultimate bad-ass in the Western.
reviews.content: Another example of how Cohen brothers can make a really simply film and turn it into something admirable.Not 100% a Western, "True Grit" explores the unlikely "work" relationship between an U.S. Marshall and a vengeful girl. The story is simply but the events make it truly enjoyable, creative, interesting. Rooster Cogburn may be one of the most bad-ass characters in recent cinema history. The acting is top notch. Jeff Bridges demonstrates once again he's a magnificent actor that can play any character.The movie is accessible for all audiences. I mean, you don't need to be a fan of the brothers in order to enjoy it.

Taking on a project like True Grit, the Cohen brothers probably met with a lot of people questioning their own "grit" to tackle sacred ground. Bridges had to be equally questioned to take on the role that is already considered a pinnacle of a legend, John Wayne. All mentioned, somehow, some way, pull it off.Everything from the pitch perfect casting, to the cinematography and score, the Cohen's "True Grit" is a worthy member of the Western genre family.Bridges take on the iconic role of Rooster Cogburn shows no signs of mimicking John Wayne's portrait of the character. Rather, Bridges puts his own spin on the character and like Wayne, delivers a wonderful performance. Matt Damon's LeBeouf, is fun to watch. Newcomer Hailee Steinfeld gives a wonderful screen debut, which no doubt will earn her several awards nods.The story is simple; young girl hires a down and out marshal to help her exact revenge upon the man who killed her father. Those unfamiliar with the original should enjoy this solely on its own merit. Those that are familiar with and love the original, your memories will not be trampled upon. This is merely another telling, one that doesn't try at any moment to wink at the audience of the first, rather, tries to present the book, which it is based on, the best way it can.There really isn't much more detail that I can provide that others haven't already provided. Coming from someone who grew up on John Wayne, that holds his movies with high-regard, to include the original True Grit, I found this latest telling to be honorable, well done and entertaining.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, do not watch this watered down version.
reviews.content: I looked forward to watching this for a number of reasons; I love Coen brothers films, love westerns and I have just read the book (which is awesome). I also read more than one 5 star review so I had high expectations, I was even excited about going to the cinema for the first time in ages, so when we sat down and started watching I was happy , until after about 5 minutes when I realized how immensely annoying the young girl is, then it was trying to decipher what it was exactly Rooster was mumbling. The dialogue was taken pretty much word for word from the book which I though would have been a good thing, but unfortunately it wasn't, there is no chemistry between the main characters at all and how this has been nominated for Oscars etc is beyond me, don't get me wrong, I love my films and I think I know a good film from a bad one, the fact that this has driven me to write a review speaks for itself as I would normally never do so.
