They have just about cornered the market on exploiting our need to be reminded again and again of just how high minded and hopeful we once were, even if all along we never fully believed our own bulls@#$. So many of their films have served as very time specific worm holes back to a moment when that particular defining quality we call "American" was being sorely tested, or more accurately, auditioned. They deconstructed our gangster era myth of noble war lords living out the American dream to the fullest in their early classic "Millers Crossing." In that one the Don was reduced to a pudgy weirdo who used "ethics" mostly as a ploy to con himself. It's very clever and very, very funny. But on their latest morality tale, the brothers have dialed down the outrageous metaphysical shenanigans, and really tweaked up their signature fastidious devotion to characters being ethically assaulted. There's a minimum of outright irony on display, but it does lurk behind every frame.In "True Grit" the Coens have ventured further back historically than in any other of their tales. It's post civil war Indian Territory that beckons the boys this time as they faithfully interpret the 1968 novel of the same name. The 1969 John Wayne version, that won him his only Oscar, was filmed largely in the Rockies, but this new one is shot mostly in Texas in settings that more accurately mirror those in the novel. The vistas and panoramas are sumptuous, with a fine winter's patina over much of the landscape. What is so striking is how harshly filthy most of the characters are, how thoroughly tattooed the men are with layers of crud. They are not just of this land but basted in, infused with, composed of it. I started to see the muck and grime as a visual metaphor, an emblem of the intimacy these people had with natural law. Sure, it's a convention of westerns to have men, and occasionally women, beating puffs of trail dust off their well worn duds as they amble into the saloon. But here the dirt feels so deeply permanent, insistently bound to their core. That's how literal the Coen's have made this Grit. For this effect alone, the film's a cinematic achievement, but there are many other worthwhile qualities to be found here as well.Hailee Steinfeld as the young Mattie is remarkable, confidently mastering the curious language that roams somewhere between Huck Finn and Hamlet. Her expression of steely eyed determination, tinted with shades of wide eyed wonder, is a constant delight. Matt Damon's Texas Ranger LaBoeuf projects so much smug pride in his Texas homeland I kept flashing on a smirking, sneering George W. Bush bopping around his Lone Star spread. I know this is a highly personal interpretation, but LaBoeuf's childish boasting and naive arrogance really echoes the overblown, absurd persona our former leader fashioned for himself. Well, that's Texas. Jeff Bridges has done a fascinating thing by taking on his character of Deputy U.S. Marshal Rooster Cogburn as though it were a heavy, burdensome cloak, or even more accurately, a dense, woolly bear skin. His movements and speech are all hampered and softened by this put-on hindrance. This Rooster is not just hobbled with drink, but slowed and dulled by voluminous memories. These countless memories compressed within Cogburn bubble and gurgle forth in a fractured flow of anecdotes, tales and recollections. It's something of a welcome thing, too, 'cause there's little else out there on the trail to to keep themselves entertained. LaBoeuf takes a stab now and then at a spoken remembrance, but all he is capable of are trite secular homilies and tedious personal facts. He's wonderfully ridiculous.Finally, the cinematography is spectacular, with royally picturesque tableaux scrupulously vivid, sumptuous rich tones and exquisite textures throughout. The sound is wonderfully precise yet oddly hushed, as though reaching our ears only after having traveled the 150 years through time. It's a very subtle effect but I kept noting how often distant action would be played as pantomime, till suddenly punctuated with brittle gun shots. A neat trick. Come to think about it, the whole movie's a neat trick. It made me completely forget why we all don't like westerns anymore, and why I will never live a Life as noble - as natural - as anyone in this nasty, messy, fine film; the most subtle, lyrical version of that famous Coen irony.

reviews.review_title: Ah hell they boys done it ahgin!
reviews.content: A beautiful, charming, funny and movingly melancholy film. The brothers deal with revenge and justice, time and aging with the same skillful deftness and pacing we are used to seeing from them. Of course it looks and sounds great too.The leads all have a terrific chemistry which makes the drama work and the danger real. Some outstanding dialogue delivered with relish. The costume design also deserves a mention.Another highlight albeit a brief one is the man in the bear costume appearing out of the blizzard to deliver some baffling and entertaining bits about medicine.
Thank god for the remake. John Wayne's original is like a Disney movie...from the 70's. Which is now unwatchable. The genius remake is streaming again. Catch it now if you like great Westerns.

reviews.review_title: the revival of the Western continues apace
reviews.content: Fourteen-year-old Mattie (Hailee Steinfeld) engages the cantankerous Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to hunt Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), the man who gunned down her father. They join forces with LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), a law enforcer who is also in the trail of the irredeemable Chaney.The Coen Brothers fashion a postmodern Western that continues the fine revival of the genre, the best outing in the renaissance since the excellent Assassination of Jesse James. Contractions are banned as characters tell us they 'will not' and 'do not', the prissy language is contrast to the fuddled and grey morality of the characters espousing them. Even Mattie, for all her youth, steel and resolve, does not make a clear choice between justice and vengeance.Bridges goes for grunge in his portrayal of Cogburn, garbling his lines throughout. He leads a charge of fine performances, with Brolin as chilling as Chaney as the precocious Steinfeld is resolute as the heroine. Outstanding.

True Grit (2010): Dir: Ethan Coen, Joel Coen / Cast: Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon, Josh Brolin, Hailee Steinfeld, Barry Pepper: One of the very best remakes ever produced. Much of it has to do with the effective writing talent of the Coen brothers whose films are a cross word puzzle of delight from The Big Lebowski to No Country for Old Men. They are master storytellers and here they embark upon their first western. The film stars Hailee Steinfeld as fourteen year old Mattie Ross out to avenge her father's death at the hands of Tom Chaney. She enlists the help of Marshall Reuben Cogburn and are accompanied by Texas Ranger LaBoeuf. The trio ride into the old west and brave the winter and the opposition. Jeff Bridges embodies the role of Cogburn with an amusing Southern drawl. When first seen he is on trial where it is learned that his taste for alcohol are a setback. He knows his skill well but will ultimately learn to care. Steinfeld brings brave determination to Ross who struggles to maintain the conflict of two personalities while ultimately suffering severe fatalities for her stern quest. Matt Damon as LaBoeuf knows Chaney but is also clumsy and conceals a lack of confidence. Josh Brolin as Chaney is introduced through Ross's verbal description but is seen much later as part of Ned Pepper's gang. He is and isn't what he seems but he is destine to face consequences through Ross. Barry Pepper must have been perfect to play villain Ned Pepper thanks to his last name. The message is still sustained in its fatalities of revenge and its lifelong hold even when we're past the driven hand of justice. Score: 10 / 10

reviews.review_title: True Grit Entertains with Underlying Themes
reviews.content: It's rare for a re-make of an American classic like True Grit to mirror the impact of the original movie based on the novel by Charles Portis. In fact, I'm surprised more is not made about the Portis novel as the basis for the two movies, because I enjoyed reading it when it was a best seller many years ago.Since the 2010 remake, I've become a groupie of the True Grit themes of redemption and the brutality of justice.As a truly American story, its special features are acted in the crudeness of the characters and the harshness of the old Arkansas County criminal justice systems which, no doubt, were closer to fact than fiction in the movie, during 1880 when the story took place.Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) is a County Marshal, but a man in need of redemption. He knows it, but doesn't know what to do about it. Cogburn's redemptive moment shows up in a person he least expects to extend him hope, when he meets 14 year old Mattie Ross (Hailee Stienfeld). She is looking for the meanest person she can hire to help find her father's killer, a criminal named Tom Cheney (Josh Brolin).Complicating Mattie's plan to find her Daddy's killer is the character LeBoeuf (Matt Damon). LeBoeuf shows up as a needing-to-be-redeemed Texas Ranger, who is out to get the same man Haddie is looking for, but for the purpose of claiming a considerable amount of bounty money.LeBoeuf and Cogburn decide to rudely pass on Mattie's intentions for justice. Rather, they join forces to split the bounty. They don't count on Mattie's stubborn determination to find her Daddy's killer. She bargains for a horse and goes off after Cogburn and LeBoeuf.Haddie is the innocent surrounded by men who lack any sense of justice. They kill because they can. A ringleader of the murderous gang that Cogburn, LeBoeuf and Haddie pursue is Lucky Red Pepper (played by Barry Pepper), whose luck eventually runs out in a brutal scene when he enters into an intense dual with Cogburn.On the redemptive side, Cogburn quickly sees something in Haddie that he cannot ignore in himself - a driving need to find justice. Soon, the story is not about the handsome bounty on the killer Cheney's head but, instead, it's to help Haddie fulfill her mission.True Grit is an American story with some stereotypical characters we can expect to find riding through a 1950s Wild West movie. Yet, with Haddie as the central anchor, it tells a timeless story about justice prevailing over evil challenges encountered along the way.Bridges is entertaining and believable as the wasted Cogburn. But, the surprise performance, for me, was Matt Damon's portrayal of LeBoeuf. This role was originally played with no pizazz whatsoever by singer Glenn Campbell in the original movie with Oscar winner John Wayne as Cogburn. I appreciated the sensitivity Damon brought to the role, the sense of uncertainty he showed when trying to outsmart and out shoot the drunken Cogburn brings a hint of humanity to both of the heartless men.I give True Grit an 8 rating because it is well directed and acted. Perhaps it would have been a higher rated movie if we could have understood more about how Hattie became such a hard driving stubborn young lady. One scene I found totally unbelievable was when she drove her horse Blackie through the river to catch Cogburn and LeBoeuf but she wound up dry in spite of the drenching ride. Otherwise, the background scenes of the Arkansas prairie, especially depicting the lonely terrain, was a realistic setting for the story. Bleak surroundings seemed to drive some men looney, like the characters Bear Man and one of Lucky Pepper's sidekicks.I'm now a True Grit groupie. Loved the book, which I will now re-read, enjoyed John Wayne as the originator of the Cogburn role and now Bridges for bringing the story back to life. Right or wrong, True Grit is a story about morality, of American justice done the old fashioned way, and redemption. A classic.

Not a common watcher of western movies here. Was not expecting to watch this with the pals, and was worried the movie was going to be slow, boring and bland. The movie starts out slow but soon picks up pace and with it all the action, humour, drama and thrill one could wish for, it was an entertaining experience even if the ending is low-key and bittersweet!

reviews.review_title: Sometimes the novel should be adhered to.
reviews.content: I really admire the Cohen brothers as a film making team and have enjoyed their films over the years, but this time, they ruined a fine story. What made the earlier version of True Grit such a great film was the adherence to the novel's storyline.Though John Wayne was miscast as Cogburn, IMO, and Bridges was a much better Cogburn, the way the Cohen version went off the rails was straying from the path laid out by the novel. Having Rooster and Mattie traveling through the Nations without LeBoef , along with removing much of the novel's excellent dialog was, I think, a mistake.I saw mention of an imagined "return to the source material" in a trivia entry for this 2010 version. This is laughable. The Hall Wallis "True Grit" hewed much closer to the novel, especially in the dialog, which is lifted verbatim from the novel in most scenes. The dialog in this latest outing is pitiful in some scenes and quite annoying to a reader of the novel in those scenes.Jeff Bridges was great as Rooster Cogburn, and just about anyone would be better as LeBoef than Glen Campbell was in the first making of the story in 1969, but nobody in the industry today could replace Strother Martin as Col. Stonehill in the original. His exchanges with Mattie, taken nearly verbatim from the novel's dialog, are inimitable.Barry Pepper was very good in the role of Lucky Ned Pepper, though Robert Duvall was also very good in the original. Overall, the casting is fine, it's just the meddling with the novel's story that hampers this version for me.The Cohens made up for such meddling by including the scene in which Rooster kicks two boys off the porch at McCallisters for tormenting a mule. That was left out of the 1969 version. It establishes another facet of the Rooster Cogburn character that Bridges had been better at showing than John Wayne was.Still, the film doesn't miss the novel's greatness by much, and it gains a lot of credibility over the Hal Wallis version with its depiction of Fort Smith and the accurate period costuming and armory detail. Weapons were more correct for the period and the final gunfight scene was pretty much exactly as the novel told of it.. So was the courtroom scene.IMO, 8 stars is an accurate rating for this fine film. The flaws I noted aren't really minor flaws and many reviewers will not see them as flaws at all. Still, the novel was the best novel published in the 1960s, in my view, and it is readable yet, describing the post-bellum years and pointing out the difference in public perception of that war's aftermath today as compared to 1968.In 1968, outright hatred for the Confederacy and for Southerners in general was not so nearly universal as it is today. The disapproval shown by LeBoef for the Missouri guerillas, with whom Cogburn had ridden, was shared with Union veterans by some Confederate veterans, so that exchange between the two men was believable.Another glaring mistake in the Cohen version is the year of birth on Cogburn's tombstone: 1825. That would have made him 36 years old at the outbreak of the war, when the novel had Cogburn describing himself and his fellow Guerillas, saying, "We was kids, and all we had was horses and pistols".Also, the Border war was already in full swing when the wider war broke out. That was part of the backstory in the novel, ignored by both versions of the film.I admire both versions of True Grit and I own both on DVD. Enjoy the film. Thanks for reading my review.

reviews.review_title: This is actually a remake of the orig movie. don't be fooled.
reviews.content: There is this strange insistence on the part of the Coens that this is not a remake of the '69 Duke film. HAW. This is SO much a remake of that movie it ain't funny. While it's not as slavish to it's source material as the '98 Psycho re-hash, it's right up there. I hadn't watched the Wayne vehicle in some years, and I could tell right away. Don't try so hard Coens. Nothing wrong w/ remaking True Grit-it's a good film.Others have already expressed what works so well here-I just wanna say I agree. Jeff Bridges is terrific as Cogburn-by NO means is he 'better' that the Duke-he's essentially channelling Mitchum from 'El Dorado' by way of Wallace Beery as far's I'm concerned. And it works, rather well. You root for the man and buy into his toughness out on the trail after the baddies.Loved Mattie here. Like watching a young Jody Foster at work. Self-assured, believable, steady, a little adult. You hope she has a great future ahead of her. I enjoyed her performance.Good turns by Barry Pepper, Matt Damon and Josh Brolin too. Solid action, great scenery and cinematography.I think as an overall film, it's better than the '69 Oscar winner, as two of the key roles here-Damon and Mattie> Campbell and Darby. No one is going to replace the Duke, and Bridges of all people, being part of Hollywood royalty, knows this better than anyone. He made the role his own and therefore the film is that much better for it.***1/2 of *****. Yes go see it. Wayne wouldn't mind.

reviews.review_title: The Coens' signatures might not always serve the story, but they certainly set it apart.
reviews.content: 'True Grit (2010)' is told with the Coens' signature dancing dialogue, realist yet distinctly cinematic style and slightly absurdist slant, all of which culminate in a very unique yet decidedly well-worn spin on an old tale in (what's arguably) an unfortunately dying genre. It's a feature that adheres just as strongly to the tropes of that genre as it does to the tropes of its head filmmakers' now iconic portfolios. While its perhaps more meditative than some and it certainly isn't an action film by any stretch of the imagination (regardless of its body-count), there's often a sense that the story has been imbued with a slower pace than necessary simply to include long sequences of deliberately cumbersome but unintentionally repetitive back-and-forth banter and odd, almost dream-like asides that serve to paint this version of the old-west as one of strange folk struggling to earn their keep anyway they can, an admirable attempt to introduce some extra - and, actually, unneeded - personality that often falls flat thanks to the fact that the rest of the piece isn't anywhere near as weird - or as slow - as these moments. Still, there's a decent sense of a dusty, rustic style and a no-nonsense tone, both of which combine with the scenery (and screenplay) chewing performances to make for an enjoyable experience. 8/10

The plot was predictable from the onset, the acting was flat and just had no heart... the language was incredibly stilted, I felt like I was watching a western version of Shakespeare... and the girl was completely unbelievable. I do not understand what people like about this movie and I do love me a good western.Sure, there were mild comparisons to the original... but I'm not even trying to leap there. Just viewing this as a movie in itself, it had nice scenery and the costuming was great. What was missing was emotion and character development, the was no connection for me at all to the characters. I saw determination in the girl's character but no emotion. THAT didn't come through at all. Neither did Rooster's character and his many obvious character flaws, they were acted but not lived nor were there any solid glimpses into the reasons for his less than admirable traits. The 'bad guys' were props, the only character that emoted at all was the Texas Ranger and his character wasn't all that interesting. In the land of westerns, he was kind of wimp.

reviews.review_title: Hailee Steinfeld excels along with a wonderful cast and the Coen Brothers
reviews.content: I saw this at the cinema last night (Saturday 26th February 2011), hoping to enjoy this film. I haven't seen the original starring John Wayne in the Jeff Bridges role, but must say that I absolutely LOVED this film.I saw this film, as it stars newcomer Hailee Steinfeld, who was BAFTA nominated for best actress and has (at least) received an Oscar nomination for best supporting actress (the results of the Oscars are unknown as of when I'm writing this). Hailee produced an outstanding performance as 14-year-old Mattie Ross, who is out to avenge her father's death at the hands of a drifter named Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). She persuades an alcoholic marshal named Reuben J. "Rooster" Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to join her in tracking down Chaney and they are also joined by a Texas Ranger by the name of La Boeuf (Matt Damon).This film is a new version of the 1969 film, based on the 1968 novel of the same name, by Charles Portis.The writing and directing credits come from the Coen Brothers, Joel and Ethan, although this is the first of their films they've done, I am sure that they have reached new fantastic heights with this film. I also wish to congratulate Roger Deakins on his cinematography; Carter Burwell on his score and Jess Gonchor for the great production design, plus all the other people I haven't listed.Jeff Bridges was wonderful as Cogburn, producing a funny performance and also I hope he wins an Oscar. Matt Damon was great (as he normally is), albeit he looks slightly unrecognizable with that huge moustache! Particular praise, though, goes to Hailee Steinfeld. She produced such an amazing performance for a newcomer aged 14 (who may well win an Oscar), but even if she doesn't win, I'm sure she will feel honoured enough to have a nomination, I know that I feel proud for her. When I meet my hopeful dream of becoming a filmmaker, I'll definitely have a role ready and waiting for her (If you're reading this Hailee, I mean it!). I felt sorry for her not to win the best actress award at the BAFTAs (which here in the UK is the equivalent to the Oscars), but my theory was that she didn't win it, maybe because she is young. In a couple of year's time, she should certainly have a BAFTA statuette at home (or two)! I was originally surprised that she was placed in best SUPPORTING actress for the Oscars, but I heard somebody say on an UK programme called Film 2011 that she may have been placed there, as she will have a better chance of winning it, I now feel that this may be true, so GOOD LUCK HAILEE!!!The action was very good. I was hooked throughout and there were plenty of suspenseful moments and also some funny parts, especially the 'best shot' competition between Cogburn and La Boeuf! I highly recommend this film to anyone and hopefully I'll be able to get the Blu-ray for my birthday (August 12th)!Overall, I give this film 10/10, as it was an outstanding film, containing great performances from veterans and newcomers alike, particularly the new great star Hailee Steinfeld, who will be a regular for me, when I am a filmmaker!

It's about time and very pleasing to see a modern day western filmed how it should be, you know with lovely smooth wide angle shots and none of this cancerous wobbly handheld shakycam nonsense... A good watch.

If you enjoyed the original, or like Westerns, then settle down to be entertained.The Coen brothers cinematography, the script and actors due justice to a great book.Every single actor puts in a good performance, both Bridges and Damon are brilliant, but Hailee Steinfield steals the show as the 14 year old out to see justice for her murdered father.The 3 leads compliment each other perfectly, mixing cross words as well as helping each other.The violence is hard, but not overdone as it would be with some directors.A great film which stands up to multiple viewings.

for me,this was a pretty decent movie,although overall,i liked the original 1969 version a bit more.i found this one dragged a little bit for my taste.it could have been a bit shorter.the acting was good though,especially by Hailee Steinfeld who played young Mattie Ross.i felt she has a lot of screen presence.the scenery was also very nice,and the action scenes were well done.i also liked the dialogue.if you liked the original,there are some things about this version you may like as well.it's all about personal taste.it;s directed by Joel and Ethan Coen,who always put put their own spin on things.if you're a fan of the Coen Brothers,you might want to check this one out.for me, True Grit (2010) is a 7/10.
With fantastic dialogue and acting. One of the five best Western movies ever made!

reviews.review_title: Not as great as I thought it would be, but still a western most definitely worth seeing
reviews.content: If your expecting a action packed western like it's advertised in the trailer, you will be left disappointed. If your looking forward to only the action though. What this movie is though is a well told story about a girl on a journey for vengeance with the help of a hired marshal to take down and kill the man the killed the girl's father. When I saw the trailer with Jeff Bridges wearing a eye patch wielding guns I knew I had to see this movie. What is shocking though is how Hailee Steinfeld steals the spotlight as Mattie Ross, the girl seeking vengeance. Although Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn stood out as well. I didn't find the dialogue all that amazingly entertaining but it's still well written. I didn't see the original so I can't compare the two films but this movie stands out pretty darn good on it's own. Matt Damon played his role well, basically the way the character is intended to be with his proud and yet somewhat metro personality. The journey for these 3 characters all the way to the end was actually quite enjoyable. It sort of feels like your with the group as they are on a manhunt. Not as great as I thought it would be but it's a western that is most definitely worth seeing.7.8/10

Last year I watched the original version of True Grit starring John Wayne and thought it was okay, but I wasn't too impressed. I've been looking forward to see how Jeff Bridges portrays Rooster Cogburn in this remake. After watching his performance, I have to admit that I was very impressed. True Grit is an amazing movie and one of the best I have seen in years.The Coen Brothers adaption has their trademark style to it. There are ten times as many goofy and quirky characters in this movie that in Napolean Dynamite. All of the characters are very intriguing and entertaining. The acting was great and I also appreciated the dialogue too.Bridges did an amazing job of portraying the crusty old Ranger. Damon was also great and I hardly recognized him in his role. I loved the banter between the two lawmen throughout the movie. There are some great quotes in this movie and I was surprised at how much humor there was for such a serious plot. Hailee Steinfeld plays the young girl who hires Cogburn to track down her father's murderer and bring him to justice. She personified "true grit" more than any other character. She was the main reason I liked this version so much more than the original.The only two minor hangups I had with this movie was the encounter with the "bear dentist" who spoke like he was tripping on LSD and the abrupt ending. Aside from that, I was mesmerized during every scene and have not seen such an entertaining movie in a long time.This is one of the few movies I have seen where I didn't find myself criticizing the movie for hard to believe effects or story line. It is very graphic and has a very realistic feel to it. I give True Grit 9.0 well deserved stars.

reviews.review_title: I'm glad I changed my mind
reviews.content: There are a lot of people who are "puritans" about old movies and don't like seeing them remade. Usually, I count myself as one which is why I was reluctant to see this film. Today, however, curiosity got the best of me and I'm glad I changed my mind. Don't get me wrong, I still prefer the 1969 version, but the makers of this film didn't dishonor it. It says volumes for Jeff Bridges talents that he can take a role made famous by John Wayne and give it a new original twist, making it uniquely his own! There have been critics that said that Wayne got his True Grit Oscar for the cumulative body of his work. They said that as Rooster Cogburn, he really gave a hammy, "over the top" performance that normally wouldn't have gotten an Oscar. Bridges makes Rooster more complex and darker. There are scenes in this film where you can practically smell him from your seat. I loved the scene where he was trying to shoot that cornbread he tossed in the air. The screenwriters stayed faithful to Charles Portis's novel and its cute dialogue and I salute them for that. To me, the one improvement over the original is newcomer Haille Steinfeld. She is amazing as the young heroine Mattie Ross. Critics are lauding Bridges for his portrayal but lets not forget this incredible young newcomer. She is skies above Kim Darby's portrayal. When it came down to it, Darby was in many ways just bratty and annoying. Steinfeld makes her courageous and strong as well. I also wanted to salute Matt Damon for taking on Glenn Campbell's old role. For you trivia lovers, they originally wanted Elvis to do it but he wanted too much money. SPOILER ALERT the only beef I have with this film is the rather downbeat ending when we see a middle aged Mattie visiting Rooster's grave. I prefer the original where Wayne jumped over the fence at the end. It was more upbeat.

True Grit is well-written, well-acted and well-executed. The Coen Brothers have created an old-fashioned Western that feels fresh and relevant. Every actor, including the supporting cast, does an amazing job of making the film feel authentic. It's a simple story, but it's a very memorable movie.

reviews.review_title: A good old fashioned romp through cowboy country
reviews.content: Many reviews of the Coen Brothers' 'True Grit' will inevitably focus on the comparison between it and the original John Wayne vehicle released back in '69. Having never seen the older film (gasp), I'm not in a position to say which is better, nor which is more faithful to the book both are based on, having never read it, but what I do know is that the newer film is fantastic.Spot-on performances from all involved, superb dialogue, beautiful cinematography and a straight forward storyline made for the most enjoyable film I have seen in some time.Most people are probably aware of the premise of True Grit, but to summarise: 14 year old Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) hires US Marshall 'Rooster' Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to help her track down and bring to justice her father's killer, Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). That's it. No twists, no turns, just a good old-fashioned romp across classic cowboy country.Also featuring are Matt Damon as Texas Ranger LaBoeuf and Barry Pepper as 'Lucky' Ned Pepper, who's gang of outlaws Chaney is tagging along with.Perfect casting throughout, I cannot fault any of the performances. Special mention has to go to Steinfeld though. I've read that she was picked from 15,000 applicants and I'm glad the casting team found her amongst all those hopefuls. She is exceptional as the headstrong Mattie. Steinfeld's up for the Best Supporting Actress gong at the Oscars which I'm sure she'll go home with. In my opinion she wouldn't be out of place in the Leading Actress nominations as she is by far the more central character in this picture. Sadly, as you can see her name is barely visible on the movie poster, but this is quite acceptable given the calibre of her co-stars - I'm sure she'll have top billing in the near future. True Grit will be Steinfeld's 'Leon' - the 1994 movie which catapulted a 13 year old Natalie Portman to superstardom.Bridges is deservedly up for Best Actor for his superb portrayal of tramp-cum-hero Cogburn, though I think Colin Firth already has that one sewn up.I'm sure True Grit will pick up a bunch of the other awards it's nominated for. I'd be very surprised if Roger Deakins and Mary Zophres don't win in their respective categories of Cinematography and Costume Design - the movie is visually stunning. Do not wait for the DVD or Blu-Ray - I urge you to go and see this on the big screen.A straightforward plot in a movie is becoming a rarity these days (I'm still trying to work out what happened in 'Inception'...) so the good old fashioned storytelling in True Grit was nice and refreshing. As said previously, I haven't enjoyed a movie this much in years. The only (very minor) complaint I have is that the pacing could have been a little better (slightly slow to get going and too quick to end) but that really didn't affect my enjoyment.

I was a kid when I saw John Wayne's "True Grit" in 1969, and years latter I got the movie on VHS and DVD. When I heard first time that will be a remake, I said to myself: "Man, I am going to replace my old 1969 Ford Mustang with a new 2010 BMW."Unfortunately after I saw the movie, I'll keep my old Mustang. You know why? It has much soul. SOUL is what this remake doesn't have. Jeff Bridge was, is, and will be, a mediocre actor. Matt Damon, Josh Brolin, and Barry Pepper they are okay, but just didn't fit in their roles. And not at the end, Hailee Steinfeld role, not even came closer to the play of the original Kim Darby, which (at that time) I would gave her at least a nomination for supporting role.

reviews.review_title: A Perfect Movie. Gritty, funny, tragic and a true classic
reviews.content: One of the remarkable aspects of "True Grit" is it's attention towards being a western, from the verbiage and accent to the endless banter on civil war captains and armies to the costumes that exhibit no modern tendencies in texture and color to the towns, jungles and the vast open space that exude the western ambiance. Well, except for Matt Damon's bushy mustache which looks like it juts a few inches above his face and looks perilously like falling off at any time. Anyway, what sets this movie apart from other Westerns is the fast talking verbal jousting that gives the first half of the movie a comedic shade. All the while, this talking does imbue our protagonists with personality which is deftly channeled into the shooting and gun-slinging of the second half making for nail-biting and suspenseful action sequences where our characters are put to their test.In many regards, this is a perfect film (perfect pace, perfect acting and so on). The Coen brothers have created some amazing films (Fargo, Big Lebowski) and some mediocre ones (Ladykillers, Burn after Reading) but this movie will go down as great movie. "True Grit" embraces the grittiness of the modern westerns (corpses, blood splatters and bullet impacts) but unlike other westerns eschews the silent morally-grounded superman cowboy for a garrulous Marshall who is fat, drunk and not averse to lying, stealing and killing but who shows true grit and courage, not as virtue but as a delicate construct of the relationship that the characters build.

A remake usually does not work as well, the same in this case, but not by much, the original was so good it was always going to be difficult to equal it, never mind better it. They don't do it. But it is still a great film, I gave the original a 9, I give this an 8, that's how close it is and still beats most films, especially westerns.This is partially copying the original and partly trying to be more close to the book, the characters are a bit more grizzled and the film is a bit more realistic, like a modern western, the scenery is bleaker, but still excellent, photography is spot on again, the music is not as great, but the general make up of the film is as good as the original.The acting is great too, if anything I would say that Hailee Steinfeld is better than Kim Darby in the Mattie Ross role, she has a big future ahead, Jeff Bridges is great as Rooster, possibly not as good, but almost, he plays it a bit different, his acting better than Wayne's but Wayne's character was better. Matt Damon does a good LaBoeuf, again different in the same way Bridges is, the supporting cast is great as well, Josh Brolin, Dakin Matthews are good but again we have a good actor in Barry Pepper playing Ned Pepper, not as good as Robert Duvall but not far off.They try to stick closer to the story in this, LaBoeuf does not die, but Rooster does, not in a scene though, an older Mattie Ross looking for him 25 years later, finds out he died 3 days earlier, that was a bit of a let down, it would have made a better film if she had met him just before he passed away, if that had been the end I would have scored it the same as the original, but that is realism for you, it always gets in the way. Nevertheless it is still a great film.

True Grit is a pure example on why, when made well, western films can be so good. This is a movie, despite being a remake, channels the westerns from the 1950's and 1960's. This is definitely a kind of film that makes we want to live in the Old West. Despite not being a typical, quirky film, the Coen Brothers made one of the best recent western films.This remake of the 1969 version is about a strong-willed girl, Maddie who hires a U.S Marshal to find the man, Tom Chaney who killed her father. She, the Marshal, and a Texas Ranger all set out to find the man and possibly another gang he has become infatuated with.The acting is a very strong point of the film. Jeff Bridges and newcomer Hailee Steinfeld were very impressive. I was even more impressed on how Hailee held her own against a very talented cast.Overall, this is one of the best western films ever made. When I first saw this film, I had trouble understanding the garbled accent of Jeff Bridges, but since then I had come to appreciate it. I also really like the powerful score because it added so much to the already-emotional moments. The Coen Brother's True Grit is an example of a modern classic and is their best film yet! It's also much better than the original. I rate this film 10/10.

As someone who desperately does not enjoy Westerns, I absolutely loved this film. I have been putting this one off for quite a while, but being a fan of the Coen Brothers I decided to finally give it a chance.I was extremely pleased, aside from the film being filmed so beautifully the storyline was so enthralling, Hailee Steinfeld was a tour de force that left me in awe when I discovered this was her cinematic premiere. Matt Damon and Bridges both also bring extremely impressive performances, but that's to be expected from two seasoned veterans.The plot was extremely satisfying, the only reason I didn't give this movie a full rating is that I felt the ending falls a bit flat. It's not surprising, and some may even say the ending was brilliant, but I expected a little more of a resolve. Not a terrible ending in any sense, just wasn't what I was expecting.I loved this movie and not only would I watch it again, but I would also actively seek it out and push others to see.

True Grit is a fantastic movie with a terrific story,a great cast and terrific characters.This movie really lives up to the novel by Charles Portis,in my opinion even more than the original 1969 movie,although I did prefer John Wayne as Rooster Cogburn over Jeff Bridges,but Bridges did still a great performance and himself and Matt Damon got the western accents perfectly.Like all movies based on books,there is a lot of detail missing,that bothers me with some movies but not this one,because I read True Grit and,although it is a very good book,there is a lot of not needed detail in it.After Mattie Ross's father John Ross is murdered by Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin),and his gold and cattle is robbed from him,Mattie seeks revenge and gets help from Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) and LaBoeuf (Matt Damon).

Just got back from an advance screening.I have never seen the original, so can' comment from that perspective.It was brilliant! I gave it a 9.Everything about this film was just incredible. The cinematography, music, the dialog was simply brilliant and frequently hilarious. The direction and editing were wonderful.Jeff Bridges should be get an Academy award for his portrayal of a one eyed, grumpy, drunken Marshall who aids a spunky (to say the least!) 14 year old girl track down the killer of her father. He puts his signature mark on this character - gruff, hard, killer with a heart of gold - and very funny. At times he reminded me of W.C. fields with his growling one liners. Some of this unfortunately was missed in the theater as we were laughing so hard at times we drowned out some of his lines. I look forward to hearing him again on DVD where I can relish his delivery once again.This is a movie about revenge, justice, trust and eventually - relationships.But it is not the story so much as the way it is told that makes this brilliant. It is drama, action, comedy all rolled up in one serving.Hallie Steinfeld was a joy to watch, and is definitely someone to watch for as I am sure she will become a famous actress. In many scenes, she carries the movie. Her performance is one to see - words cannot describe it.Josh Brolin is also great - but he doesn't get enough screen time to shine.The only thing that prevents me in giving this a 10 is Matt Damon, who - in my humble opinion - was miscast and seemed out of place with the veteran actors and talented newcomers.His performance was 'okay' - and the film itself is so wonderful that I still highly recommend it - even to those who are not fans of the Western genre. This is great story telling at its best.I plan on seeing it again... that in itself, says a lot.

reviews.review_title: A rare gem from the western genre
reviews.content: I have seen quite a few western films and most of them are pretty mediocre. However, this film was great and made you forget the mainly awful western films that came before it. Even if western films are not your thing, you are most likely going to enjoy it. The plot is pretty simple: a 14 year old girl is out for revenge after a man murdered her father. The actress of the main protagonist is very good. Definitely recommend this film if you haven't seen it already.

reviews.review_title: Matty Ross, a fourteen years old girl who wants to obtain justice for the murder of her father, decides to take the law into her hands...
reviews.content: I must confess that I am passionate of the Coen brothers movies, but this one is not the best of their films. Definitely have used another theme from their favorite "West" with wild figures of American creativity. They chose their favorite actors (Brolin, Bridges, Damon) but all this did not work properly. The Coen brothers choose western again, after the award-winning No country for old men. This time they do a remake of Henry Hathaway's movie, starring John Wayne (who won an Oscar for this role), put his place Jeff Bridges, filming with surrealism and cynicism the characters of the Wild West and with their special sarcastic humor, create a pure western, with too slowly rhythm, minimum but brute violence, and sporadic... shooting. The beautiful photography, the interpretation of the little Hailee Steinfeld which impresses the audience, the good, although one-dimensional interpretations of all the actors and attentive, without exaggeration direction, unfortunately is not enough to save the new creation of Coen from the boring effect. Pity, because the names in directing and the cast prepares us for something much more interesting than a boring movie, where the journey to revenge and atonement is without 'true grit' and mostly without any originality.

I grew up watching John Wayne movies. The man is movie icon. His body of work is legendary. Since Hollywood is seriously lacking in creativity these days it came as no surprise to finally see a remake of one of "The Duke's" films. I must admit that when I first heard that someone was remaking True Grit, I was appalled! And his only Oscar winnings performance to boot!? Blasphemy! Those arrogant Cohen Brothers! Who do they think they are? During the next few months the idea really started to sink in. I began to really consider the audacity of the dynamic brotherly directing duo and I became a believer. I considered the Brothers own legendary body of work. Eight Academy Awards between them, including two for Best Picture (Fargo, No Country For Old Men) and various other accolades. They even inspired me to read the book! After a bloody inner battle I realized that if anyone could pull this adaption of the Charles Portis classic and meet the Duke standard, they could.Now for the actual review.....True Grit is a story about a young girl named Maddie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) whose father is unjustly murdered by one of his employees, a simple minded criminal by the name of Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Maddie sets out to the town her father was killed to settle his business affairs, to send his body home for funeral, and to see that Chaney is brought to justice. After discovering that justice will not be sift as she sees fit, Maddie hires U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to hunt Chaney down. As they prepare for the hunt, they encounter an arrogant Texas Ranger by name of Lebeouf (Matt Damon) who is also on the scout for Chaney under a different name for the murder of a Texas senator. Together the three go after Chaney, who is now banded with Lucky Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper) and his gang of miscreants.First and foremost the casting was brilliant. I was convinced that no one could play Rooster Cogburn like the Duke did, not even Jeff Bridges. And I was right. However, this isn't the Rooster Cogburn of John Wayne lore. This Rooster is a much dirtier and dingier portrayal. There is no doubt about the man's courage and toughness, but there is some question about his character. Is he a good man? Or is he bad? By the end of the movie, Bridges has played the character so well that there will no be doubts to what the answer is. Matt Damon as LeBoeuf is monumentally better than Glen "The Rhinestone Cowboy" Campbell. He captured the arrogance and later the humility of LeBeouf very well. And newcomer Hailee Steinfeld is the most impressive by nailing the sassy and confrontational Maddie Ross. Made even more impressive by the fact that she has very little acting experience and easily garners the most screen time. Finally, the Cohen Brothers are masters at both writing original screen plays and adapted screen plays. While True Grit won't win an Oscar for Best Movie, it is deserving of multiple nominations and will more than likely be treated duly, although the Golden Globes managed to thumb its nose at the movie in most categories.

True GritTo tell if a gunslinger has true grit, have them ride through town sidesaddle, twirling a parasol, whistling: When Johnny Comes Marching Home.And while the employer of the elderly gun-for-hire in this western doubts his fortitude, she engages his services nonetheless.Subsequent to collecting her dad's corpse, 15-year-old Mattie (Elizabeth Marvel) goes about acquiring someone to bring her father's killer–Chaney (Josh Brolin)–to justice.Due to his plucky repute, Mattie opts for the alcoholic Cogburn (Jeff Bridges). However, to his chagrin, she insists on riding along.A Texas Ranger (Matt Damon) in purist of Chaney's boss (Barry Pepper) later accompanies the pair on the treacherous trail.A more distilled translation compared to previous cinematic interpretations, this Coen Brothers edition of the popular novel captures its violence, dialect and darkly humorous tones perfectly.Ironically, due to their incontinent bladders, young and old people are the worst long- distance travel companions. (Green Light)

reviews.review_title: A movie about death and judgement beyond the realms of civilisation
reviews.content: True Grit begins with a death and ends with a death, and is about justice. While the word vengeance is cited throughout the movie it is not truly vengeance that drives Mattie to leave civilisation and travel into the wilderness in search of her father's murderer, but to make sure that justice has been done.Death and justice are two themes that a common throughout the movie. Near the start Mattie watches a hanging where three men are being punished for their misdeeds. The first is in tears and uses his last words to warn the crowd against following in his footsteps. He got drunk and murdered a man in a fit of rage. The second man was after vengeance and killed an innocent person, but is justified in his own eyes. The third is an Amerindian, and is denied a voice (it is interesting to see the portrayal of the natives in this movie. Blacks are treated as servants, while the Amerindians are treated as being less than rodents).Mattie is a very intelligent and determined individual who makes sure she gets her own way. This is seen as she negotiates with the man whom her father bought livestock from as she seeks to wind up her father's business in this town at the edge of civilisation.It is clear from the start that the town in which Mattie arrives is at the edge of civilisation as it is at the end of the railway line, and beyond this town is only wilderness, a place where outlaws run to escape the consequences of their actions.While the movie is about justice, and the rule of law, where Mattie travels the law exists only in theory. In practice only the strong survive and justice is sought at the barrel of a gun. She learns this quickly when she confronts her father's murderer and attempts to arrest him only to have him laugh at her. In the end, the only justice that is found, is justice at the barrel of a gun.

14-year-old girl Mattie Ross hires Rooster Cogburn, a hard-drinking lawman, to pursue an outlaw called Tom Chaney who murdered her father. The pair are joined on the trail by a Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf, who himself has been tracking Chaney for killing a Senator. Each of them us tested on their dangerous adventure.Remakes of classics are rarely superior but many will agree that this Coen Brothers effort has succeeded. Jeff Bridges has the task of following in the footsteps of John Wayne as Cogburn and does so with style. With fine support from Hailee Steinfeld and Matt Damon and a great score and you have a winner.

It's okay, the original John Wayne version is much much better! This one felt rushed and all the actors apparently think talking like you have a mouth full of food and stiff jaw makes you sound country. Just watch the original and save the time.

reviews.review_title: Perhaps My Favorite Western Of All-Time
reviews.content: When the Coen brothers first announced this remake of the classic 1969 western, I thought it was a poor idea. Remake an Academy Award-winning endeavor from the Duke himself? Good luck, right?! But then, a funny thing happened--it turned into a serious passion project for the Coens, also shepherded along by such names as Steven Spielberg & Roger Deakins. When all was said and done, it turned into perhaps my favorite western film of all-time.For a basic plot summary, "True Grit" tells the story of young Maddie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld), who hires Deputy Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to avenge the death of her father at the hands of the coward Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Along the way, with the help of Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), Maddie and Rooster track Chaney via the notorious Lucky Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper) gang.What elevates this movie from the original is the closer following of the source material: Charles Portis' novel. The Coens portray a much darker, grittier time and circumstances--probably much more accurate to the period than the original's 60s bravado. Whereas that version was all about the Duke, this one focuses on the rightful charge: the young, plucky Ross."True Grit" also does all the "little things" (which so often end up as so much more) perfectly. The acting is flawless, the direction is solid, the visuals are often jaw-dropping, and even the music adds series emotional depth to the entire production. Every scene is riveting, and will have you on the edge of your seat. Even the comedic and light-hearted moments do their job and add some needed levity.Thus, I consider 2010's "True Grit" to probably be the all-around greatest western I've ever seen. There isn't a single scene that is a letdown, and all the other filmmaking factors converged to produce a masterpiece. Whenever I hear of a seemingly "bad idea remake", I always use "True Grit" as an example of how re-working a classic film can produce a better result if enough care is taken with the material and each storytelling component.

reviews.review_title: Very prolong movie, little action and not interesting
reviews.content: I'm not a fan of coen brothers movies after I seen 'No country for old Men' so if you don't like that movie you will get why this movie is no better than that one. There are a lot of plot holes and lots of camping throughout the movie (mostly night time talking) and little action and poor execution at the end not to mention the villains were only introduce near the end and they were ridiculous one kept gawking like a chicken because his mental, one rode side saddle in a gunfight, another had sheep's wool on his legs which looked stupid and the main good guy Cogburn sounded like Jonah Hex. The little girl Mattie was annoying and it didn't make sense why she was bitten by a snake and why Cogburn would suck the poison out to only have her arm amputated in the end.I heard there was a classic of this with John Wayne which I haven't seen yet but your better off watching that because this movie is overrated just like no country for old men.

reviews.review_title: For the enjoyment it brings, go SEE the "Rooster" crow at daylite (or even nitetime)!
reviews.content: In 1969, longtime movie star JOHN WAYNE won his only Oscar for a film role by playing a drunken "two-handed shooter" in a film called "TRUE GRIT". It was a memorable performance, although many felt the award was mainly given as a "lifetime achievement" honor (He later performed with legend Kathryn Hepburn in a "reprise" of his role, in 1975's "Rooster Cogburn") The Coen brothers have RE-MADE the basic "TRUE GRIT" film for a "modern" audience, tho it kept the idea of using very "formal" dialogue circa the late 1800's. The awkwardness of the dialogue made the 1969 version pretty "hard-to-take" in many ways-- but this new version manages to give a good "CONVERSATIONAL" tone to it, & that helps it come across as quite FUNNY at times In this new version, Mattie Ross (HAILEE STEINFELD) is a 14-year-old girl whose beloved father has just been killed by an outlaw named Tom Chaney (JOSH BROLIN). She's wise and tough beyond her years, & simply won't accept the way the town of Fort Smith, Arkansas has allowed Josh to get away scott-free Hailee toughly bargains with horse-trader Colonel Stonehill (DAKIN MATTHEWS) to get enough money to personally hire an old eye-patched marshal named Reuben "Rooster" Cogburn (JEFF BRIDGES) to find Josh so she can kill him He's uneager to get involved, but needs the money— mainly to build-up his supply of WHISKEY, which seems to be his main interest in life A Texas Ranger named LaBoeuf (MATT DAMON) comes to town, also wanting to catch Josh because he's wanted for killing a State Senator back home. He's keen to capture Josh alive, in order to get a big REWARD that's been posted on him After initially agreeing to work with Jeff, since they're working at opposite purposes (& Matt doesn't want to allow Hailee to come WITH them as she wants), the lawmen eventually go their separate ways Josh is pursued into what was then the Indian territory (now Oklahoma), where he apparently has joined up with OTHER lawbreakers including a gang run by Lucky Ned Pepper (BARRY PEPPER) Jeff, Hailee & Matt keep having encounters & "tussles" with various inhabitants of the area, and they're frequently violent in nature (to the point of being deadly & "final") Will Jeff eventually FIND Josh? Will Hailee have her wish of being able to KILL him for what he's done to her family?... Will "Lucky Ned" REMAIN lucky, or will "true grit" by his pursuers rule the day?... Will Hailee escape the perils she HERSELF faces (from wild animals & others)?... What will "postscripts" show happen to various of the main characters after the "basic" CHASE ends?... I found this film to be a real PLEASURE: Jeff & Hailee were EXCEPTIONAL in their lead roles, & Matt (in a somewhat "quieter" role) also does a fine job (as do Josh & Barry in much smaller roles). The "stilted" type dialogue actually "WORKED", giving a real "mood" and humor to the "Old West" proceedings Thus, for the finely-crafted enjoyment it brings, I'm rating this film at 9.0 out of 10 stars Go SEE the "Rooster" crow at daylite (or even nitetime)!

reviews.review_title: One-eyed and left-eyed at the same time
reviews.content: The main interest is nostalgia in this film and that is slightly short. The first film with John Wayne was a mediocre average western only saved by the presence of a 14 year old girl chasing and hunting the killer of her father. The Coen brothers performed a miracle and give this film a strength and power it did not have in 1969. After spaghetti westerns now is the time of kaddish westerns.They more or less try to be a lot more effective as for the feelings and emotions of the audience. They use the girl at her maximum in all situations. The story though is simplistic but it provides us with some beautiful pictures and landscapes and it increases the dramatic tension a lot.But that does not make a great film and not even a beautiful film, except the touristic discovery of the Santa Fe region and its wilderness. The ending is different and it adds some posthumous depth to the story but fundamentally we are very far away and even more than far away from the tension of Sergio Leones' and Ennio Morricones' films.Yet it is pleasant and I must say the hanging scene is a lot more impressive in this version probably due to the nice sound track that makes the breaking of the vertebrae a lot more audible. But let me give you a final piece of advice: do not spend the night with the local granny.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

reviews.review_title: If the climax is chopped off, it is a classic winner
reviews.content: Isn't there a genre Coen Brothers have not tried. Science Fiction and Fantasy may be, but who's to say what's to come. They have left their unique mark in any genre they have attempted, be it the crime thrillers, spy thrillers, periods, romance and now western. Contains the perfect recipe that has all the ingredients in perfect measure for a western - motivated and stubborn protagonist in pursuit of revenge, supporting characters with vested interests, technology for the best wide shots and beautiful locales going with them are the super talented cast. How can that not go down well? Mattie's (Hailee Steinfeld) father has just been murdered by his help Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). She identifies the perfect man Rooster (Jeff Bridges) to exact her revenge who is a bounty hunter notorious for his trigger happy fingers who reluctantly takes on the mission due to a meager negotiation. LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) is a U.S. Marshall in pursuit of Tom Chaney for various previous crimes and wants in on their pursuit but falls short on his ability to please and differences in approach. Rest is how they fix their differences and accomplish their mission.A lot rides on making Mattie's character likable and Hailee Steinfeld does an excellent job by showing the stubbornness and innocence associated with her age and maturity to deal with the veteran gunslingers. Jeff Bridges, Josh Brolin and Matt Damon are accomplished and talented actors and there should not have been any doubt about their output. It is gritty than stylish, realistic than audience pleasing (except for the climax). Screenplay and character development are textbook and well executed. The pre-climax where Rooster pushes the horse to its limit is exhilarating and something I have never seen before. But the climax was totally off leaving all we have digested of Mattie's character down the drain.If the climax is chopped off, it is a classic winner

Joel and Ethan Coen have actually surpassed the original True Grit which won an Oscar for John Wayne in 1969. Jeff Bridges is Rooster this time and he is perfect. The great discovery though is Hailee Steinfeld as a 14 year old girl who hires Rooster to avenge the death of her father by an outlaw. Bridges is a bounty hunter working for Mattie(Steinfeld). The journey borrows heavily from Lonesome Dove, another gorgeous western. The Cohen's have obviously learned the pace, style and look from that t.v. mini series. Even so, I cannot praise young Steinfeld highly enough, she deserved an Oscar. What a find in a girl who is a natural talent who is the real star of the Coens' wagon trail.

reviews.review_title: A new Grit, re furbished 2010 style
reviews.content: I don't think there's nothing the Coen Brothers can't pull off. They pull this remake off beautifully, and Hailee Stanfield is an acting revelation indeed, even topping the great Bridges as cowboy legend, Rooster Cogburn putting his own spin on the John Wayne character, a plus if you're a Bridge's fan. Josh Brolin runs third place as one of the baddies, while Matt Damon hits fourth in still an impressive acting role as Rooster's sidekick, amazing to think this original role was played by, no less than Glen Campbell. The four mains are of that high calibre. You know the story. Girl wants revenge and justice over father's murder and hires Bridges with her moolah, to find the assailant and kill him. As only seeing this as I had a free double pass to see it, I'm glad I did, even though I've only seen it once. Watching Jeff Bridges do his thing, I love, and he's funny too, where in the original, this was the Duke's only acting nomination, and when an different steps into the shoes, and is original, that's what makes a real actor, but it's Stanfield's performance that shines out among the others. Sorry Jeff. All in all, what we have is a refreshing new, if a little loud take on a remake, a wonderful piece of film making for which the Coen brothers can feel proud. Haunting track to end credits.

First of all allow me to clarify, I am not going to draw comparisons to that of the original John Wayne film because the Coen Brothers version should be seen as another adaption of the novel, rather than a remake. And before you metaphorically ask yourself whether i have seen the or read the novel the answer is no. The following review of True Grit is judged on face value...Now that the air is clear let me start by saying True Grit follows in classic Coen Brothers fashion, it is a little different to most Hollywood westerns. Quite refreshingly, the film seen through the eyes of 14 year old girl Mattie Ross. Which reminds me, do not go into the movie expecting a saloon door swinging, face off dueling, shoot em' up. At least 30 minutes passes until the first bullet is fired BUT in saying that there is good balance of grounded and believable action thrills (they call it TRUE Grit for a reason) and character exploration. Yes, there is even crisp moments of humor too, just like that ^.The acting is superb from Jeff Bridges who is made for the role of the aged and rugged US Marshall Rooster Cogburn, although his raspy voice is sometimes hard to understand initially (don't you hate that). Matt Damon is pitch perfect and Josh Brolin is also very good, despite only featuring for around 20 minutes. But the real gem is Hailee Steinfeld who delivers a confident coming of age performance, in order for the film to work she needed to nail it and not only did she do that... she brought a nail gun to the table, deconstructed the table and then built it again. It was exactly what she needed to do with the character of Mattie. Of course the cinematography is both technically sound and brilliantly captured by Roger Deakins, one of the best in the business. The score swings seamlessly between thrilling orchestra and delicate piano and the overall feel/ production design and costume is spot on.But did True Grit stick the landing? For me it didn't entirely have me gasping in ore by the credits like I so badly wanted it to. I wanted to walk out saying 'god that was awesome' but instead I said 'that was enjoyably solid'. I can't quite put my finer on it... It could be because it has a level of predictability (surprisingly for the Coen Brothers), it could be because you are denied of some back story and closure to a certain extent, it could be because the start and ending seemed a little 'tacked on' and didn't quite tie together cohesively. I could tell the audience felt this way too because at the start of the credits there was a wave of silence that lasted for some time. (Note, these are all small things that don't butcher the film at all)Never the less, I definitely did not regret seeing it by any stretch. The Coen Brothers prove once again why they are the best director duo in the world and True Grit proves to be a very solid, refreshing western that balances a smart script and realistic thrills nicely. Go and see it, make up your own mind.

Great actors, great story, great film. Coen brothers and Bridges have done it again. Matt Damon is just Matt Damon so of course he's great, Hailee Steinfeld is UNBELIEVABLE. Definitely worth the watch, feel like I should watch the original now...

Jeff Bridges plays the crotchety Rooster Cogburn in this remake of one of John Wayne's best movies. It is my opinion that Bridges grit far exceeds Wayne's. I was never so pleased with a remake as this one. Young Hailee Steinfeld is a young beauty with a sharp tongue. Quick wit in this character again outshines the role of past. Often we speak of remakes with a grimace due to the fact they rarely hold the light of the past. I challenge all John Wayne fans to give this a watch and try to make an argument to fault the newer version. It is my opinion this was a truly better story.

reviews.review_title: I'm very sorry to say but it's more like True S**t
reviews.content: I'm sorry to seem narrow-minded but I can't understand the hype of this film after having seen it? The narrative was almost making me sleep because the progression is very slow and most of it is just the characters travelling. There is some action featured but I've seen far better in majority of films. There were also some random bits. One including a guy jumping out of the trees, swinging his arms like a chicken and making silly noises which put my friend and I in hysterics! Then again, the Coen brothers seemed to develop a ridiculous narrative in 'Burn After Reading' which also had random parts. Therefore, it seems to be their auteur style.I couldn't understand the conversations because Jeff Bridges just grumbled throughout. He needed subtitles cos I can understand R2-D2 better than this character! The exception of this film was Hailee Steinfeld who spoke very clearly and represented a very powerful and independent character for just a 14 year old girl. Yet her name isn't prominent in the advertising which I find wrong. I must admit the settings were very good as well.Although I haven't seen the original or read the book, I wouldn't recommend this. This is Simply because I feel you wouldn't be missing much. It didn't really teach anything and I found it hard to empathise with the characters. However, in a way, I'm glad I watched it because now I know for myself what it's like and I had good fun talking about it with my friends.

reviews.review_title: Best Coen film since No Country
reviews.content: Firstly this film isn't for Sunday afternoon western fans. Do not expect heaps of unrealistic gun fights etc and if that is what you want then go elsewhere. This movie is more in line with Unforgiven for exampleTo summarize this is a vengeance movie - girl wants to track down and kill the man that murdered her father and hires the help of alcoholic, loose cannon, bad-ass and bounty hunter Rooster Cogburn to do the job Cogburn is played by Bridges, and it is without doubt the best Jeff Bridges performance I have ever seen. All cast members are incredible here, I hadn't seen Hailee Steinfeld before but she is unreal in this as Mattie. If only all 14 year old's were this cool! As with other Coen movies the focus is on characters and accents, and the unusual way that the cast speak provides many opportunities for comical moments - witness Mattie's negotiations for a stolen horse, four ponies and a saddle. Lot's of laugh out loud spots in the theatre I was in. I especially liked Matt Damon's deliveries and the dude wearing the grizzly bear. There are countless good bits and memorable one liners here *spoiler* A very creative movie, I really liked the surreal backdrops and star-fields at the end of the movie when Bridges has the girl on horse back and is carrying her The sound, as usual, is absolutely amazing. No bells and whistles, just solid sound recording and design. Loudness and range are used to really good effect with everything accept gunshots occupying a modest volume level. So the first gunshot is through the roof and really produces a physical reaction! Brilliant and economical use of surround as usual. Very sparse use of music, and all kinds of unusual sounds thrown in. Will watch again just to hear it My only regret about this film is that it wasn't longer, and at nearly two hours it seemed to go by incredibly quickly. Top marksAgain, action junkies go elsewhere

reviews.review_title: Rooster Cogburn was once played by The Duke, and is now played by The Dude.
reviews.content: Set in the 1880's, a young girl named Mattie(Hallie Steinfield) looks to avenge her fathers murder, by hiring Ranger Rooster Cogburn(Jeff Bridges) in hopes of capturing Tom Cheny(Josh Brolin), another Marshall(Matt Damon) comes along for the ride. But will they capture Tom before he gets away.Coen brothers have always been good storytellers, and this is no expectation. the way it was shot was beautiful. Also some good performances by Matt Damon, and Josh Brolin. But the two who really take the film are Jeff Bridges and Hallie Steinfield. She at a young age really holds her own with all the other actors, she will come into her own. And Jeff bridges has Rooster plays in his own way and not trying to do John Wayne. One last best film for 2010.

If you're a fan of westerns, you're going to love this film, because it hits every single one of its notes right. It's everything we've ever wanted from a good, solid western and then some. From the very first minute we're drawn into this world of the good old Hollywood Wild West, although in this case the typical Wild West has a touch of realism in the form of a rather dark atmosphere. There are no real heroes and all the victories are Pyrrhic at best, which fits the Coen brothers' modus operandi rather perfectly.The film's real strength, though, are its characters. Each of the three main characters is well-developed and believable, although they all recycle some old clichés into a new format. Damon's LaBoeuf is a dandy, but still well-meaning and competent. Steinfeld's Matti Ross is a precocious little miss I'm in charge, but she has a spine of steel and more determination than any of the other character. And finally there's Bridges' Rooster Cogburn, who's absolutely the best character in the whole film. He's both sympathetic and repulsive. He's terrifying and pathetic. He's a quandrum of opposites and he's absolutely unpredictable. One of Bridges' best performances by far.Add in some rather sweet side characters and a suitable old western storyline and you have a movie that manages to keep you invested from start to finish. There are no empty moments or wasted conversations. Everything feels premeditated. Pretty much the only reason that keeps this film back from being more than just great is the fact that it doesn't really invent anything new or allow us new viewpoints into the genre. It's just an extremely good western, which is more than fine in my books, but some may find it a bit lacking in that regard. Plus the ending is the kind where you either love it or you hate it, which is neither a plus or a minus.

reviews.review_title: Let's give it a big hand.
reviews.content: Perfectly agreeable throw-back to a familiar they don't make too much of now. It manages to convey a vivid sense of place and time while avoiding being a retro rehash of what John Wayne did.There isn't much to this story self conscious machisimo with more than a little heart. It's more about creating moods and some dazzling set pieces that are deliberately painful feeling.A vivid protagonist is the real selling point though and my inner misogynist liked seeing her try to make it in a man's world and then get more than a little humiliated. I'm not proud of that but she was so clever in her first scene. She is totes adorbs yet oddly scary, like a Southern Gothic Wednesday Adams. I like it.I didn't get anything negative from it but it oddly escapes my memory when I think of movies I've seen.

This film is not bad. But it isn't great either. The Bad - It is particularly boring at times when the two main characters are conversing whilst slowly moving along their journey. The cinematography is nothing to admire. But worst of all is the film's antagonists, if you can call them that. They don't serve their purpose as our heroes' main rivals, the only purpose they serve is being a device that brings our heroes together. We here about them throughout the entire film, the terrible crimes and killings committed. Boy-oh-boy these people sound menacing, I feel scared for our dear heroes as they creep ever so closer to finding these treacherous scoundrels, but I bet it's gonna result in a mind blowing conclus...wa...what...they're dead? That's it? We see them for less than 10 mins and they're all dead? That sucks. They were kinda pointless huh. And it wasn't even a satisfying death for the antagonist, I never hated him, I had no reason to, I had barely seen him. No stunning fight we were teased about happening for the last hour and a half. Just the few bullets shot and hey presto the bad guys are dead. This film also falls more under the romance genre whilst not really having any romance in it. The relationship between the main characters isn't that convincing, I never became truly invested in their friendship, they were usually quite disjointed, so I never felt sad at the end. Lastly the plot is quite bland and boring, yes this is a remake that was based off a book, but still on its own the plot just doesn't stand out. So I hear ya, why am I giving it a 6 when I've done nothing but talk shit about it, let me tell ya.The Good - The acting is pretty much masterclass. Everyone acting just nails it. An Oscar or two should have been won by these actors/actresses. Also the costumes and makeup are spot on, it all looked quite convincing. The music is good, but not amazing. And lastly the action is quite cool. But as far as anything good goes, that's about it.All in all, average film that could have been something more if it wasn't for a lacklustre plot with just as bad antagonists. I advise you do watch it if you haven't seen it, but don't expect much.

There are many things to like about this movie. It has some moments that are full of suspense and also some moments full of comedic relief. But after the third time the experience runs so dry it becomes a flick that starts empty handed and ends nowhere.True Grit isn't a western. It is set in the era. But the characters, the environment and the plot are far from the actual life in that era. To a degree where the movie is stunning in the first place and keeps getting worse with every time you watch it again.That starts with the plain and simply intimidation of Mattie getting reimbursed with ridiculous claims and the vendor is giving in and in to a point where the audience cracks up laughing for it is so plain unbelievable. With all due respect, but the Coens start it with a basic perception that treats a 14 year old orphan with the same respect a current jury in NYC would do. In a time where many people just got enslaved, raped, worked to death and murdered without anyone ever caring.This idea then goes on for about 2 hours. The regular bad-ass loner, the goofy sidekick, the gotta-care-for-kid. End of story. Again it is not a bad movie, on the contrary, but even for Coen-standards the story and the characters are so overdrawn, the movie sadly only ends up as solid, nothing more, nothing less. Mediocre in every regard.While the Coen brothers have a well deserved reputation to come up with remarkable movies this one lacks out on exceeding in any regard. Just another movie out there.

The Coen Brothers expand their unique talents to the Western genre in this effective remake of the 1969 John Wayne classic centering around Mattie Ross, a stubborn teenage girl with a huge chip on her shoulder. Angered and without remaining options, she enlists the 'aid' of old, drunken, but extremely tough U.S. Marshal Rooster Cogburn (Bridges), and glib, cocksure Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Damon), then sets out on a perilous quest to apprehend Tom Chaney (Brolin), the elusive hired hand who murdered her father. Ending seems abrupt, and not quite as effective as it could be, yet the film still delivers with sturdy direction, believable characters, good lines, a vivid sense of time and place, and strong acting, especially Steinfeld in the central role as a young woman who's much smarter—and tougher—than she seems. ***

True Grit refers to the trait of toughness of character. True grit seemingly referring to raw rough Rooster more subtly and might actually refer to the toughness of the no-nonsense, no-fear 14 year old girl bent on seeking her revenge. Unfortunately that's about it for the character's layers; they are one dimensional containing this "true grit" and because they are so simple we are less drawn in and can't truly engage with them beyond the superficial level of getting the bad guy. It is amusing to watch this 14 year old girl negotiate and wisely confront and manipulate these much older, wild western men.It is supposed to be a humorous western. But it wasn't a really funny movie nor was it a great western adventure. Whatever it's supposed to be, this combo did not make it anything memorable. It could have been Gritty and raw but the humor took us away from that or it could have been very funny but the seriousness of it being a western and not a comedy took us away from the comedy. The dialogue was a little interesting and intellectual stimulating but the verbose, almost Shakespearean Rooster mumble, in his true grit fashion, made it exhausting to follow. The typical Coen Brother realistic?, gloomy, uncertain ending is getting more typical than the Hollywood endings, is therefore no longer surprising especially in a coen brothers flick and despite being a little different or quirky these endings do not save the movie.The individual scenes The Coen's make are quirky and unique and expertly executed. They are masters at creating intense suspense and sudden action such as the famous scene of Rooster riding with two guns for a showdown with the bad guys. The cinematography is also marvelously shot with scenes that contain such life and vibrancy or are completely devoid of that and rather have a moody barrenness, that we can become so absorbed by this other "character" which is the background.
