The individual scenes of Coen's are as always excellent but taken as a whole there seems to be a lack in story almost like something is missing or something random/gratuitously quirky goes on for too long.

reviews.review_title: Historically and cinematically solid. Well done, Coen brothers.
reviews.content: It takes true grit to attempt to remake the 1969 Oscar-winning, John Wayne classic, but the Coen brothers were up to the task and thankfully they were competent in their rendition of the Western tale. After the success of their dark, humorless drama No Country for Old Men, the Coens have returned to the scene of dark epics to test their directing skills yet again, this time adding some of that Coen humor to the mix as well.But thinking of this movie as a remake of the first film is road to disappointment, so don't. The Coen brothers drew their creativity from Charles Portis's 1968 novel, gave a few nods John Wayne's way, and then made the movie entirely their own. The result is a wonderful experience of all the authentic period settings, speech, accents, clothing, hair, and oh, those teeth.I won't give away any details, but the acting in this movie was absolutely superb! Jeff Bridges made no attempt to imitate or replace John Wayne as the rough, gruff, and vulgar Rooster Cogburn and in the end created an incredibly convincing character. A pleasant surprise, nearly all of the actors and actresses in the film put out some of their best performances to date, even if only with small roles, including Matt Damon as the inept Texas Ranger, Barry Pepper as Lucky Ned Pepper, and Josh Brolin as the hopeless coward Tom Chaney. On top of it all, Hailee Steinfeld made a fantastic Mattie Ross, playing the naively headstrong girl that avenges her father's death by pursuing his murderer with U.S. Marshall Cogburn.The Coens' True Grit is a impressive visit to the classic Old West that neither diminishes nor tries to compete with the 1969 film. Definitely a classic to add to the Coen collection! 8/10

The star of this film is Hailee Steinfeld. Forget Jeff Bridges, Josh Brolin, or Matt Damon, as good as they are in this film. Hailee Steinfeld's Mathilda has to show toughness to Bridges' Rooster Cogburn who doesn't want her coming along. By the end though he has to concede she was more than able to meet any challenge. She faces down a terrifying Tom Chaney (Brolin), seeking him out in spite of his ruthlessness toward her father. She is cool when Rooster and uptight Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Damon) squabble over leadership in the hunt for Chaney. She holds the screen and conveys toughness well. Hailee Steinfeld will be a star if she wants to be. Set in 1877, Mathilda wants to avenge the death of her father. She rejects all attempts to ignore her on account of her age. We first see her toughness when she is trying to prevent a lawyer from ripping her off for a horse. She has a hard time convincing Cogburn to lead the manhunt for her Dad's killer. He evades her, dismisses her, and tries to send her home, but she won't have it. She won't back down from the evil killer - played with manic ferocity by Josh Brolin. She isn't deterred by the violence she sees in pursuit of her Dad's killer. Viewed from 2013, her toughness seems extraordinary but I think she survived in the environment in which she was born, just as people do today. Her courage in directly confronting her father's killer when he spots her at the river was for me the most electrifying part of the movie.There are moments of random oddness such as an encounter with a doctor cloaked in a bear fur which reminded me of the random encounter in Fargo when Frances McDormand's cop was contacted out of the blue by an old classmate. Jeff Bridges is crusty, foul-tempered, drunk, and rough around the edges. When he sees Matilda's determination to bring Chaney back to Texas for trial, he finally agrees to help her. I thought Bridges was fantastic. Barry Pepper shown himself an actor to watch, as he continues to choose unconventional characters and roles that run against type. Josh Brolin is also fantastic as Chaney and Matt Damon continues to choose roles more based on their quality rather than his ego. The film is gorgeously shot - lots of washed out color which gives the film the look of an old western. The Coen Brothers show themselves to be such iconoclasts in the variety of films that they direct. The only common denominator seems to be a willingness to look unflinchingly at human nature and show it warts and all. Their curiosity seems to know no bounds. They rarely strike sour notes. "The Ladykillers" and "A Reasonable Man" might not have been the most electrifying, but even they were were worth checking out.Their knowledge of styles and conventions, which they then put their own touch on is what makes them so interesting. This take on a classic western, overlaid with the lead of such a strong young woman and some fantastic performances, only continues to do that.

I have long been a Coen brothers fan, and this film simply bolsters that trend.I found the characters to be believable and easy to empathize with, the visuals to be gritty yet spectacular and perfect, the dialog was very well done, and the storyline was maintained at a good pace. There were some extraneous details thrown in (the bear man) that probably added little to the story, but I found them entertaining nonetheless.Many reviews have compared this film to the original. While this may not be entirely fair, it is difficult to avoid.Unlike most, I watched the original AFTER I saw the 2010 version. I think the 2010 True Grit was the superior film. The 1969 version seemed simply designed to showcase Wayne yet again, and the acting of the other cast members was quite wooden and hollow. John Wayne was simply John Wayne. What more needs to be said? And while some would argue it was irrelevant to the story, shooting scenes that are supposed to be occurring in Arkansas/Oklahoma in the grandeur of the Rocky Mountains was a bit....much.While this may be complete heresy to say, I think Jeff Bridges made a better Rooster Cogburn than John Wayne.I recommend readers see the 2010 True Grit. I greatly enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: Coens Continue to Do What They Do
reviews.content: Basically an excuse for the Coen brothers to write witty dialog for 90 minutes while following a very straightforward, simple plot, which is just fine by me. Mattie Ross might be one of my favorite characters in film over the last few years, and considering she was sharing screen time with either Jeff Bridges or Matt Damon, two of my current favorite actors, pretty much from start to finish, that's really saying something. She's always got the right words for the situation, spoken in a way that's always fresh and comically creative. Despite a few chaotic, breakneck action sequences that seemed to drop in from nowhere and the requisite amount of bizarre, "wtf is this guy" oddball Coen extras, this never had trouble keeping me fascinated. The final scenes are a bit anticlimactic, but in a way that's even more fitting than any tearful reunion could've been.

reviews.review_title: True Grit as it should be
reviews.content: True Grit is based on the western novel by Charles Portis and even though many look at it as a remake of the 1969 film starring John Wayne as Rooster Cogburn, this is not even close to the same. While the 1969 version was quite funny this version is much grittier and dark.When I heard this was coming out I went back and watched the 1969 version so that I could make a comparison and I found them both very gripping and entertaining in their own way.I've read the novel and I am a big westerns fan and watch anything available at the first opportunity. I am also a big fan of the Coen brothers and haven't missed many of their movies. They very rarely make a bad movie.True Grit is their first Western, and is as only as the Coen Brothers could have made it.They have made a much more faithful adaptation of the novel the way it was told in the book from the point of view of Mattie Ross, the 14 year old girl.Halee Steinfeld is quite brilliant as the smart, independence and tough character of Mattie. At times she out shines the big name actors that she shares scenes with like Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and Josh Brolin.Some reviewers and critics have said that the end of the film seemed rushed and somehow abrupt, but this is how it should have been in my opinion and is in line with the way the novel ends.I enjoyed this movie and give it 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: You'll stay intrigued, and even laugh throughout this movie!
reviews.content: It never ceases to amaze me how a great movie can get lower reviews than it deserves. ALL of the actors were very good. It was impressive on all accounts. I don't like a lot of westerns, but this is a great movie! Relax and allow yourself to be entertained!

reviews.review_title: A much better movie than I was expecting
reviews.content: I think the worst thing about Hollywood is that there are so many great stories that have never been made into movies, and so many where they have and they did good enough, no need to muck them up with a remake. Yet because Hollywood is a business, they muck them up anyway.That said, the remake of "True Grit" is better than most. Jeff Bridges can never replicate what John Wayne did, so he does the character in his own, PG-13 way. Good for him. They try to replicate the feel of the 19th century. Make it a bit more 'gritty' (if you'll pardon the pun) by having the girl lose her arm and become a strange old spinster.They slightly mix up the "One-eyed Fat Man" line, but it works.Kudos to the supporting cast, the set direction, etc. Everything in this movie seems to work well. I think it was just the ending that dragged on a bit and maybe wasn't necessary. (Was there a snake-bite in the Wayne version?)

reviews.review_title: Highly entertaining, wonderfully acted and excellently written, but somehow not satisfying enough to be classic
reviews.content: The western has been a genre in dire need of a comeback as of late. The Coen brothers have always had some love for the setting (No Country for Old Men notably), so if anyone is to be up for the challenge of bringing it back, it would be them. What was unexpected was for them to tread into remake territory, bringing the John Wayne classic back, a film I admittedly have not seen. Viewed as its own beast, True Grit 2010 is a highly entertaining, very well written and very well acted western tale, but didn't fully satisfy my hunger for some good old fashioned retribution.The film is about young Mattie Ross hunting Tom Chaney, the killer of her father, with the aid of notorious US Marshal Rooster Cogburn and occasional aid of Texas Ranger LaBoeuf, who has been chasing Chaney for some time. Mattie is not satisfied simply letting the two men take care of it and insists to accompany them herself. The three reluctant allies make their way through Indian territory to face Chaney and the gang he has shacked himself up with.The Coen touch is clearly felt in the side-characters encountered, notably a bear-skin wearing doctor of questionable honesty. These moments give it almost a noirish feel at times, but truth be told this is as close to a straight genre film as the Coens have ever made. Western through and through, True Grit does little to mess with the formula and tone, unlike perhaps more daring films like The Proposition.Even through it is a genre film, its a damn well made one. The setting feels like a long-lost memory at this point for most audiences, and is represented beautifully. The dialogue rarely if ever feels modernized, but strays from unintelligible archaic babble. Even more importantly, the film can be downright brutal. The old west was, I imagine, a violent place compared to modern society, and the film does not shy away from the blood, racism and cruelty. Those who can't take animals getting hurt should be wary of the film's climax, and those who squeam at the sight of blood should bring a shoulder to bury their eyes into.The best part of the film is indeed the characters and the performances behind them. The weight of the movie falls on the shoulders of young Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross, who stands with Chloe Moretz as one of the great emerging young actresses of the year. She shows maturity well beyond her years and pulls off some incredibly impressive dialogue believably, especially notable in the first twenty minutes (the bartering scenes are almost the highlight).Those worried Jeff Bridges wouldn't be able to pull it off can put their worries to rest, as while Steinfeld is the emotional center, Bridges carries the movie as the entertainment. His performance is highly believable, yet this is Mattie's story and not Cogburns. As such, he's an incredibly funny and occasionally cunning major character. Matt Damon pulls off the arrogant asshole LaBoeuf as well as the necessary changes his character undergoes. Josh Brolin gives a perhaps confusingly meekish portrayal of Chaney, but it just makes his character that much more interesting. Barry Pepper makes the most of his small role as the gang leader.The problem with the characters is that nothing really seems to happen. Mattie is already hard as rock when we meet her, rather than having to build up due to necessity. Rooster only begins to change his stripes at the very end, and does so very quickly. LaBoeuf emerges as almost the most interesting character to watch change, but is relegated to the sideline. Perhaps I'm expecting too much of an old story, but I also felt unsatisfied by the ending, with everything working out a bit too neatly aside from one tripup.True Grit is not the best film of the year, as many thought it may well be. It is a very well made and entertaining western sure to please fans of the genre and not make its detractors as bleary-eyed as they might expect, but its ending prevents it from reaching classic status. Hopefully its success ushers in a new wave of westerns, for the cinema scene surely needs them.

The film True Grit is about a witty young woman named Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) and her search for her father's killer. Her father has been killed by a man named Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) who has fled into Indian Territory. After consulting with the town sheriff, Mattie hires Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) a Deputy U.S. Marshal to help her hunt down Tom Chaney and to bring him back to be tried for her father's death. Mattie chooses Rooster because she believes he has "true grit". LeBoeuf (Matt Damon) a Texas Ranger is also searching for Mr. Chaney. He teams up with Mattie and Rooster in hopes of finally catching Tom Chaney. The theme of this film is about a girl hell bent on finding Tom Chaney. She believes in justice and will not except that her father's murderer will not pay the price. She picks Rooster even though he is a drunk who can barely role his own cigarettes. Mr. Cogburn, Mattie and LeBoeuf set out on this journey as three people who barely can get along. Cogburn continuously makes jabs at LeBoeuf and at times mocks the Texas Rangers. Mattie uses her wits and sharp tongue to belittle the grown men to the point of being switched by LeBeof. Over time they develop a sense of mutual respect for each other. Mattie pulls her weight, LeBoeuf saves Cogburn with a long shot from his rifle and Cogburn saves Mattie from the snake bite. In the end they get what they set out for, Mr. Chaney is dead. The long chase is over. The Coen brothers did an excellent job directing, writing and editing this film. The flow of events kept the viewer intrigued. The film never became boring. The scenes in the film pass from one to the next fluidly. The camera angles, objective and subjective points of view made the viewer feel as if they were participating in the chase. One scene in the film that the Coen brothers did an outstanding job using subjective and objective point of view is near the end of the film. LeBoeuf and Mattie have just knocked out Chaney and are on top of the cliff side looking down into the bottom field. Cogburn is seen at one end and Ned and gang at the other. The objective point of view allows the viewer to take in the landscape and realize what is about to happen. After jawing back and forth Cogburn demands that the four men fill their hands with lead. This is where the excitement begins. The camera switches from objective to subjective several times. A wide objective view shows the Cogburn racing towards the four men all on horseback. Then the camera switches to subjective and puts you in the saddle of the horse. You can see Ned's men being shot from Coburn's point of view. The sounds and camera angles make you feel as if you are in the fight. After the dust settles Cogburn is trapped under his horse. Ned's three men have been killed. Ned rides up to Cogburn and draws down on him with his gun. Cogburn is a dead man. At this instant, the view goes back to the subjective point of LeBoeuf looking down his rifle barrel. A shot rings out and Ned is seen falling from his horse. I truly enjoyed watching this film. I liked the narration done by Elizabeth Marvel who also plays Mattie's character as an adult. The film was suspenseful all the way through. It kept me intrigued and cheering for Mattie, Cogburn and LeBoeuf.

I don't really fancy myself much of a Coen brothers fan, and the idea of a 'True Grit' remake seemed rather unnecessary, so it took four years and a rather desperate desire to kill a few hours before I finally bit. In the end I'm glad I did.Lacking much of the Coen brothers signature quirk, this is a simple, straightforward and well made movie. The performances do tiptoe the line at times, yet I have to say that without them the movie would lack a certain spark.Though it never quite hits its groove and lacks the simple profundity that it seems to be going for, 'True Grit' hits more often than it misses.

True Grit seemed to be a very straight forward Western to me. There are bad guys, good guys, and a precocious young woman. The plot was pretty straight forward. It was the characters, the acting, and the dialog that was great. I am a big Jeff Bridges fan, and he was as good as ever as Rooster Cogburn, the irascible, one-eyed, hard-drinking, Federal Marshal, with the pretty good heart buried down deep. I thought Hailee Steinfeld played Mattie well. She was earnest with the single-minded goal of revenging her father's death. Matt Damon's role of LaBoef, the Texas Ranger, was fairly understated. Not over the top; just nice.Regarding the dialog, before reading anything about this film, I described it as Shakespearean with a Western flavor. I guess other people see it the same way. I often complain to my wife that the dialog on many current television dramas is not realistic. The dialog in these legal and cop shows is often very fast paced, full of big words, perfectly composed and delivered. I tell my wife that people do not speak like that in real life. Well, I don't know that the dialog in True Grit is any more realistic, but I loved it. The dialog between Mattie and the owner of the town stable over business matters is one heck of a rapid-fire, back and forth battle of the mouths. Just what I don't like normally, but I got a kick out of it here. The dialog in other parts of the movie is even more poetic and beautiful.My final thought concerns Mattie. I was fearful that this lovely nubile young woman might suffer at the hands of these crusty lonely men out in the middle of nowhere. Nothing of the sort occurred, nor was it really even suggested. Kudos to the Coen's for not going there. By the way, Mattie seems to be a great assertive role model for young women.

huge disappointment and I'm a Coen brothers fan. Why did they make this movie? I was expecting a hardcore western, not that it had to be, but what a pile of crap this movie was. There was simply nothing to be interested in and a waste of time on the Coen bros part. and the nominations?? what are those for? garbage. True Garbage, not True Grit.don't waste your time at the theater. wait for it on cable if you must. My opinion is that anyone who says this is movie is good is just lying to themselves and only want the movie to be good simply because it's a Coen bros movie and yes I'll gladly admit they've made some amazing movies but this movie is an insult.

reviews.review_title: Neither the true hit nor the true s*it - a boring western with some great acting
reviews.content: I am a huge fan of Western movies and also of Matt Damon's acting and that was why I was really looking forward to this movie. I haven't seen the original with John Wayne but I have seen other movies starring him and know about his strong presence and particular acting even though I largely prefer the Italian Westerns and their actors and think that John Wayne is somehow overrated. After many positive reviews and an entering at the list of the top movies of all times on this site, my expectations were quite high for the new version of True Grit and then crashed dramatically down. I won't say that it is a bad movie but I would honestly say that it is a rather boring that is saved by the great actors, the magnificent landscapes and the movie score. True Grit is neither a True Hit nor the True S*it.The movie is a rather slow paced character study where the actors do a very well job, especially the young and talented Hailee Steinfeld as stubborn young girl Mattie Ross that wants to chase the killer of her father with the help of the often drunk, used and pitiless but rather smart Rooster Cogburn played by the very convincing Jeff Bridges. Matt Damon plays a young, modern and somewhat emotive Texas Ranger but is less convincing as usually. On the other hand, I didn't see any sadness, fear or despair in the role of Mattie Ross, a young girl in a stranger town that has lost her father recently; her only emotion was her stubborn sense of vengeance. Rooster Cogburn did a slightly better job and shows his two sides as a prudent tutor and nostalgic storyteller but also as an alcoholic with a quite grey life. But even though Rooster saves Mattie in the end, I miss somewhat a closer contact between them, a developing relationship between them and I would have liked to see a more intense final ending between those two characters. I was also surprised to see that the development of the character was abruptly broken when Rooster got suddenly heavily drunk out of the blue after so many sacrifices during the chase and I thought that inappropriate. The role of Matt Damon seemed strange to me, sometimes he acted like an arrogant and pitiless ranger and later as an almost warm-hearted friend. Some people may call this a developing and profound characterization but I rather saw the whole thing as an unconvincing lack of continuity. Every time I thought that there would be an interesting and tension filled relationship between the characters for example when the Texas Ranger left the group to chase the bad boys on his own and enter in conflict with the other two main characters, nothing really happened or evolved. But what really left me disappointed were the roles of the evil guys. They had nothing menacing, nothing bad and nothing outstanding apart of the embarrassing and unnecessary bad buy that was imitating animal noises to cut off the little rest of atmosphere and tension in the movie.And with this allusion comes my next important point. The whole story was rather boring and tensionless while the main idea could have been interesting. Something like a convincing final duel or intense chase between the good and the bad was missing. A part of a few shooting scenes, there was a lack of action in the movie as it tried to touch a rather emotional, nostalgic and finally dramatically and philosophical style. That could have been another interesting approach, but the movie even failed from that point of view. The nostalgic speeches of Rooster about his wife, his career and his demons are completely random and not very touching, the thoughts of the young girl are quite linear and predictable while Matt Damon showed two different attitudes in a rather disturbing than convincing manner.Many good ideas that could have given something special to the movie have been left out in my opinion. If the bad boys and their three hunters were marching through a territory of the Indians, I would have liked to see a cause of conflict between them. But the good and bad guys were just randomly galloping through rather beautiful landscapes. But the whole chasing story is somehow based on a few unbelievable coincidences. The fact that the girl meets the murderer of her father was predictable and the way how she met him was quite unoriginal for example. I also thought that the killer had nothing menacing at all. He was afraid of the young girl and almost begging and crying face to face with the leader of the gang (who were those guys anyway?) but should have been a cold hearted and legendary murderer across several states? These lacks of logic and some boring points throughout the whole movie could not have been hidden only by a few sympathetic word plays or jokes throughout the whole flick.When there is a random story with many coincidences and less convincing characters, even the greatest actors, the best movie score and the most beautiful landscapes can't quite help to completely save this movie. I would have preferred a more original or even unique story and not a remake of a rather average western. I think that the talent of the actors was wasted in this unoriginal movie. Only those actors save this movie from being an absolute faceless average Western like "Appaloosa" or worse. That's why I don't really understand the whole hype about this movie. I would only recommend this flick to collectors that would absolutely see any film with Matt Damon or Jeff Bridges and those who adored the original flick. But sadly, the great times of the brilliant westerns have gone a long time ago. With this kind of movie they won't come back either even if I would hope so.

reviews.review_title: Almost perfect, but for the last 15 minutes....
reviews.content: Almost perfect: the beauty, the wit, the fairy-like characters - this is Brothers Cohen, of course! But the movie ought to end in 1880, with the light lit in the cottage as the last image. The 1903 fragment offers gratuitous information, so that the viewer is free to ponder the absolute impossibility of the lips of that young girl to have become the lips of this grown-up woman, or over the fact that if the Texas Ranger "must be in his seventies" in 1903, he must have been in his fifties in 1880... Who would ever have thought! He certainly didn't look his age. But these remarks are quite petty. It is difficult to understand, though, why True Grit receives so little attention compared to some other films (no names mentioned). It is probably because it would be unfair to compare any other director to The Brothers!

reviews.review_title: A fine re-imagining of the John Wayne classic
reviews.content: You cannot avoid comparing this film to the iconic John Wayne film of the same name, and I won't try. Jeff Bridges and the directors re-imagined the Cogburn role, and rightly so. Trying to be John Wayne would have been a mistake, and a recipe for failure. I would score that a success. (Full disclosure: it has been at least thirty years since I have seen the 1969 film, but I recall liking it a great deal) Matt Damon and the supporting cast were fine. But Hailee Steinfeld stole the show. She, and the role she played, were utterly outstanding. Kudos.A note about the much-commented on use of language. It was all quite formal, and it really set the atmosphere of the film, establishing that this was a different time than our own. Of course no one really knows how people spoke back then, but I suspect that a lot of people did speak more formally in those days, at least educated people. But I suspect that many others did not, whether from lack of education or temperament.Anyway, this is a fine film, even with a few plot holes, and I recommend it.

I absolutely enjoyed the movie from the first second it started. The dialogue, characters and the numerous surprising twists the story took - it all had me enchanted. A good and different western movie.
The only thing that kept me away from rating it top score was the ending of the movie. It worked, but didn't satisfy me. I have watched a few other movies by the Coen's and, to me, it always seems like the budget runs out just before the ending and they just have to wrap it all up with what they've got. A bit disappointing.
Yet, looking away from the rushed ending I really enjoyed the movie and would absolutely recommend it. Worth watching!

reviews.review_title: Flimbsy remake of John Wayne's Greates Western
reviews.content: My first question is "why" did they remake a John Wayne classic and a John Wayne award winning performance. Second, the movie is a flimsy remake. Yes the improvement in the Glen Campbell character was better but that was it. The case of the original movie included John Wayne, Robert Duvale, and Kim Darby. You can't get any better than that. This movie was truly a bad remake despite the hype. First of all,John Bridges cannot faithfully portray Rooster Cogburn and now let talk about Hailee Steinfeld.......she doesn't even touch the performance of Kim Darby and was totally miscast. This whole is just a bad remake and never should have been made in the first place. I went to it with an open mind but quickly realized this movie could never live up to the original. I guess all the younger generation who have never watched a John Wayne movie will love it because it is a motion picture in a different era that allows you to use fowl language in it. But when you cut all that away.....go buy the original or rent it and watch it. This does not even come close.

True grit An interesting and well-acted film. The director frankly hurts the film in many ways such as by using bad camera angles and giving every character in the film more or less the same tone in dialogue. I remember the hype behind this film when it first came out. Far from being a classic considering it has not stood the test of time.

reviews.review_title: Praise for Haillee Steinfeld, Can't understand Bridges, some uncomfortable scenes
reviews.content: I enjoyed this more than I expected to especially since I'm not a real fan of the Westerns. Haillee Steinfeld as Mattie is what makes this so watchable, she's just fantastic as the young woman tracking down her father's murderer with the help of a stubborn (mostly drunk) U.S. Marshal. That famous reins in the mouth/double fisted shootout scene was pretty awesome too (but still not as good as the original).As for Jeff Bridges taking on John Wayne's iconic role; while I appreciated that he didn't just do an impression, instead giving his own 'take' on Rooster Cogburn I couldn't understand what he was saying most of the time -it sounded like he was chewing on gravel.I've also come to the realization that Matt Damon can carry off just about any role he wants (although that spanking scene made me very uncomfortable) On that note I imagine PETA was fairly involved here too -jeez that last scene with the horse! 10.13

I read where the brothers said this was going to be closer to the book than the 1969 John Wayne original & it's pretty much a carbon copy to the original movie!! Clearly the book was not read by the brothers nor anoyone else worked on this!! The patch is not even on the correct eye for crying out loud!! Look at pictures from this & the original version that is following the book!! Just the original gives a more happy ending!!Kim Darby played Mattie to a top to where you wanted to bend her over your knee & spank her. This girl doesn't know the character & has you wanting to throw her out of the boat, (figure of speech)! Jeff, Matt, Josh & Berry are some fine actors but they are so lost on this that they seem like newbies!!This film should be one that's out of print & forgotten about, it's how pathetic it is!! Watch the original version please, you will not regret it!!

reviews.review_title: The Coen brothers reviving the Western genre
reviews.content: With "True grit" the Coen brothers made a remake of the 1969 film of the same name from Henry Hathaway. This time they succeeded, where in 2004 their attempt to remake "The ladykillers" (1955, Alexander Macjendrick) failed miserably.This time no "neo film noir" from the Coen brothers, but a Western. A courageous choice, because the Western was seen as a genre at the brink of extinction at that time.The film is about the hunt on a contract killer (Tom Chaney played by Josh Brolin). This hunt is undertaken by Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld), a 14 years old girl whose father has been killed by Clancey, and marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges). The marshall is pragmatic even leaning towards opportunistic. The girl is pertinacious of the "an eye for en eye" kind of type. Their interaction is the driving force behind the movie. At the end of the movie they are both damaged (although in different ways) but have come closer to each other.The film has an undercurrent derived from the Old Testament. It is no accident that is starts with a quotation from "Proverbs" (28:1) "A wicked flee even though there is no one to pursue him". This quote definitely relates to Chaney. The film does not quote the sequel "A righteous man feels as safe as a lion" which would be a pretty accurate description of Mattie.From the John Ford Westerns we know the beautiful landscapes of Monument valley. "True grit", which was shot in New Mexico and Texas, has many beautiful landscapes too. Highest praise deserves cinematographer Roger Deakins however for a scene in which Mattie has been bitten by a snake and Rooster Cogburn tries to reach medical help in time. The heat of the moment, the sweat on the skin of the horse and the starlit skye all add up to a few magical minutes of film.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, easily the best of Coen
reviews.content: One doesn't expect much of the Coens. They are totally 1970s in their contrived formula for the most depressing thing they can think of, which is exactly what the self smug, self righteous geek in the café always concocts.But here, they finally get in touch with the times, in the remake of the Western drama-adventure in which a very young girl enlists a rogue lawman and a handsome Texas Ranger to help her find her father's killer.The original TRUE GRIT stood out in its era, not so much because it was great, but because it was about the only film of the era which was true to the alleged "reality" the directors preached. Most Westerns of the era were one dimensional caricatures. In fact, they were so goofy that the John Wayne westerns came across as the most realistic in terms of characters.And the Coens manage to finally come up with an action film based more on a realistic look than one based on "contrived hate and depression" that only raving lunatics could enjoy.Here, they stay very close to the original. They give it just a touch of their own individual treatment, without going overboard, and that works. This is not a "groan" invoking movie.It is very watchable.The key is the one eyed fat man, of course. And Bridges, I dare say, is a bit better than the duke in this role. He is hilarious and credible at the same time. In fact, he'll probably remind you of someone you know personally.The other characters are good, too. The ranger is an improvement.However, the young girl sounds more like someone reading lines. She looks like she was cast for her looks, making you wonder if they were looking for a model instead of an actress.The direction of the lines is good, as we get a realistic stress of words that makes us feel these were eighteenth century Americans.However, the girl runs through her lines faster than a person could possibly think of the words. Hence, she really just seems to be reading memorized lines.But overall, it is a decent movie. My score of 6 is above average. I gave the original a 7. I am a harsh grader. For me, 5 means average. I give it a 6, because it was watchable and pretty well done, but I certainly don't feel any inclination to ever re-watch it.If you like this, you should like the original, and if you like the original, you should like this. There just isn't enough difference to warrant otherwise.

Nothing much to say, great movie with great cast. The script is well written and this is antoher masterpiece by Coen's. Roger Deakins delivers another spectacular visual miracle. 10 nominations for Oscar and sadly 0 won. We will get them next time.

reviews.review_title: As Gritting as the Rating demands
reviews.content: This is probably the first movie to remind me of the awesome aura projected by my favourite series Deadwood. Although slightly different in style (this movie utilized a more authentic cowboy language and a more direct, flattering and less intense storyline) but the mechanism of the flow of plot was truly an award-winning effort.Also contributing to the movie's unforgettable moments was a strong cast, particularly Hailee, whom I thought was placed in a wrong Oscar category as she seemed like a main actress, having more time appearance than her 'main actor counterparts'. She reminded me of the strong-willed, hard-headed Trixie (Deadwood) without the constant swearing.The Coen brothers did made some bad movies, but TRUE GRIT was a masterpiece in rejuvenating the classic cowboy behaviour and it was truly an enjoyable experience. It is not a heavy movie to watch, but the issue of 'grit' faced by each of the 3 companions throughout the movie is something we all can relate to in real life.

The Coen brothers latest project is handicapped with the fact that it will be inevitably compared to the Henry Hathaway directed Original, as it is bound to be. As they must have been aware of this I had good expectations for this adaptation of the Charles Portis novel. A decent effort was made; locations, cinematography, historical accuracy are all superb. A particular bright spot was new comer Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross. However, the performances of Mr. Bridges, Damon and Brolin were phoned in. Particularly annoying and unconvincing was Jeff Bridges screeching dialog. Barry Pepper made an excellent "Lucky Ned Pepper" however his screen time was sadly minimal. The Coens have and can do better.

I saw the original True Grit way back when you could only watch movies at the theater. Normally I refuse to watch remakes, as they are never as good as the original. I am glad I talked myself into watching this and you will be glad also, as It is awesome.

reviews.review_title: The Coen brothers doing serious again - Thank god.
reviews.content: Inevitably this film will be compared with the original True Grit from 1969 that starred John Wayne but having never seen it , i can only judge it on it's own merits and on the whole i thought this was a very good western.Some actors careers dwindle when they get older . They lose their way and make some real stinkers ( Robert De Niro being the obvious example). Jeff Bridges is the complete opposite. The older he gets the better his performances are and despite his age he tends to star in more Oscar nominated film that most. He is superb as Rooster Cogburn , the US Marshall who is out to kill the man that murdered the father of Mattie Ross , played by Hailee Steinfeld and what a mature acting display we see from her. This is directed by The Coen brothers who are on a roll at the moment with films i really have enjoyed , which is a surprise as I'm not keen on a lot of their earlier work. All in all , True Grit is an entertaining film that is really hard to dislike and although nominated for best picture at this years academy Awards , its unlikely to win but i do hope Hailee Steinfeld wins an Oscar for best supporting actress because i think she deserves it .

reviews.review_title: A fine and sometimes beautiful movie
reviews.content: I know that a lot of people rave about this movie. I won't do that. But I did very definitely enjoy it, more so as it went along.Some praise the acting. Jeff Bridges does a fine job creating a real human being, not just a caricature, which would have been a lot easier. Matt Damon is very good playing his exact opposite, a very understated character.To me, however, the most striking thing was some of the cinematography, which was really very beautiful. To me, it really went a long ways toward creating the atmosphere of the later part of the movie.What I liked least was a lot of the dialog. Yes, people wrote in that very stilted style then, even those with little education. But to hear dialogue like that I find strange. And, frankly, many of the actors seem uncomfortable delivering it. At times the language becomes much more natural, as when Matty and Clancy are arguing in the river, and you notice how much more natural the delivery becomes. In a sense, it is like actors, even perfectly good actors, trying Shakespeare for the first time: they don't know yet how to make the very different language sound like the everyday language of the characters.As a result, and as when you have actors trying Shakespeare for the first time, a fair amount of the dialogue gets lost.Still, I enjoyed this movie and was never bored for a moment. Though, to be honest, I don't know that I would want to see it again.

The Coen brothers have always existed as somewhat of an anomaly. After two trailers and more than a dozen of their other films, I thought I knew what to expect. I did not. Granted, I came into the film fresh off of the high from No Country for Old Men, assuming a more serious form of Western with snippets of humor thrown in here and there to break up the tension from the stunning visuals. In regards to True Grit, I have not read the book, or seen the original film (quite intentionally, and contrary to burning desires), but I believe Joel Coen when he said of Portis's novel, "the book is just an oddity. It's a very odd book." And coming from a Coen, that statement, in itself, is quite odd.But astute. The intelligent, well-spoken Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) takes it upon herself to exact revenge upon her father's bumbling killer, Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), eventually enlisting the help of a drunken, cantankerous marshal, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges), and, by sheer coincidence, a longwinded and highfalutin Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf (Matt Damon). The film is not only at times an honest and non-prescriptive look at the nature of violence, morality, and law, but also one hell of a laugh riot and bloodbath.To be honest, I should have expected the sheer volume of humor from a Coen film, but with the sparseness of it in No Country for Old Men, I wasn't expecting hilarity that beckoned back to the constant laughs of a film like O Brother, Where Art Thou. And the Coens give the audience permission to laugh quite early, deflating the seriousness of a few men's final words at a hanging, shortly followed by funeral parlor humor. In fact, rarely is there a scene that doesn't offer some sort of laugh, no doubt in part (a big part) to Jeff Bridges' drunken, cantankerous, no-nonsense marshal and, on frequent occasion, his banter with the self-aggrandizement of the prideful LaBoeuf.The Coen's have been making great films for a long time, but this one seems right up there with No Country and Fargo. It combines incredible wit with grave seriousness, and all without being didactic. Around midway through, Rooster is quite drunk and listening to a conversation LaBeouf seems to be having with himself about the nature of morality and law. He speaks of the distinction between malum in se (wrong in itself) and malum prohibitum (wrong by due to law). For the casual viewer, a scene like this might display value for its humor, since Rooster consistently spouts drunken vitriol at the tongue-flapping defensiveness of LaBoeuf, who slurs ridiculously because he nearly bit his tongue off in a scuffle moments prior, but the philosophy could titillate the serious viewer as well. There's something for everyone in this film, and that seems to be what the Coens have begun to master nearing their 30th year of filmmaking.One could ruminate upon the distinction between the instinctual hunting of a man from Rooster, or the calculated rule-following tendencies of a man like LaBoeuf. Near the end of the film, Josh Brolin arrives to surprise the hell out of the audience, along with Barry Pepper, by playing their criminals either sympathetic, in Chaney's case, or as caring in spite of their lawbreaking, in Ned Pepper's case. It becomes clear that the characters seem trapped by the roles they must fulfill: bad guy, good guy, vengeful child, perhaps because that is the law of the plot, a law that cannot be broken. Unlike many of the films released this year, the Coen's True Grit begs for a second viewing just to appreciate the nuances in character and theme, in spite of the entertaining distractions.The only possible issues that I can even see people having with the film are its music and the ending. The music is oddly religious through a collection of stylized church hymns but, in spite of a quote from Proverbs at the beginning of the film ("the wicked flee when none pursueth"), religion seems largely nonexistent from the film. Perhaps that's the point, and the letter of the law versus the spirit of the law is an underlying point, but it seems more incidental than intentional and, overall, distracting. The ending, as well, seems unnecessary. By the end of the film, Hailee Steinfeld has proved herself as Mattie Ross, and her adult actress far from fills her shoes in the limited screen time she has. It serves to show only that she's endured irreversible consequences from her adventure and that she's always appreciated what Rooster did for her. I could tell that from the ending of the story proper, without the needless addition of a coda.But these are trifling concerns, and didn't in the least sour my viewing of the film. The Coens' True Grit is a wonder, and I hate that I have to wait to see it again. So often, a Coen film is such a visceral experience, and True Grit didn't disappoint. I want to go back to that world, feel the dust in the air, hear the bones crunch, and smell the alcohol on Rooster's breath.

reviews.review_title: Well acted, great production but dull
reviews.content: 3 of us watched this tonight and all agreed that the acting was excellent. The production is top notch but the dialog, the script is dull and the ending rather anti-climactic.The young girl who wishes to avenge her father's death is the best character in the entire story but she isn't given much time to allow much personality to show with exception of the brief sadness over her father's death, and her awe of what is happening around her. She spends a lot of time staring, watching, trying to comprehend but we don't really know her that well as a person.The same could be said for the rest of the characters. They have a fairly narrow margin to express themselves in.Beautifully shot, well done but anti-climactic and dry.

Never saw the original with John Wayne but need to. But this one is really awesome. As newcomer Haylee Steinfeld is great and promising as the young teenage girl who is obsessed with trying to find her father's murderer. At the hand of a not too bright ranch hand, played by Josh Brolin.As Brolin's character, Tom is on the run. She hires the help of US Marshal Rooster Cogburn. Played by Jeff Bridges who is the true star of the film. As one of the posters mentioned. Despite being reluctant at first, he and the young lady's characters relationship grows.They are joined by a Texas Ranger played by Matt Damon. At first, he sees the young lady as trouble. And Cogburn as huge competition as he has his own reasons for getting Tom. But the three slowly yet surely learn to bond well. While pursuing Tom and his gang.It is so hard to find a good Western at the movies these days. It seems as though "Unforgiven" with Clint Eastwood out in 1992. Was the only great and true Western we have seen. But hopefully that Westerns aren't dying down. As True Grit is by far, the best Western I have seen.Really great acting, writing, and scenery brings to the tale. Of the old fashioned Western. Go see it as it is well worth it. All three stars and supporting cast totally do their jobs and are awesome for it.Don't take my word for it, go and see it for yourselves!

True Grit is the new film from the Coen Brothers, not a remake of the 1969 classic starring John Wayne as "Rooster" Cogburn, but a new adaptation of the Charles Portis novel. A new Coen film is always of interest, but does their version of True Grit cut the mustard?The film follows 14-year old Mattie Ross (an impressive feature film debut from Hailee Steinfield), who sets out to avenge the death of her father at the hands of hired man Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). She enlists the help of the aging and mostly drunken Reuben "Rooster" Cogburn (Jeff Bridges), a US Marshall who has, as she sees it, 'true grit.' Accompanying them is Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), who is also in search of Chaney. True Grit is not really a surprising film for the Coens to have made. After all, they have done straight thrillers before, most recently with No Country For Old Men, and most of their films are in fact period films set in the past. However, whilst No Country For Old Men managed to be an intensely affective thriller, its real achievement was its outlook on life, which lent the film a depth and a resonance that was there if you wanted to see it, and gone if you just wanted thrills. The main problem with True Grit is that it has very little depth and no resonance. Excitement it does have, with plenty of nasty characters and several bloody shoot-outs. It is full of good performances that give real dramatic weight to the outlandish characters. The central relationship between Mattie and Cogburn is well handled, as is Damon's secondary role. The Western landscapes are fantastically well shot and the period is skilfully imbued with a sense of eerie danger and reckless cruelty. However, as a whole, the film doesn't hold together. Many scenes feel like comical interludes from other films and many more serious sequences are handled as if they have much more import than they really do. The writer-directors approach these scenes as if they are key to the film as a whole, but it always remains unclear exactly how. In the end, the film feels completely lackadaisical, almost as if the Coens made it up as they went along and only permitted one draft.The characterisation of Tom Chaney is one of the film's more obvious problems and is an indicator of what is wrong with the whole film. Absent for most of the film, his entrance is long anticipated but ultimately rather forced. He is neither the chief villain in the film nor is he a concrete character. He appears neither evil and pitiable, a non-character who is presented in an unfocused and poorly judged light. The lasting impression is that he, like the film, doesn't make any sense. True Grit goes for dark and, for the most part, achieves it. But the typical Coen humour seems forced, clichéd and not very funny. Many of the scenes set a palpably sinister and brooding tone, but nothing is ever made of it. It feels like the Coens did a lot of research to get a powerful level of authenticity into the film but then, when the time came to write the script, opted to prioritise making good use of the research than writing a coherent story. To a big fan of the Coen's, this film was something of a disappointment. Perhaps the problem lay in the tackling of a time that they knew little about, or maybe it is evidence that Hollywood just can't figure out exactly how to make a proper old-fashioned Western anymore. As good as the trio of lead characters are, True Grit feels like a film that was considered much too highly by the talented but momentarily lost duo. A step down from A Serious Man, maybe the film would have been better if they had taken a little more time in pre-production. For more reviews for latest releases, check out filmwhinge at blogger.

Waited two years to see this film as I did not want to be caught up in the hype surrounding it and risk not enjoying a Coen production for what it's worth. I definitely recommend it to those who (in this day and age) still appreciate a well-made Western complete with a solid plot of revenge, rugged terrains, mean-looking villains and a gun-toting-take-no-prisoners female at the helm of the cast. Haley Steinfeld is a revelation in this movie. I think it was Nicole Kidman who once said that children don't act they do as they are told (when it comes to acting) and to an extent I agree with that statement but have to take an exception with this film (as with the career of Dakota Fanning thus far) some children are just born gifted and the gift of acting is very apparent in Steinfeld who essays the role of a child who has become a product of her environment and is now hell-bent on avenging the death of her father with the help of a hired bounty hunter played by Jeff Bridges in fine form. Matt Damon and Josh Brolin co-star.

reviews.review_title: Common Western story recipe but with goofy comedies
reviews.content: The story is just another common Western story, with those all too well known ingredients like the lawmen, outlaws, bounties, and revenge. But this movie nicely adds the quirky mix of the overly faithful conviction with that constant score of old church songs. The comedic situation are very funny since they're well designed that they happen all of a sudden with a lot of coincidence elements happening again and again. The character development is also very strongly done for the three main cast. And that also adds up to the comedic situation when they happen. The acting overall for me is indeed a good one. Jeff Bridges doesn't lose his crazy antics from his days at The Big Lebowski. Matt Damon acted out the Texas Ranger character a little bit flat here. Hailee Steinfeld did very well in living out her character in opposite of senior actors. Josh Brolin and Domnhall Gleeson adds up nicely even with their small roles.

A good entertaining film, and for those that have not seen the original John Wayne/Kim Darby/Glenn Campbell version, it would probably tick all the boxes. However, although a good actor, Jeff Bridges cannot command the screen presence that John Wayne could. I also thought Kim Darby made a better and more believable Mattie Ross. I'll leave the jury out on Glenn Campbells acting capabilities. In the original the character of Rooster Cogburn was more rounded, he had sense of humour and friends, a Chinese man and a cat. I personally have not got much time for re-makes, all of the ones I have seen have invariably fallen short of the original, and this film is no exception.

I watched this one with very high expectations, being a fan of Coens' Serious Man, Miller's Crossing and The Man Who Wasn't There. Unfortunately, I do not think it is a great western, or a film in general. First of all it lacks the philosophical depth of questions posed, like pre-destiny, the physical and moral nature of the Universe or randomness - that lie underneath Coens' other, more notable efforts. True Grit seems to exist only because the Coens felt like making a western, there is nothing more to it, it is what u see and hear and nothing more. The story is not profound or complex, it's basically a chase after a killer. The girl acts well but her character is too smart, too tough to feel real. There is a lot of talking in the movie, mostly hard to understand, but it is neither deep nor interesting enough. I read opinions that this is such a "realistic" western, but it comes short also in this respect. The scene when the guys argue who is a better shot and they shoot to pieces objects in the air is very unrealistic, taken from some lousy westerns. I read from several sources that in fact the colts and other revolver guns used in the Wild West were very unreliable, imprecise and they jammed often. It was not easy even to shoot a man from 20 feet afar, never mind shoot a little bottle flying in the air. I think in this respect and several others True Grit is not in the same league as Unforgiven by Clint Eastwood. I do not understand why the Coens decided to re-make True Grit exactly, as the original did not seem to have a very interesting script in the first place. And the political correctness regarding animal cruelty does not allow for any horse to be shot during the several shootout scenes when it would make perfect sense to aim for the horse rather than the rider.

I have to admit that Im a regular movie goer, not a fan of the westerns. But because of all the hype and the reviews, I happened to watch True Grit. The movie is very very slow. I was hoping it to be a thriller or at least have some fast paced entertainment. I did like the Coen brothers' No country for old men and was hoping this would be along the lines. Anyways for people who read reviews and hope to watch a good movie, I would rather watch the Fighter or anything else. Because this movie is SLOWWWW and Im not sure what is so great about it. Yeah the movie resembles themes from a lot of old western classics, but I didn't pay money to watch an old western. All I wanted was some decent entertainment and good bang for the buck. I was disappointed and bored!!!

reviews.review_title: I Wouldn't Change a Single Frame of this Fine Film
reviews.content: Last night I watched the 1969 movie version of this book and then just had to read it again. Much like seeing the east side of the Cascades as you drive west towards Seattle, there are scenes in the movie that simply take the air out of your lungs (it was filmed in Colorado). It made me homesick for the mountains of Washington, the playground of hiking, climbing, and mountain biking I left behind four years ago when I moved to Spain. After watching the film for only the second time (I saw it the first time when I was 11 at a drive-in) I stayed up until 4 am reading the book from a PDF I found on the web.The book is narrated in the no-nonsense, straightforward fashion you would expect from a good journalist, as Portis was before he gave it up to write fiction full-time. He has a great ear for dialogue and he obviously researched the speech of the era as there are many phrases and words that are now out of use or just impossible to invent. Folks just plain spoke different back then, something Portis was keen on having us hear. Take this little exchange:"I don't believe you have fifty dollars, baby sister, but if you are hungry I will give you supper and we will talk it over and make medicine. How does that suit you?I said it suited me right down to the ground. I just don't think you could make up a line like "right down to the ground." That Portis was a newspaper reporter shows in his attention to details like this small one (but all details, big and small, are important, of course). I suppose that I take more notice to Portis' ventures in language because I am up to my own eyebrows learning Spanish and I subconsciously am translating everything I hear and read into castellano, as it is called here, mostly. And evidently Portis was a bigger fan of the Duke than I because he wrote the character of Rooster Cogburn with him in mind. The author also had a fair ear for humor of which the novel and both movies abound.I found myself one pretty spring day in Las Vegas, New Mexico, in need of a road stake and I robbed one of them little high-interest banks there. Thought I was doing a good service. You can't rob a thief, can you? I never robbed no citizens. I never taken a man's watch.""It is all stealing," said I."That was the position they taken in New Mexico," At least both sets of film makers have enough wisdom to recognize the wisdom in the book.The original movie certainly isn't perfect, not by a long shot. But any criticism of it would be like criticizing the way people talked back in the 1880's. Films are different today, mostly better in my opinion. There are some problems in the 1969 version with some of the side characters and bad acting. The musical score is sometimes bombastic and annoying. The first five minutes which recount the murder of Mattie's father are tiresome and have been wisely excluded in the Coen brothers' remake. More than anything the 1969 movie is absolutely gorgeous from start to finish. The old movie has a better and more satisfying ending than the new one which follows the book more closely. The old movie is pure Hollywood, not always a pejorative, especially in this case."You're too old and too fat to be jumping horses.""Well come and see a fat old man sometime."

Based on the original source text more than the 1969 John Wayne film the Cohen brothers return with this Wild West tale of redemption and revenge. Simply when Mattie Ross's father is gunned down by Tom Chaney (Brolin) she sets herself on a mission to avenge his death and see Chaney brought to justice by hanging but at 14 she will need some help in the form of Reuben J. "Rooster" Cogburn (Bridges, think Lebowski with an eye patch) and joined by an almost unrecognizable Matt Damon as law man LaBoeuf, the unlikely trio set out on the criminals trail. Now as a fan of the Cohen's earlier work but not so much of their recent output I approached this film with caution and I was right to, its not that it's a bad film it's just that it isn't that good either. It looks fine and is acted well but the pacing is all wrong, you never really get to spend any significant time with the characters so you never develop a relationship with them which leaves you ultimately feeling empty and cold. It is also hard at times to understand what anyone is saying in their southern drawl which also doesn't help. Add to that the bizarre quirks like the weird tourette's guy and the bear man and the ending that just comes abruptly from nowhere and it's a strange watch. On paper it all points to it being a great movie, sadly on the screen it just falls flat.
Though the original film will always be a favorite, matt Dam and Jeff Bridges did a magnificent jo in this film. All the cast were great.

reviews.review_title: A near perfect film that will be impossible to forget
reviews.content: This movie gets started so flawlessly I almost swallowed my tongue. Both Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld are truly incomparable and their performances will raise the bar on your idea of what's possible on film. The original True Grit suffered from several flaws nowhere to be seen here. Is that a measure of our collective maturity? I suspect it is though that's not to deprive the Coen brothers of their just due, which is considerable. I have no idea how they found the perfect Mattie though I understand they went through thousands of auditions. Still it would have taken enormous personal luck, the kind only good karma can supply, to have found someone as dead on as Ms Steinfeld.My biggest complaints are that Josh Brolin's role was far too small and I found Matt Damon's performance somewhat out of place though I imagine both were directly out of the novel. Even with a good movie in a 2-hour film I'll check my watch at least once to see how much longer it has to go. This time I checked once out of fear it would all end too soon.

I was very much looking forward to seeing this film because the John Wayne version is one my favorite Wayne films. That said, I must confess that I was very disappointed. Others say don't compare the two films, but to me that's seems impossible. They're so much alike (right down to the same lyrics in some scenes), that trying to separate them would seem to me to be an exercise in futility. The acting is first rate (Seinfeld is amazing and in my opinion carries the film even more so than Kim Darby does her version), but the story is almost boring and proceeds at a much slower pace. It does have it's funny moments (as does the earlier version), and as with all movies made now (as opposed to 35 years ago), virtually everything from the art direction to the costumes, to the violence, is much more life like. But much is missing from this movie that in my opinion adds much to the story. I won't spoil it for anyone by adding specifics, but I'm pretty sure that many would agree. I waited until this was available on video so I could watch it in my own mini theater, and I'm glad that I did. If I had spent $7-$10 to see it, I'd be REALLY bummed.

reviews.review_title: Young Mattie Ross enlists the services of drunk old US Marshall Rooster Cogburn to apprehend her father's murderer
reviews.content: As a rule I don't put any faith in remakes, ever. Especially if I didn't care for the original. 'True Grit' is now one huge exception.Joel and Ethan Coen are two of my favourite writer/directors of all time with their unique blend of intelligent storytelling and surreal comedy, so you might think that I am biased in what I say but I put off watching this film for some time because it just wasn't important to me. Plus, I never go into a film with who made it in mind.What I gathered was that the Coen brothers would have taken a more sensible and conventional approach to this remake of a John Wayne Classic and I was right. There is none of that trademark surreality associated with the Coens.But I didn't go far enough in my assumption by guessing that this was in fact an updated adaptation of Charles Portis' classic novel rather than a remake of an old western movie. What we have here is one of the finest westerns I've ever seen... in my opinion! Young actress Hailee Steinfeld provides possibly the finest child performance I've ever seen (or will at least admit) as she portrays the 14 year old Mattie Ross, a girl looking intelligently and methodically to bring her father's murderer to justice; the outlaw Tom Chaney.To do this, she seeks to enlist the services of grizzled old drunk US Marshall Rueben 'Rooster' Cogburn over the confident, strict and matter-of-factly Texas Ranger LaBoeuf. But when Cogburn and LaBoeuf join to collect another withstanding bounty on Chaney's head, ordered by the Texas court, Ross refuses to see Chaney hang in Texas and stubbornly sides with the two lawmen to see that she will avenge her father's death.The trio quickly become conflicted with one another, which puts them in more danger than they expected! 'True Grit' reeks of authenticity, almost as if the John Wayne classic never even existed but then saying that, Jeff Bridges' handling of the iconic role might not have been so well appreciated but then that would have to be one tough audience as Bridges displays some of his finest ever acting. You may laugh and you may cringe but you may almost smell the whiskey on his breath and the sweat beneath his arms.Joel and Ethan are superb directors, though, and if you've seen the majority of their films, you'll feel something of a family atmosphere if you don't see their appreciation for their cast so clearly.Jeff Bridges and Josh Brolin are familiar with the directors, thanks to their iconic roles in 'The Big Lebowski' and 'No Country For Old Men.' Matt Damon belongs to a fraternity of popular actors who have been able to express their character skills more freely with a Coen film than with your average feature (George Clooney and Brad Pitt).Damon's performance isn't extreme but it's a nice contrast to his previous and more recent works and it's a joy to see him acting more methodically, as does everybody in this film, notably also Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper. I'm not a fan of Period Drama but this is as close as I get.'True Grit' isn't an action western but it has plenty to keep you preoccupied, it's a full-on story that deals with the issues of how hard people have to be to get by but it doesn't preach it to you. It also somehow captures the feel of old 50's/60's westerns yet doesn't alienate people who have little interest for them.I give 'True Grit' a 9 out of 10 and all because it does what it says on the tin. It defines itself!

reviews.review_title: Honestly, the same as the John Wayne Version
reviews.content: Mattie (Steinfeld) hires Rooster Cogburn (Bridges) to hunt down Tom Chaney (Brolin) because he killed her father. Texas Ranger LaBoef (Damon) joins them.We are told this version of True Grit is based more upon the book. I didn't see much difference between this and the John Wayne version. They are basically the same. However, there were a few directorial changes (additions, omissions) I saw, but I did notice something kind of out-of-place: the lines given to Hailee Steinfeld as she recited them sounded more like she was reading poetry or that a writer from the Deadwood TV show came in and gave her that cadence to spew out. It was annoying in Deadwood and it was doubly annoying here. Is that what they meant by this version being more in tune with the book? At times she wasn't the only one to spew that cadence as Matt Damon as LaBoef had a couple shots at it too. Did author Portis write those words in such a way, they would sound like a poetry reading, or some kind Shakespearian Iambic Pentameter verses in the book? If so, I can well understand and like better the John Wayne version which was more conversational and real.The other thing not noticeable unless you know it, and I do, from reading about the John Wayne version and that is that Kim Darby who played Mattie Ross was 21-yrs old when we were all told the character was 14-yrs old. In this version, Hailee Steinfeld probably was 14-yrs old. No biggie, but the cadence given her most of the time had her acting like she was 40. Yes, I cannot get over that out-of-place cadence. Sorry. To be honest I didn't see much difference between the Rooster character in both John Wayne and Jeff Bridges. They were the same. To be honest again, Bridges portrayal made us think of John Wayne a lot during the movie. That shouldn't have happened. Maybe it is the way the character was in general and I felt Bridges was channeling Wayne. However, his performance was still excellent and worthy of an Oscar nomination and I am again being honest. One of the things about western movies is that, most times, you see a lot of wonderful scenery. Here, they showed some, but could have and should have shown us more. They forgot that the scenery is also a part of the story. Bummer. The other thing I noticed was that there was no memorable music. Another bummer. But, over all, this was still very good. Had there not been a John Wayne version, we probably would not have noticed any difference. Well, except for those annoying cadences that is. But, you see all the trouble a remake does regarding comparisons etc. If the Wayne version was good enough, why bother with a remake especially since the remake was basically the same except for some minor differences. But, for my money, the John Wayne version was totally good enough and I am being honest again. Violence: Yes. Sex: No. Nudity: No. Language: No f-bombs; one GDI was heard

Rooster is hired by a very plucky 14 year old girl, Mattie Ross, who wants to avenge her father who was murdered by the cowardly Tom Chaney, who made out for Indian territory and who may now be riding with an outlaw, Ned Pepper, and his gang. They are joined by a determined Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf, who wants to arrest Chaney for a crime committed in TexasBridges completely disappears inside the role of the surly, tough, hard drinking marshal, while Damon gives one of his better performances. As soon as you meet Chaney, you know you loathe him; he's that much of a heel.

reviews.review_title: Not bad but only marginally better than the original
reviews.content: The Coen brothers can always be counted on for some interesting cinema and "True Grit" is no exception. Here they revisit the 1969 film that won 'The Duke' his sole Oscar. It isn't a straight remake, though, since they stick closer to the novel by Charles Portis.The story follows teen-aged Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) as she seeks to recruit a man with 'true grit' in order to bring her father's murderer to justice. She eventually finds the man she's looking for in U.S. Marshal 'Rooster' Cogburn (Jeff Bridges). He teams up with a Texas Ranger (Matt Damon) who's tracking the same man but neither are thrilled when Ross insists on accompanying them.The aforementioned cast members all do a fine job, especially Steinfeld & Bridges. Josh Brolin plays the villain, Tom Chaney, but it's a role with little substance. Barry Pepper plays the leader of the outlaw band, 'Lucky' Ned Pepper, and at times it seemed to me like he was channelling Robert Duvall, who originally played the role.As far as I'm concerned, the film's biggest drawback is the script, particularly the dialogue. It's all very formal, with the effect that some of the performances seem artificial. People have suggested various reasons for this but I could have done without this eccentricity on the part of the Coens. Apart from that, the script is pretty good, though the plot's close enough to the 1969 adaptation that I have to wonder why the Coens even bothered.As for the visuals, they are stellar, as you might expect from a Coen brothers movie. Roger Deakins' cinematography is exquisite and the direction is well-handled (jointly) by the brothers. Musically, Carter Burwell's score is pleasing though not as striking as his scores for "Fargo" or "Miller's Crossing".Ultimately, "True Grit" is worth watching but you could end up being irritated by the dialogue like I was. Also, if you've seen the original you may find that you've already been there, done that for the most part. Overall, not a bad movie but overrated, at least for the moment.

reviews.review_title: Welcome 'modern' remake of a John Wayne classic
reviews.content: Welcome 'modern' take on the John Wayne classic directed by the Coen brothers' (Joel and Ethan Coen).It basically follows the story of 14 year old Mattie Ross as she avenges the killer of her father hiring a U.S. Marshal, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges, in the John Wayne role) and utilising Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon, well disguised with facial hair make-up).Ross isn't your typical 14 year old! Quite annoying at times with her personality! Played excellently by an actress called Hailee Steinfeld who apparently rose to the Pitch Perfect franchise!The film has sweeping visuals and a Producing credit for Steven Spielberg.A welcome remake of an older film.

The Coen brothers let me down on this one, as did most reviewers alive. I cannot recommend this movie to anyone, though the western aspect did appeal to me. Jeff Bridge's character is funny and fun to watch, but it is nothing to get head over heels for.I mean, you can watch it if you want, but it's not something I would personally recommend. Not even to a fan of the brothers.3 stars...

TRUE GRIT is the story of a 14 year old girl in the American Wild West who enlists a drunken Marshal to find and bring to justice the man who killed her father.There are a number of positives about this film. The acting is good, as are the sets and costuming. The editing too is quite smooth and effective. However the Coen brothers show their urban roots in their inability to shoot the countryside effectively. The Wild West in their hands is a rather tame and enclosed place.Whilst Jeff Bridges is usually an excellent actor, he mumbles his words so much in this film that understanding more than one word out of two is difficult. Hailee Simpson puts in a good, though not brilliant, performance. The standout however is Matt Damon, who shows a remarkable talent for reflective acting. Whilst the Coens use all the technical innovations that the Wayne film didn't have they are unable to replicate the power of the earlier film, which lay in an American optimism that has now collapsed. The most powerful element of this film is the language which replicates the richness and power of the Bible (which was the only common reading of the time). Certainly a decent film but constrained by the limitations of the directors.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic, captivating western with amazing style and rocking performances
reviews.content: There is no arguing that the western genre has been into a household genre in Hollywood, rostering many, many classics from the days of John Wayne as a classic western hero, to the days of Clint Eastwood in the Dollars trilogy, to the modern day of spaghetti westerns. With Joel and Ethan Coen, the genre-busting geniuses behind some of the best modern day classics, working behind the camera; this remake of the 1969 classic demonstrates a mixed bag of the charismatic style of the Coen Brothers' filmmaking and amazing storytelling brought by incredibly talented writers. This 1880s-set film stations Hailee Steinfeld in the role of 14-year old farm girl Mattie Ross who travels to an old town in New Mexico in search of someone to assist her in search of a vicious outlaw Tom Chaney (played by Josh Brolin), the man responsible of the murder of her father. She reluctantly hires Rooster Cogburn (played by Jeff Bridges), a roughneck U.S Marshal to aid her on her journey. Along the duo comes ruthless Texas Ranger Labeouf (played by Matt Damon) who's also intent on hunting down Tom Chaney, but for his own personal reasons. These three sprawl across the west and encounter some unexpected and dangerous surprises during their chase for Chaney and his goons.The Coen Brothers bless this film with pure maturity and captivating style, and the screenplay takes credit for this. The powerful appeal of the film begins with the solid visuals of the old west, and with Santa Fe desert serving as the backdrop of the old western town; the result is an authentic, moody representation of the old west. Then we are introduced to the main character Mattie Ross who is energized by an astonishingly riveting performance Hailee Steinfeld. She is very mature on her role and her performance and stunning dialogue shines quite powerfully for a girl who was only 13 at the time of filming. It is no surprise that this young teen was nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress, despite having the most screen time than her main co-star Jeff Bridges who is also very charismatic in his role as the ruthless gun-totting Marshal who was last played the legendary John Wayne in the 1969 original. Matt Damon performs well as the Texas Ranger Labeouf, only its too bad he doesn't quite get all the screen time he deserves. Now the storytelling is what comes as the film's top appeal. The plot progresses at a near flawless pace and builds up to its nail-biting climax. The plot is written so elegantly that no single moment throughout the film ever feels wasted. Plenty of violent gunfights and intense stand offs that pay solid homages to old classic spaghetti westerns, but don't go in expecting a straight forward gunslinging actioner. There are tons of moments rested for plot development. These scenes however, are made up of strong, colorful 19th century dialogue that is written brilliantly.True Grit is an incredible work of art by the Coen Brothers, and easily one of the best films they have brought to the silver screen. This movie is a brilliant successor to the western genre. With the outstanding performances by its stellar cast, stunning writing, and captivating visuals, True Grit is a film worth your time.

reviews.review_title: Great acting, but no reason to exist and the ending ruined it for me.
