reviews.review_title: This film most decidedly has True Grit!
reviews.content: Now I'm not one for cowboy films or the Spaghetti Western despite my father roping me in to watching repeated screenings from multiple editions of classics like The Magnificent Seven (1960) and The Big Country (1958). However, the Coen Brothers re-make of True Grit (with good ole Spielberg overseeing the project as producer) is timeless in its execution of both its cast and set.The film opens with an establishing shot, first used in 30's cinema, of the tumbleweed, down trodden, good-for-nothing patriarchal cowboy town. One recalls not so much John Wayne, choking at the dustbowl on horseback, but the menacing Clint Eastwood shooting down one deputy after another in Pale Rider (1985). The establishing shots in True Grit (2010) are reminiscent of the ES's we see in Charlie Walters musical re-make of the Grant, Hepburn and Stewart trio in The Philadelphia Story (1940) called High Society (1956) starring Bing Crosby, Frank Sinatra and Grace Kelly respectively. However, the scenic views aren't so beautiful yet mesmerising. This is also not so dissimilar from Baz Luhrmann's experimentation with the establishing shot in his recent production of Australia (2008) starring both Kidman and Jackman. There are beautiful panned ES's and WS's of the endless Australian outback.Hailee Steinfeld more than earned her award for best young performer and her nomination as best supporting actress (in the Broadcast Film Critics Association) for her portrayal of the feisty outspoken 14 year old girl who spins us rhetoric far beyond her years. She confronts her male supervisors with articulation and dexterity. They are flabbergasted even angered by her sharp wit and tongue to boot. Even Mr. La Boeuf, proud Texas sheriff (played marvellously by our almost unrecognisable Bourne hero Matt Damon) utters at one point that he doesn't know whether to kiss Mattie Ross (Steinfeld) or give her a good smacking for speaking out of turn. To which Ross retorts, with a perfectly serious and stern look, "neither would be pleasant." Although I am not ofay with the 1969 original True Grit, Steinfeld's character manages to cleverly manipulate both La Boeuf (Damon) and Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) through challenging their egotistical and proud nature; although both males seem to disagree on what is deemed to be right and wrong. The 'trial and tribulations of the famous trio' plot line is a familiar narrative device also featured in Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969) as well as briefly emerges in the killer couples hit and feminist favourite Thelma and Louise; with the smooth and sexual introduction of Brad Pitt and his 6-pack! Although this platonic bond between our three favourites, in True Gritt, is not without its problems. The camaraderie between La Boeuf and Cogburn is restored when Cogburn saves La Boeuf's life. This reminds me of the climactic scene where the prodigal son (played by Aidan Quinn) saves his father (Anthony Hopkins) in Legends of the Fall (1994).The emerging success of True Grit not only paves the way for the future film career of Hailee Steinfeld, as something tells me she's not going to repeat the Macaulay Culkin disaster, but that the Spaghetti Western genre is becoming ever more prominent and popular among audiences of today. 3:10 to Yuma (re-make of the 1957 classic; produced in 2007) directed by James Mangold and starring Russell Crowe and Christian Bale, as well as Brokeback Mountain (2005) also starring Damon are both prime examples of this. The latter obviously is more contemporary in its portrayal of the traditional Western genre but its originality was both commended and rewarded for this.For me, the Coen Brothers 2010 production of True Grit would have received 10 out of 10 if it wasn't for the peculiar appearance of Ross as an adult woman in 40's/50's. It destroys our vision of Ross as a child character. Coupled with the reported death of Rooster Cogburn, the narrative then appears to lack substance. If this is the Coen brothers attempt at moving the fictitious tale into a legend, it is a poor strategy that should not be repeated.Despite this, and certainly last but not least, Jeff Bridges (nominated as best actor by several ceremonies with some yet to come including the Academy Awards) portrayed as the cantankerous drunkard yet hero-of-the-day is flawless. Casting, setting, characterisation and re-invention of this re-make is purely sublime! You'll be sitting on the edge of your seat from the opening scene! THIS FILM MOST DECIDEDLY HAS "TRUE GRIT!"

The most famous (not the very best though) poem in the German language is "Der Erlenkönig". It was written by Goethe and Schubert put Music to it (not his very best Music either). The poem is about a man that rides home with his dying son in his arms, the son hallucinating about the 'Erlenkönig' a mythical figure beckoning him to join him (which means Death and which the father is very well aware of).Towards the very end of this Picture, it is like seeing the Erlenkönig reenacted. A rather bleak remake hereby gets a gigantic boost.John Wayne was no actor and a person with rather abominable political views (which he sadly was not aware of) but he was a great star. Jeff Bridges is a formidable actor but, curiously, he is no star, which great actors seldom are. Great stars Always play themselves and their roles are just different sides of that self (Clint Eastwood is Always Clint Eastwood and whenever he attempted to act the results were catastrophic).Furthermore there might be added that the Music in this film is far better than that in the original and with the end in mind that was, IMO, reason enough to do this remake.
Good western. Excellent cast. If you like westerns would highly recommend.

reviews.review_title: loved every minute of it, screw the kings speech this should have won
reviews.content: i love the Coen brothers, i really do, all of their films have been they can do no wrong in my opinion and they carry on this tradition with this film. i have never seen the original true grit which may get me slated a large amount by fans of the original who refuse to accept a pretty damn good remake. i thought the standout performance was actually not given by Jeff, who still played an amazing part, but from Hailee who played the young girl who shown she can act very well and is actually one of the few good child actors along with Chloe Moretz. Even though i am not a large fan of Matt Damon he performed his role very well and played what is quite a simple character in a way that he seemed far more complex. Finally for Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn, he played the perfect hard ass, grouchy drunken old man he had to play, i cant compare to John Wayne because as i said previously i had not seen the original. the story is very well executed and told and the one real action sequence in the film in which Rooster faces off against 4 criminals in the finale is a very well done scene which doesn't go too over the top with the action but still entertains. plus its great use of dark humour every now and then because lets face it, dark humour is awesome.overall a very good film, highly recommend it over Black Swan, Social Network (which was okay and is still worth a watch) and the King's Speech.

John Wayne may have been Rooster Cogburn first, but he is by far outdone by the phenomenal Jeff Bridges in the Coen Brothers remake of the 1969 film. The aforementioned directing duo breathe new life into the classic Western tale of a teenage girl who hires a disgruntled former Marshal to find the man who murdered her father.As Mattie Ross, newcomer (at the time) Hailee Steinfeld brings gumption and raw talent as the feisty teenager. Steinfeld shows a guarded vulnerability alongside her veteran co-stars, but she is not second-fiddle by any means. She holds her own by commanding each scene she is in and steals the show from fellow actors Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon. As Texas Ranger LeBeouf is a barely recognizable Matt Damon, providing his brand of cynicism to the mix. Damon is no stranger to being in a Western (having starred in the less memorable "All the Pretty Horses"), but this role allows him to shine at the right times. The dialogue between Damon and Bridges is biting as each man tries to outdo the barb of the other, challenging the other's ability to be top dog,; both injecting humor. Equally crisp are the exchanges between Damon and Hailee Steinfeld as Steinfeld's stubborn Mattie refuses to let LeBeouf treat her like a helpless child; drawing much of LeBeouf's ire and providing him with a controlled foil in comparison to the more outlandish Rooster Cogburn.And rounding out the trio of heroes is a well cast Jeff Bridges as the iconic Rooster Cogburn. Bridges brings the "true grit" of the title in his vastly different portrayal of the grizzled gunman. He plays Cogburn as a man initially unconcerned with anything other than his next drink, but when Mattie Ross enters his life he does everything to dissuade the teenager from being involved. When she refuses and they spend so much time together on their journey to find her father's killer, Bridges brings out a reluctant fatherly affection in Cogburn as evident when he helps save Mattie near the film's close.The film is expertly shot by legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins. He utilizes the barren surroundings of the American Southwest in making isolation so prominent. Being surrounded by mainly desert or wooded forest pits the main trio against the elements other than dangerous criminals. The scenery is exquisite as Deakins highlights the landscapes with a keen eye that the setting becomes its own character.Give this Western a hit and you will love it...or just like it.

reviews.review_title: How can you say this is not a remake?
reviews.content: This film is a total remake of the 1969 film starring John Wayne, Kim Darby, Glen Campbell, Robert Duvall, Dennis Hopper and directed by Henry Hathaway. The Cohens took it and tried to duplicate but it is NOT a better film. I think Hailee Steinfeld did an okay job in True Grit 2010 but she couldn't come close to Kim Darby's performance. Jeff Bridges is OK as Rooster Cogburn but he doesn't come close to the John Wayne performance. Matt Damon is pretty to look at but Glen Campbell did it better. Josh Brolin as Ned Pepper was good but he was absolutely copying the Robert Duvall performance. I submit this film to the cut out rack of the local Walmart. Sorry Cohens but you got this wrong. You should have been completely original and NOT duplicated. It's okay but it is NOT the better film. This does try to be the same movie and it fails because of it. 1969 rules.

Tom Chaney was a hired hand by Frank Ross. Frank Ross and Tom Chaney went to Fort Smith to buy some horses. Chaney had been drinking and lost all his money at the town bar playing cards. Chaney thought he got cheated, so he went back to the boarding house to get his rifle. Frank Ross trying to stop Tom Chaney was shot and killed. Chaney took his horse and 2 California gold pieces. To avenge her father's death, Mattie Ross (a 14 year old daughter) went to Fort Smith Arkansas. While there she hires the meanest Marshall, a Rooster" Cogburn. Word has it that Chaney was hanging with "Lucky" Ned Pepper. Met by LaBoeuf (Texas Ranger), Mattie and Cogburn set out to Indian country to hunt Chaney down. John Wayne won a Best Actor Oscar for True Grit in 1969 why would you mess with it. Jeff Bridges babbling in the film was a little hard to understand at times. The dialog, was more like the book but I'm a true believer of if it isn't broke then don't fix it. 4 out of 5 stars

reviews.review_title: So..., they do make 'em like they used to. They make them better!
reviews.content: So it turns out they do make 'em like they used to! More than that, they make them better. I recall seeing Jeff Bridges interviewed by Jonathan Ross around a year before True Grit was due out, and what stuck in my mind was just how apprehensive Ross was about a film he cherished so dearly being remade. It's an uncertainty i understand wholeheartedly, and Hollywood has bad previous when it comes to remaking much loved classics. It's pleasing to say then that the Coen brothers' update is a unmitigated success on all levels. This is a film that firmly intends to stand on it's own two feet without any fear of being overshadowed by what went before and it does so with assurance and conviction. From the first few frames it's clear that the period detail and production values have been painstakingly researched and attended to. The Coen brothers have never been conventional film makers and it's refreshing to see them coupling modern film making techniques with the pacing and feel of an old fashioned studio western. It's almost as if the Coen's are saying, remember all those naff cowboy films from the 40′s, 50′s and 60′s? – well this is how they'd look if the same directors made then now. Filmed between New Mexico and Texas, it's a grand looking film with strong biblical undertones that lend satisfying heft amid the themes of redemption and Godlessness. Performance-wise, words can't do it justice. The trio of turns from Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and Hailee Steinfeld are all fascinating and multi-layered. Bridges is truly gritty as he grunts and growls his way through the majority of the film and although it's not always possible to make out exactly what he's saying all of the time, it's getting the general gist that really counts. Eye patch aside, it's a million miles from the John Wayne performance and all the better for it. It'd be all to easy to just make a list of comparisons when discussing a remake such as this, but that really wouldn't be doing sufficient justice to what is a confidently made western that recalls a bygone era while having the smarts to operate on it's own terms.

reviews.review_title: True Grit is simple, undemanding and pleasurable
reviews.content: My opinion was that the Coens have lost a little of their luster with their last 2 films. Burn After Reading was just too chaotic (even for a Coens film), and A Serious Man, for all its existential questions, didn't feel relevant. But in True Grit, the Coens decide to play it straight, much of the aspects that made the Coens popular are not present here. The Coens chose to glorify the material over the form. True Grit is simple, undemanding and pleasurable.Josh Brolin is despicable as Tomo Chaney,the man who killed Mattie Ross's father. Hailee Stanfield was absolutely amazing as the headstrong girl who will stop at nothing to bring Chaney to justice. Jeff Bridges as the unkempt Rooster Cogburn is a different Cogburn from John Wayne's interpretation, but has the same level to screen presence. The minor parts played by the other cast are perfect complements to this keeper.
Great cinematography. Perfect performance by Steinfeld. Outstanding dialogue by the Cohen Brothers. Apparently, this film is more similar to the novel than the 1969 version.

True Grit keeps the Coen brothers going on their streak of great movies from their 2007 Oscar-winning thriller No Country for Old Men to their Jewish satire in A Serious Man, they are on a roll. Their remake of the 1970 John Wayne western is no less short. With Jeff Bridges in the exhilarating lead role and with talented Steinfeld backing him up the acting is superb. The Coen Brothers put us in a western world spinning together a revenge story with bits of graphic violence to satisfy the credibility. for the people who did not like the prolonged violence in No Country for Old Men, but liked the stylish production this is the film for you. It has more of a focus on humanism and there is plenty of humor for coen humor fans.

reviews.review_title: Why Did They Make this Movie?
reviews.content: Frankly, I agree with the written reviews of the 1-star crowd, but I can't in good conscience give it that rating because if it were not a remake it would be a 5-star, OK western. What has everyone so ticked off about this movie is that there is so little that is new about this version that it makes you wonder why the Coen brothers made it. I swore after "A Serious Man" that I would not let the Coen brothers reputation make me mindlessly go see another of their movies without first doing more research. Darn, I did it again. I am still in the thrall of "Fargo" and "The Big Lebowski." There is nothing in this remake that I would consider significantly different or better than the original: cast, script, locations, cinematography, etc. I love Jeff Bridges but his mumbling, drab interpretation of Rooster Cogburn is two-dimensional compared to Wayne's. And to the people that scream "Stop The Comparisons!" I say if you don't want to be compared don't do a remake that practically mirrors the original. The locations and cinematography were as much more colorful than the original as was Wayne's performance over Bridges'. In the horse trading scene I felt like Strother Martin was getting his pocket picked. All the hype that preceded the release of this film lead me to believe that the Coen brothers had done something completely different with True Grit. Unfortunately that is not the case. What we get is a "made-for-TV" quality copy of the original. Sad.

reviews.review_title: Not A Coen Favorite, But It's Still Solid
reviews.content: True Grit may be the most un-Coeny Coen film of their entire filmography, but my golly do they write just the darndest scripts! Also, Hailee Steinfeld is a restless savage in this movie and Jeff Bridges is a profit. (Verdict: B)

True grit absolutely blew me away , as someone whose not to keen on westerns i found this film to be extremely enlightening , it had so much heart , and that was certainly helped by Hailee Steinfeld , what a amazing little actress she is , child actors usually irritate the crap out of me but she was utterly outstanding , and not to mention Jeff Bridges , finally! his talent used in a movie! most of the films I've seen him in , hes a ceo of some massive cooperation who pushes papers , but this time we got to see him shine and in a spectacular piece of art , not once did i see this film going down hill , get boring , or get repetitive which is usually what westerns are like , shoot a Indian shoot a bandit , film over , no! this film was going somewhere! And it did go somewhere , right to my heart.I don't want to say much else as i don't want to give away to much of the film , but you certainly will not! regret watching True Grit!

reviews.review_title: Great Movie but Matt Damon drags it down to an 8
reviews.content: I will admit I have never seen the John Wayne version, and I probably never will, and I also think John Wayne was way overrated. There, now that I got that off my chest,this was a pretty good movie.So the story is about a teenage girl whose father was murdered. Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) is taking care of her fathers arrangements and hires Federal Marshall, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to track down her father's murderer Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) but as part of the deal she has to accompany him. To add to this Texas Ranger Leboeuf (Matt Damon) is on Chaney's tail as well to collect a bounty on him.I really liked this movie. It is pretty dialogue heavy for a western, but it was well crafted and shot. Jeff Bridges, is a standout as the grizzled old Marshall Cogburn, and gives a grade A performance. Hailee Stanfeld was also excellent in this one and showed a lot of poise for a young actress with a part with such stylized language and as word heavy as this one. I think everyone was well directed and gave great performances, with the exception of Matt Damon. I don't think Matt Damon gave a bad performance, I just think he wasn't the right actor to play Leboeuf. It could just be his character, the writers, or the director, but Matt Damon felt real out of place in this movie and his character came out much more as a caricature instead. That being said it was still a great movie, especially if you like to see new versions of the old west.As I said, I did really like this movie and will watch it again. My only problem was a casting decision that brought in Matt Damon which felt out of place, but otherwise this is a great one worth a view.

Perhaps my let down is because I had high expectations for the film, but man that was a mediocre movie. The Good: It looked fantastic, the cinematography was again brilliant. Also, the acting was well done, and overall it was a well crafted film. The Bad: What an unoriginal bland story!!! Yes, I know it was a remake therefore how could it be fresh, yadda yadda, yadda. It was like watching Jeff Bridges Crazyheart character and throwing him on a horse with a pistol. By all means not a half bad idea. But when you throw in a stereotypical whiz kid and a cocky brash Texas Ranger and never bother to try any REAL character development it's just far too simple and unoriginal, especially when considering it's basically a character driven movie. Then you throw in the Brolin's character (the bad guy), and that character is even less complex than imaginable. He's a guy that killed the girls dad and another man, and we never dive into his character much or rarely see him. And it's not like his character is shrouded in mystery, his presence frankly is hardly ever felt. But alas, it's the Coen Brothers (who I really do love), and it's Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon etc...and this movie will be heralded as a classic.

reviews.review_title: Modernized NEW telling of a CLASSIC film
reviews.content:
Nobody can take the place of John Wayne in any film, there is ONLY one DUKE. However with that being said the Coen brothers put a modernized twist on the classic True Grit. John Wayne received an Academy Award for best actor and Jeff Bridges' portrayal of Rooster Cogburn earned him a nomination.
Westerns, a genre of film that is lost and far and few between. The cinematography and landscape this was shot on was fantastic and had that authentic feel to it. True to western format the dialogue was perfectly intertwined throughout the film. The directness of the story of a young 14 year old girl looking to avenge her fathers murder by seeking out the killer. It is driven with fantastic performance by young Hailee Steinfeld (Maddie Ross). Throw in a mix of Matt Damon and Josh Brolin as ensemble characters the film is a perfect draw. A sensible, well written and entertaining western with very good performances. I give this 2 thumbs up and a 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Wow. And I thought I hated Westerns!
reviews.content: This is a phenomenal new film from the Coen Brothers. Out of all their films it is the most empathetic, with the most empathetic characters. Being a Coen Brothers film, I am quite familiar with a number of the films which often feature enjoyably bizarre, but not particularly likable, heroes and heroines and villains and so on and so forth. But this inspired re-tooling of the John Wayne classic is not just a superior movie but also a very relatable one. I could imagine being the characters, and that's unusual for Joel and Ethan who went to my college and appeared to have a love for Flannery O'Connor (according to one guy). Hailee Steinfeld who now is a big name and has moved on to more conventional roles is great as the tomboy Mattie Ross who is hellbent on killing Tom Chainey (the very rugged and ugly-sexy Josh Brolin). Jeff Bridges steals the show as Rooster Cogburn, he gives the character a more sinister edge than the original. While the humors all there, there's a darkness and a world-weariness to Rooster that wasn't as present in the original, where Wayne was a more flamboyant and in-your-face presence. Matt Damon makes a great and very cocky LaBeouf who sobers up to Mattie Ross as he is continuously made a fool of. On a technical level the film is great as well, with gorgeous cinematography reminiscent of the Coen's No Country and a riveting soundtrack by Carter Burwell. The film is a fun, slightly creepy, and involving western drama. I hate westerns as a general rule because typically they're a bit cheesy, but this one really pulled you in. I highly recommend this, Lonesome Dove, and The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly as the few well-made western films out there.

reviews.review_title: True to the grit of the true western
reviews.content: A Western is, when it is true, a song that pays homage to the soul of the western civilization - that grit which build the land - we must remember, that USA is founded on a spirit - an old spirit from the Christian homelands from whence the settlers left - a spirit of courage and good heart that may die, if no one sings about it - in recent times most songs about the old west have been cynical, brutal and in reality self-loathing - then comes this movie from the Coens - true to the fantastic book, that should be obligatory school-classic, and it is marvelous, what the brothers have made here - the best since Ford and The Duke passed on - and thank you, guys for keeping the Christian matrix of the old story - for it is both a story about integrity and true grit and also a hymn about justice, sin and being saved from the "snake-pit" of hell "when the man comes around!". 10/10

Another cinematic masterpiece by the Coen Bros. Jeff Bridges plays the title. He carries it off very well and should win the Oscar for best actor. The simplistic story has enough to keep our interest. The PG-13 rating is almost R for violence.Attention to detail and authenticity has become a Coen pictures trademark. However, as Shakespeare used language only the learned (aristocracy) could understand, so the Coens write for the screen. Not that the dialogue is beyond most people's cognitive skills, but it very often requires more attention than normal to be understood. This can be a problem for some. Yet for others, the sublime eloquence that only a Harvard English professor could lay bare can be very enjoyable.If this is to be taken as a flaw in film making, it can be argued that it contradicts authenticity because it contradicts reality. Most folk just don't talk that way; never have and never will. But the Coens, no doubt, have a creative need to demonstrate their clever use of language. And clever it is. Very.

reviews.review_title: A terrific western with the first fine film the Coen Brothers have done that I really liked.
reviews.content: I must confess I am not a big fan of the Coen Brothers films. Mostly they have done dark comedies like The Big Lebowski, Burn After Reading and Barton Fink (which wasn't too bad). The thing is their style is not something I really liked. I appreciated it and it was refreshingly different but I just couldn't adapt myself to it. But that's my problem and even though I didn't like those films mentioned, they had a intriguing style, which made me understand why they are such avidly acclaimed film-makers. When it came to True Grit. I wanted to see it (having seen the original a couple of months ago) and give the Coen's a chance with a more serious film. They have done that of course before with No Country for Old Men, which I haven't seen.Basically the true story is the same as the original with a young fourteen year old girl Maddie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) whose father is murdered by Tom Chaney (Josh Broline). She wants revenge and justice for her father so hires deputy sheriff Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to help catch him. They are joined by a Texas sheriff LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) who wants Chaney as he murdered a state senate in Texas. Together they travel after Chaney to apprehend him.The one thing I would say I didn't like about this is the film didn't really have any heart or emotion really not like the original. But it is beautifully shot and edited with truly wondrous scenery thanks to gorgeous cinematography by Roger Deakins, the script is surprisingly witty and sharp with some great laughs. The Coen Brothers have captured the essence of the Western period perfectly. The acting as well, Jeff Bridges impressed me with a good performance but he just wasn't as convincing or believable as John Wayne. Matt Damon is less impressive I'm afraid and it's easy to see why he hasn't been the focus by critics. He gives a reasonable performance and his competent enough, but he looks out of place (like Christian Bale as Dickie in The Fighter) and comes across as rather a bland character. But the best person in this is the young actress Hailee Steinfeld as Maddie. She has been nominated for best supporting actress and she fully deserves it. She gives an excellent performance and radiates a real maturity on the screen and perfectly portrays Maddie with strength and confidence. She is the one with "true grit" both character (Maddie being strong willed to ask for help and go with them to avenge her father despite many dangers and never giving up) and actress (filling the big shoes of a major role). She gives one of the best performances of a child/teenager actress and I will look out for her in future roles which deserve to be bigger (as she has done other things). True Grit isn't on par with 127 Hours, The King's Speech and Black Swan but it's certainly one of the better movies of this year and ably directed and it deserves high praise. The 8.1 rating on here is well justified. This version is just as good and in some ways better than the original. Highly enjoyable.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic Re-make. Do not compare to original
reviews.content: Before watching this re-make, because the original is one of my favourites, I found myself wanting it to be a terrible attempt. However within the first 10 minutes, the spectacular backdrops and excellent direction (as always) from the Coen's had me hooked from start to finish. True I found myself at times comparing the two films, but found that while doing this, both attempts at the story had there strong points and weaker points.Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn always had tough task ahead of him, trying to re-deliver the character that John Wayne almost definitely made his own. He does this by playing the role even darker than Wayne did, but still producing comedy moments like Wayne did with the sheer intelligence and sharpness of the script. I felt that the big catchphrases from the original should have been left out, as Bridges was never going to take these from Wayne and make them his own. This almost cheapened the role a tiny bit for me.Matt Damon as LaBoeuf was very enjoyable. The Coen's obviously didn't want to change his characters persona much from the original and to be fair, the role suited him to a tee, and he played the role extremely well. I feel that this was his best film for a while.I enjoyed the acting of Brolin, however the role in the Coen Brothers Re-make had been significantly shortened and we did not see him nearly enough. I also enjoyed Hailee Steinfeld playing Maddie Ross, this is the one role that I preferred the later adaptation.I feel that this is another great Coen brothers film. Even a sceptic like myself was put at ease by the script, direction and ultimately the sheer beauty of the production. None of the acting disappoints and a few excel (mostly Bridges and Steinfeld).If you've never seen the original then enjoy. If you loved the original free your mind and enjoy. If you hated the original, chances are you'll still love the Coen brothers effort!

When I first the trailer for this film, and I learned that it drew inspiration from a John Wayne classic and starred Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon, I got excited. When I saw this in the theatre, I can honestly say I was not disappointed.The acting is excellent. Hailee Steinfeld does a brilliant portrayal of the main character, Mattie Ross, a 14-year-old girl who is determined to punish Tom Chaney, the man responsible for killing her father. Jeff Bridges (Iron Man) delivers a great performance as Rooster Cogburn, a tough, whiskey-drinking U.S. Marshall. Matt Damon (Saving Private Ryan) provides a decent portrayal of LaBoeuf, a Texas ranger who is also in pursuit of Tom Chaney, but for different reasons.The story is very well written. It is largely character-driven, as much of the plot deals with the relationship between the three main characters. There are a number of conflicts that develop between the main cast, particularly between Rooster Cogburn and LaBoeuf. There are also plenty of action scenes that take place throughout the film.Overall, True Grit is a very well-done film and I'd definitely recommend seeing it

As a JW fan i was a little apprehensive about another remake, but I am pleasantly suprised to say, it's excellent, the same story, but with subtle embellishments and changes enough to make it fresh. Think the performances were top notch and the decision to focus more on Maddie is inspired

reviews.review_title: One of The Coens Best and Most Underrated Movie
reviews.content: I'm not a huge fan of the Coen brothers comedies I just don't like there sense of humour but I love it when they go serious and dark because True Grit is my second favourite film of there's falling just short of No Country For Old Men because this is a masterpiece and one of my favourite westerns. This movie could have been extremely boring but it's not it keeps you constantly engaged with its engaging dialogue and very good central conflict. The great thing about the central plot and conflict is how realistic it is as it constantly focuses on the main characters instead of the antagonists making you feels the same satisfaction and desperation as Mattie Ross does when they meet. This movie looks stunning the cinematography is beautiful and very well lit. The girl who plays Mattie Ross, Hailee Steinfeld blew me away in this movie she should have won the Oscar for this movie. But Jeff Bridges is her equal it's just such an engaging and intriguing performance that's makes you feel sympathy for his character and also gives and Oscar worthy performance here it's a shame he hasn't had more Coen brothers collaborations with Bridges but they definitely bring out the best in each other. Matt Damon is very overlooked here because I think he gives one of his best performances here because he's so held back in True Grit and has fantastic chemistry with Bridges and Steinfeld and should have at least received a nomination for his efforts. While this is a dialogue driven movie it's still a western with action and they are very well handled and give the movie a bigger entertainment factor. This is an amazing movie and one of my best Coen brothers western and one that I'm watching right now as I write this review. 100%-A+

This is a very good movie and much "Truer" to the 1969 original than say the 3:10 to Yuma remake was. I like the leads Bridges and Miss Steinfeld but sorry, neither can compare with the Duke & Kim Darby. The little touches of the original have been tossed aside. Even super lawyer J Noble Daggett doesn't appear in TGII. Cogburn's Indian cook/servant General Lee is awol (too politically incorrect); yet some nasty treatment to all the Indians in the film. I'm glad the Coen's have tipped a cowboy hat to the Duke & Darby but it seems Josh Brolin as Tom Chaney has been reduced to a near cameo. The role is beneath him. One of film's best negotiations- beteween Darby & Strother Martin has been diminished in the remake. Too bad no worthwhile score, I'm sure Robert Earl Keen could have done the film very proud. Adios.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the original
reviews.content: Other than Hailee being a better match than Kim Darby to the book Matie, this movie is a waste of time and resources. Te original with John Wayne was a much better movie.

reviews.review_title: It's not that it was bad... it's just that there was no reason to do it.
reviews.content: This movie is full of great performances. Really. And I'm sure everyone involved enjoyed the challenge of remaking such a classic western. AND I give them kudos for rising to the challenge.But there's really no point. Unless (1) you happen to be a huge fan of one of the stars of this remake (2) or you don't like John Wayne, you will only watch this once, because it can't measure up to the original. It just can't. There is nothing about the original to improve upon, so why try? That's the problem.As for remakes in general, this is one of the better remakes I've seen, but there was no reason to make it. In fact, not so long ago, I went to see the original in a theater. It can still draw a crowd. Why not just re-release it?

reviews.review_title: A strong bond of trust, friendship, and mutual respect develops between to completely different characters. Or are they so different?
reviews.content: The 2010 remake of "True Grit" stars Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn, the character made popular in the original version by John Wayne. Rooster Cogburn is a U.S. Marshall, who has a rough and tough personality and a reputation as a formidable opponent to outlaws. He is hired by young Mattie Ross, played by Hailee Steinfeld, to find the man who killed her father and bring him to justice. Displaying all the aspects of a good western such as resonating gun fights, authentic costumes, and rugged landscapes, the use of modern technology takes you back in time to another era.The theme of this movie focuses on the relationship that develops between Mattie and Rooster Cogburn. At first, he dismisses Mattie's attempts to hire him, believing her to be a simple minded young girl who couldn't possibly understand outlaws and revenge. But as their relationship deepens, he begins to see that she is as strong and determined as he is. She is unwilling to let anything stand between her and justice for her father's murder. It is in this determination that Rooster discovers that he and Mattie have a lot in common and a strong bond of trust, friendship, and mutual respect develops between them.As Rooster Cogburn and Mattie set out in the wilderness to track her father's killer, they are met with many obstacles which only stand to strengthen their bond and Mattie's resolve. Similar to the quirky relationship found in the movie "Harold and Maude" (Higgins, C., Ashby, H., 1971), the age difference between the two characters would seem to present an unlikely relationship. But Rooster and Mattie form a lasting friendship, albeit without the romantic interludes. They learn things from each other and are equally surprised at how much they care about what happens to the other. The final scenes of the movie show Rooster making a desperate attempt to get Mattie medical help after a poisonous snake bite. The emotion that is displayed in these ending scenes is heart wrenching. The camera angles, lighting, and lack of dialog add to the urgency Rooster feels to get Mattie the help she so desperately needs. It is the style of movie making that allow the viewer to feel like they are peeking through a window to another time and place, while peeking into the hearts and minds of its' characters.

reviews.review_title: A return to form for the Brothers Coen
reviews.content: This reworking of the Western classic is a real return to form after their last couple of misfires. Casting, cinematography and script come together beautifully, as do the superb locations. This movie combines the best aspects of No Country for Old Men, Miller's Crossing and Oh Brother Where Art Thou?, while also retaining strong links with the Western Genre.I was especially impressed with Hailee Steinfeld's performance, but I really don't think there was a bad performance throughout the movie.True Grit is the Coen brothers doing what they do best: telling a strong, believable story with characters you feel you can know amidst incredibly evocative scenery.It is well rounded enough that you don't have to be a fan of action or westerns to enjoy it: my wife is normally a Rom Com junkie and dislikes most Coen Brothers films, but even she loved this one!Do beware though: there are some graphically violent themes (it's the Coen Brothers, after all), but they are short-lived and in keeping with the story.I highly recommend this movie!

reviews.review_title: The main character/actress that plays her save this movie from being forgettable.
reviews.content: Hailee Steinfeld played her role prefect and is the only thing that makes it worth a watch. Overall it's well acted but because of the way it ends you feel like your missing a lot of pages from a book, You know what happens and can easily figure out the missing pages but it makes the pacing alittle less enjoyable.I haven't seen the original but i have seen John Wayne movies and once you have seen one you have kind of seen then all , so i would guess this is the better version of the movie and say it's worth a watch and i think all ages would like it it.

reviews.review_title: A very disappointing film by the Cohen Brothers
reviews.content: I have always been a fan of the Cohen Brothers. I have always enjoyed their stories, their approach to directing, their choices of actors, and nearly all their movies. I have always thought they were great story tellers, with a taste for the paradox that I really enjoyed. I was looking forward to see this movie.This was one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time. I give it a 3 for some good acting, but I heard several people while leaving the theater commenting "what a waste of money" and I couldn't agree more. I cannot believe the good reviews.It was a slow, pointless movie, with some absurd scenes (so how exactly did a wounded Jeff Bridges recover to the point of being able to reach the summit from the valley in just a couple a couple of minutes and be able to merrily jump down in the hole to save Hailee?). I thought the scenery was weak. The ending felt like a sequence of "we have to do something to quickly finish this". There was some good acting, but the characters were not believable. The shooting scene felt just like a scene (ok, so the Brother Cohen are not Tarantino, and I usually enjoy their "crudeness", but this scene really didn't make it for me).

I must admit I have a weakness for any film with Jeff Bridges. I watched it three times the first time at the theater and twice at home. After my first viewing I felt a bit unfulfilled. I wanted to see more Rooster and LaBoeuf. Subsequent viewings gave me a greater appreciation for the film without the sense of loss, as I knew what was coming.When I first saw the film I thought it was lacking something. Later when I saw it again I realized it wasn't that the film wasn't well written or didn't have a good ending. In fact the problem was I was left wanting more. In hindsight that's probably not such a bad thing.check out our full review at 3guys1movie.com

Finally! Not since "Appaloosa" has there been (in my experience) a Western made with love. Faithful to the time in details, within the limits of art, "True Grit" is a superb Western. It seems to be simple story telling but is nevertheless flavoured by the eccentricities of the Coen brothers: everyone speaks as though they are in a "penny dreadful"! I was reminded of Jack Webb's "Dragnet" when all the actors were supposedly instructed to act as though they were reading their lines. In "True Grit" it sounds as though the actors are not only reading from an 1880's dime novel but living it. Buffalo Bill Cody would have loved it! The cast is very, very good. There is nary a misstep by any actor and, as everyone has said, the young star is frankly amazing and well deserved her accolades. All in all a superb motion picture with a certain Coen quirkiness. But be warned: you may weep for a horse.

reviews.review_title: Please stop this Coen love in.
reviews.content: This is not a terrible movie. However, it is SURELY not up there with the likes of 'The Hustler' or 'Children of Men' at the time of writing. Oh, it is? Evolution is still incomplete. Sometimes, people cream themselves over everything a director(s) does.Mr Nolan is another example. I swear if he released a movie about a door warping the critics would be claiming it 'a thought provoking tour de force'. Believe it or not,I'M A FAN of the Coens. The Big Lebowski makes my all time top 10. Fargo gets some abuse, but it's an excellent movie.Some of their latest stuff has been average at best. 'A serious Man' was awful. This movie was a remake. And not a great one. Acting? Fine. Plot? Meh. No more than 5/10 at best (unless you've been blinded by the hyperbole).The Coen's are in that 'too clever to be criticised' bracket. Well, not for me. Make a decent movie again or give room for others who can.

reviews.review_title: Not someone who enjoys remakes of classic films....but
reviews.content: After viewing many times the original and this movie I find the the 2010 version is as good if not better then John Wayne's True Grit. This version has added multiple creative scenes, filming, acting and mostly dialogue. Jeff Bridges brings to the screen remarkable acting skills Wayne was not able to. In addition JB is a noted actor with numerous awards for films like The Last Picture Show, The Big Lebowski, The Contender and most notably Crazy Heart. All these roles were a challenge to his seasoned abilities and he carried them off like a "star".

reviews.review_title: And one day the Coen brothers went into classic storytelling!
reviews.content: Pretty straight forward: Coen brothers show that they can tell a story without going deep into the antihero thing that was starting to bore me. So finally they decided to shoot a movie where the hero is really a good one, without reminding us how extremely mediocre life is. And you know what? They did it pretty well, in such a difficult genre like western is. They way they told the story was sincerely great and for the first time ever I get to the end of a Coen Brother's movie and feel that it was concluded. All the rest is obvious. Do I have to flag that Bridges and Damon are good performers? Guess not. The girl does it well also. This is a good western and Its strength is how well the story is told.

reviews.review_title: As good as the John Wayne version
reviews.content: As a child I spent many Sunday afternoons watching the week's action movie on the BBC. John Wayne's True Grit was one of the best.The language in this is stilted, maybe it was how they really spoke in the 1870s or maybe they copied the dialogue from the book. I didn't like it but, like watching Shakespeare, I got used to it after twenty minutes.I bought the original and viewed it again just before watching this. They are very, very similar. The original is a little more fun, this is a little more gritty. Was it worth making another clone of the book? Well, it is a very good story and well worth introducing to a new generation. I would happily watch either again.

All the breathless praise I read here must be about a movie I never saw. For me, True Grit was pretty much a bore. A real highlight was Jess Bridges's voice, which was a wonderful creation and a character all in itself, as unique and illustrative as Brando's in The Godfather. Another thing the movie had going for it was the dialogue with its quaint, rather formal sound created mostly by everyone avoiding contractions (I'm, You're, Didn't) and using the full forms (I am, You are, Did not). And the dialogue sometimes had delightful phrasing. But I don't think I'd go much farther than that for the movie. The plot was simple and straightforward, too much so to hold my attention, and where it took a turn, as when the girl suddenly found Chaney, it was predictable. Gosh, it looks like the end of the hunt, both men are deserting her, everyone is heading home, all her time and effort and money are down the drain, o woe! But wait, hey, there's Chaney after all, just a few yards away. Gasp! Who'd have guessed? Well, actually, I guessed, and I never even saw the original True Grit.Did Jess Bridges deserve an Oscar nomination? What he did with his voice was terrific, no doubt, but as for the rest we hardly ever saw his face. He was always at a distance or in the shadows or hiding behind his beard. There wasn't that much acting he had to do, once he came up with The Voice. If there were an Oscar for most original voice, he'd definitely deserve that.So what about the nomination for Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role for Hailee Steinfeld? The rationale for that nomination completely escapes me. In fact, I was not impressed with the performance at all. She often rattled through her speeches in a monotone that not only sounded flat and dull but it was often hard to make out what she was saying. Bad Shakespearean actors often do that when they spout the words without nuance, without expression, without knowing what the words mean. The other actors had similar speeches, often slightly florid in expression, and they filled them with expressiveness, and they were easy to understand. I suspect her support came from sentimentality around the idea of a young girl playing such a key role in a major film.

After making 'No Country for Old Men', no one should have wondered if the Coen brothers could make a credible western. No one doubts that they are important filmmakers. They have cojones. But if I jump off the sycophantic bandwagon for a moment, I can truthfully say that they have made more films I have disliked (or at least considered ordinary) than ones I have been in raptures over. This remake is faithful to the original but has the Coens' inimitable wit.Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) seeks to avenge her father's death by the outlaw Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). To help her, with breathtaking casuistry, she persuades Marshal Rueben 'Rooster' Cogburn (Jeff Bridges), who has killed 23 men and loves to 'pop a cork', and Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) to accompany her.As I do not rate John Wayne, whichever way Bridges played Cogburn was going to be better. Like all his funny characters, he is sinfully funny and isn't, contrary to general opinion, over-the-top. He acts drunk only in scenes where he is drunk, and his wisecracks always come at the right time. But in conclusion, it's a burlesque of his Oscar-winning turn in 'Crazy Heart'.Teenager Hailee Steinfeld has been lauded – rightly – for her grown-up performance. But I'm not sure that it stands up as one of the all-time great juvenile performances – not when compared with Jodie Foster in 'Taxi Driver', or Linda Blair in 'The Exorcist'. Steinfeld speaks her complex dialogue too quickly, and wears a constant detached expression. She makes the Wild West seem like a giant Jungle Jim. (Harsh maybe, but there is stiff competition for these rare roles, and kids are often more dedicated than adults).I was impressed that so many people laughed at everything Cogburn said. Ask them what he was saying and they wouldn't be able to say. His argot is so foreign that I doubt even he knows what he's saying. Paradoxically, that's part of his appeal: you have to listen carefully to make out his witticisms, and when you do catch a good one, you laugh all the more heartily.Matt Damon does nothing interesting. His character dies in the book – one bit the Coens should have stuck to. Why is he so prolific an actor? Who likes him that much? Josh Brolin also contributes very little here. It's a shame no one is making a case for Barry Pepper, who plays the main villain. This character-actor is much more than 'Jackson', the ace sniper from 'Saving Private Ryan'.Brit cinematographer Roger Deakins gives the film the look and feel of 'Unforgiven' (it looks beautiful). Not a bad thing, but the Coens are supposed to be luminaries, not looters. But perhaps I'm being pernickety. They may have revived the western.www.scottishreview.net

reviews.review_title: If you like Western films, you'll love this.
reviews.content: Definitely deserving of an 8. This remake of a classic 1960's Western film could not have been done better. As many reviewers have mentioned, the Coen Brothers have not quite lost their touch with accents, and the Southern drawl and Old Western speak fit in perfectly. But what is really worth watching is Hollywood's latest child star, Hailee Steinfeld establish her credentials in the acting world, especially when she is playing a character of such resilience and determination as Mattie. And what makes her character stand out is that it is quite easy to see a similar scenario happening in real life - we are all familiar with Jeff Bridges (Rooster Cogburn) and Matt Damon (Texas Ranger LaBoeuf) in the acting world, but it is the new and relatively unknown Steinfeld who really deserves the screen time she gets. The only part I did not like was the ending, which I found a little too abrupt and rather unappealing. But other than that, well worth the money.

My 7th grade Social Studies teacher read this novel to us, in daily excerpts, and I remember enjoying it, despite not being a "Western" kind of kid. I hardly remembered any of the story, going into the movie. I went to see it because I'll see anything the Coens do.The script was excellent. There was a quick, dry, subtle humor to much of the dialogue. Hailee Steinfeld really impressed me, right from the start. She nails her character immediately, when she's talking with the funeral director, articulately and shrewdly calculating, and when he offers that she may kiss her dead father, she dismisses the idea dispassionately, as though her mind is occupied with other things, saying quickly, "the Spirit has left". She balances that lack of sentimentality with a zeal for righteous justice for her father; well done. Great to see a kid actor that's not awful.Damon is good here. Ever since "...Mr. Ripley", I've been able to appreciate him as more than a pretty boy actor. In all honesty though, of the three actors that get the most screen time, he's the one that's most average.Jeff Bridges is great. That rambling wreck of a body, booze-soaked, dusty, and sun-cracked. If Oscars were handed out to body parts, that one good eye would run away with it, this year. I mean it - it seems like, in some scenes, his eye gets its own lines.Brolin does a good job as a simple, weak, violent low-life.Pepper, as brief as his appearance was, was very good. Cogburn and Pepper's familiarity with and seeming professional respect for one another was nicely done.The whuppin' that LeBoeuf puts on Mattie was probably the most uncomfortable moment in the movie, as she's really a grown girl, but still a kid. It gets to Cogburn too.Go see it. Some won't like that the end is a little staggered and slightly predictable, but it's the Coens, working within someone else's story, and they do it well. It's not "A Serious Man", it's a different kind of film, for a much wider audience, and it's very good. 'Specially the dialogue.

I am happy to say that I was finally persuaded to watch this movie by all the good reviews posted here. I was not disappointed. Among many other things, I found the use of language and the featured thespiansʻ mastery of the acting arts more than sufficient to justify the high score I have awarded it here. So fascinating was this work that I conducted my own investigation to determine the various principles or "rules" that lent such a peculiar yet distinctive air to it. It did not take me long to discover these principles for I have a talent in this direction in the way some people have for summing and spelling. But I do not boast of my own gifts in this direction, for movie analysis is not everything.In the first place, the language used was not one to take kindly to the use of contraction. Nary a single apostrophe was used in place of a letter throughout the entire epic regardless of the speakerʻs station or virtue. We do not have to assume that this dramaʻs makers believe that people of the era and location did not use contractions in their every day speech. Instead the actress Hailee Steinfeld gives the secret away in her own capable portrayal of the 14-year-old Mattie Ross. Not only have 14-year-olds always used contractions in their speech, they have also always had a tendency to move about when speaking, or when engaged in any activity during their waking hours. But Steinfeldʻs Mattie Ross calmly remains still as a middle aged spinster when delivering her demands and pronouncements.And that is it exactly. The novel True Grit was expertly written by Charles Portis in the first person from Mattie Rossʻs point of view. Not the 14-year-old Mattie Ross, but the middle aged Mattie Ross; the very proper, very strong, Mattie Ross, survivor and possessor of true grit. And in fact, every one in this memoir speaks out of Mattieʻs mouth. So we have a tale populated by characters speaking and acting in varying degrees like middle aged Mattie Rossʻs and that stunt may as well have been invented by the Coen brothers such is their gift for strange stunts. Anyway, that is the secret to the style of the movie, and revealing it is my contribution here. I did not think it necessary to present a synopsis of the story since it is available in various degrees of accuracy and skill in the other reviews here.

I was disappointed with True Grit, mainly because so many critics had given it such great reviews. I usually like Westerns so I was hoping for something I would enjoy but I felt let down. The film looked authentic and Roger Deakins' cinematography was beautiful, but I didn't find the story particularly interesting and the ending was anti-climatic. Mattie Ross, a 14-year-old farm girl hires a tough, old U.S. marshal, Rooster Cogburn (Bridges) to track down her father's killer. Matt Damon plays a Texas Ranger who joins the chase. The first problem was the accents. Bridges and Damon adopt 19th century sounding regional accents. I struggled to understand what Bridges was saying most of the time. Damon's verbose and mumbling Texas Ranger was equally hard to comprehend and his outmoded speech patterns were irritating. Strangely, Ross, although supposedly from Arkansas, sounded like a modern American teenager. It was a rather incongruous combination. It would have been better without the accents. Cogburn is an unbelievable character and almost a cartoon. He's tough and fearless but with a heart of gold. He acts as Mattie's protector and apart from his drinking and penchant for shooting criminals he's almost too good to be true. Mattie Ross seemed too precocious and outspoken for a 14 year old. Damon's character is almost a cipher, someone who talks funny and dresses stylishly but you never work out who he is. I didn't really connect with the characters or care what happened to them.Although nominally an action film, there were only two real action scenes in the movie, neither of which was particularly memorable. Ross and her posse chase the bad guys, find them relatively easily, and the evildoers are punished. The Coen Brothers talked about the comedy in the movie, but I missed most of it. There wasn't much tension either and it was all very predictable. I felt that 3:10 To Yuma and Unforgiven had more interesting story lines. Overall, True Grit was OK, but I really expected more given the hype. I have been disappointed by Coen films in the past so I probably don't get their humor. In my view their films are usually not as good as you would hope.

After getting a bad snubbing at this year's Golden Globes, True Grit returned with a hammer to grab as many as 10 academy award nominations. Questions about its worthiness are better set aside because, though no one really gives True Grit a chance at the ceremony, all of these nominations we think are well deserved.Essentially, True grit is a movie about a daughter's pursuit to nab her father's murderer played by Josh Brolin. 14 year old Mattie Ross(Hailee Steinfeld) finds assistance in US Marshall Reuben "Rooster" Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) and Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) and it will require a display of true grit by no less than all three to get them through the task.Coens to their credit make True Grit in the way of the Traditional Western. It gives us the historical feel that we expect from the genre. We believe True Grit has done as much to revive the genre as has James Mangold's remake of 3:10 to Yuma, another good western in recent years. It is something that a movie like No Country for Old Men cannot do. Thus Coens' decision to remake True Grit is an important one, their approach is even more. True Grit takes a different course than a usual Coen movie, yet for its technical remarkability it has "Coens Bros." written on it in bold font. It gives it an edge over the original 1969 adaptation of Charles Portis' novel. It is not without the dark humor they are known for and they also give us the typical Coen childlike adults in Rooster and Laboeuf.For comparison the Dude(Bridges) as Cogbern matches up to Duke(John Wayne) well and beyond. The performances of the lead actors push it even far.True Grit gets our thumbs up for adapting a classic western tale and doing nothing wrong with it, putting in all the brilliant things Coens know so well. This is the very best they have to offer. Heres a salute to the Great Western.REVIEW ORIGINALLY POSTED ON cueforchange.blogspot.com

The Coens must be considered True masters of contemporary American cinema. They have again crafted a well told story in a style that is simultaneously majestic and real. True Grit stands out for it's characters, cinematography, acting and sound design, but what exceeds all other aspects of this film is the dialogue. Credit must be given the actors and director for the execution of the script, however the rhythms, textures and painterly means of creating characters with their words is truly exceptional. We hear the landscape in this film, the silence, the rasp, the distance from humanity. It is a stark world, but the dialogue sings itself into the rhythms of nature when appropriate, and emulates the ugly, primal moaning of mankind at other times. The meter is absolutely joyous to listen to, and miraculously fits this gruff environment. And it is funny- I found myself laughing numerous times at not only the characters intent, but the wordsmithing of the Cohen brothers. Damon may come off as the most over-matched with the dialogue, but as the film progresses, he reconciles his choices well with his character and never pushes too hard. Bridges can do this role falling off a log; the gruff, drunk, self-possessed, but we absolutely buy his perspective of the world- he is shaped by it's wilds, and is the vehicle through which we understand the landscape. But the real prize is Hailee Steinfeld- wonderfully confident absent the attitude we so often see with the younger actors. She handles the dialogue with great ease and utilizes it surgically in the film, making us want to root for her, despite the awful intentions she has. The mission really becomes subjugated to our interest in the characters and the environment, and although this departs from our "traditional Hollywood" conventions, it is refreshing, accurate and reflects how we look at our own history. A brilliant script and execution again, and I cannot wait to get my hands on the DVD.

reviews.review_title: Another Coen's Western, and this time FOR REAL!
reviews.content: After "No Country for Old Men", the Coens returns to join in the direction on the Western style making the "reboot" of the John Wayne's classic Western "True Grit" making one of theirs most fantastic movies. And managed to bring "everything" with them!The story of "True Grit" begins when Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) arrives in town to deal with the burial of her father and find a way to bring Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) the murderer to justice. When she finally meets Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) the local Marshall, with drink problems, promising him $ 50 in return of help her find and capture Tom Cheney. On their journey, joined them both the clumsy but competent Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon). Together they embark on a journey through the vast and dangerous West looking for Chaney, that will bring them many dangers later. The story seems a typical adventure-Western story, the Coens managed to make it magnificent with its elements.When I say that the brothers were able to bring "everything" with them was exactly to do with the elements of their films. While they are loyal to the old classic, also were super faithful to Charles Porti's novel and managed to bring and join their elements: humor, simple and intriguing dialogs and brutal but sometimes fun violence (not like Tarantino though). But even being a Western, it also managed to be an adventure with drama (with some emotional times).But without any problem the brothers were also loyal to Western style giving a lot of epic moments: shootout sequences; a badass shooter; Indians, an outlaw gang and moments with the landscape of the West around reminding us how beautiful it is.And like any Coens movie, the cast is outstanding: Hailee Steinfeld is superb in every detail; Matt Damon as always fitting into any kind of movie without problem; Josh Brolin (despite having a small appearance) has a fantastic performance, but who shines again is Jeff Bridges, simply perfect!Another Coen's masterpiece, fantastic direction and writing; intriguing dialogs; hilarious and smart humor; exciting and epic moments on Western style, the Coens once again didn't disappoint at all.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, but not as faithful as others indicate
reviews.content: First off, I must say I loved the book and the 1969 film. Those who say this version is a "more faithful adaptation" of the Charles Portis novel probably haven't read it. With the exception of the epilogue, the 1969 film follows the novel more closely and contains more character development. In the first film we spend more time with Rooster, Mattie, and LeBoeuf in the beginning and learn a bit more about them. LeBoeuf never leaves the expedition in the book or the first film as he does twice in the 2010 film. The dugout scene is more faithful to the book in the first film as well as certain sequences of events. I read that Jeff Bridges moved the eye patch to his right eye because it was more comfortable. If that's the case, he should have shot left-handed. Any hunter will find a flaw in this. Nitpicking, yes, but that's what we do sometimes when we're comparing things. I loved the Coen Brothers adaptation, but most of the reviews here are pretty over-the-top regarding a pretty good film, but not a 10 out of 10. Jeff Bridges was good, Hailee Steinfeld was brilliant and closer in age to the book's Mattie. Matt Damon was wonderful, but his time on-screen was cut too short by the directors. So, see this film, but read the book and watch the 1969 version. In my opinion, John Wayne deserved the Oscar, and Glen Campbell's acting wasn't as bad as some have written.

The Western is our Great American mythology! True Grit was a great movie, deserving of it's Oscar nomination. The Duke would be proud.I love the modern gritty westerns, which to my memory go back to Unforgiven. And just like in Unforgiven, the movie is more about realism then the mythology, but just like in Unforgiven, there was one moment that reminded me why I love cowboys and indians, a throwback to the mythical westerns of old.Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges character) faces four outlaws on horse back from across a baron plain. Then, they rush, Rooster pulls his revolvers, the score swells and an amazing mythological western shootout breaks out in slow motion. I still get goosebumps.I don't know if it's the best film nominated this year, but it's certainly the one I'm rooting for.

I don't understand the point of this movie. Why take such a great original film and then effectively reshoot it in the dark with newer and less talented actors.All the best shots, lines and scenes are straight lifts from the original. Matt Damon is equal to Glen Campbell's performance in the original but everyone else falls short to a greater or lesser degree. Bridges is a shadow of John Wayne, and Brolin et al are no match for James Caan and Dennis Hopper's gang. Steinfeld is not far short of Darby's performance but it does seem like an impression at times, and unfortunately the few scenes she is at her best are again those that are lifted straight from the original.The changes (and they are minimal) to the story make no significant difference to the tone or feel of the film and are barely enough to disguise the nature of this vanity project for the Coen brothers.Given the choice you should skip this and watch the original.

reviews.review_title: Not the best Coen Brothers-Movie, but its cast shines
reviews.content: The Coen brothers and the Western genre: at the latest since their Oscar winner No Country For Old Men, we know that this combination fits. In True Grit they take a completely different, almost conventional path. Based on Charles Portis novel of the same name, which spawned the 1969 film classic starring John Wayne, young Mattie Ross sets out to find her father's killer. She is assisted by a marshal who seems to be long past his prime.The story focuses on three protagonists. On the one hand, there is the young Mattie Ross, embodied by the then 14-year-old Hailee Steinfeld. Considering that this was Steinfeld's debut in a leading role, she appears almost too experienced and is on an absolute par with her more experienced colleagues. By too experienced it means that one hardly notices her young age. Yes, in those days one probably had to take on more responsibility earlier and shed the infantile behaviour prematurely. The latter is most noticeable when Ross makes her cheeky and disrespectful announcements without regard for the possible consequences. Of course, she is naïve at times, but this is less due to the writing of the character than to Steinfeld's authentic acting. She is particularly fun in combination with her companions Reuben Cogburn and LaBeouf. The former is in none other than Jeff Bridges, who once again delivers a veritable firework of cool. Bridges makes almost every role he plays look easy, even if it's one that's really tailor-made for him. As Cogburn, he is filthy and frustrated on the surface, but doesn't want to let it show in his appearance. When signs appear that he has long since ceased to be what he once was as a marshal, he immediately plunges into stubborn confrontations. He usually leads these against LeBeouf, played by Matt Damon. It often seems that this character was cast just for these arguments, which hurts Damon's presence somewhat. One hardly buys the role of the sovereign and almost ruthless cowboy because he only fits into this kind of role to a limited extent. Much more adequate is the villain part of Josh Brolin, who does exactly his job in very little screentime.True Grit is on the one hand a typical Coen film. Bloody brutality when you least expect it, beautiful images from the wild Western, captured by cinematographer Roger Deakins and peppered with clever and eloquent dialogue. On the other hand, the film is very different from their usual style of making. And this is precisely where the problem lies. The abstruseness of Fargo and No Country For Old Men is missing here. The approach seems almost generic and in its plot the film leans too much on the old version. As a result, it's nothing you haven't seen before multiple times. Still, the Coens put their stamp on the film again, especially with the stellar cast, and make True Grit a very atmospheric film experience. Nice homage to the Wild Western, even if that's about it.

As a dyed-in-the-wool John Wayne fan since childhood, I thought no one could do a better job with Rooster Cogburn. Duke, you are my hero, but Jeff Bridges is simply amazing to watch. Almost the same dialog, line for line in some instances, lifted directly from the wonderful writing of Charles Portis's novel of the same name, but given a different, sometimes more sinister twist than Duke's version. In many ways, funnier too. The Coen's took the spirit of the original movie, went back to the source material of the novel and made it better. SPOILER ALERT: This version is a bit truer to the book, the Duke's version leaving out the reminiscence of a grown Matti Ross about her adventure with Rooster and LeBeuf in tracking Tom Cheney and Lucky Ned Pepper. END ALERT.Thirteen year old Hailee Steinfeld is closer to the age of the heroine (14) than was Kim Darby at 21 and is a much more formidable and determined Matti.Everything about this film is first rate and each character moves the story along and whether a major or minor role, they are a gem to watch.Do yourself a favor and see this movie. You won't be disappointed.

this movie i had some doubts. when i walked into this movie i read some reviews before it started. they were all good but some said it got off to a boring start. they were right. however once the journey to find the girls killer began it was exciting, funny, and unpredictable. I'm not a big fan of westerns but i like Jeff bridges and i heard that Jeff might be nominated for an Oscar for best actor so i saw it. this was i wouldn't say better than the original but equally matched to it. also i think that Jeff should win an Oscar for this. this movie i thought was better than crazy heart, not by much though. Jeff has had an unbelievable role on movies. he had crazy heart, than tron legacy, than this. anyway back to the movie. i didn't think Matt Damon did a great job at his role in fact i was hoping that Jeff would just shoot him and get it over with. but with any character like that he turned nice and of course he did. go see this movie you wont regret it

A collection of gifted monologues and understated comedy. Underrated performances all the way around. One of Bridges better performance and great character acting by Damon. Not to mention great scenery and cinematography - The Coen Brothers nailed it once again!

This is quite different to the John Wayne original.
It's a very good western in it's own right.
Great performances from the main cast while Hailee Steinfeld as the young girl Mattie Rose is superb.
Forget about comparing it to the original this is just one of the best westerns around.
Well recommended..

As a massive fan of john wayne i kept putting of seeing this film and when i did see it i sort of felt a comfort in knowing it will never touch the only one true grit ,but also it was not bad ,jeff bridges took the role on well ,quite a varied cast filled in the bits but as usual massive mistake matt damon ,how the firk he was ever cast in a film i really dont know ,dry ,cant act ,thank god josh brolin rolled up to bring someguts back in the film ,also why the hell where they all speaking in some old school butlers language left over from my first ladybird book,all in all it was ok ,but not a splat on the original.

I had a chance to see this tonight, it was a spur of the moment thing and I started watching with absolutely no expectations, I didn't even know who was in it... I was in for quite a shock!!!Within 5 minutes I knew with 100% certainty that I was about to see a really good movie; Hailee Steinfeld blew my mind. As soon as that little girl started speaking it was glaringly obvious this was not going to be just "another Hollywood flick". This movie is perfect and it hits you immediately - like an electric shock. It sucks you in and does not let you go.Within 10 minutes I knew I'd be I writing a review on IMDb when I got home, which is something I rarely do despite seeing 100s of movies every year. But this one deserves it, demands it. It would be an injustice if I didn't help spread the word - people must be told: this is one of the best movies you'll ever see.Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and especially Hailee Steinfeld all deserve Oscars and any other awards we can give them - they "nailed" their roles. Perfect acting. Perfect writing. Perfect direction. The film had me literally on the edge of my seat, several times gasping and uncontrollably speaking out loud "wow, this is good". Make sure you see this - it is shockingly good.

I'm not to much of a fan of Westerns, I do love the Dollars trilogy and the Good the Bad and the Weird (a Korean movie I know lol)though.The story seems to portray every single person as a lame cardboard cartoony stereotype of the old west rather than just being more natural. Not only that but it's seriously racist towards the north American Indians (As far as I know if they were going to hang the Indian then at least let them finish the speech because that's what they did) The story is pretty generic for a western, it doesn't reinvent the genre like I have heard it does.The acting for most is campy if not bland, the soundtrack just sounds uninspired and the direction is connect the dots type and not to impressively edited.Bridges and Damon gave really embarrassing performances that seemed to cheesy for the screen.But now it kinda boils down to this (I'm sure I'm gonna get a lot of hate for this but this is my opinion).Mattie Ross's portrayal by Hailee Steinfeld is being praised as godlike, impressive and tour-De-force like, well if you all want to hear my voice on this get ready, I might spoil down so you have been warned.I'd replace Mattie Ross's name with Mary Sue. Her performance is hideous, irritating, over hyped and beyond overrated. She just doesn't make the movie like everyone says she does.Seriously, everyone should quit ''jacking off'' over her performance because she deserves a middle finger and here's why. She showed no emotion when her father was killed, her voice sounded so silly, stereotypical and cringe-worthy in all the moments that where meant to be serious, demanded to much of Rooster Cogburn, had a very retarded and dumb look on her face throughout the entire picture like if she had smelled rotten eggs and worked with a stink look on the face (you guys honestly call this good acting), acted to much of a brat that wants to get everything done their own way and the way she acted maturely seemed really off as in ''I'm above all you guys and I treat all of you the way I want but I have to show a really fake mature side that seems to be the same as my spoiled side'' and contradicts what she said early in the film about her father having justice and won't necessarily kill Chaney butt kills the guy for revenge anyway.If there is a redeeming quality of this film it's the scenery although the movie in itself is very generic and boring.

This film a great example of lazy film making, with historically incorrect locations and props, and incomplete sets. The film begins in Fort Smith Arkansas, with most of the women are wearing hoop skirts. (By 1878 hoop skirts were a long-forgotten fashion.) The players soon head out of town, across wide expanses of open grasslands with mountains in the distance - scenery typical in some parts of the great basin, but not at all like the woodlands that covered most of Arkansas at the time. The main characters come across a "mountain man", complete with a bear hide with a mounted head with intact eyes, teeth, and tongue in an open mouth - the type of display one would find on a bear rug hung in a mountain lodge. Later on, they come across a "silver mine" with rails, but no trace of any material in the form of a dump outside the adit - a quickly-assembled prop with no thought to reality. Cogburn discards pocket whiskey bottles across the countryside during their little adventure - bottles without labels - as if the makers sold their whiskey that way.
