Everything about this movie cries out as one more example of lazy movie makers ignoring important historical details just because they are too lazy or ignorant to do it right. Almost forgot - where the black people?

reviews.review_title: A true Western that heralds the arrival of a major new talent
reviews.content: As a Coen brothers fan, I was thrilled to hear that they were doing a film adaptation of Charles Portis' novel "True Grit"—and casting Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn. Although the novel has been adapted for film once already, this version seems to adhere more closely to the spirit of the novel, perhaps because it's not masquerading as a star vehicle. At any rate, this is a classic Western as only the Coen brothers can do it—snappy, witty dialogue, three-dimensional characters, explosive action, and sentiment that is earned rather than begged for. The cast is populated with stars—the aforementioned Bridges, Matt Damon, Josh Brolin, Barry Pepper—but the movie belongs to the newcomer Hailee Steinfeld, who plays 14 year-old Mattie Ross with a remarkable blend of genuine righteous vengeance, child-like naiveté, and—yes—true grit. Despite all the big names in this cast, she's the one who probably has the best shot at an Oscar nomination. The movie itself is entertaining and well done, as just about all Coen brothers films are, but it may very well become best remembered as this young actress' feature film debut.

reviews.review_title: The Western is Alive Again! And fantastic!
reviews.content: The movie was fantastic, truly wonderful - you could tell from the first few minutes how good it was going to be. Production, writing, direction, acting, lighting, costumes, music - all flawless.Jeff Bridges inhabited Rooster completely; a feat impossible for a man who has not been on horses most of his life (vis a vis: Rancho Deluxe). The young girl, Hailee Steinfeld, is quite amazing - the camera loves her, and she is the real True Grit of the title. Matt Damon performs flawlessly in a very difficult role. Other supporting characters are alive and fully realized, even those in minor parts.Beautifully visualized and paced, authentic and raw. !!! Coen Brothers !!! Highly recommended.

True Grit 2010 is a very good movie although it losses the strong grip in few sequences. The Direction, Acting, Story/Screenplay, Editing and most of the content are praiseworthy but The Cinematography is Outstanding, it makes the movie look very real and takes you in 1800's.Considering it's a remake, I must say it might be a better version because it creates an even better environment. I was not sure that I'd like the movie (because I didn't like No Country For Old Men much) I was not expecting anything but I was wrong its very good. Also I didn't expect any thing funny but there were thing made me laugh.I am going to give it a 8.2/10. 10 Oscar nominations are deserved IMO.

reviews.review_title: The Coen Brothers do it again!
reviews.content: The 3rd best movie of 2010 in my opinion. Plot: A young girl sets out with a U.S. Marshal and a Texas ranger to avenge the death of her father. I have never particularly enjoyed Western movies, but I really liked this. Directed by the Coen Brothers(No Country for Old Men,O Brother, Where Art Thou?, The Big Labowksi, and Fargo),craft a fantastic Aventure/Drama. I still cannot believe this is a remake. I have never seen the original but judging the ratings it's got, this may be one of the few remakes that is actually better than the original. This movie is a pretty graphic movie despite it's PG-13 rating, but I was surprised to find the movie hilarious at times. Most of the hilarity comes from Jeff Bridges's character and he definitely deserves an Oscar for this. His character is a drunk and dry humored aging marshal. I'm sure his accent will be mimicked to death, just like Borat, Austin Powers and Forrest Gump's. Matt Damon plays a cocky Texas ranger and Josh Brolin plays the outlaw that killed the girl's father. All of the acting is good. Other than Bridges's performance, I really enjoyed Hailee Steinfeld who plays the girl. I see a bright future in acting ahead of her. Also I must mention Barry Pepper, barely recognizable under the make up is fantastic the short time he is on screen. I would definitely recommend this to any Coen Brothers fan and anybody looking for a good adventure movie. Even if western movies aren't your cup of tea, you will still enjoy this.

reviews.review_title: True Grit not worth the ticket price
reviews.content: Come on it . This was the EXACT almost word for word script of the original Movie starting John Wayne The story line was identical except the end last ten minutes and a couple of skits I was so hard to watch I nearly walked out but just managed to stay and be totally bored. Plagiarism , what about pirates'. Poor old John would turn over in his grave , he won an Oscars and the change of pace for John gave him a string of follow up movies with the same theme . One tough patch eyed sheriff with grit. All this new lot are doing is duplicating the original , shame shame shame . has not the industry got more talent than that , looking at some of the latest releases I am beginning to wonder Nominated for 10 Oscars what for duplicating what was given Oscars before for the same movie Sorry guys and gals this one is a waist of time and space ..and even if they changed the story line a bit more it could have just scraped in as entertainment But its not entertainment to see an exacts duplication except the actors The original was written by Charles Portis, and screen play Marguerite RobertsGee I wonder if they are going to be paid for the works on this new movies of the same name There has been so many attempts to remake an older movie , never have I seen one that has taken 99% of the dialog and story line and simply directly copies it The new script writers must have spend hours re running the john Wayne DVD to get it so exact, so tell me how that is worth having any credibility for . Same goes for direction it takes no talent to copy what's on the screen before. The only advantage would be people that have not seen the original then it would be entertaining

reviews.review_title: The grit of an Oscar Contender
reviews.content: Usually before the movie, I only saw 1 Coen Brother film and that's O Brother. Now I'm a big fan of the original John Wayne film (although it could been more faithful to the novel) so when I heard the New True Grit would come out on Christmas, I was full of hype and when I walked out when the film was over, it lived to it. It was more faithful to the novel itself and it hardly ever change the film point of view. The film is about a 14 year old girl named Mattie Ross who hires an alcoholic U.S. Marshal named Rooster Cogburn to go after Tom Chaney who killed her father and is hiding in Indian territory. Not knowing the land well, Cogburn also hired a Texas Ranger named Laboeuf (pronounce as La-Beef) to help him with the land (he departs a few times in the film). Meanwhile, Mr. Cogburn is also after a man named "Lucky" Ned Peppers who is with Tom Chaney. The film (some of you will find it a little slow) is well made which is worthy for Oscar nominations (lets hope it doesn't snub it like the Golden Globes or there will be pain) so see it. Warning: besides the PG-13 rating, The film has violence and blood that pushes it to an R rating so you have the right to be surprised of it's bloody violence. Trust me I was surprised all right.

reviews.review_title: Worth a look if only for discussion sake.
reviews.content: I must admit that until recently I had never read the book on which this film is based. I am however, familiar with the 1969 film version. So I decided to hold a little film festival and screen both versions back-to- back, beginning with the original. It was a lot of fun to realize that the John Wayne film stuck so closely with the novel. A kid could have faked a book report by watching it. Since it had been 40 years since I had seen it, I had forgotten how green Glen Campbell was as an actor, but I had to remember how hot he was at the time - career wise - with his music and everything, so I can imagine this was quite a plum for him. Think: Elvis in Jailhouse Rock. I didn't like Kim Darby much at the time but she too in retrospect was excellent as were all the supporting characters including Robert Duvall, Dennis Hopper, Strother Martin and John Fielder - outstanding. Which brings me to the remake. I've read it on these boards before and I must agree: Bridges is no Duke and had I not read the book I might have let this film get by with a lot. The "new" Mattie doesn't fill the role nearly as neatly as Ms. Darby. Her role brings to mind the more modern smarty pants kids written for the screen today rather than one from the 1870s. Glen Campbell's "Labeef" is superior to Damon's even with the buckskin (which in hindsight I can't see Campbell wearing anyway). Most of all, I was disappointed that pivotal scenes were just missing as was much of the exposition from the original. Explaining what "sand dodgers" are for example. And when Mattie runs into Chaney at the watering hole in the remake it is nothing like the book when she comes down a steep grade such that she could not easily run back up for help from Rooster and Labeef. The original stayed true to this. The remake in fact had Labeef leave very early in the film only to reappear at opportune moments; he wasn't even there to damp the chimney at the dugout when they first run into Lucky Ned! The remake had Mattie do it. Labeef is supposed to be somewhat of a dandy: more talk than action. I think in the end Campbell filled this bill better. Another scene lacking is the ferry scene where the book clearly states that Mattie swum her horse across the river to beat Rooster and Labeef who had sought to leave her behind. The '69 version captures this verbatim; the remake was cheap as was the scene where Mattie falls into the hole with the snakes. The book had Chaney fall in after her as did the '69 film. The remake did not. In fact, in the book and '69 film Mattie's rescue was true whereas in the remake it was not. The remake is anticlimactic in every sense. The 1969 version is the standard.

Not really a necessary remake. Sure it is done super well. Bridges is a damn great actor, and he is good as Cogburn, I won't compare him to Wayne Oscar-winning original role cause that would be unfair. Also, Bridges pretty much copies it verbatim, so there is nothing to talk about with that. This, alas is my big problem with this movie. It has absolutely no reason to exist. It added nothing, it good the same story in the exact same way. The only thing that is different is the ending, which is a touch bleaker, while to original was typical ride off into the sunset western. However, one change does not make a movie full of the same magically necessary.This one was written and directed by the Coen Bros. Such unique, groundbreaking talent they are, you will see none of their personas as filmmakers here. None of their quirkiness is here. This could have been made by anybody. I am coming off as a bit harsh here and am really not trying to. This is actually not a bad movie at all from a technical standpoint. The acting is all great. Matt Damon is a little more grizzled here, and the young Hailee Steinfeld is particularly memorable as Matty, maybe even more brutal than her original counterpart. All the music and cinematography is stunning. The old west is captured very well. It is perfectly watchable and entertaining. A movie, though, almost more than anything, needs to have a reason to exist, needs to have something to bring to the table, to truly work in my eyes, and this one does none of these things, so, honestly, cannot really recommend it. Just watch the original. Its a landmark western. This is an unneeded clone.

This film is abundant in cinematography. Great western feel! Jeff Bridges is a premier actor as is Damon who managed to conceal his identity to me for the first moments of his presence. And the young lady is quite good herself, able to convey such a mature young girl with ease.Both Jeff and Matt did a wonderful job at conveying characters of the time as well as the dress.What this movie lacked was feel. Both the female and male leads were cold. One didn't feel any true bond or emotion between the two. The only warmth in the movie was when Damon left the two near the end and he said his goodbyes to the girl Jeff, though a fine actor played his part to far. There is supposed to be a warm heart that pours out as Wayne did in the original. A drunken rough man who had a heart for the girl underneath the rough exterior. Jeff was not able to portray this and for that the film failed.The gunfight at the end, appeared rushed and lacked and real visceral feel.

It's always hard to be a dissenting voice, you know, I really did want to see the Emperor's New Clothes. Unfortunately, for me, the new Coen brothers' True Grit remained stubbornly naked, and I found myself repeatedly looking at my watch, and wondering if it would soon be over, and what was I gonna have for dinner after.I do like Coen movies, my favorite is The Big Lebowski, but there are several good ones. I enjoyed Brother where art Thou, which I guess is similarly old school. So with Oscar buzz, and those clever Coen boys in charge, I had high hopes.And I like the actors too. Matt Damon has done some great stuff, love the Bourne movies. And Jeff Bridges is always watchable, and The Big Lebowski is probably one of the high spots of his career. So it's not the actors or the acting. Damon and Bridges are good in this movie, and Hailee Steinfeld does a very good job as the heroine Mattie Ross.And it looks good too, nice cinematography of the Wild West.So, I wondered, where does it all go wrong? I've never read the original book, and I can't really remember the John Wayne movie, other than the feeling that it wasn't played totally straight. But my guess is, that in a Wild, Wild West where dudes shoot other dudes in the back over a dollar or an unkind word, it isn't super plausible that a 14 year old girl would make much of a bounty hunter. Today, an opinionated girl can be a mouthy bitch, and get away with it. Seems to me that back then you would just shoot the annoying little tyke and move on to more important business.In other words, I suspect that the book is meant to be rather funny, and not a believable illustration of your typical mis-matched posse with a pompous and loquacious Texas Ranger (Damon as le beef, not LaBoeuf), a drunk, one-eyed, over-the-hill marshall (Bridges as Rooster Cogburn), and the annoying and vengeful innocent (Steinfeld as Mattie), in search of what seems to be a bunch of dim-witted and incompetent outlaws (Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper as Tom Chaney and Ned Pepper). In one scene, Chaney (the, maybe, villain) even explains to Mattie how to shoot a gun properly... while she's pointing at him. There ain't no way this is a serious scene! But... the Coens play the whole thing very straight, as if the source material was a straightforward serious piece of fiction. For me, this didn't work at all. I sensed the underlying comedy, but didn't see anyone laughing.To compound the problem, the Coens combined serious with super retro realism, with a big emphasis on authentic Olde West style, and, in particular, retro style of speech. It's sort of interesting, of course, to get a feel for the old west, but for a modern audience, I just don't feel that it adds anything. I know we talked differently years ago, but, as long you keep the Rolex out of shot, I'm cool if they all sound like you and me.In summary, the photography and acting was very good. But it's played too serious, with too few laughs, and with an overly retro feel that strives for authenticity but is distracting and adds to the seriousness quotient. Not a bad movie, by any means, but definitely not worthy of the hype. And, I think, ditto for the principal actors, Bridges, Damon and Steinfeld. All three are good, and I liked their performances, but I think you have to do better to win an Oscar.

reviews.review_title: A Boring Film Wins An Award
reviews.content: Mattie Ross (Elizabeth Marvel) narrates her father's murder by Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Chaney robs her father's horse and his two California gold pieces. While collecting her father's body, the 14-year old Mattie (Hailee Steinfeld) inquires about hiring a Deputy U.S. Marshal to bring Chaney to justice.The Sheriff gives her three recommendations, and she decides to hire Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) because he is described as having true grit which is what Mattie wants. He repeatedly rebuffs her attempts to talk with him. The next day, she attempts to hire Cogburn offering him $50 after reminding him of the government's payments. He doesn't believe she has it and refuses.Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) has been tracking Chaney for several months for the murder of a state Senator in Texas. After meeting Mattie, he proposes that they should team up with Cogburn, since he knows the Choctaw terrain where Chaney is hiding.After finally securing Cogburn's services for $100, Mattie is instructed to meet him the following morning to begin the search for Chaney since she insists on going. Instead of meeting Mattie, Cogburn leaves a note and a train ticket telling her to go home while he goes to apprehend Chaney.She gets on her horse and find Cogburn and LaBouef on the other side pf the shore. She is no doubt bold and brave to cross the river and reach there.The next day, she learns Cogburn and Laboeuf have agreed to split the Texas reward on Chaney and accuses him of fraud. After a dispute, Cogburn ends his and Laboeuf's deal and he leaves.White in hot pursuit of the "Lucky" Ned Pepper gang with whom Chaney is with, they meet a doctor who instructs them to a cabin for shelter. Two outlaws, Quincey (Paul Rae) and Moon (Domhnall Gleeson) are staying there, one of whom Cogburn knows to a friend of "Lucky" Ned Pepper.He questions them, Moon is fatally stabbed by Quincey whom Cogburn gun down. Moon explains that "Lucky" Ned Pepper (Barry Pepper) and his gang were planning on returning later that night. Cogburn kills two members of the gang, as well as Pepper's horse, but accidentally wounds LaBoeuf.During the night and the next day, Cogburn drinks a great deal of whiskey. He and LaBoeuf argues again.The next morning, Mattie encounters Chaney at the river. She draws her father's pistol and shoots him when he tries to take her with him but he survives. The pistol misfires as she tries to finish him off; he drags her back to Pepper who uses her to make Cogburn leave. Pepper orders Chaney not to harm her and to take her to safety.Once alone, Chaney disobeys Ned and tries to kill her. In the nick of time, LaBoeuf appears and knocks Chaney with a boulder. They watch as Cogburn takes on the remaining members of Ned's gang.LaBoeuf shoots Ned through the heart and kills him from four hundred yards away, impressing Mattie with his skill as a marksman. Chaney wakes up to attacks Laboeuf, and Mattie shoots Chaney in the chest and knocks him over cliff, killing him.The recoil creates a knock-back pushing her back into a pit of rattlesnakes. She was bitten before Cogburn could save her. Cogburn rides day and night to get Mattie to a doctor, carrying her after he has to kill Mattie's exhausted horse.Twenty-five years later, Mattie – now 40 and with only one arm, the result of an amputation necessitated by gangrene from the snakebite – receives a note from Cogburn with a flyer enclosed inviting her to meet him at a traveling Wild West show with which he is performing when it stops in Memphis. When she arrives at the site, she learns that Cogburn died three days earlier.

Hollywood must be running out of ideas or something. I just don't understand the point of all these remakes, and I certainly don't understand the point of this movie. Why take such a great original film and then effectively re shoot it in the dark with newer and less talented actors.All the best shots, lines and scenes are straight lifts from the original. Matt Damon is equal to Glen Campbell's performance in the original but everyone else falls short to a greater or lesser degree. Bridges is a shadow of John Wayne, and Brolin et al are no match for James Caan and Dennis Hopper's gang.Steinfeld is not far short of Darby's performance but it does seem like an impression at times, and unfortunately the few scenes she is at her best are again those that are lifted straight from the original.The changes (and they are minimal) to the story make no significant difference to the tone or feel of the film and are barely enough to disguise the nature of this vanity project for the Coen brothers.Given the choice you should skip this and watch the original.

This movie is great no matter if you have seen the original or not. It did John Wayne's version justice but also maintained its own style. I think it was a great remake and had me interested from beginning to end.

reviews.review_title: Truly beautiful from beginning to end
reviews.content: This is truly a classic movie that deserves a place in everyone's collection.The story is beautifully told, acting is superb, music is so smooth and catchy that it blends perfectly with the story, camera work also excellent. Everything is combined together in a flawless way that make up an unforgettable experience.The movie totally surpasses my expectation of how a western could be. There is action, there is gunfire, there is horse riding and cowboys' words. But what is so special about this movie is that it is a story very very beautifully told. True Grit is an emotional cinematic experience that everyone will have joy and pleasures after watching it. It's so easy to fall in love with this movie and you will find yourself watching it over and over again just for the pleasant feeling it brings you. Even though I know and remember every little detail of the movie, I still watch it again so many times and enjoy it every time.A must-watch!

...is what you must tell yourself if you are a Western hater like myself.Paradoxically, I list Peckinpah's _Wild Bunch_ at the top of my all time favourite films and have a deep soft spot for the lesser _Magnificent Seven_, which I've seen a 100 times and hope to see a 100 more. A great staple of rerun teevee. But the original _True Grit_? Few things make me reach for the remote to change channels quite as fast.But I don't call either of those favourite films Westerns either. They are genius explorations of the maligned and taboo subject of "masculinity" - maligned especially in the sterile, ideologically puritanical times we find ourselves in today when anything with even a whiff of musky, sweat drenched maleness is denounced as an attack on women and cast out as the new twin secular Satans of "rape culture" and some mythical beast know only as The Patriarchy.This is the story of a Man. A whiskey soaked, emotionless killer. But one that still possesses a useless trait that has been forgotten in our i-phone and Facebook neutered times - "honour". This Man crosses paths with a young girl, similarly weighed down with a burdensome sense of "honour" - a girl with pride, fearlessness and steel cold determination in seeking justice for the grave injustice of her father's murder.This is also a a story of a rock and a hard place colliding, and how in the process, mutual respect, then a platonic bond, is forged. This is an archetypal story of a Man and a Woman.Hailee Steinfeld and Jeff Bridges are the two core characters involved here and their performances are flawless. You forget this is a mere Western. And the Coen brothers, this is possibly their finest hour.This is an impeccable film. You would do a great disservice to yourself to not give it a chance to suck you into its magic.Minus one star for Matt Damon as a third leg in an otherwise perfect film. His role was far better suited for someone like Edward Bunker (RIP 2005). Waste of a good role.

A difficult task it is, to take a near iconic movie and improve upon it, but the Coen Bros. and cast most certainly did it here. The poetically earthy cadence and content of the richly written dialog was masterful, as was the ease in delivery by all in the cast who spoke it.Bridges completely owned and clearly reveled in his wonderfully nuanced performance, and the young actress who played Mattie filled the tall order of making real and believable the unusual precociousness of her character. The entire cast delivered, not the least of which was the traveling doctor or Bear Man, whose all too brief appearance was a delightful Coen Bros. confection.This is one of the all too few films that measures up to the difficult task of intelligently entertaining the eye, mind, and spirit; something the Coen Bros. have been able to achieve with uncanny consistently.Bravo!

My expectations were too high after all the hype I've read on this. I hoped to see something that would rival, or at least approach my all-time favorite Western, "Unforgiven." In my opinion, this does not approach the brilliance of that movie. The performances are all very good, and there is clearly an emphasis on witty, stinging dialog throughout the movie. I think this diminished what little tension was present in this movie. Occasionally, Jeff Bridges' character borders on slapstick, particularly when he is drunk. While this may be accurate with the book and the Directors' instruction, for me it had the effect of diluting a movie that in my opinion lacks tension. Also, I felt that Bridges' character and Damon's character had arcs, but I didn't see one in the girl's character. Also, the conclusion felt rushed, and lacked suspense. There was no gradual movement from comedy to the dramatic, just wild swings. For me, the Directors have always had a way of building suspense from very subtle but potent directing. This was clearly lacking in True Grit.

Watching some of these Coen brother flicks 10+ years after their initial release and you'll realize how over-hyped a lot of them are. Is True Grit it a bad movie? Not at all, but it's not that good either. Nothing really interesting going on here and would never sit through it again. To be honest, I wouldn't even recommend it UNLESS you're out of Westerns to watch. I'd say watch it at least once but you're not missing much if you skip it.

reviews.review_title: An independent and spirited young woman persuades a grouchy old Marshall to find the man that killed her father.
reviews.content: My John Wayne friends are upset with me for going to see this film. They are loyal to the Duke. This film especially Jeff Bridges does "The Duke" great honor. If he does not do a Tom Hanks and win back-to-back Oscars, it will be sad. I found the film mesmerizing and action filled. I loved the dialect and grammar. The characters were well-developed and demonstrated the full range of human behavior. Barry Pepper was exceptional and was a perfect model for the myth of "honor among thieves". And, the you actress performed far beyond the original. Her character demonstrated a believable determination and "True Grit". She was fearless without being an "Annie Oakley", she was willing to do what she had asked the Ranger and Rooster to do. John Wayne would love this film.

What a wonderful remake of a classic. I never thought I would like this movie after growing up in the John Wayne era and thinking very highly of this great star... even with his short comings and movie flops. This is why this movie was such a pleasure to like and a nice surprise while expecting the opposite. Both movies makes have comparisons and special moments for me: Rooster: Bridges plays this part differently yet as good as the "Duke". I enjoy Jeff B in most any movie he makes.. such a talent.Mattie: Hailee is much more convincing (age obliviously)to the book.. splendid performance from a new actress...not perfect but solid.LaBoeuf: Matt Damon is much better cast than Glen C in the original. I wish we would have seen him a bit more.Lucky Ned Pepper: I have to say I was wishing for Robert D to appear.. his performance in the original fits better for me and I could not get past that Moon: missed Dennis Hopper and the chopping of the Turkey :) Tom Chaney: Toss up but I might prefer the original actor to Josh B Other great moments.... the grit and dirt of the movie was so much more realistic than the original...the man hanging along the trail lol. The ending scene.... while I still wanted to hear "watch a one-eyed fat man jump" watching John Wayne ride off...I prefer this version much more than as an eight yrs old and needing to feel good as I did then....If I could critique anything... I actually wished the movie would have developed characters a bit more and been longer. Also I was a bit confused by the doctor in the woods performance.. seemed more than a bit strange.Overall a great movie but like any remake.. the only thing I missed was a combination of the two to make something perfect... They did as good a job as anyone could with this ... Not an easy task with such an iconic movie (to me at least) as the original. Great Job!

reviews.review_title: A great movie, not a remake
reviews.content: I eagerly await any Coen brothers film. I have been a fan of theirs for (gosh) almost 25 years, ever since I first saw "Raising Arizona". I've seen the 1969 "True Grit". It is a great movie, and the Duke is, well, The Duke. But don't be tempted to compare the two movies. They are quite different.Older westerns starring the likes of John Wayne, Gary Cooper, and others are classics. But they also still paint the Old West, despite their efforts, in a fairly sanitized fashion. In the past 20 years or so, we have seen the genre evolve with movies like "Dances With Wolves", "Unforgiven" and shows like "Deadwood". Newer tellings of the Old West show a darker, more authentic and (no pun intended) grittier version of the harsh frontier where the bad guys don't always wear black hats and the lines of right and wrong are not so clearly defined.I'll leave the scene-by-scene retellings to others, and will comment on the film as a whole. It is typical Coen brothers. At first the tempo and use of language takes a little getting used to, not unlike watching a Shakespearan play (after the first few minutes you get uesed to the meter of the dialogue). Not only was it a different time (contractions weren't used a liberally), but the language is an affect and device in itself. We see this early on with Mattie's negotiations with Rooster and with a stubborn merchant. It establishes the the meter of the dialogue and Mattie as the true protagonist.The settings are bleak and forbidding, but beautiful in their desolation. One feels this is what the frontier must have been like and reminds us the sturdy souls and rogues willing to venture into such places. Rooster Cogburn is such a man, hard-drinking and morally suspect by our standards. Bridges's is NOT redoing John Wayne. He wholly owns this character and makes it his own. Matt Damon as the self-important Texas Ranger is excellent. Both are comical and in their own way heroic. Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper lend small but notable performances as the villains. But the true revelation is Hailee Steinfeld. Her maturity and grivitas holds its own and even overshadows the performances for her more veteran co-stars. Personally, I was reminded of the way Saoirse Ronan owned "The Lovely Bones" (though the movies are far different). While others in TG are complex and colorful, they are still somewhat caricatures. Steinfeld's performance is the glue that holds the entire movie together and transforms what might be farce into art.Forget about The Duke. Enjoy this movie for what it is. Another triumph by the Coen Brothers.

True Grit, directed by the great Coen Brothers, is a remake of the classic film starring John Wayne. The film starts off as expected; Mattie Ross asks Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to help her seek revenge on her father's killer, Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Rooster acquires LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) who joins Rooster on his quest to find and kill Ross's fathers killer. The film has a unique style, much like the original, and we see a sort of bond create between Mattie (forgot; future star Hailee Steinfeld) and Rooster, while at the side is Damon. The film had some good western action sequences, but this isn't the kind of film you'd expect from the Coen brothers. Matt Damon was out of place and Jeff Bridges (tremendous actor) seemed, to me, a little overdone. Although I respect that they were trying to keep the original style of the older film, it didn't match up as I expected it to. Nonetheless, this i definitely a film worth checking out; 7/10 Rated PG-13 110min

reviews.review_title: Attention! This is not a classic!
reviews.content: OK, The Coens are always on big horses, but not with "True Grit". After so many masterpieces, there comes a time of retrogression. The originality of screenplay cannot be compared with the one from "Fargo", "Hudsucker Proxy" or "No Country For Old Men". It's just an average one, with some woody lines and nothing to impress me. I love old western movies and i really appreciate the "true grit" of Coens in "attacking" such a genre, but it really fails to deliver any substance for the future. Stop transforming any ordinary production in a "true classic"! How can this movie be a true classic, when it copies a lot of aspects from past masterpieces? The Coens aren't Sergio Leone or Clint Eastwood. After "Burn after reading", this average western movie simply proves a lack of originality. Not every movie of The Coens can be a masterpiece. Not even Spielberg or Scorsese can always deliver "true classics". Jeff Bridges is stiff, i enjoyed his "Crazy Heart" performance, but this one is stiff. Matt Damon shows some soul in his acting, but not as always. The girl has "true grit" but sometimes her character is very annoying. In my humble opinion, The Coens must work hard to make a stand able comeback, as with "No Country For Old Men". Despite of this, "True Grit" will be a contender to the Oscars 2011, because we're all lost in this "mainstream" syndrome, that keeps us from voting remarkable movies, instead of LABELS. Attention! This is not a classic western for the future charts. It copies in a bad way many "a la John Wayne and Clint Eastwood" themes, but the problem is "blood simple": TRUE GRIT simply doesn't deliver a classic movie. It remains an above average film by the extraordinary (not this time) Coen Brothers. 6 out of 10.

This was a solid film. It truly felt like a western, while also having the comedic themes of a Coen's brother movie at the same time. Hailee Steinfeld at such a young age, set such a high bar to surpass with her performance as Mattie Ross. Jeff Bridges as a drunken U.S. Marshal was a perfect role. I never really think of Jeff Bridges as a western guy, but he fits in perfectly in this movie. The score was beautiful, as well the the production design recreating an old western town. The only issue is that they focused a lot on Josh Brolin's character, for him to not be in the movie that much. Lucky Ned seemed to be more of the main villain instead. Also, Jeff Bridges is a little hard to understand at times, but only a little. And, I didn't really care for the weird, possibly sexual chemistry between Steinfeld and Matt Damon. This movie got 10 Oscar nominations, and it at least deserved one, not the goose egg it received.

This is the 4th coen brothers film i'm watching. I watched 'Oh Brother where art thou?, Fargo, and Big Lebowski. i'm thinking of watching no country for old men. But why??? Because now i'm very interested in Westerns. At first i hated westerns such as Clint Eastwood movies and John Wayne movies. After i watched True Grit, i was shocked. It was one of the best movies i've seen this year. (it ties with inception) What i liked about this movie was the dialogue and the characters. Jeff Bridges was very good as Rooster Cogburne. Hailee Steinfeld was the best in this film. she should get an Oscar. Matt Damon was fantastic with his character design. Please watch this. This changed my mind of westerns. It has a lot of dialoge and talking... but i was never bored. I was surprised that it had Rated R violence but it was rated PG-13. Character: 10/10 Story: 9.5/10 Overall: 10/10

I found it very difficult to stay involved in this movie. I did manage to watch the entire thing (never could watch only part of a movie unless it was horridly bad) but I found other reasons to pause it for a bit that interested me more. I've always liked westerns and John Wayne's in particular. This was nothing like the John Wayne version of this film. I understand that this 2010 version was more derived from the original book but it was very dry and didn't have any entertaining value. The vernacular was also quite annoying to listen to. The original book may have been written with no contractions (that was the way books were written in that time) but people didn't normally talk that way. This was a very sad vehicle for some otherwise stellar actors and I'm surprised that the Cohen brothers felt it prudent to unleash the final product to the big screen. It did well at the box office but I'm sure that this was at the behest of some good PR work only. I would have been very disappointed had I payed the overinflated entrance fees demanded by theatres these days to see this movie.

Raised on westerns I love the John Wayne original. Kim Darby was under-appreciated and excelled in her part. The Original -- is a Western / Horse-Opera of singular significance.This 2010 edition is a Historical Costume Drama with slightly hyperbolic & overwrought dialog that, non-the-less, better characterizes the style of speech of the time -- IF you were to see a live performance on the stage of a playhouse -- instead of on the streets of a 's~~t-kicker'.No fault of the cast, here. Their diction, stilted, of the highly filigreed dialogue is fully of the time.Most viewers will scarcely recall the actors in their characters.Arguably John Wayne is too recognizable whereas Jeff Bridges looses himself in Rooster Cogburn. Maddy must be the character who sticks out like a sore thumb because that is the whole point.The lasting impression of the first version upon several viewings is that it is Kim Darby's Maddy who has 'true grit'.The lasting impression of the second edition is that many characters display 'true grit' -- it was, after all, a gritty time. This edition also features great incidental characters.The faithful details and production values of the costuming & set dressing are too well captured by the better technology and are, if anything, too bright & clear -- loosing some of the hard-fought-for realism.This would have been a ten in my estimation if the sound-scape had more ambient character in settings of exterior scenes and the too well lighted interiors of some scenes had revealed more dust motes and a more crepescular office interior in the stables scene.My guess is that the studio pressed for a shorter running time in the final edit which rushes the Last Act.This is one worth owning. As is the first one.

reviews.review_title: Shao Kahn would say " That was pathetic ! "
reviews.content: I first saw the original movie, from 1969.As Hollywood turned out to sacrifice any art and quality for money, I just knew it would be way superior to the new version.Boy, was I right...I often wanted to log in and rate remakes of movies, but this time, I did it.The movie misses key moments, and looks like a lousy resume of the original.The beginning tells the story with a couple of words, which is a joke.It does not show the little girl that is so familiar with money and acts like a grown man.The girl in the new movie is way inferior to the one in the original.When I saw it, I thought she deserved the Oscar too.The part where she complains about the meal and the room share that were too expensive, is missed in the new movie.Many crucial moments are brought together just to save about 20 minutes of the run time.WTF?! Jeff can never be compared to John Wayne, we all know that, but he acts like a street comedian.He does not play good even in the drunk moments.There are no sparks in his eyes, no enthusiasm in the stories he tells, nothing!Now, if I compare both movies frame by frame, I will end up taking all of the bandwidth.The music is also inferior to the original one, the new movie looks like some kind of a low-budget soap opera from South America.Even the shelter scene with the chimney is made like a telegram, asap.I quite laughed at the 10 star reviews, and I knew they were left by Americans.Poor people...Making a movie 40 years later, with way more potential effects, budget and actors, and yet it looks like a joke...

I ain't seen a western 'fore I set my eyes on this 'un. I must say it had some real grit. Some "True Grit". Story is of a darn feisty young'un with the name of Mattie Ross. Her pa was shot and killed by Tom Chaney, a runaway with a mission of not getting' caught. She hires a drunkard called Rooster to capture and come to see he being properly hanged. With the help of LaBoeuf, they go on a adventurous search fer this criminal. Jeff Bridges does a fine job as Rooster, as does Hailee Steinfeld in the role of Mattie. Only problem I found with this film was much of it was slower than molasses. It's not real easy to get thru at times. That being said, its not a bad movie and if you remain patient, I think you will come to enjoy it like I did.

reviews.review_title: The Coen brothers hit the spot with this meticulously crafted and beautifully shot return to the glory days of the Hollywood Western.
reviews.content: The Western as a genre has been conspicuous in its absence in the past decade or so. A few have been there or there abouts – 3:10 to Yuma springs to mind. A few have fallen drastically short of the mark – a preened Colin Farrell trying and failing to fill the spur jangling boots of Jesse James in American Outlaws (the less said about Wild Wild West the better). Audiences have been crying out for a good, ole fashioned, character driven Western simmering with suspense, dripping with macho charisma and parching the viewers' throats by virtue of dust coated, sun bleached backdrops. True Grit ticks all of the above boxes and that's before we even touch upon the cast. The film is based on 14-year-old farm girl Mattie Ross who, seeking retribution for her father's murder, enlists the help of the meanest gunslinger she can find. Here Jeff Bridges is superb as a gnarled, world-weary U.S. Marshall, his authentic graveled drawl and practised indifference hark back to the cowboy antiheroes of old. Over-enthusiastic Texas Ranger, Matt Damon is also pursing the fugitive outlaw Chaney (an all too short turn from up and coming Josh Brolin). Damon and Bridges bounce off each other to provide the other key ingredient to any classic Western – humour. Watching Ross marshal the lackadaisical bemused Bridges and vim filled Damon is genuinely funny, and on a regular basis. The trials and tribulations of this skilfully balanced trio culminate in a heart-pounding finale.For many that are familiar with the somewhat quirky nature of the Coen's work might not be suspecting such a straight and almost reverent treatment of the original 60s John Wayne classic. However it is exactly this that makes for a winning formula. The film relies on tidy screen writing, tight direction, compelling acting and literally jaw-droppingly beautiful, painstakingly detailed sets. It is no coincidence that these components provide such an effective and successful nostalgic comeback for the genre that once defined Hollywood.

It' such a great movie. I think that the actress that played Mattie is amazing especially when she was only 14. I should congratulate Hailee Steinfeld of making Mattie such a great and enjoyable character But i know that i'm 12 doen't mean i don't understand what's happening. I also know how to feel for the characters. I think that i like the 2010 version than the 1969, but that's my opinion. I know it's a re-make and people don't normally like re-makes, because they're classics. But i'm born in the 21st century which means i like more newer movies than older. That's all i need said also i know that i have wasted my time typing this BUT WHATEVER!!! IT'S NOT LIKE I CARE. ~kaikaiwolf322

One thing we can expect from a Coen brothers' movie is strong character building and performance. And True Grit does not disappoint at all. The characters are generally strong and feel unique. However, Mattie stands out on a shining pedestal. Her performance is strong and her character - although difficult to bring - very convincing. Notable too is the performance of Jeff Bridges, who succeeds in setting down true grit.A great movie, nice landscapes, nice historical research, but the story is surprisingly simple (nothing like Lebowski here) and predictable, and would not convince without good actor performances.If you liked the movie, you should read the western novel 'True Grit' by Charles Portis.

reviews.review_title: Not a 10 or even a 9 But Still a Great Movie and Story.
reviews.content: Not a 10 or even a 9 but the Coen brothers bring their superb touch to the remake. As a avid Western buff, I was very eager to see this film. I had seen the 1969 film in a tacky little theater in Virginia Beach 41 years ago. Nothing about this newer film is really better than the John Wayne version but it still holds up as a great and entertaining film.The two films very obviously have two different approaches to tell the story originally created by Charles Portis in the book. From a different beginning and a very different ending, we see that this is a story about Mattie and not Roster. Marshall Cogburn is very important but the story comes from the journals of Mattie Ross' life and not from Roster Cogburn. While watching the film I kept looking for a larger presence in the story from Cogburn and then realized that this was the greatest difference and the Cogburn character was not the driving force as in the first version 41 years ago. I believe it is because, as good as Jeff Bridges is, he is not and never will attain the stature John Wayne had achieved by the time he played this role. But because of that, it was more Cogburn and less Bridges.Better points include a more realistic age for the actor playing Mattie, a 14 year old girl. LeBoef is a more believable character, young and very dedicated to his calling. Maybe only a Texan can appreciate the difference between Matt Damon's and Glen Campbell's performance. The exchange with Col. G. Stonehill is better not having to play it around the persona of Strother Martin. It shows the intelligence and presence of mine that Mattie possessed.Points that were weaker include a very awkward LeBoef in his first conversation with Mattie. The obvious age difference sets this up. I was not convinced by Josh Brolin's portrayal of Chaney the murderer. Continuity errors are rampant as if the audience will believe in an 8 shot revolver or an amazing shrinking and growing rope.But never mind any of this, the movie is from the same book and this screenplay has less of a fairy tale ending than did movie made in 1969.

TRUE GRIT is a Coen Brothers re-make of the classic 1969 movie that starred John Wayne.In this new adaptation, Oscar winner JEFF BRIDGES (The Big Lebowski, TRON, Crazy Heart) takes the reins in the lead role of US Marshall Reuben J. "Rooster" Cogburn, an aging bad-tempered bully of a man, now well past his prime  who seems more interested in whisky than in law enforcement.Rooster's life is plodding along at his preferred languid, mellow pace until he is confronted by a 14 year old schoolgirl Mattie Ross (ably played by newcomer HAILEE STEINFELD), who hires him and then demands that he bring to justice Tom Chaney – a member of the "Lucky" Ned Pepper gang and the killer of her father. Mattie is very determined and gets her way to ride along with Rooster on his quest (much against his better judgement) Along for the ride, is US Texas Ranger LaBoeuf (played by MATT DAMON – The Bourne Trilogy, The Departed, The Talented Mr. Ripley) who is also after Tom Chaney – for the killing of a Senator up in Texas. The rest of the film is really about the adventure of the pursuit of the Lucky Ned Pepper gangAlthough some of the performances were good (noteably Hailee Steinfeld), I thought that Matt Damon in particular looked quite miscast – he really didn't look to comfortable or convincing in the role of LaBoeuf  and I got the feeling that the "baddies" just weren't bad enough  on occasion they were just too darn polite. I gather that Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld have been Oscar nominated for TRUE GRIT, I feel that might be a tad ambitious.I was looking forwards to TRUE GRIT, but I found that this film was an almost word for word remake, hardly anything was different to the original – no extra dimensions seemed to have been added or improved upon. On it's own merits as a standalone film, I would have scored TRUE GRIT higher, BUT – due to the fact that this is a re-make of an existing film classic – by the usually very talented Coen Brothers, I really don't believe that it added anything to the much better original – I am dropping the score slightly to 7/10.TRUE GRIT is 110mins long, is a PG-13 certificate and will be on general release from Friday 11th February 2011

reviews.review_title: Not nearly what it could have been.
reviews.content: A cruel bandit named Tom Chaney has recently murdered the father of a young girl named Mattie Ross. Chaney escaped the law and Mattie feels that he needs to be brought to justice. On her quest to find a bounty hunter she finds an aging drunkard named Rooster Cogburn who may be just what she needs.True Grit is not a bad movie by any means, it's actually a good movie, it's just a severely underachieving one. Considering that it was directed by the Coens, who are the best directors working today, and starred Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon it should have been an instant classic. What it turns out to be is an often touching sometimes exciting film that completely fizzles before it's over.All the acting is exceptional, especially the young Hailee Steinfeld who should have a bright cinematic future ahead of her. Many of the characters are quite endearing as well and you genuinely care what happens to them. And, as to be expected from the Coens, it is expertly directed, until the end at least.Now the bad news. A large portion of the movie is shown in the trailer and so many of the events, in an already somewhat predictable storyline, are known going in. The pace is out of whack. Most of the comedy is too silly for my taste and I found Jeff Bridges' character to be used as comedy relief a bit too often. The ending is also a major disappointment as it seems to happen far too quickly and it feels like there must be a missing reel somewhere.True Grit is an enjoyable movie that will likely please many audiences. I just find it to be very disappointing being such a huge Coen Brothers fan. They usually have a knack for making you think even if you don't particularly enjoy the subject matter or the movie itself. True Grit fails to make you think, but provides you with a mostly fun time at the theater.

reviews.review_title: Oh Coen Brothers Where Art Thou?
reviews.content: Perhaps the Coen brothers are trying to be literati these days. I almost walked out of "No Country for Old Men" in the last half, thinking the Coen brothers had creative differences. But no, they were sticking to Cormac McCarthy's novel. Same with this movie: many people say it sticks very close to the novel. My response? Who cares! It's a movie.This was no Fargo or Raising Arizona or anything--just a boring, unoriginal western. The first real scene with Rooster in the courtroom was boring and lacked real drama. Not even that humorous. But the directors spent a lot of time on that scene, which was useless. Then Mattie proves herself to be a hard-nosed negotiator with the town's merchant, in an amusing but also long-drawn out, and unrealistic scene. And how come we don't even see a photo of her father, or have any information about him other than he was a trader? How are we supposed to root for Mattie (who doesn't even show she misses her father that much)?The scene where she plunges into the river with her horse was supposed to be highly dramatic--but it too went on too long, and it was missing something. It's quite sad, esp. for the horse, that such a scene lacked real drama. The whole scene with finding the hanged man, cutting him down, and meeting up with the Bear Man dentist (the most Coen-like character in the entire film, but out of place), was also pointless. I just felt Rooster and Mattie were just sauntering around Indian country (where were the Indians, btw?) in an episodic way. Their horses were moving so slowly, I was wondering if finding Cheney was even their goal anymore, or was it to chew the cud and listen to Rooster talk about his ex-wives to Mattie (yawn)?Some real action happens in a log cabin, where Rooster almost gets Mattie killed telling her to get on the roof and drape a blanket over the chimney. But the motivations of the 2 rogues or their relationship with Cheney or his crew is not very clear. Finally, one of them dies with a shot leg, 4 fingers chopped off, and a knife through his chest, but while he's dying, he looks like he's just winded from a bench press workout--very unconvincing. Where's the coughing up of blood and trauma from such horrible wounds? Then, in a rather ridiculous scene, Damon's character LaBouef gets dragged around while Rooster picks off a few shots from a distance at night. They all get back together but admit they lost the trail, Mattie and LaBouef make up, he leaves, and then the next morning at the creek she actually runs into Cheney (a wasted Brolin). This scene is pretty Coen-like, since Cheney recognizes Mattie but does not believe her to be a threat, she fires at him but only nicks his rib. These actions are mirrored in Fargo, where the thieves come up next to the house but are not deemed a threat until they actually smash the glass, and also the shootings are messy and ill-aimed. Anyway, we come to the best part of the entire film: Barry Pepper's portrayal of an outlaw. His look, speech and mannerisms transport us back into the past. But he gets dispatched eventually by LaBoef's carbine, after another dramatic attempt by the Coen brothers to show Rooster charging the 4 outlaws with 2 six-guns, but the shots and action seem unsatisfying for some reason. Cheney (who shot Mattie's dad when Cheney was drunk) seems to be no more than an illiterate animal, not a trading partner the father would keep around him, and he hits LaBouef over the head with a huge rock (which would probably kill him) and unceremoniously gets shot off the cliff by Mattie, in a very unsatisfying ending to the revenge, which is the main plot line of this movie. She falls down a well and stirs up a rattlesnake nest in the ribcage of this dead man, gets bit on the hand, and Rooster rescues her, sucks the blood out of her hand, and rides like the wind for the doctor, killing her horse from the exhaustion. Years later we see Mattie grown up, trying to visit Rooster, only to learn of his death months prior. She is a spinster and visits his grave. The end.I'm not sure what the great appeal of this vehicle is for a Western, other than the novel concept of a young city-girl who hires a cantankerous sot who happens to be a deadshot (this too was ruined by the errancy of Rooster's shooting the bread, perhaps another Coen touch that diminishes the character unnecessarily) to find and bring to justice her father's killer. I expected more danger, more originality, with the quality of the directors and cast, and even a successfully proved plot. But the movie seems empty, and Rooster lacks charisma, and it seemed just like an episodic Western drama, with no real excitement or passion, except the very last scene when Rooster rides the horse all night to the doctors; that scene was the most dramatic and meaningful of the entire film. Many people have problems with Rooster's speech. I was baffled at this criticism, since most actors whisper these days, and that is why I need subtitles. But I didn't need subtitles here, even with Rooster's cant. And Mattie's speech was also a realistic touch by the Coen brothers to show that in the old West, people actually did have better vocabularies than we would expect, esp. if they come from cities. In the HBO series Deadwood, this type of speech, combining a genteel vernacular with Wild West terms, would seem to be proved. But still many people disliked her "fast, Shakespearian talk" which only shows they had no clue that the directors were going for realism in late 19th century American speech.

Best motion picture, best actor, best supporting actress, best director and best adapted screenplay winner at the Oscars. That tell you enough? I enjoyed this film, but like my opinion of "Unforgiven", this western also didn't feel like a "best picture" to me. Interesting of note is that Jeff Bridges won best actor for the remake of a 1969 John Wayne film that he (Wayne) also won the best actor award. So apparently if you want to win best actor, audition for the next remake of "True Grit". In 30 years. The acting was exceptional, save for Matt Damon who is still good, I just didn't buy into his characterization. The panoramas of the old west are beautiful (and all locations are actually in the USA), the score is majestic and of course the story is captivating. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A great epic film made by 2 great filmmakers
reviews.content: A truly epic beautiful western. The Coen brothers had me with blood simple. Fargo is one of the best 100 movies of all time. Their genius is making a WESTERN whose time has come and gone into a magnificent WESTERN. The Coen Brothers have shown that they can take any subject or genre and make it into a great movie. They surpass themselves in this film. It is epic and the photography is superlative in color so artful that they bring to life the vistas of the west. The film is much closer to the book, unlike the 1969 film. I was never a big fan of John Wayne because all he did in each film was play John Wayne. Jeff Bridges IS the person he plays in all of his movies. He is the new kind of modern actor who are portrayed as real people rather than as film stars. Matt Damon has quietly become one of the most outstanding actors on screen. My wife and I hardly recognized him at first and his performance was miles ahead of Glenn Campbell in the old movie. Subtle and spot on. The young woman was great though too clean for a woman (girl) of the old west. (a minor Quibble) I admire greatly Josh Brolin who is not only a fine actor but takes on what is really just a Cameo role. The picture, though epic in scope, is tightly filmed and enjoyable in each segment. Oscars ALL AROUND!!

I'm a big fan of the Coens and this latest entry does not disappoint. Fabulous visuals, dialog, music, acting, screen play and directing makes this a winner across the board. If you are a fan of classic western fare this should be a must see for you. Star power abounds throughout with the highest grade to Jeff Bridges who adds yet another notch to his butt stock of acting diversity. "The Dude" is truly an American icon with a body of work that puts him in a class with the likes of DeNiro, Hoffman, Pacino and few others. No high power ending in this film, but it is consistent with the Coen's style and the film in general. I saw it on its opening day as well as later at the $2. theater and thoroughly enjoyed it both times. Good show, see it ! ......8.5

reviews.review_title: An ok western with some good performances!!!
reviews.content:
I can't say too much about this western without spoiling anything.
All i can say is that it is a visually goodlooking movie with some great performances from Jeff Bridges and the female lead.
Other than that, it is a pretty boring movie but a very average western.
I don't understand why it was nominated for so many awards.
Don't get me wrong, its not a bad movie but it isn't anything that special.
I see reviews that give it 10/10 but thats hardly the case here.
Only a 6/10 for me i am afraid.

reviews.review_title: A movie that should never have been made!
reviews.content: Boring, boring, boring. Movie's are an art form and as such should be treated with more respect, in particular those movies that are perfect in every way, such as the original True Grit with John Wayne. To remake this movie is like trying to supplant Leonardo Da Vinci's Mona Lisa with a new painting with Mona in modern dress. Most of the dialogue in the new true grit is the same as the old. However John Wayne's delivery of these great lines was funny and touching, while Jeff Bridges are incomprehensible at times and not funny in the least. It's amazing that Hollywood is running out of ideas for movies and doing all these remakes lately, while TV seems to be blossoming with great stories such as Spartacus:Blood & Sand, Boardwalk Empire, Deadwood, and many many more. I've read many many good books that have yet to be made into movies. Where are all the great screen plays of these books. Hollywood if you want to make remakes, make them for movies that originally sucked. I'll give you a good example, "The Keep" was a fantastic book but the movie sucked badly. Peter Sellers must be rolling over in his grave to think that his Inspector Clouseau movies are being remade. It's Blasphemi!!!!

The Coen Brothers films are all great, and for those who prefer their more "satisfying" films, this one, while not at all syrupy or overly sentimental, certainly fits the bill. This film will be remembered years hence as one of the great westerns. I never felt I was watching a remake. I never had the feeling it made any cheesy references, or tried to be anything other than the best possible film portrayal of the original material from the novel by Charles Portis, and it achieves that goal with superior excellence.The performances are all quite incredible, Jeff Bridges should win another Oscar for best actor, and Matt Damon for supporting. Of course the sensational Hailee Steinfeld steals the show with an incredibly touching performance as the spunky, smart, capable young Mattie Ross, forging her way in a man's world in order to avenge her father's murder. If she is not at least nominated for best supporting actress it would be a shame. A perfect balance of humor, realism, suspense and action make this an all around crowd pleaser. Although there is no overt romance, Mattie's innocence, pluck and verve in a world of dark forces provide a romantic quality of good vs. evil that is stunning to behold, and is felt deeply. Of course as an old timer myself, who remembers well the original film version with the great John Wayne, I can say this film is a perfect addition to the record, and somehow pays tribute to the old master without trivializing or even giving a conscious nod. The fact that the film was done in the western tradition, and done so well, is the best tribute one could hope for to Wayne. And Mr. Bridges does that as perfectly and masterfully as could be expected from any actor on Earth. This highly entertaining film carries its own weight and carries one along in its story with such force that conscious comparisons and critiques to the original are all but forgotten while viewing. But too many comparisons are burdensome, and this film stands completely on its own. This is a wonderfully made film, truly "The Perfect Movie" and perfect for the holidays to leave audiences satisfied and yet longing for the day when men and women may act again with honor and True Grit.

I just read the book, True Grit, by Charles Portis and was intrigued to rewatch this movie. Much of the dialogue is word for word from the book, which makes it so much more of a true representation. There is a slight deviation in LaBeouf's storyline from the book, which I don't particularly love. Overall, it conveys the same message as the book in an emotional and not over the top way.

Wow! I was swayed by the massively good reviews of this movie. The other reviews are overstated! The original was an ORDER OF MAGNITUDE better than the remake. In fact, Josh Brolin more or less screwed up the classic character of Rooster Cogburn.Sorry, it blows.Adding Line for length Adding Line for Length Adding Line for Length Adding Line for Length. Adding Line for Length. Adding Line for Length. Adding LIne for Length. Adding Line for Length. Addming Line for Levant Adding LIne for length Ladding Line for length Jesus Christ they make it hard to write a concise opinion of a movie. I'm just adding words so that my review is done.

reviews.review_title: Excellent and much closer to the book
reviews.content: The new True Grit film is a must see! Despite bring reluctant to go to see a remake, I was pleasantly impressed by this one. Jeff Bridges puts his own style on Rooster Cogburn and Hailee Steinfeld is a young actress to watch out for; it is rare to see such a young actress who can act with her face, gesture and words together.The location filming was superb and whoever chose the locations should receive an award.Happily, the iconic Rooster-versus-4-bad-guys scene has been included in the remake. I would have been disappointed had it not.The ending... was... sad...

I really wanted to like this movie and give it a chance. The original, while suffering from Glenn Campbell's incerdibly bad acting, and the miscast Kim Darby, is a western classic. This re-make doesn't know if it wants to stay true to the original, or wonder off into head scratching territory? The acting was just plain bad like the whole cast agreed to make this movie for a paycheck.Why does Hollywood think every classic needs a re-make? I can't think of one that actually surpasses the original, and this movie proves that true. Get the original, get some popcorn and watch the Duke at his best in the original True Grit.

Don't get me wrong, the movie wasn't total garbage. I love Jeff Bridges as well as the Cohens. Even Brad Pitt, especially in some of his older roles. However, as I stood up at the end of the film; all I could think was that I probably would have enjoyed and appreciated the story an awful lot more if I had read the book this movie was based on. The trailers as well as release date had struck me as one of those yearly time-killers for families with not much to do on Christmas day. Evidently, I was right.I think my main issue here is the last few scenes in the movie. Just as you finally get to know the characters, it's all over. If this movie were one of those literary triangles the teachers made us draw in middle school English it would be exposition, climax, resolution.It felt like the movie spent a lot of time explaining the situation and setting up your feelings towards each character only to give you ten minutes of an actual story.Plus Jeff Bridges stabs a pony.

reviews.review_title: Get reacquainted with some old friends in a new way
reviews.content: Excellent! It's NOT a remake of the 1969 movie, but a 2nd movie based on the novel. Same story & characters, but much better cinematography, music (reminiscent of Ken Burn's "Civil War"), and apart from the uniqueness of John Wayne, much better acting. Great cast! The Cohen brothers remain faithful to the novel, as the 1st movie pretty much did; nothing wacky or added just for effect - but you do get an authentic 1880s experience - attire, speech, attitudes, etc. I really enjoyed this classic visit to the Old West and being reacquainted with some old friends in a new way. If you like westerns, a good story, and great characters, you'll love this telling of "True Grit".

I thought this was entertaining, but I don't see what all the hoopla is about. The story moves rather slowly, and takes quite some time to pick up steam. Now, obviously this is not an action film for the most part, but the problem is there seems to be a lot of dead time and space with not a whole lot going on. Once it finally gets going, it gets a bit more interesting.The acting is overall pretty good from the girl to Matt Damon. Jeff Bridges isn't bad, but I'm just not a big fan of his in general. I mean, Bridges is the Big Lebowski after all, but it seems like a little of the Lebowski comes out in all of his characters (this one included) even where the big lebowski is not called for. Matt Damon does a pretty solid job overall to the point that you forget you are even watching him. I thought the ending was terrible and random, which is typical of the Coen brothers even though this is a remake. For me, this was watchable, but not great.

The Coen brothers have hit a home run with this film. In my fifty-eight years, I've seen many westerns. I was a boy when westerns were 80% of everything seen on television and at the theater. I was raised on John Wayne. So, my apologies, Duke. This True Grit is a better True Grit. And here's why: This film is faithful to the original story by Charles Portis. Those, on this site and others, who criticize its dialogue should read the book. It takes little imagination to appreciate the disparity in the education (and vocabulary) that surely existed in the American West of the mid-nineteenth century. This phrasing, along with the Coen brothers' obsessive attention to detail give this film an authenticity and believability I've not seen before in any western.The acting of, then thirteen-year-old, Hailee Steinfeld is simply amazing. Already nominated for two awards for her role as Mattie Ross, I'm predicting an Oscar nomination for her performance. I recently saw an interview with this young lady and I found myself stunned at the differences between the actor and the character she played. Ms. Steinfeld's demeanor, voice inflections, posture, and facial features are nothing like the character she portrayed. To see such sagacity in a young actor is astounding and rare.There aren't enough acclamations for the cinematography of Roger Deakins. Its magical yet realistic beauty pops from the screen like a Rembrandt masterpiece. Known for his work on such classics as The Shawshank Redemption, Fargo, No Country for Old Men and A Beautiful Mind, True Grit is his best work to date and an Oscar nod may be in his future as well.For those who don't like remakes of truly great films, please consider this: There is nearly a half century between the two films. With the possible exception of 'A Farewell to Arms,' and films that were originally foreign, I find it hard to cite a remake I like better than the original. True Grit has to be one of them.

reviews.review_title: If you can't make it better, don't do it
reviews.content: I am a Jeff Bridges fan but this movie was just awful. They should truly know better than to try and remake classics, unless they're just going to be CLEARLY better. What's next, a remake of Casablanca? Matt Damon's performance was the only thing worth watching. Bridges' performance was just pushed and strained. I suspect he can play a pretty good drunk. Why did he have to push it so ridiculously over the top. The ending was rather ridiculous as well. In the original, the loss of the Texas ranger was heartbreaking (which is fine in movies), but flash-forward and show her without an arm? Please, that just turns my stomach. Also, you followed a great deal of the script verbatim, but you cut out many of the best lines. Cogburn to Leboeuf about Mattie getting a whipping, "LaBoeuf. Put it down, I said. You're enjoying it too much." Cogburn about the death of the ranger, "That Texican saved my neck twice. Once after he was dead." Also, what's the deal with alternating between using contractions and not using them. My gosh, either get it right or don't do it. It was just annoying the way you did it. It's just (suppose to be) a good movie, not an historical documentary.If you're a Jeff Bridges fan, and want to stay that way, skip this one. Both my wife and I felt that we had wasted the $3.95 Amazon fee and also 1.5 hours of our life. I actually don't believe that the original was John Wayne's best performance, but it was quite good. However, this remake does nothing but show how hopelessly out of ideas the movie industry truly is, and how they are abusing us with cheap tricks to sell a few movie tickets. If they keep this up, they will truly eventually wreck the excitement of going to the movies.

Hands down my favorite movie to date! Would give it a 12 million out of 10 if the scroll option would allow it!A Classic Western story retold by a group of some of the most renowned cast and crew of this century. Roger Deakins (who is one of my favorite cinematographers) exceeds to portray both the beauty of the land and the character's emotions. The beauty of the land is represented in the film by capturing the colors and openness of the western world, the huge mountains, and large landscapes. Tom Chaney's character emotion is fantastically portrayed towards the end when he is fed up with Mattie Ross. There is a low shot when he is sitting down and he slowing tilts his head up and says, "I don't need no affidavit, all I need is your silence". The way Roger had that lit from a low angle made the audience understand the frustration and anger that Chaney was feeling.Oh, and the music! Carter Burwell excelled at making each song fit so well into the scene in which it was playing. It help tie into not only the part of the plot in which was unravelling, but also subtly tied into the characters emotions too!

reviews.review_title: Very strong performances by Bridges, Damon, and Steinfield...but a very slow, simple, and boring story
reviews.content: I must first admit that I have never seen the original 1969 version starring John Wayne, so I can't compare this film with that on any level. I just read all the rave reviews from this film on Metacritic and Rotten Tomatoes, and considering all the greatness the Coen Brothers usually churn out when they make films, I decided to see this with my dad today. I also know that this was picked as one of the Top 10 Films of the Year by the American Film Institute, and I usually agree with their picks when it comes to rating films as well.First and foremost, this film is extremely well-acted by all of its principal actors, most notably Jeff Bridges, who once again has lots of fun creating a roguish, partially insane, quirky character and look. Bridges also supplies much of the comic relief in the film will all his strange antics and attitude. Damon is also strong in his very limited role. His character isn't developed very much, but he delivers his lines well when he gets his close-ups. Steinfield is also solid, as the whole film rests on her shoulders, and she allows us to see a strong and stubborn teen girl who refuses to see herself as a weak, 2nd-class citizen of the time period. The character actor who plays the horse trader at the beginning is also funny and spot on, as well as the lawyer in the courtroom interrogating Bridges, and Barry Pepper as one of Cogburn's formers gangleaders. Most of this film is all about the acting and characterizations of everyone involved, and the film succeeds on that level. This is why I am giving it a fairly decent rating overall.However, at the same time I found the story to be painfully slow and far too simple for my tastes. Perhaps this is because this original was a family-oriented, PG-rated film when it was released in 1969, and it is told from a 14-year old's point of view, so considering that fact, it couldn't a be a more complex story with more plotting. It was almost something in the same vein as Disney or Little House on the Prairie, with some Coen Brothers violence added in sporadically, but still such a sweet and simple story without complexity. I'm all for character development over action scenes and such, but this move simply had too much character development in my opinion, as the first 80 minutes is just conversations and talking while slowly riding horses, without any suspense at all. Literally nothing compelling or engaging is happening on a plot level until the very end when they meet Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin - decent, but not given any screen time to do anything substantial). The film just plods along showing off the beautiful scenery in the background with characters talking and talking / exposition, etc. - but the Coens seriously needed an editor to cut some of the talking down. It's just talking withot advancing the story. I personally loved all the dialogue and talking in "The Social Network" - but in that movie the dialogue was always moving the story forward, and that was a more complex story. Here the movie just doesn't go anywhere until the last 15 minutes. They should have had some Indian tribes surprise them with shootout / attacks in the middle of the film a couple of times or something just to add some suspense and energy to the story. It was just way too simple and straightforward for my tastes. I prefer more complex plots that require more characters, more plot strands, and move at a faster pace. This just didn't challenge me or interest me intellectually - but I suppose that's how lots of Westerns are. Just shoot em ups scripts with good guys and bad guys, which is just boring for me. Again, the performances by the 3 leads are great, but I just wish the story had been more interesting and engaging.

Any doubts I had going into this film, because it is a remake, were completely blown away within the first five minutes. The directing is, once again, phenomenal. The Coen brothers definitely did not disappoint. The film is a true western, perhaps even 'grittier' than many of the classics my father made me watch over and over as a kid. As with many of the Coens' films, they're attention to detail of the setting is incredible. Despite this, the thing in this film that will be talked about is the acting. It's amazing to say the least. To those of you out there, like me, with a case of nostalgia who are worried about Jeff Bridges not being able pull off John Wayne's "Rooster Cogburn" there is no need to fear. Jeff Bridges not only 'pulls it off' but makes it his own. This is Jeff Bridges' "Rooster Cogburn," and it's equally great in its own way. The rest of the cast from Damon to Steinfeld to Brolin is nothing to skip over in a review. They did a fantastic job, especially young Steinfeld who really impressed me. I can't imagine the pressure of being the lead in a Coen film at that young of an age, and yet she takes it in stride. In the end, you can not go wrong seeing this film. Though not as satirical as some of the Coens' other films, it is nothing short of fantastic and should not be overlooked this holiday season.

So much better than the original. Jeff Bridges starts out good and continues to get better throughout the film - the gravely voiced, cantankerous bastard of a marshal who does what is necessary, when it is necessary, because it is necessary.
