Certainly worthy of an Oscar nomination (but, most likely, not a win).Matt Damon is the perfect foil/partner to the Marshal - a fop of the first order, yet magnificently duty bound.Josh Brolin does a nice turn as the target of the manhunt - a bit dim witted; but, uncaringly evil.Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie, performs as an equal to Bridges here. Her performance elicits the best out of whichever cast member she is playing against. Could be a long shot winner here, but probably not - too many other strong women this year.The script adds volumes to the characters - truly, a work of art; without which, no amount of acting could have raised this film to this level.Direction, scenery, pacing - all excellent.A good film to see even if you don't like westerns.

It has to be said that I am not a huge fan of American movies as I often find them to be self-indulgent and biased. I am however a huge fan of both Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon, and the performances offered up here were sublime. Jeff Bridges was brilliant, and perhaps his best performance to date. It was a true pleasure to watch his character develop from the morally questionable and jaded lawman to the necessary hero of what is portrayed as a very wild frontier. I loved the way the movie alters your perception of the character without actually changing the character completely. Damon was equally good, and it was good to see him playing a role outside of his usual 'government agent' alter-ego. So, the film in the round? Captivating, gripping, extremely well written and the musical score was perfect for the mood of the film. The sets were excellent and the huge vistas really helped to describe a vast country that is almost impossible to grasp by modern city dwellers. Now I said that I am not a fan of American movies, and I am absolutely not a fan of westerns, but this film was enough to cause me to reconsider. I wont compare it to the original, but it is a fantastic movie and well worth watching (even if you don't like westerns). I definitely will watch this again, and maybe even again after that. Bravo.

It's remarkable movie and not typical for the Coen brothers, in my glance. This time they brilliantly made the classic Western movie and else with Jeff "Big Lebowski" Bridges. It's very huge gift for me because I'm big fan of the brothers Coen, Jeff Bridges and "Big Lebowski" is one of my favorite film. In the "True Grit" there is everything what I love in Western movies and even more, interesting plot, charismatic characters, good guys and bad guys, shooting, rivers of rum and whiskey, adventures and terrific acting cast from thick and mustached Matt Damon, brutal Josh Brolin, unrecognizable Barry Pepper and very talented the little star Hailee Steinfeld. I got the delight with that film and recommend its everybody who likes stories about true men.

First of all, i would like to say that the performances of all the actors involved were flawless. Especially Jeff Bridges, Hailee Steinfield and Matt Damon who i must say i preferred to Glenn Campbell in the original, but why waste such top talent in remaking a classic. O.k, they kept to the original book, by starting the film with Mattie telling the story as an old lady, but basically it was almost word for word as the original. The shootout between Coogburn and Ned Pepper was not a patch on the John Wayne film for excitement. Remember Wayne twirling that rifle around one handed. Yes, i know John Wayne had a special handle put on the rifle so he could do that, but as i have stated in some of my other reviews, that was what going to the cinema was all about. Watching something and someone that is larger than life. Also the one thing that was missing, which i think is important in any film was first, a good supporting musical score. In the original, after Mattie was bitten by the snake and Coogburn put her on Blackie the horse and then rode like hell to get her to a doctor, there was a good score by Elmer Bernstein, giving the scene more effect and secondly there was hardly any humor. In the original you had a side story of Coogburn's relationship with his servant Chen Lee and a cat named General Sterling Price. As i have said, as a movie it is good in it's own right but why waste time, talent and money on remakes. Kevin Thomas.

reviews.review_title: A great way to close off 2010
reviews.content: True Grit is a well timed incarnation into the Western genre and a worthy remake of a classic. Performances by the three lead protagonists were excellent, especially by the very likable and relatively unheard of, Hailee Steinfeld. Oozing with typical Coen flare, set pieces in this film were beautifully shot. The dialogue was compellingly heavy and at times genuinely funny so come into the theatre prepared to do some listening.I would highly recommend this film to Western fans and to all those who need a break from all of the 3D films being churned out. There is a distinct lack of action for two thirds of the 111 minute film, as should be expected in a movie from these directors. Though, slower paced than your average tale of justice it definitely didn't lack emotion.True Grit is highly commendable and should be on your list of films to see before the year ends.10/10

reviews.review_title: Glad I used a movie pass
reviews.content: I expected that this movie would be great, instead I got an average, overplayed, and drawn out western. The only star of this is Hailee Steinfeld, who easily defeats anyone who tries to stop her with a sharp tongue. Rather than try to incorporate some teenage girl features, the script and directors stick her in a tomboy role. Granted this is a girl who is asked to grow up rather quickly, but no one takes on that persona in a few days. Having been a fan of Bridges for years, I expected better than this from a guy who made White Russians famous. Bridges can be funny at times, but that almost makes up for the fact that it's hard to take him serious. A federal marshal with a drinking problem and who somehow is still employed and a good shot. Gene Wilder's character in Blazing Saddles was more believable than Bridge's and the Coen's Cogburn. The climatic fight scene is laughable at best according to this historian (me). Cogburn's speech would have been interrupted with the sound of gunshots. No one in that time period would have sat and listened to some guy tell them why he was going to shoot them. Then the fight begins and Cogburn somehow escapes with two minor wounds...are you kidding me? Four guys and the most they can inflict on one target is two minor wounds. Keep in mind these are outlaws, who live and die by their guns. Then as Pepper swings around to blow Cogburn's brains onto the dry landscape, La Boeuf comes up with a miraculous shot to save a guy he hated only a day ago. I hate to spoil the enjoyment, but this is pure Hollywood story telling as far as that shot goes. La Boeuf is somehow able to hit a guy in the head from 400 yards away with a gun who's effective range maxes out at 500 yards. For comparison purposes that's like hitting a pencil eraser from 50 yards or so away. Last but not least, is Brolin's Chaney. The audience hates him for killing Mattie's father, but since we're not introduced to him until last quarter of the film we're breathing a sigh of relief that the end must be near. La Boeuf claims Chaney puts on a dim witted act in order to gain peoples' trust easier, yet Brolin apparently decided to make Chaney mentally handicapped or so it appears. Of course, this maybe why Chaney when confronted by Mattie with a pistol in hand tells her the gun isn't cocked all the way back. Chaney also happens to have a rifle on him, which he only uses as a crutch after getting shot by Mattie. I can't decide which would be worse; getting killed by a 14 year old girl while armed with a rifle or killing a 14 year old girl that's hunted you down. Either way you look like an idiot and Chaney succeeds at almost accomplishing both scenarios. I find it laughable that Pepper would decide to leave Mattie in the care of Chaney while moving to a new hideout. Geez, Pepper thanks for setting up the next part of the story for us. A lot of reviewers have raved about the cinematography of this film and in some respects it's good. The negative is that it all looks like the exact same landscape. While traveling on the prairies of western Kansas, you're likely to find different landscapes and habitats in only a short distance. The western town isn't anything too spectacular, although it might be a little too clean. The thing people forget about the west is that people tossed garbage, raw sewage, and everything else in the road. Of course it would rain on occasion and you'd get a nasty blend of all those things plus any animal droppings from the various animals that were led through towns. Sanitation did not exist and people were lucky if they did not get sick from the diseases that lived among the filth.Overall this film goes too long and can be laughable at times due to the various impractical scenarios that the audience is led to believe. Once again though Hailee Steinfeld is an up and coming actress to be reckoned with if she can successfully transfer the energy she brought to this film to other roles.

This is a fairly straight forward telling of the story by the Coen Brothers. And that's what makes it a bit on the disappointing side. There was certainly the Coen humor present and a few interesting visual twists, but for the most part, this lacked the Coen Brothers typical M.O. of taking material and twisting it inside out, whether it be their own or not (No Country For Old Men). In the past, there have always been cinematic and story-telling surprises around every corner. Not here. For much of the movie, this could have been done by any decent story-teller of a director. I expect more from the Coens. It was almost coasting for them. My wife, in agreement, said that it seemed as though they were fulfilling a contractual commitment to a studio.

Saw True Grit on Wednesday. I was surprised with just how good the film was.Haven't read the book that both this film and the 1969 version were based on, but this film version seems to be a fuller, more believable account. I absolutely did not recognize Matt Damon as Texas Ranger LaBoeuf! Of course many scenes are shared with the 1969 version and the film includes the classic "Fill your hands you son of a bitch!" line from Rooster Cogburn.I read somewhere, and I think it's true, that a big difference between this and the earlier version is that the focus on the story is firmly on Matty Ross, not Cogburn, who though a major character, is a supporting one. Some elements are entirely different. For example, in the 1969 version, after threatening everyone and sundry with her lawyer, we finally get to see him and discover him to be a short weedy man with a high pitched voice! There's a good reason that never happens in this version, but I won't spoil this for you. Suffice it to say that scenes towards the end of the film reminded me of certain French films, and are better for that. More like "Dead Man" and "The Grey Fox" than the previous film, which is a GOOD THING.

Before I say anything else, let me say this: I am a big John Wayne fan, and I loved the original when I saw it as a child. Needless to say, I went to this movie expecting to be let down and underwhelmed by the remake, but held out hope since it was a Coen Bros. project and they usually produce good films. I was surprised. This is an outstanding movie that now has become one of my favorite westerns, right up there with Unforgiven and Tombstone. I have never read the book upon which both films are based, but I imagine this version follows it more closely. The story is far richer, and the characters are given greater depth. Jeff Bridges does an excellent job filling the very big shoes of John Wayne in his famous portrayal of Rooster Cogburn. In fact, I dare to say he is even better in the role! Matt Damon plays Texas Ranger LaBeouf, and is perfect. Barry Pepper plays Lucky Ned Pepper and even looks a little like Robert Duvall in the role. But the real star of the film, and the person around whom the story revolves is Mattie Ross, who is played with Oscar-worthy depth and skill by the unknown actress Hailee Steinfeld. I'd never heard of her before this film, and I doubt the Academy will recognize her for her work because she is so young, but this young lady really impressed me. I expect to see much more from her after this movie. You will leave the theater a little sad, but the film offers plenty of laughs just like the original. LOVED IT!

reviews.review_title: Sad effort in a hitherto great resume.
reviews.content: GWTW, On The Waterfront,Bridge on The River Kwai, Zhivago, Ben-Hur, The Family Way, Butch, The Graduate, Midnight Cowboy, Fargo, No Country for Old Men. What a quality list of superlative films.(My opinion.) Shame on the Coens for this mumbling mess. Pity the fine actors who fell for this con. Too much admiration for these guys apparently leads to "we can do wrong". Sympathy for the cast. Good fortune to the talented young ingenue, in fact well done actors all round. Spin the bottle again, lads. Be original, as you used to be. Don't do this again - it was awful. Even the effing horse died. That is when I finally gave up. Lovely cinematography when you guys played it for real. This mess was not worthy of your gifts. Go back to thinking for yourselves. We know you come from Minnesota but that is not your fault. (Joke.)

reviews.review_title: Tedious and boring to sit through
reviews.content: I don't usually bother to use my time to place my feelings out there with the rest of humanity on cinematic productions that are so widely reviewed with so many differing opinions but this film looked to be a great days entertainment by seeing so many agreeable reviews about it but alas!I was cheated out of my ticket money with a soggy screen play that seemed like a poor try at working up something new for an audience that is lost in a mire of horrible blood,guts,violent and relentless marijuana laced crime and vampire movies and a pretty teenage wooden girl actress who looked and sounded as if she were on the wrong set. I couldn't believe my eyes and ears. No beautiful soundtrack to serve as a plus to the visual grandeur the movie was depicting which sometimes can make me sit still for an otherwise, boring flick! I see the good reviews for this rotten tomato were, saying it was really close to the written word so maybe that,was the underlying respect for this clunker that was needed to feel the true beauty for the film. My 70 year old woman friend date liked it,and I am also 70 and lived a lifetime of love for the cinema, give me stereo, wide screen,3-D and the works!The Father of 2 sitting on our left side liked it also he said, so it looks like one will either love or hate it but the Reviewer that has said it best for my taste is Rex Reed: December 14, 2010 New York Observer.

Probably one of the 10 best movies I have ever seen. The images, the dialog and the characters are flawless. Far better the the John Wayne version, I am afraid. The beauty of this movie will transport and transfix you as very few films can. I felt as though I was witnessing actual events in the American frontier in real time. The composition of the shots is stunning. The natural beauty of the setting is breathtaking. Though there is violence, the film is a welcome anachronism in the sense that there is no foul language or sexual innuendo for a 2010 film, and thus one could easily recommend this as a family-friendly movie. If only the film industry could equal this stunning creation more often! This lost the Best Picture Oscar to a movie about - victory over stuttering?Incidentally, this film makes use of that wonderful old hymn, "Leaning on the Everlasting Arms," which is also featured in another of my all-time favorites, "The Night of the Hunter."

reviews.review_title: Shallow, business-like roles and unimpressive storytelling
reviews.content: True Grit was an attempt by the Coen Brothers, who are known for their postmodern takes in their movies, to make a postmodern Western. They partially succeed in bringing in some postmodern elements, but ultimately, as with many of the recent Coen Brothers movies, the movie fails to deliver.The first thing that stood out to me in the course of this movie was the unemotional and shallow characters. Who, in real life, can be so unemotional and even if we accept that this is "just a movie", why would anyone think that such unemotional and shallow characters would hold any appeal to any audience? In any case, the Coen brothers thought so and in doing so, make a muck out of what could have been a potentially interesting social drama set in a Western setting.Now, we come to know by the first few minutes of his screen time that the main character, the anti-hero, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) is a very nasty sort of bloke who routinely makes his unpleasantness known. In my opinion, Jeff Bridges does his best to make good out of an exceptionally shallow role. In one of the scenes, Cogburn kicks two Native American children who are sitting outside a cottage, thereby showing that he is a racist in addition to being a generally nasty person.The other main character was Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld), who fills the role of a very business-like and again, unemotional, child protagonist. We rarely come across children who behave in such a manner as Mattie does in this role and even if we did, we can be sure that such a child is suffering from some kind of a social disorder. So much for my pop philosophy. At any rate, Steinfeld again tries to make the best out of a bad situation, but thanks to the nature of the role, ends up again being too artificial to be even fictionally appealing (for an element of realism is always an important element of fiction).After mostly boring and shallow performances however, the scenic settings and the action in some of the scenes form a sort of saving grace. In the end, the movie ends pretty abruptly and we never see any conclusive end to the story as such. Who knows? Maybe in trying to be as shallow as possible, the story unconsciously finds itself reflecting an aspect of reality where many of real human relationships remain unfulfilled and inconclusive at the end.

Many people will give this movie excellent ratings because they like the Coen Brothers or Jeff Bridges. I liked the movie, but it definitely had flaws. The dialogue was very stilted and took away from the characters. It made sense for the precocious girl to speak in this manner, but not anyone else. The criminals with a third grade education spoke as if they were in the middle of a Shakespeare Western. It is too bad, because Bridges is good as is the young woman.Overall a disappointment. It was merely an average movie with a genre rarely made anymore. It could have been so much better. The story line was excellent as was the suspense. I believe that if this movie were made with unknown actors or director that this could have been a made for TV (cable of course) movie.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of 2010
reviews.content: This is not the 1969 classic starring John Wayne. Much like the Tim Burton version of Charlie and The Chocolate Factory it is it's own film Everyone in the film is at the top of their game. There is not a single bad performance in the film.Jeff Bridges shines as Rooster Cogburn. In the original we could tell it was Wayne. Here, we see nothing of Bridges.For it being Hallie Steinfield's first film she is phenomenal and has just as much screen presence as Bridges.After he got away from the Bourne films Matt Damon has consistently impressed me. His performance in this film is no exception playing the exact 180 of Rooster Cogburn.Josh Brolin, despite only appearing in about ten minutes of the film, gives a great interpretation of the film's villain. More of a wet dog than an immediately noticeable threat but is just as willing to kill Mattie Ross as he is anyone else The cinematography is, in many ways, exquisite. There is one shot in particular where Cogburn, trying to show his skills at shooting throws a biscuit in the air and fires. The angle chosen is a highly interesting one The film is rich in humor and smart dialogue. Exactly what one would expect from a Coen Brothers film.Try to remember that the original will always be there. This film does not change that

This is a fairly good film. Not the best Coen film but really well done nonetheless. True Grit is never the first thought when the talent involved in this picture is ever discussed elsewhere. But it is sincere and well executed; Steinfeld gives a career making performance (if any stands out she does bc of the script) and without a doubt was excellent. The dialogue is sparse, sometimes to the detriment of the story. Some lines seem muddled or unclear. I don't know if the sound was off or the style of the editing. I'm not a technical guy but something seems unmixed properly. The sound design is off but I digress, It's just not the definitive. Even by western standards; 3:10 for Yuma's remake for example is more gritty. True Grit has genuine heart though if that piqué's anyone's interest. Every aspect of this film is well crafted. The action is tight. Some day when looked back on the only defining aspect of this film will be Steinfeld. The Coens have down better work, as well as Damon and Bridges. Pepper (supporting) and Steinfeld (starring) were the best acting wise in the end. Ironic bc Pepper filled his performance with realism unlike Brolin unfortunately. Pepper feels of the period, Brolin feels like a star cameo on a tv show, I feel it was the only casting that was interchangeable and could have been filled by any number of character actors. Bill Paxton in the eighties woulda crushed that role. Brolin plays it very surface level, no depth. The film is immersive though I will give it that as stated lots of heart. But also immersive in the unfortunate sense that because you as the audience have to interpret and train your ear for the dialogue.

reviews.review_title: True Grit versus the real True Grit
reviews.content: While I enjoy Jeff Bridges, he IS NO JOHN WAYNE! His version of True Grit was admirably done but I suppose there is no real way to measure up to the original, is there? While watching both and keeping an open mind, I still come away as forever a fan of John Wayne's version. Some of the scenes in Jeff Bridges version were over the top, like watching a Rob Zombie movie. John Wayne's screen presence was enough to sell the character of Rooster Cogburn and he didn't need all of the extra graphic language and gore to show that he was one tough son of a b****! The only way to describe the real True Grit with John Wayne is that it was everything a movie could want, a believable plot and not a lot of garbage and distractions inserted to help you like the movie. Again, I enjoyed both, but still think the original is the standard bearer! Just my opinion......................

Honestly I couldn't understand "Jeff Bridges" for most of the run time, kindove made it hard to care about the personal relationship he forms with "Hailiee Steinfeld". Also what is the Films message, I guess it could be a few things but the film doesn't really seem to settle for one. It's a disappointment because the film is so well made, I found myself mostly admiring the direction rather than the characters.

I was wary going in to this one. I do like John Wayne movies and after watching Russell Crowe try to be Glen Ford, rather than the character, in 3:10 to Yuma, I feared Jeff Bridges would follow suit. At least, that is, until I saw the trailer. Then it was "I don't remember Rooster Cogburn speaking with a hairlip". This movie was good enough to instantly remove any reservations I had about it and kept me entertained the entire time. I don't even remember looking at my watch. Jeff Bridges did an awesome job with the character and the remaining cast was very good as well. Loved it.There is one thing that disturbs me. I noticed this viewing Open Range on its opening night. When Robert Duval's character, Boss Spearman, unloads the shotgun through the wall of the feed shed into the back of one of his adversaries, the blast knocks him into a wall on the other side of the alley and the dude's leg is twitching as he lays in the aftermath. At this point the crowded theater broke into a laugh.?? I found it disturbing then and did again a few nights ago as Quincy is shot in the head by Marshall Cogburn. WTF? I guess "my bad" for expecting the God Damn playstation generation to understand or view a western properly.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest westerns ever made, one of the finest Coen brothers movies ever made
reviews.content:
Let me begin by saying I love the Coen brothers as filmmakers. I've yet to see a movie by them that I didn't like. This one? This one is up there as one of their best. When you eliminate comedy movies, it is their best (well, perhaps tied with No Country For Old Men).First, Bridges plays an incredible Rooster Cogburn. He really ties the movie together (get it?). You like him almost immediately and get the feeling that isn't going to change.
Matt Damon doesn't start off a likeable character but he grows on you and you can't help but like him by the end.
Hailee Steinfeld plays a strong albeit pretentious character out for revenge.I can't promise you'll like it... but I do think if you're curious about westerns, this is as good an entry to the genre as any. The story is compelling, the scenery is beautiful and the characters are incredibly interesting and good to watch.

reviews.review_title: If you want to view True Grit, get the 1969 version
reviews.content: The remark of the classic movie "True Grit" should be considered a shell of the John Wayne classic from 1969. The new film liked the story, the film editing, the cinematography, costume design, quality acting, and direction of the 1969 movie. They even cut a half hour from the old version & left important parts of the story out all together. If you want to see a top quality western, get the blue ray copy of the 1969 movie "True Grit" and wait for the 2010 version on DVD, it will be available soon enough...do not like the line ruleThe remark of the classic movie "True Grit" should be considered a shell of the John Wayne classic from 1969. The new film liked the story, the film editing, the cinematography, costume design, quality acting, and direction of the 1969 movie. They even cut a half hour from the old version & left important parts of the story out all together. If you want to see a top quality western, get the blue ray copy of the 1969 movie "True Grit" and wait for the 2010 version on DVD, it will be available soon enough...

reviews.review_title: This film had brilliant acting, along with stunning shots but lacked the fluency of a great movie
reviews.content: This movie grew on me, I started out loving the camera angles and general feel of the movie. Especially through the eyes of Mattie Ross, with her stubborn can do attitude. However I found as soon as the story actually started to set into an adventure Mattie was played down and had no real role for the rest of the movie, which was a shame as her character had been particularly interesting at the beginning.Rooster was played excellently although a major problem was his speech, as much of his conversations on his horse with Mattie are inaudible and it was really hard to get a firm grasp of his character, when you couldn't understand his conversations. LaBoef was played well apart from the fact that he was shot in a critical place, with no dressing or medical attention somehow managed to carry on as normal, which was slightly annoying, however his character was played extremely well. Chaney however was exceptionally annoying, how they found him in the end, was as though the audience had been cheated of the trio finding him at the end of their elaborate journey. To have him just killed by the Mattie as well, was a disappointment as firstly she was not authorised to kill, as she was not a Marshall and so would have been trialled for murder, as well as the fact that neither of the bounty hunters in the film would have got any reward, rendering the whole ordeal fairly pointless.This film had brilliant acting, along with stunning shots but lacked the fluency of a great movie, it instead relied heavily on chance, as everything in this movie seems to have been left to it.

For starters, I believe this film will revitalize westerns the way Unforgiven did in 1992. The Coen Bros. have created a remake far superior to the John Wayne classic. I had the advantage of seeing the original, but not reading the original book (I plan on reading it since I got it for Christmas). IMO, John Wayne shouldn't've won an Oscar for this role, it was a usual, run of the mill Wayne character. In other words, Jeff Bridges blew Wayne out of the water. His Rooster Cogburn is a much more deeper, sincere (and obvious) drunk, which strengthens him. At first I had trouble understanding what he was saying, but I gradually figured it out. This further solidifies Bridges' comeback as a really talented, skilled actor. Matt Damon's performance was the most like the original character's, that of LaBeouf; this isn't a bad thing, it's still a great performance. I was disappointed at how little I saw of Josh Brolin, he only has maybe at most 20 minutes of screen time; he's one of my new favorite actors, he's like Daniel Day-Lewis: he can play any role and totally disappear in the role. This is probably the only major criticism I can offer the film: too little Josh Brolin. Now Hailee Steinfeld, she's got a real career ahead of her. She was by far better than Kim Darby in the original film; she made the character more disciplined and determined and believable. It seemed Darby played the role as a little girl trying really hard to act adult and not always pulling it off, she was frequently irritating at it; but Steinfeld plays the character perfectly, by making her totally adult, not trying to act adult, but making her believably adult; as in it's not some act she's putting on, it really is a part of her character. Also, the look and feel of the film was spot-on; although it doesn't establish an exact time (as in, for instance at the beginning it would say,"Arkansas, 1875" or something like that), you know where and when you are the whole time, every detail of the film is precise and accurate, from the costumes to the setting to the Southern dialect. The Coen Bros. are among my favorite filmmakers (Fargo is one of my all-time favorite movies), and they just keep on spitting out classics; I still think Fargo is their best, but this one is definitely yet another classic.

I'm a big fan of the original movie, and when I saw the first preview of this remake, my heart sank. Why in the world would they attempt to remake this masterpiece? Having seen the movie yesterday, I have to say, I'm glad they did. One of the previous reviewers commented that Kim Darby's performance was great in the first movie. I couldn't disagree more. Ms. Steinfeld knocks this one out of the park. I will be watching for movies from her from now on. I detested Kim Darby's performance, and everything she did wrong, Steinfeld did right. Her intelligence and determination seemed real - with Darby, it seemed forced, unnatural. I loved it.

reviews.review_title: Perfect and faithful telling of the story
reviews.content: This movie really didn't have a star in it.. it was told with an ensemble ..Everything was correct.. the language from the book, the grey weather and country of what looked to be the actual Indian nations..A perfect ending ..John Wayne carried his version and had to being saddled with Darby and Campbell..This version was carried by actors giving perfect performances of defined characters..To compare the two is to not understand what they are...
I liked the movie very much. There was a version previously played by John Wayne. I was also curious about that movie. I think I missed Western movies. I was very impressed.

reviews.review_title: Good but not as good as people are saying
reviews.content: I watched this film last night and have to say I really enjoyed it. In fact I can't say anything bad about it. The acting is great, direction fantastic, story is good, scenery and costumes spot on, script well written etc. etc.Hailee Steinfeld was fantastic, her dialogue and presence in all her scenes just stole the show. For such a young actress she showed so much power, confidence and character it just made every scene she was in entertaining to watch. Jeff & Matt were also fantastic but credit were credits due Haillee was amazing.Now, back to my title of this review. "Good but not as good as people are saying". I don't know if it's because I watched the Fighter a few days ago and it set a very high bench mark but both myself and my friend that went to see True Grit left feeling nothing. We can't put our fingers on it. As you have just read the film was good in every way but somehow left us feeling, well nothing. Confusing I know, all I can say is go and see it for yourself and see what you think. You wont regret it because in no way shape or form is it a bad film. It does everything well but just didn't have the wow factor either. That feeling you get when a film has made an impact and you wont forget it. In fact that sums it up. A great film you probably wont remember.

This movie captivated and enthralled me. The story was not shot in the grand cinematic style of the original with John Wayne but was a grittier and more realistic presentation. Jeff Bridges did one of his finest performances. Matt Damon delivered the quality we have come to expect and Glen Campbell was unable to deliver in the original film. Josh Brolin as Tom Chaney was a much improved and almost child like character. Haillee Stanfield did a good job as Maddie; however, Kim Darby's performance in the original was different than anything I had ever seen in movies at that time. I believe Darby's performance was a ground breaking role for actresses. Still, I felt that the remake was superior to the original in many ways until the final scene of the film. The original John Wayne version left me happy as it wrapped up the odds and ends of the story. By jumping ahead a decade or so the filmmakers took away from the story itself. I liken it to watching a documentary on the 2004 Red Sox and their breaking of the "Curse of the Bambino" and ending the documentary with the White Sox sweeping the Red Sox in the first round of the 2005 playoffs. It just wasn't germane to the story.

I've never really liked child actors. I know the protagonist of the original novel is also a 14 year old girl, but I just don't like it. That's the age of childishness that attracts some unscrupulous men. The recent arrest of r kelly also reminds us that show business is a hiding place for some of this crap. Romeo and Juliet plays are art, but this is the film industry, and shooting children in adult films should be banned. The story is otherwise clever and engaging, and modern cinematography makes these wild scenes very appealing.

reviews.review_title: Quite boring all the way, plus an over dramatized finale
reviews.content: Since I did not read the book and I can't say I remember the original movie, I'm just judging this one as a standalone: no comparisons.Well, even though I believe the movie shows a good production value on a technical level, I could not find many other redeeming aspects to it... One of them is Hailee Steinfeld's performance as Mattie Ross, which I found all in all solid, and actually better than those provided by all the other 'big names'.However, aside for that, the movie is quite a bore... the whole story came across as pretty pointless to me: lack of a driving force, no memorable moments, excruciatingly linear plot, seriously underdeveloped characterizations for both main and secondary characters (e.g. what is Brolin exactly doing in there?), etc. The performances from Bridges and Damon felt rather stifled and uninspired, and by the way, it wasn't easy to follow what they were mumbling all the time, as it sounded like they thickened their fake accents by stuffing whole packs of cotton wool in their mouths (set the fake accent switch to Italian-mobster-mode and they're both ready for the lead role in The Godfather part IV).As for the over dramatization... well, that actually happened all of a sudden, and the result is that the last part of the movie was almost unbearable in this respect. Seriously. It almost felt like the Cohen bros. had a sudden change of heart, and that for some inexplicable reason they wanted to turn the movie from a (lame) western into some kind of over the top depressing (and lame) tearjerker.So, all in all I think this movie is watchable (except for the last 30 minutes or so), but not a good one. 5/10

I found very little good about True Grit. The Kim Darby fill in came across as cold and humorless. Kim Darby was cute and she grew on you. The Hattie girl just wanted to show she was tough. When it turned out she never saw Rooster again I felt good for Rooster. As a grownup Hattie reminded me of the wicked Witch of the west in the Wizard of Oz. Jeff Bridges wasn't much better as Rooster. Having just won an Oscar for Crazy Heart and being featured on 60 minutes I suppose he felt he could mumble through the picture and it would be seen as a profound performance. None of the performances made me feel anything for them, for their time period, nor for the experiences they shared. I think the Coen brothers were trying too hard to make it a classic and also to be more realistic and unsentimental than the original but in doing so left the film lacking any warmth or heart.

reviews.review_title: I hate westerns. But I liked this one.
reviews.content: Typically westerns are boring with cheesy cinematography, terrible acting, and wretched screenplay. The remake of True Grit, however, was an exception. It was clever, surprisingly funny, and had impressive acting. The young girl, Mattie Ross, was given a witty script that she acted out with an excellent condescending tone. The Texas Ranger is hilarious, even if they make fun of his Texas pride consistently throughout the movie. Jeff Bridges did a beautiful job of being a drunken- yet soft- Marshall. My personal favorite was the witch doctor, who questioned whether or not they needed "medical attention." Though the Asian man- who owns the store where Rooster Cogburn resides in- was not as prevalent of a character in the new version as he was in the original, it did not deteriorate the eloquence of the movie at all. If you let that be the reason you dislike True Grit 2010, your spit is overpowering.It doesn't matter if you "can't remake a John Wayne movie." It's Jeff Bridges 41 years later and the Coen Brothers accomplished a remake masterpiece. True Grit 2010 maintains the classic western cinematography with faded transitions and horses riding in the sunset. But the Coen brothers made it even better. Cast your preferences and spite aside, western lovers. The remade version of True Grit is a modern-day classic and is worthy of immense praise.

reviews.review_title: Nice but too classic for a Coen brothers movie
reviews.content: Being a big fan of the Coen brothers' cinema, I can immediately write that this True Grit is clearly their least successful film for my taste. The casting, the script and the film making are however there but it lacks here the touch of madness and mastery characteristic of the gifted brothers. It's very classic and it does not transcend the genre of the western.

I saw this movie at a very hush advance-advance showing in Norway, as it is only opening in Europe in a months time. To cut this short, I was completely unimpressed, and more so now that I learn via IMDb that this is a remake. While the performance of the respective actors are good under the circumstances and within the limitations of their script, the story lacks fleshing out beyond dissing between characters. The score is overused with too scarce a change in melody, and what seems promising as a western at first turns into a tissue melodrama with the obvious side effects. Motivations, except for the female lead, are obscure, and the further the list goes into supporting, the further the characters and motivations go binary. This is one of the most boring westerns I saw so far, and it doesn't do much to overcome its, granted solid, effort, which I recognize. I shall now seek out the original movie, usually the remake is only a pale copy.

reviews.review_title: True to the original, but a different movie!
reviews.content: I have been waiting for this movie for months now and I want to tell everyone that my expectations were met and surpassed! I loved the original True Grit and I am a huge fan of John Wayne, but Jeff Bridges' performance made The Duke look like an amateur! Hailee Steinfirld stole the movie and she truly was 14 when the movie was filmed! AMAZING! She and Jeff Bridges both deserve Oscar nominations!I came home and immediately watched the original version and compared the two versions and was shocked to find that the dialogue was almost word for word the same. I think the new version has a much better ending and I found it both rich and rewarding. Please see this movie people. There are not explosions and special effects every ten minutes, it is just a beautiful story told from the eyes of a precocious and strong willed 14 year old girl! I wish more movies like this were being made for us real adults!!!

I'm not sure why the Coens remade this movie, as it doesn't seem to me that they made any enhancements, and they followed pretty much the same plot. Well, they did their laid-back thing, which is sometimes enjoyable. In this case, I felt they removed any drama or suspense that might have been had and that was very satisfying in the original movie. Maybe it's because I had already seen that previous movie; if you haven't, maybe you would enjoy this. I advise you to turn on the subtitles, though, from the start; I had to resort to them half-way through or so, after I hadn't been able to understand a word that was said between two characters in one scene. Jeff Bridges speaks as though he has a wad of tobacco in his mouth; the other male actors just seem to mumble. It's amazing that the characters seem to manage to understand each other ;-). I facetiously asked my husband, "are they speaking English?" The subtitles revealed that they were mumbling a very formal form of (old-fashioned?) English, which turned out to be humorous at times. Maybe the actors just didn't feel comfortable with it. Or maybe the dialog was meant to contrast the female protagonist, who appears well-educated and well spoken, with the rest of 'em. If so, it didn't seem to be an effective ploy. Other than my complaint about their diction, though, the actors did a good job of creating odd-ball characters. I was particularly impressed with Matt Damon for hardly appearing to be Matt Damon, although I couldn't quite "get" his character from the dialog that was written for it. That seemed to be true for all of the "characters," none of whom really stood out for me.

reviews.review_title: good movie, not as good as the john wayne's one though
reviews.content: their choice of someone to fill john Wayne's boots was rather strange. i like Jeff bridges but he's no john Wayne. he tends to play characters in a very low energy way. the spark, or patter of dialogue was much better in the john Wayne's version as well. Still it's a good watch and does have it's moments. very good supporting cast performances. Jeff Bridge's rooster was perhaps a little darker than Wayne's version but the low energy acting of bridges could account for this. when i say low energy, i'm not suggesting bad performance. Jeff bridges style has always struck me as a laid back hippie type. Of course i don't claim that my review is unbiased, as i am a duke fan.

I grew up on the original classic with John Wayne. A film that has been shown a multitude of times in my 40 odd years and still I stop to watch it.So it was with interest that I watched this remake. And it basically is the same movie just made in the 21st century to broaden the story's appeal to a new generation. After all how many people will now sit down to watch the old classic westerns? Especially people of a generation younger than me.There were almost the same lines "If I met a Texan who didn't drink water from a horse's hoof, I'll buy him a drink" and the same scenes - Mattie swimming the river on her horse. The classic reins in his teeth, guns blazing charge was poorer than the original So if you're going to just repeat it all, then why bother? Nothing new was added. Except for CGI which was frankly poor - the opening scene of the train coming into the station is a prime example. As well as Rooster and Mattie on horseback.Very disappointed.

what a nice reprieve from flashy, special effects. instead of concentrating on CGI we get real dialogue, and suspenseful situations. glad to see that modern film making accentuated the feel of the old west. case in point this movies representation of bad teeth, they looked so real.i hated watching the 60's & 70's "westerns" with shiny leathers and hippy looking native Americans.this was bridges flexing his muscles in thespian craft, like he added his own touch to rooster's character. the real scene stealer was the young actress, stansfield-having not been familiar with her as an actress, she showed her talent. the real treat was josh brolin, how he could be kind of goofy, and a little slow to a menacing cold-blooded killer, in less time than it takes to blink. so worth the ticket price & time to sit through & watch! my 8 year old was so moved by this tale, set in a time that will soon be forgotten. it gave him the motivation to put down his hand held electronic device and play outside!

I wanna shortly write about film. Because film is quite fluent that s why time passed like water. I already adore modern westerns for example 3.10 Yuma Train or Hateful Eight etc. I even thought main character is John Ruth :)

I enjoyed this movie however I was expecting to see a remake in which the story line was more in line with the original. For instance the storyline did not focus as much on the essence of the character portrayed of Mattie Ross in this version. I felt her role was considerably weaker, and much of the "glory" was given and focused on Matt Damon and Jeff Bridges. In the original, the movie focused more on Mattie Ross' role, however the men in the movie received the greatest focus. However I do believe the gal who portrayed Mattie Ross in this newer version did not act out her role as convincingly and as well as Kim Darby. Thus the "glory" was given to Bridges and Damon. However if a better choice had been made on the selection of the Mattie Ross character, the focus would have been on her, as we experienced in the original version. Thus the story would have followed suit with the original because the female character in this version would have been the primary focus of the storyline, as it was meant in the first place. Also the stabbing of the horse with the knife to get it to run faster and longer was fairly corny. Also the ending was so ridiculous because we were expecting the ending we were accustomed to in the original version. The added commentary made no sense because this wasn't a true story, so why the unnecessary dialog of who went where, who died when and so forth. Were we introduced to this information in the original? No! So, why bother throwing it in just to create a "filler"?? Overall I felt the movie was more of a bummer than the treat I was looking for.

Being a big John Wayne fan I had my doubts about seeing this movie.I went today to see it and all I can say is excellent.Not once during the movie did I find myself comparing it to the old one.From start to finish it was as though I was watching a new movie.Fantastic bit of movie making by the Coen Brothers to be able to accomplish this.The Duke I'm sure is smiling right now.The legend lives on.Wondering how many awards this movie will get.It has my vote.I have seen some of the other Coen movies and have always been satisfied...but this takes the cake...I can't say enough good things about this film...if you like westerns this one is a must see...Iwill definitely buy it when it comes out on video and will enjoy watching it many times...congratulations to the Coen Brothers.It's on my list of greatest movies.Don't miss it !!!!

Cannot think of a single reason this film is better than, or even as good as, the original. Although its well made, the acting good, Bridges great, its just a totally pointless exercise. Watch the original. Re-release the original. It is 100 times better. Its a very good academic example of how you can make money from dumbos pure through marketing. Its like getting Warhol to copy the Mona Lisa and then people paying as much as the original to buy it. They buy it simply because its new and because the original had a reputation. Thats all. The dumbos totally devalue the original work, and thats saying nothing about the people trying to make a quick buck off the backs of the original artists.

True Grit was enjoyable tale of 14 year old Mattie Ross's (Hailee Steinfeld) journey to have the murder of her father avenged. In order to bring her father's murderer to justice she hires U.S Marshal "Rooster" Cogburn (Jeff Bridges); known for getting his man. They are joined by LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) a Texas Ranger looking for the same man for a separate offense.Mattie Ross's character is written with maturity and intelligence. Hailee Steinfeld portrays it wonderfully. She holds her own on the screen in the midst of Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon like a seasoned veteran. I have yet to see an interview with Hailee it will be interesting to hear what she normally sounds like to understand how much a departure this character was from her real identity. Her introductory performance is second only to Jennifer Lawrence of "Winter's Bone".The only scene that left me uncomfortable was the scene in which Rooster kicks to Indian children who were sticking a donkey with pointed sticks off the porch. I do not care for animal cruelty but when he pushed the children and the laughter in the audience reminded me off the era; post civil war. The same civil war vet that protected a donkey probably wouldn't have raised a finger to help a Black person.After shaking that off I got back to enjoying the story, which I did. The script was written well and interesting. It was an old fashioned good guy, bad guy shoot 'em up which was worth the time.rivareviews.com

This movie is a must see! I am not typically into Westerns BUT this movie offered comedy, drama, and suspense. It was the best movie I have seen in a long time. The scenery was awesome, the music impeccable, and the acting was superb. I have never called my friends and parents right after a movie and immediately started recommending. However, I did exactly that with True Grit. My husband and I saw the original not too long ago. We thought the plot was good but the older movies just seem to go a little slow for us. This movie had everything the original did but it seemed the comedy was much better, the movie was at a fast pace, and the picture quality (of course) was a huge improvement. HIGHLY Recommended!

Probably the worst Cohen brothers movie to date. It is just a fashioned copy of the original, like few years back when Total Recall was made with Collin Farell, shich was shot from shot the same. Same here. No emotions, no tension...and most of all no grit. Tarantino's Hateful Eight is a far better western then this. I cannot help but think that this is getting praises only because it's a Cohen brothers work. I gave it 6/10, but would had gotten with 5.5/10 if I could. Friendly advice, go watch the original.

It's surprising that opinions about this good western ranks from "horrible" to "masterpiece". Truth is between those extremes, but far near from the second. A "not so classic" western indeed, but westerns weren't "classics" in the decades of '50 and '60. Clint Eastwood don't renewed the genre with "Unforgiven". The master John Ford did it in "The Man who Shot Liberty Valance" (1962), that really is a far superior film (and more "revisionistic") that this valuable 'remake' of the John Wayne's film directed by Hathaway. OK, as Hathaway's, the Coen's film is a very good western in his own terms, the acting is good and the cinematography excellent. Bur, sadly, we lost the Duke.

True Grit felt as authentic as to the old west as an western movie could get with some good acting and solid dialogs. What did leave me a little disappointed was that the story never really picked up pace, it never got that interesting, it just kept on moving in a normal walking pace until the credits rolled over the screen. Basically it's about a young girl who wants revenge upon the man who killed her father but she needs help to track him down. That said I could now finish it with one sentence. There is not much else to it, it's that straight forward. Don't get me wrong though, it is still worth a watch if you are in to westerns or if you are in for a good movie, but in all honesty I enjoyed '3:10 to Yuma' for instance a lot more.

reviews.review_title: First One Was Way, Way, Way Better
reviews.content: The original True Grit was way, way, way better. Coen Brothers created by comparison a dull and dry movie. It lacked the energy, tenseness, chemistry, humor, poignancy, and DIALOG of the original John Wayne version. Individually, the actors shone out more in the original John Wayne version as well -- John Wayne played his role with much more richness than Jeff Bridges; Kim Darby was captivating and completely outshone the young actress in the Coen Brothers flick who got way more PR than she deserved by the way; and who can beat Glen Campbell and his portrayal of a gentlemanly Texas Ranger? Not Matt Damon; not even close. Bottom line: I'd rather watch the original John Wayne True Grit 50 more times than to have to watch the Coen Brothers version ever again. The DIALOG.

reviews.review_title: Shout out to the people who made this movie
reviews.content: I don't write movie reviews, because I don't trust what strangers whom I don't know write about movies...movie tastes are too personal and quirky. This is to the Coen brothers, the actors, composer, cinematographer, and all the people involved in making this movie. The brilliant, succinct dialogue, the music, the acting, the beauty of the scenes, the clothes, the vibe...all masterful. The original True Grit is a personal all-time favorite and you all managed to put this film right next to the original and John Wayne!

reviews.review_title: I'm not a Western fan, but True Grit was great
reviews.content: I usually don't care for Westerns or cowboys, but True Grit was very well made and very enjoyable. There are excellent performances from the entire cast, including the young girl. Typically, kids are annoying in movies, but she delivered a strong performance. Bridges was great (and funny) as the drunken marshall. Matt Damon was great and even the small performance from Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper were very well-done. I found this movie to actually be really funny at some parts. At points the whole audience was laughing. The only disappointment I had was that the ending felt rushed. It seemed as if it ended too abruptly and you wanted more from the climax. I'm really surprised that this movie was not nominated for anything at the Golden Globes. I'm still not a Western fan, but True Grit was definitely a good movie.

reviews.review_title: surprisingly told straight forward by the Coen Brothers
reviews.content: Based on the novel by Charles Portis "True Grit" is a remake of the John Wayne's 1969 film by the same name. This time around The Coen brothers write and direct this Western tale of revenge. Mattie's father is shot and killed by the outlaw Chaney (Josh Brolin) and now Mattie wants payback. Her mother is too grief stricken and her brother is a baby that leaves her with the job of pursuing down the murderer, but she'll need some help. She is witty and head strong and eventually gets the help of a down and out lawman named Cogburn, who she believes has enough "True Grit" to help her track down Chaney. Along the way she meets a Texas Ranger only known as LeBoeuf played by Matt Damon, and the three go off on an adventure and discover a few surprises along the way. This film has a simple premise but is filled with some great writing and characterization. Its gets a bit dialogue heavy at times, but is never boring. Jeff Bridges gives another Oscar worthy performance and Matt Damon surprisingly slips in to his character easily. He is a great actor but in this film he really took it to another level. Josh Brolin and Barry Pepper appear briefly but give memorable performances. I believe this film is one of the best written films this year. It should certainly win a couple of awards for Best adapted Screenplay. More than anything the character that holds this whole film together is Mattie herself played by the relatively unknown Hailee Steinfeld. She is interesting to watch and holds her own against veteran big time actors, throw in an Oscar nod for her as well. I don't think the film itself will win best picture (although the Academy is partial to the Coen Brothers ) but it definitely deserves a nomination. I didn't like "No Country for Old Men" or "Burn After Reading" but "True Grit" is a welcome surprise and one my favorite Coen Brothers films. This is a good ole' fashion western, surprisingly steered straight forward by two directors who do everything but . Go see it! for more check out www.tickingticket.blogspot.com

Ever since playing Red Dead Redemption, I've began to find Western movies very interesting. So, when I first heard about this film, It was definitely a must see for me. It didn't disappoint in the slightest. I haven't seen the original movie, so I can't compare, but for what it is, this film is outstanding. Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon give excellent performances, and I'm usually not keen on Damon. The storyline is brilliant, and very atmospheric. A lovely, character driven film. There's some very touching scenes, which don't feel forced in the slightest. The Coen Brothers certainly know how to draw out some lovely performances, and the cinematography in this was brilliant.Overall, a fantastic film. Highly recommended.

Mattie Ross is a teenager. She is clearly past the age of puberty. This means she would be menstruating regularly. At the time this film is set (1880), there were no such things as tampons. Nor were there any commercially available menstrual pads. Women (and girls like Mattie) had to use rags, strips of old towels, etc., to absorb their menstrual blood, and they had to wash and dry them after use. These rags were extremely uncomfortable to wear. No girl or woman would be able to ride astride while wearing them. This would cause chafing, even bruising, and great discomfort, and the risk of blood leaking down their legs, through their clothes, and on to the saddle would be very high. At this time menstruation was regarded as a shameful secret, and no young girl would take the risk of any man becoming aware that she was having her period. How could Mattie have hidden this from the men? How would she have managed to wash and dry her rags? How could she have ridden astride a horse day after day? How could the Coen brothers have made a film that totally ignores this aspect of a woman's physiology? It's completely absurd. Maybe men watching the film wouldn't think about this, but I guarantee any woman watching it would think, 'Hang on, this is is ridiculous.'

Hello. I don't usually write reviews but after reading some of the raving on this site and then actually seeing the movie I have to say I am bitterly disappointed. No doubt the acting is superb and the scenography is quite as it should be... but man oh man was this hard to watch. What was this movie suppose to tell me? That you are born, you live and you die? What was the point of the ending? I got nothing.ANd while we are at it, what was the point of Jeff Bridges talking like he had a brick in his mouth? MAke the movie even harder to watch?I gave it a three

reviews.review_title: Grabs you and doesn't let you go
reviews.content: This movie is a complete classic, from the dialogue, to the acting, the action, and overall the raw human element make this an unforgettable movie in my book.The dialogue is great, regardless whether or not it is completely accurate to how two individuals would carry on a conversation in the late 1800's. The picture that the dialogue creates for the characters in question make it absolutely immersive and simply great. You are transported to the events in play.The acting is more of the same. The way they capture a realistic emotional or visceral reaction in the characters is believable and convincing.The directors and writers also managed to capture the environment around them and things like animals in an encompassing way.I'm not one to write reviews, but this movie was so great I could watch it multiple times and still want to watch it again. Work of art, thanks to the creators.

... for directors and actors.
Not too bad and not good.
You can watch it, or leave it be.
Neither fish or flesh...

reviews.review_title: Great imitation but still an imitation !!
reviews.content: Has the movie industry sunk so low that all they can produce is re-makes ? Not only does it seem to be a trend in Hollyweird . But TV is doing it as well. Granted there are quite a few movies that deserve to be revisited . Primarily because they would benefit from better cinematography and effects. However, this is not one of them. The cast of characters perform in true A-list fashion . The cinematography is excellent as one would expect from such a project. The tough part comes when trying NOT to compare Jeff bridges to John Wayne . It's painfully difficult to keep from disliking anyone who has the temerity to attempt to play one of the Duke's roles. Lets face it. There was one and only one John Wayne and Jeff Bridges ain't him !!! So, in closing I will say this. While they managed to do a decent job of it. I hope the movie falls flat on it's face. I find it repugnant that people be rewarded for lack of originality and laziness. And furthermore I myself will go out of my way to avoid any movie with Jeff Bridges in it. There is no way he can claim this as an homage to the Duke. Rather, I feel that ANY actor who would allow themselves to be cast in one of John Wayne's signature roles has little or no respect nor any class . There are certain things you JUST DON'T do. The next thing you know they will be doing a re-make of Casablanca or It's a Wonderful Life .

"I once lapped filthy water from a hoofprint and was glad to have it" Inspiring words from Texas Ranger LaBouef as he reclines with his unlikely vigilante compadres by the campfire. More importantly, words reflective of a feeling I was left with upon walking away from True Grit.There's a couple ways one can convey a sense of desolation in film. One is artfully...with an almost abstract yet mournful beauty and longing that ruthlessly sinks it's talons into one's pelt...often drawing blood...blood willingly given because the feeling is both terrible and exquisite all at once. The other is ironically...with a haphazard attempt at the first, perhaps, but without the underlying element of soul there to breath life into the artwork. Ironic still, is the mystery of the Coen brothers giving us an example of each...the first, with No Country for Old Men...and the second, with True Grit.No Country was masterful in its capacity to leave one thirsty for something...ANYTHING...that might provide hope..while simultaneously cultivating a deeper, existential acceptance of the poetry of an ofttimes ruthless, predatorial universe. Alas, no such mastery was to be found in Grit. How can there be mastery when the characters themselves are a bunch of morons? How can there be mastery when the viewer is penned, like a country chicken, in the cage of a myopic, pointless story line? There's just not enough of anything to give this movie free range, which is the signature allure of the Old West. Maybe this is the fault of the original, but I'll never know. I haven't seen it nor do I intend to...especially now. With little to work with ("no excuse!" I cry) the Coen's are left grasping at straws...like trying to work in a few randomly inserted elements filched, in spirit, from Jarmusch's Dead Man. It worked for Jarmusch...but flopped in the dirt with Grit, lacking context or continuity. Or trying to wring some remote feeling of heart or nobility from the walking dirt clod that is Rooster Cogburn...something successfully portrayed in Cat Balou or Unforgiven..........or the Grinch Who Stole Christmas.Grit just kind of wanders around, poking in the dirt while occasionally, almost listlessly, killing someone as if out of boredom. The climax? A lazy dust devil, without momentum or majesty. A twirl or two in the heat of the day, then gone without making lasting impression.The music played and the credits rolled. All I can say is, thank god for hot showers and filtered water

It would be futile to review this film without comparisons to the 1969 version. The 1969 version netted John Wayne an Oscar win...the only Oscar win of his career. I'm going to predict that Jeff Bridges is going to get a strong Oscar nomination from this film. In my opinion he deserves it. For the first few minutes of the film it was difficult not to think of John Wayne's characterization of Rooster Cogburn. But it was not long before Jeff Bridges beguiled me into his portrayal of Cogburn. Bridges' portrayal stands very well on its own. The other possible Oscar nomination that may proceed from this film is for Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross. The young actress steals your heart with her youth and vitality while presenting a very credible portrayal of a self-possessed, head-strong Mattie Ross. Matt Damon presented an enjoyable LaBoueff, but his portrayal was completed eclipsed by Bridges and Steinfeld. Josh Brolin's Tom Chaney was likewise credible, though it was a bit surprising seeing him play a bit of a dim-wit. Barry Pepper was a very pleasant surprise as an almost charming Lucky Ned Pepper, the leader of the outlaw gang. Unfortunate for Brolin and Pepper that the story necessitated their limited screen time.This movie gets a rock-solid '10' from me. I plan to see it again in the theater, and the DVD will grace my collection.
Three characters that we all hate at a momment but cant exist without each other.

I haven't seen the old True Grit. In this new one, I didn't really see the true grit in anyone. All the three lead actors seemed to be doing their respective jobs (in the story), nothing special. I didn't find the motive of the lead actors - which was the premise of the story line - convincing enough. So perhaps there was something missing in either the script or direction. I did admire the acting skills of Hailee Steinfield considering she uttered long heavy lines.

The story is compelling, and the dialogue is surprisingly droll which enhances the bleak atmosphere even more. The direction is superb, Carter Burwell's score is wonderfully atmospheric, the pace is more secure here and the final shoot out which stood out in the 1969 film is glorious.

Great, entertaining film by the Coen Brothers. Jeff Bridges pretty much steals the whole movie but is followed close behind by the little girl Hailee Steinfeld. At first I thought a PG-13 movie by the Coen Brothers would hold them back from their usual style, but it is plenty violent and often very funny with the usual Coen's dry sense of humor. The scenery is also great, the film takes place in Arkansas, and I'm not totally sure if the filmed on location but knowing the Coen Brothers they probably did and they did an awesome job of capturing the open plains of the State during winter. With it being a western (I'm not the biggest fan of them) and the run time I was a little concerned but it felt no where near the 2 hour length it ran at. As for it being a remake, I haven't yet watched the original but I did see this one with my dad who said it followed the original pretty well and I have also read that the Brothers stayed extremely close to the source material so if you are a dedicated fan to this story no need to worry. I highly recommend this if you are a Bridges, Coen Brothers, or western fan.

From the first scene, this movie showed it had problems. Flicking off a quick adaptation of the 1968 Charles Portis novel, the Coens should have done more re-drafts to translate it into their first actual Western. The protagonist girl, Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld), voice-overs from the start, which acts as a poor substitute for action. Mattie chooses "Rooster" (Jeff Bridges) to help her find the "coward" Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Rooster is not really the true grit US Marshall promised, but more like a mumbling annoying caricature. And Mattie isn't a loving daughter seeking revenge, but a rich swot balancing her moral ledger. The Coens used the book's period dialog unchanged, but inconsiderately have the characters speaking that complex dialog very fast for the period. Rooster has a forced-in-his-throat affectation. To make his dialog even more difficult to hear, he constantly leaves a cigarette in his mouth, and gravelly mumbles out of the left-hand side of it. LeBoeuf (Matt Damon) is permitted to affect a non-Texan accent for his Texas Ranger character. Add these affectations to period dialog and we endure unbearably fast speech without the benefit of subtitles. To further add to disbelief, Joel and Ethan Coen throw in a discussion discarded from earlier movies. To quote the 14-year-old, "Malum in se. The distinction is between an act that is wrong in itself, and an act that is wrong only according to our laws and mores." Huh? You get the idea. Sure the cinematography is beautiful, the period dress excellent, but the movie is boring. And if you like gritty emotion, you won't find it in this movie. The storyline has them trek into Indian Nations, implying conflict with Indians, but again, not in this movie. So for those who usually like the grit of Coen movies such as No Country for Old Men, I would suggest waiting for their next one, their next original one.

OK, True Grit was a very well made movie, it had a great cast with great performances. It had beautiful scenery and the Coen brothers paid very close attention to detail. Having said that, it was not at all what I expected, I didn't realize it was a comedy, and that's what it was more or less. It was laugh out loud funny, and the audience and myself laughed throughout, but I could have swore the movie was about a girl avenging her fathers death, but that played a back seat role to the comedy. I don't know, I just expected some No Country for Old Men intensity at some point, but there was none. The girl barely even seemed bothered that her father was just murdered. So it was an entertaining film, but if your looking for a "gritty" Unforgiven type western, this is not it

reviews.review_title: I loved the John Wayne version, but this one equals it.
reviews.content: In comparing the two films, I expect that quite a bit of discussion went into the changes that were made from the original. Although slight, they are telling, and in most cases I find them appealing, although with reservations. It is a beautifully crafted, wonderfully acted film, especially by Hailee, the young actress who won our hearts with her version of Mattie. And the script was literate, with familiar passages from the earlier version, and thoughtful amendments. I would not denigrate it by calling it a "remake", since it is an entirely original film, resting upon a familiar and well loved story. I have a deep affection for the western genre of film, and this is an extremely worthwhile addition. Deeply satisfying, visually satisfying, storytelling at its best. Highly recommended. If you are a fan of western films, and who among us is not, this one is not to be missed.

Well, I haven't seen the original 1969 version nor I have read the book, so I couldn't say what of what I like & dislike about the movie is 'new stuff' and what is copied/adapted.To me this seemed like a decent western, but I was left with an overall ambiguous feeling. It was entertaining but it didn't seem realistic at all and sometimes it seemed to go nowhere.For instance could one conceive a bigger 'deus ex machina' than the post- 'the trail is cold'-discussion 'oh look there they are watering their horses a couple of hundred yards off our camp'-solution ?!? It just make no sense. The whole falling into the hole thing + snakebite was also very theatrical. And one guy against four? First Matt Damon in what was a clear suicide attempt than Jeff Bridges being Superman.Don't get me wrong, it's a just story, sure, and it shouldn't be overanalysed, but maybe I started off with a wrong expectation of realism.

reviews.review_title: An unexciting waste of two hours
reviews.content: True Grit was much to my surprise nominated for 10 Oscars, the second most so far for this year. I planned to visit the cinema expecting a great night and by the look of the trailers and the great reviews it had received a film I would remember for a long time. After sitting through two hours of constantly waiting for the film to become exciting it eventually ended in a spontaneous scene that wasn't needed and made no impact to the story whatsoever. After leaving my friends and I had agreed that the film was poor and deserved a two out of ten, the scenes of action that the trailers reveal are literally the only enjoyable scenes in the entire movie, the remainder of the film is filled with constant dialogue which barely kept me sitting on my seat for the whole film.Overall if you are a genuine fan to western movies 'True Grit' will be an enjoyable experience for you. However if you are simply looking for a great night out for you and your friends don't waste your money on this and go and see something a little more reliable like 'Paul' or 'The Fighter'.

True Grit tells a classic western story. After her father is murdered by lowly criminal Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), 14 year-old Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) hires the drunken old US Marshal, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to help her track down Chaney and bring him to justice. Texas Ranger, LaBeouf (Matt Damon), who is trying to track down Chaney for a separate crime he committed in Texas, accompanies them on their journey. The three of them find themselves face-to-face confronting numerous dangers on their expedition including several run-ins with ruthless outlaws. The ten Academy Award nominations True Grit earned including nominations for the Coen Brothers, Jeff Bridges, and Hailee Steinfeld were all very deserved. Read my full review at: http://themuddoctor.blogspot.com/2011/08/true-grit.html

SEE?? No Oscar for a half-baked re-shoot of a Classic. When will Hollywood learn? Did the Cohens really think they were going to top the Original? C'mon, gimmie a break!!When you already have a Timeless Classic, LEAVE IT ALONE! This half-baked attempt to "re-make" True Grit, only flopped flat as a pancake.... and Jeff Bridges vs. the "Duke" ??? - Really? - REALLY?So many times, The "Hollywood" types don't have any ORIGINAL thoughts or ideas, and just enough money and backing to be dangerous. As you sit and ponder what went wrong, you might re-think your daytime Jobs and open a Deli or something and leave the movie making to the Reel experts (PUN intended) as opposed to pulling out your wallet and suddenly see yourselves as another DeMille.Give it a rest, boys, - "You can't handle the Truth!"

reviews.review_title: A story of a very brave young woman
reviews.content: My father sent me a copy of "True Grit" when I was in the Army, saying that it was the best novel about the South he had read since "To Kill a Mockingbird". I thought it was very good, and went to see the "John Wayne" version, thinking it was very good. When I heard that there was going to be a remake, I thought...why botherWhen the new version came out, I saw it in the first week, and was "blown away".My wife bought me a copy for Christmas, and watching it again, I'm thinking that it is one of the best movies I've ever seen. It is Texas and Arkansas, which share being part of the old South, and a bit of the "Wild West". The music is fantastic...old hymns. I have ten granddaughters, and I will make sure that they see this story about a brave, brave young woman.I will say, don't spread a rope around a camp site. It won't keep the snakes out.

First of all, in my opinion Jeff Bridges played a better Rooster Cogburn. Now I don't mean to offend John Wayne fans but I just found Jeff Bridges performance more entertaining. Now to the movie. True Grit is a good movie. I just watched it and went on the theory that it was based on the book instead of the original movie. I found True Grit very funny and entertaining. It was a bit slow in the beginning. That is my main beef with this movie. The movie moves along at a leisurely pace, maybe to leisurely to me. Now I'm not the type who needs explosions every where to like a movie. If you look at my top 10 movie list I put No Country For Old Men in there. I refer to that because that movie is very slow. For that movie it works. With this movie I wished it would have moved a bit faster and went right into the search for Chaney. When the movie finally picked up it got really good. I found it very humorous. I was laughing throughout the whole thing. Another small thing that I didn't like was the finale with Tom Chaney. It seemed like it ended to fast. As soon as she was captured it only took like ten minutes to get her back. After the very fast ending I thought it was over. After that I was ready for the movie to be over. It felt complete. Then there was an epilogue which left a dry taste in my mouth.Other than the pacing, the finale, and the ending, I really enjoyed this film. It had hilarious moments, great action and great acting. I gave this movie a 7. With me a 7 means I really liked it. I am not to generous with ratings. I've only ever given 2 movies 10's, those being It's a Wonderful Life and Schindler's List. Altogether it was a very enjoyable experience. I find it the superior of the 2 movies and highly recommend it.

This is a film more notable for its portrait of a town and the performance of Jeff Bridges than it is for its story, which, when you stop to think about it, is pretty thin. The acting is good all round and some of the photography is beautifully evocative of the epic landscape except for the epilogue which seems to be shot on DV and was a lame ending anyway. But the film belongs to Jeff Bridges. Matt Damon is a useless appendage and Hailee Steinfeld, the ostensible centre of the film, acts very well but her character seems to learn nothing about herself, a fault of the story no doubt but frustrating all the same.
