The town is interesting to see in its detail and in its political structure, however, once we leave the town we are supposed to enter a mythic landscape but this is scuppered by the paucity of the story. The only epic constituent of the film is the character Jeff Bridges plays and his performance is the only real reason to watch the film. Barely recognisable under the beard, Bridges is the seen-it-all Rooster Cogburn is a lawman with no respect for the law, a cold blooded killer who risks his own life to save others, a showman who keeps to himself and a stranger to himself and his past. It would have been a much more fun to watch his story than this one.

This was a tough movie to watch. I wanted to turn it off half way through but I stuck it out. After watching it, I had to take a shower and cleanse my soul by watching The Searchers.The good parts of the movie were Matt Damon as LaBoeuf. Glen Campbell in the original was awful. And, Hailee Steinfeld was wonderful. Both Kim Darby and her did a great job but Hailee Steinfeld was excellent.The look and feel of the original Henry Hathaway version and the Coen Bros. version is like comparing a beautiful Rembrandt to Etch-A-Sketch. The cinematography of Lucien Ballard is beautiful and he captures the majesty of the west with the choices in filming locations. The Coens don't get this. They just don't get it.Elmer Bernstein's music score. 'Nuff said!!! The supporting cast in the original was amazing. Robert Duvall, Dennis Hopper, Strother Martin!!, Jeff Corey (very slimy), John Doucette.And then there's Rooster Cogburn. Talk about one of the worst casting choices in the Coen film. Don't get me wrong, I really like Jeff Bridges, but his mumbling really got to me and he was not at all lovable. Everything about this performance is wrong. John Wayne on the other hand put in a performance of a lifetime. I'm choking up right now just thinking about his real emotions saving Mattie from the snake pit, the famous phrase (we all know it) when he puts the horse reins in his mouth (beautful scenery, beautiful cinematography, beautiful editing and beautiful acting) and of course the final scene. To see John Wayne do that scene brings tears to my eyes.

The critics have a tendency to over-rate anything by Cohen Bros. If you watch the original you will note that a lot of the dialog is identical (perhaps the scriptwriters for respective version lifted it from the source novel?). Even how the actors are positioned and what they do are the same - note Ned Pepper while yelling at Rooster from the camp. The camera set ups around the final shoot out is almost identical scene by scene. Also the landscapes (autumal vs. grayish winter) looked more stunning in the original. The only actor who manages to improve on the original is Matt Damon. Some of the plot additions and characters are irrelevant to the plot (e.g. a meeting with a "dentist" in the forest. The original actually shows us what led up to Matties trek for her fathers murderer - this one does not. If you want to remake something that was good in the first place and put your own mark on it one should do better than this.

Although I usually love most of what Jeff Bridges has done over the years, IMHO this remake of True Grit was a huge disappointment. Perhaps it was wrong to expect a worthy remake of any movie by The Duke. I don't know if this is even a possible expectation. Another reviewer correctly stated the viewer should not compare the new version to the old.After not watching the original for decades, I watched the John Wayne version last night and enjoyed it immensely. During the updated version, it felt as though I was forcing myself to keep on watching, in hopes it would get better. To be completely fair, I must admit to being a huge fan of the older Classic Westerns. I grew up watching Gunsmoke, Rawhide, etc. and thoroughly loved the Clint Eastwood Westerns. Just about anything Hollywood has unleashed as a Western since 2000 has been a great let down. Since the turn of the century, it appears audiences are only attracted to blood and guts gore and care less about content. Maybe my tastes are age related. Those who relish Classic Westerns will not be impressed by this version.

I loved it! For the characters, every asset is maximized in pursuit of their goal. Mattie (Hailee Steinfeld) maximizes the threat and services of a good lawyer, her sharp wit, intellect and many other skills. Rooster (Jeff Bridges) uses his gun for killing, entertainment, and an old West version of instant messaging. And La Boeuf (Matt Damon) maximizes his one good asset, dogged persistence. The movie opens with a tune immediately very familiar and comforting. Variations of Leaning on the Everlasting Arms, never sung until the closing credits, make up most of the score. The song is a song of comfort; I started singing the words in my head during the movie and felt peaceful and strong right away. The message of True Grit is that this feeling of comfort and resolve can be obtained in a violent and unpredictable world by sticking to your guns, maximizing your assets, and rolling intelligently with the proper restaint when something unexpectedly bad happens. Leaning on the Everlasting Arms tell the movie's message in song; the character of Mattie embodies it. The moment she enters any scene in the movie you feel that everything is going to be OK. Mattie, a 14 year old girl, will work it out with her amazing intellect and ability to cut through all bullshit to get to the roots of truth, justice and most of all grit. It is grit that Mattie admires the most and so she picks Rooster as the U.S. Marshall to pursue her father's killer over the other Marshalls. She also picks a Texas Ranger, Le Boeuf to accompany them and comes to admire his persistence though not his fumbling ineptitude at catching criminals. She also develops a bit of a crush on him. While the other characters suffer from mental problems of one sort or the other, and have little plan or talent for executing one, Mattie is optimistic and cheerful every day because as Big Boi recently rapped, she has a "backup plan for her backup plan" and she has many tools in her bag (including a gun) to see it through to completion. Most of all she has the ability to pick talent and corral that talent towards her aims. In this regard, the Coen Brothers must of seen something in her they value in themselves. The Coen Brothers surely corralled great talent to present this movie to us flawlessly: the setting, costumes, the beards, the comedy, the score, the violence, the casting, we are once again in the hands of masters and it's all very comforting again. For me the movie becomes epic at the end. I don't use the word lightly. In Colorado and in the outdoors community, we reserve the word epic for an outdoor adventure that has gone completely south. You don't epic when you forget your peanut butter and jelly sandwich and get lost for 10 minutes on your hike back. You epic when you are caught in a whiteout at 4pm at 12,000 feet and can't ski anymore and have to abandon your skis. It's not really cool to epic, usually it means you were unprepared or made a bad decision. But it happens to most everybody who spends anytime outdoors, because we are only human and the natural world and weather and events are sometimes violent and unpredictable. Mattie forgets that there is a pit behind her, in the usual Biblical lyricism of the film, and gets bitten by snakes. As Rooster rushes her to the doctor they hit a point where they are in the wide open, there are no trees, no features. The movie has been reduced to landscape, to effort, to breath, to a sick young girl, and her earthly father for the time being. The heavenly father is supposedly there too watching down on them, they are in his everlasting arms. But for the atheist Coen Brothers, it is not the arms of the heavenly father that save Mattie. It is the powerful athletic legs of Mattie's horse, Little Blackie, a horse that she picked for it's talent and loves. She picked Rooster for his grit and talent with a gun, not his big gut from years of alcoholism and she loves him too. Like all her other good choices it puts her in good stead as the fat man is able to run with her in his arms to the doctors house when Little Blackie dies from exhaustion. We can love others and ourselves and detest those we should detest with confidence, when we make good trades and choices, choose the right people based on their talents and grit and do our best to plan out the achievement of our goals and the overcoming of the epic situations that get in the way. Such a clichéd movie (actually it's just my review that is clichéd), I can't wait to see it again.

"I was informed that it was the Coen Bros. (True Grit) that actually had not seen the original Film as well as Jeff Bridges." I argue: It is virtually impossible not to have seen or least in-part True Grit, the original Film. Kim Darby (who played Mattie) in the first film taught myself Drama in Film at UCLA, so of course we all had to watch and hear stories about her experience for a semester. If you own a TV, then you have seen True Grit... John Wayne's only Oscar Performance and being that it was a Paramount Picture Production and the new Film is also and being that Bridges is a "Duke" fan, the comments I believe were to draw the attention away from some of the negative reviews and the somewhat hapless advertising that Paramount has done for the sequel. True Grit was the biggest film of the Summer of 1969 and everyone saw or heard about this film then. Glen Campbell who played the Texas Ranger in the original film was on all the Talk Shows and Clips were played! Kim Darby thought then was a new bright young star was everywhere! And John Wayne, for any decent Filmmaker, they have studied the role of "Rooster" greatly. The Coen's are sometimes anti-Hollywood and many see anti-commercial Film and are sometimes it seems anti-publicizing their own Films. But that is the way they work... the new Film is more of a Roger Deakins Film, long time Coen Bros. Cinematographer than anything else and his vision is again amazing which makes the film well worth the price of admission! Its the most conservative film they have ever made and their first real western. It fails is many ways and Bridges seems not very comfortable playing the part that Duke made so famous. Again, I don't expect the Coens have to answer to anyone as they have always done it their own way and made wild comments about their films, sometimes positive and many times negative. The new Film draws sometimes verbatim from the Original Script which accounts for the Editors to have drawn from the original film. And of course Thespian Actors such as Bridges applaud themselves by not drawing off somebody else's performance! I strongly advise to screen the original Film. "The new True Grit will gracefully ride into the sunset!

'True Grit' (Coen brothers) offers you a very enjoyable ride with Mattie.. A dedicated 14- year old who's going after the murderer of her Dad. Hallee Steinfeld plays a convincing mature young lady. With Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon as men on her side she goes out to do so.. Excellent cinematographic work (Roger Deakins). Cameramovements excellent. Wide panoramic shoot out in the valley beautiful captured. Grading suitable. A remarkable Coen brothers film with some chronologically errors..

reviews.review_title: Disappointed in the acting and slow plot
reviews.content: I read all the reviews about not comparing the two movies (1969 vs 2010)... That makes no sense as the two movies are based on the same book and were very close in telling the story (Mattie Ross has a much stronger role in the new movie which I did like). I would have liked the characters, especially Jeff Bridges to speak a little more clearly as it mostly sounded fake and very annoying. Subtitles on a few parts would have helped.. It's almost like they thought everyone back then should speak like cavemen (although some of the conversations were very educated which contradicted their ability to speak).I did however really like the humor and one liners added to the movie as well as the great action shots (hanging 3 at the start, chopping off fingers, cutting down man from tree, etc).It was worth seeing for sure but I will not see it again or buy it for my movie collection.
Good cast good acting good scenery good filming but regretfully a nothing plot

reviews.review_title: Worst Western ever, and very boring! OVER RATED!
reviews.content: This movie was way to over rated, My friend and I went to see it because we only heard good things about it. We expected a REAL western movie with gunslinging and big action scenes but all we go where scenes with the main character mumbling and staring at people.... The main story was very boring for a western, All they ever did was ride their horses, Talk and Shoot one bullet every half an hour which is rare in a cowboy movie.. I know they tried to stick to the book but i think they should have made it a little bit better... It was VERY boring.. I was actually yawning..See it if you like the book and are more of a Story person, If you like real westerns with gunslinging and all of the other cool features with westerns do NO SEE IT!

I absolutely love this remake. Hailee Steinfield was phenomenal as Mattie (as was Kim Darby in the original BTW) and Jeff Bridges does a good Rooster - in fact if there was a weak link at all I would have to say that maybe Matt Damon was possibly slightly miss-caste as the Texas Ranger. But the star performance of all was the language - and if the script writer doesn't win an Oscar for this film then there's no justice. Along with Mattie's pony-tails, it just seemed to capture and encapsulate the era perfectly - and it was beautiful - poetic even. Is this better than the original? You might think this should be the six million dollar question: but the truth of the matter is that it really isn't that important a question - because this remake truly stands on its own two feet. My gut feeling is that the original will stand the test of time better that this remake - John Wayne at his absolute best is simply something that is impossible to duplicate - but then this remake doesn't try to - and in this it makes for a beautiful addition to the Franchise.The one part of the film though that might have been better left on the cutting room floor was the slightly random and completely extraneous interlude with the Doctor in the Bear skin. I guess this was being "true to the book" - but even so....

Hello all.First of all i would like to say that i enjoyed the movie.It was well played by the cast and some of the scenes were beautiful shot but for those who did not saw the 1969th movie, please do.For those who enjoyed that one i can assure you that you will enjoy the John Wayne film.Personally i watched both of them one after another and i liked the first one more.It seems that the new age westerns are missing something that the old-school once have but i am not really sure what it is.Maybe the views, or maybe the authenticity i don't know.Maybe someone will understand me :).For those who will be seeing the John Wayne adaptation in the role of Rooster Cogburn i just can say ... have a nice trip :)Bye!

Was really looking forward to seeing True Grit. From the trailers and the reviews it appeared as though it was going to be great. I really like a good period movie, especially westerns. The look, sound and feel of the time period was captured quite well at the beginning, but once they left town to set out on the hunt there wasn't much to distinguish it from other westerns, as there was only a few people still involved in the plot and there was no towns or settlements to capture the essence of the time. The other thing I didn't like was there was very little action in the first half of the movie. They did a good job of developing the characters, even though mostly the conversations were uninteresting, but it needed a fight or shootout or something to reflect how tough it was in the old west of that period. After all it is a western. The ending was more like an old Disney movie, not what you'd expect from the Coen bros. The acting in the movie was terrific. Gotta give them credit. Bridges and the girl were outstanding as was Matt Damon. I wish Josh Brolin would've been given a bigger part as he was the man they were chasing.

This is one of the best modern westerns out there, albeit its a remake. Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon are excellent as well as the supporting cast. Barry Peppers "Lucky Ned" was great and sadly didn't get written into the script enough.The one oddity I found was the vocabulary, grammar and the cadence of the actors speech. It gives this movie a very unique feel among westerns, in a good way.This is the best modern western since Unforgiven by far and I highly recommend it. And the only "romance" is the fatherly affection Rooster feels for Mattie!

I never saw the original True Grit but was Mattie Ross as obnoxious as portrayed in the remake? The story is fairly well done and enjoyable as is the cinematography. I'm not a huge fan of westerns but this one kept my interest well enough. I think Bridges and Damon did a fine job portraying their respective characters but Mattie Ross seemed a bit green. I didn't find myself believing her character. Her whole persona was that of an obnoxious child who gets whatever she wants. I think her stubbornness could have been accomplished in other ways that would make her character more likable and relatable. At any rate, the movie was "ok" overall, nothing spectacular and nothing horrible either. I'm sure it will be enjoyed by most people who are fans of this genre.

reviews.review_title: Great remake. As good as the Classic? Time will tell.
reviews.content: Comparing True Grit to the original is like comparing apples to watermelons. If you start there, you will be disappointed. The first is one of the greats of all time and a classic, the remake is a great movie, in time, maybe a classic. Time will tell on that.I was first intrigued when I read a review that stated the lines in the second version, the Coen version, were straight from the book. After just finishing the book, I can honestly say, the author of that opinion is delusional, on drugs, I wish I had , and flat out wrong. In fact, the first True Grit follows the book, scene for scene and line for line , much more accurately than the remake. It is like A Christmas Carol or Bonnie & Clyde. If you read the book, or book(s) for B& C....all the movies put parts in that follow the books & yet all of them go on their own too. Between them all, you get a lot of the original story....eventually. The first meeting between Mattie and Rooster, in particular, piqued my interest in regards to reading the book. As I assumed, meeting at an out house was not in the book. It is one of the few flaws in the remake that is typical of modern film makers. It appears, some of the least desirable human conditions excite the young movie minds, be it vomiting or bowel movements, the young directors seem to think the public wants to watch these less dignified and visually unstimulating acts. The Coen brothers most heralded film, Fargo, again had a prominent vomit scene, so you should come to expect that in their creations. What is worse is, the scene is completely out of character for Mattie Ross. If you read the book you will know, she would never have chose to do that, no matter how headstrong she is, she is still at the age of 14, a lady. A very practical lady at that, who would have waited for Rooster to re-enter the bar so she could converse.The distinct difference in the basic plot and decision making of Rooster, in the remake, compared to the book or the original movie, is confusing. His knowledge of the Indian territories is discarded to some extent in the new version along with his resolve to catch the bandits and the relationship with the Texas Ranger. In book adaptations, I can't help but always wonder, if you didn't like the plot, why did you do the movie? That being said, this is an excellent film. The look, direction, music, mood, acting, script is all of the highest quality and it was enjoyable from start to finish. Seeing an ingénue is always exciting and Hallie Stanfield shines. Between her, Chloe Grace Moretz and Raffey Cassidy, one has to wonder, how can a kid understand life enough to portray that emotion on film? If you haven't seen them, both the original and this version is must see for movie aficionados and for the causal movie goer alike. Both versions are fun and examples of the best of their era or any other era.

This movie is great.The acting is amazing Jeff Bridges should win a Oscar and Matt Damon was also amazing.This was a lot better than the first TRUE GRIT.This movie also has a lot of action and some parts of funny and this movie also has a lot of drama to.This also is another great movie by the Coen brothers.I also like that Matt Damon leaves in the movie and then comes because it gives the movie more excitement.The bad part about the movie was the beginning and the end of the movie.But over all the movie was great and exciting.I also think Jeff Brides did a better job than John Wayne from the old TRUE GRIT.I also think the person who played the girl was really good.This movie is really good and I suggest you watch it.

reviews.review_title: Good remake however, credit should be given where credit is due.
reviews.content: After much anticipation for the release of this film, I sat down to enjoy a fine performance by the main credited actors, Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and Josh Brolin. It quickly became apparent that the true star of this feature was not to be Mr. Brolin nor Mr. Damon and not even the seasoned Mr. Bridges. The incredible performance by a young Miss Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross stole the show. While Damon, Brolin and Bridges all turned in wonderful performances, it is my opinion that the theatrical credits on the advertisements should actually have omitted Brolin as a headliner and listed Miss Steinfeld in his stead. Although it was Brolin's character of Tom Chaney that tied the entire plot together, he actually had a total of only 10 minutes of screen time. I look forward to seeing more of her work in the future.I rather enjoyed Mr. Bridges interpretation of the role of Rooster Cogburn that John Wayne had made so famous. "The Duke" has some big boots to fill and "The Dude" did his best to fill them. Watching Bridges performance, I couldn't help but be reminded of Kris Kristofferson. All in all a great film with actually very little "blood n guts" gun fights. I would suggest to all who see this one also take the time to watch the original "True Grit" featuring John Wayne and see what a great job Bridges did with holding true to his character.

reviews.review_title: Simply the most impressive movie making Hollywood has done in some time.
reviews.content: If you are a fan of westerns, or just fantastic movies you must see True Grit. This is easily the best movie you will see all year. Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld were amazing. As a big time John Wayne fan I have to say that I went into this with some skepticism. Avoiding this movie due to being a John Wayne fan would truly be a loss. This movie is well made, and detracts nothing from the original. If anything it enhances it and fills in a huge amount of emotional depth that I feel was missing before. The script was perfect and the performances incredible. Hailee Steinfeld's performance as Mattie is Oscar-worthy. She is the Mattie I wanted to see, likable and strong willed. Bridges is effortless as Rooster Cogburn. I felt like this movie was made by people who were passionate about getting it right. This is a movie worthy of and surpassing it's heritage.

reviews.review_title: This is the "True Grit" that John Wayne SHOULD have been in!!
reviews.content: This is the "True Grit" John Wayne SHOULD have been in. Everything from the scripting to scenery to props to costumes.....all of it top notch. The dialogue reminds me of the excellent scripting of HBO's Deadwood, minus the profanity. The sentence structure and verbiage are perfect. Jeff Bridges portrayal of Rooster Cogburn in sterling. As an avid John Wayne fan, I was afraid I would find it lacking or in some way demeaning or "less than" the Duke deserved. To this fear I now say to Jeff Bridges, "The Duke is proud of your portrayal of the character he earned his ONLY Oscar for." I don't know if that matters to Jeff, but it matters to me and all real John Wayne fans. This is a movie you do not want to miss.

So not having any expectations set the only thing to get me excited for this film were the Cohen brothers, the trailer and of course Jeff Bridges. I watched the trailer a number of times and after seeing the movie I can tell you they show entirely too much in the trailer. That being said, if you haven't seen the trailer, avoid it.Right off the bat the film gets into the story of Mattie's dad and quickly gives the audience a breakdown of who this girl is based off of her immediate interactions with people in the beginning of the film. The girl who is casted for Mattie did a flawless job. She was truly remarkable in her role.Throughout the movie the dialog is sharp, witty and cunning. Many times I found it hard to keep up with all of the back and forth diatribe. Many of the words/terms I didn't understand to be honest and I fancy myself to be decently educated. You can tell the Cohen's did their research for the time to match the speaking, clothing and decor of the old Western times.The chemistry between Bridges and "Mattie" is top notch and even better is the relationship between Bridges and Damon. My respect-o-meter for Damon keeps growing after every film I watch him in and he does not disappoint in this film at all. All of the side casting, who are mostly unknowns are great and more than memorable. The one spoiler I'll give is a simple casting one, Barry Pepper makes a great appearance in the film and until watching him in this role, I forgot how much I like him as an actor and wish he did more work.I loved Crazy Heart and would whole heartedly expect Bridges to be nominated again for this role. This guy has become so much better with age. He is equally impressive in this movie as he was in Crazy Heart. There are some similarities to be sure, but the roles are diverse enough where you won't have the feeling of "Been there, done that." If I had one wish, not complaint, it would have been the score. I'm big on film scores and that is one element I felt lacking in the movie. There were some major opportunities to enhance some scenes with a proper score. Aside from that, I felt nothing but love and admiration for the movie and it'll make a nice edition to my limited Blu-Ray collection.In conclusion, if you're a Western fan, go see the movie. If you like the Cohen Bros.' previous works, go see the film. If you're a Bridges or Damon fan, go see the movie. If you want to know how it compares to the original, "I can do nothing for ya son."

Not a great movie, but wonderful in many ways, especially the performance by Jeff Bridges. I liked the vast scruffiness of the landscape. Also this is the rare Coen Bros. movie with human warmth. (Although the other movies generally don't suffer for their chilliness, except for "The Hudsucker Proxy.") I wasn't all in for the performance by Hailee Steinfeld. She's beautiful, and did well enough, except that I thought the portrayal could have been more stern and rigorous. The Mattie Ross character works much of her comedy playing against an Old Testament determination for vengeance that seemed softened in this movie. She seemed too warm and cuddly, especially toward the end. Don't know if that was the director's choice, or the actor's.

Let me start by saying i'm not a Coen brothers fan, i'm sure many of you will say that's because I lack the intelligence or a certain nuance required to enjoy such masterpieces, maybe you are correct. In any case I am entitled to my opinion.First of all I was really looking forward to this film, I have not seen the original but it seemed to tick all the right boxes, wild west, action, deep story, a star turn by Jeff Bridges. Most of this was gleaned from the quite misleading trailer and various reviews on this site. Well I can't say it had any of those things. Like previous Coen films I found the story to be slow paced and dragging in parts, I felt there was no development with the central characters, no sense of where they had come from and why they were the way they were, this made me completely disinterested in them or what happened to them, by about halfway through I couldn't care less who lived or died.I feel like cinema is something that has evolved over time with non-linear storytelling almost common place these days. There's nothing wrong with a story having a traditional beginning, middle and end in that order, but it does need to work harder to hold your attention and this film just doesn't and feels outdated because of it.

reviews.review_title: True Grit is often spoken about as a classic
reviews.content: True Grit is often spoken about as a classic. It's John Wayne's apotheosis, a Western that even people who hate Westerns have often seen. It was made in 1969, the year of Easy Rider, Midnight Cowboy and Medium Cool. Those films captured and seemed to be on the side of the turbulence gusting through American society at the time. What made True Grit stand out was that it appeared to back authority rather than revolution, the rule of law rather than the romantic appeal of outlaws. Westerns haven't gone out of fashion (the likes of 3:10 to Yuma, The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford are evidence to the contrary), but it's hard not to approach the film without wondering why the Coen brothers chose to make it. Unfortunately, by its close, that question still hangs there wholly unanswered.

I've never been a big fan of Westerns, though I've certainly respected the concept. But despite my lack of enthusiasm for the genre, I truly enjoyed this movie. What it really brought it to life for me, though was the acting. Jeff Bridges is a truly great performer. I've seen and enjoyed several of his movies, but the way he portrayed Rooster was very convincing. While his character wasn't entirely unique I found it very easy to believe and enjoy. And Hailee Steinfeld's performance was just as strong. I found that both of these characters together drove the movie and set it apart from other Westerns that I've seen. The energy between the two was very strong, and most of what I enjoyed from the film was just listening to their dialogue. Overall, a very strong movie that was driven by well played and interesting characters.

reviews.review_title: A good movie. Not The Duke, but still enjoyable.
reviews.content: I didn't expect to like this movie. I'm a big John Wayne fan, and I was not happy with the "heresy" of remaking the movie that won him his Oscar. However, having said that and having seen the new film, I was pleasantly surprised.The Coen Brothers' denials to the contrary, this is a pretty faithful remake of the 1969 classic, but that's o.k. It was an enjoyable story then, and it's still enjoyable now.The performances are uniformly good, with Hailee Steinfeld creating quite an impression, and Matt Damon definitely outshining the rather wooden performance of Glenn Campbell in the original. However, Barry Pepper and Josh Brolin, although good in their roles, don't really make me forget Robert Duvall and Jeff Corey.Jeff Bridges is good as Rooster. Don't get me wrong. But he can't compare to John Wayne, especially in the final gunfight. ("Fill your hand, you son-of-a-b****!" It's the greatest delivery of a line in The Duke's career, IMO. With Bridges, it's just another line in an good performance.) Overall, a good movie, but all it did was make me want to go back and watch the original.

Mercyah81's comment, "Bridges, you couldn't understand a damn thing that came out of his mouth," was right on the money. I bought the DVD, and after about 20 minutes I turned the closed-captioning on so that I could understand what the hell Bridges was saying.One of the best parts of the movie is the hanging at Fort Smith. The two condemned white men get to say their last words, but when the Indian tries to say something, the executioner yanks the hood over his head then walks over and pulls the lever. Very authentic mindset for a movie based in 1880.The part where they found the guy hanging 50 feet off of the ground, and the ensuing body-trading, was just plain weird. It added nothing to the movie.

I was very surprised when I saw this movie because the Cohens are usually so great with movies. This movie was a carbon copy of the original. I can't see how another poster said that it was original and incomparable to the original. The only thing different in this movie was the ending. It was a poor ending at that. It didn't fit at all with the rest of the story and was completely unnecessary to include. I'm very angry at the Cohens for this movie. It is a shame that this movie was nominated for an Oscar and other movies that were deserving were not (like Inception). It just goes to show you that what Monique said last year at the Oscars was true. Politics is sometimes put before performance. I wonder if Spike Lee would have directed this movie if it still would have been nominated for an Oscar.....just saying!

This is my first time I am watching a movie directed by the Coen Brothers and I must confess that I am impressed. In "True Grit", Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) was 14 years when her father was murdered by one of his helping hands named Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Mattie with a very strong mentality wants to do everything possible to get hold of the killer for revenge. Now, she is in a state where she can only rely on Rooster Cogburn (Bridges), a Federal Marshall whose status for shooting his prisoners makes him the right person for Mattie's intended cause. Later an agreement was reached to embark on an adventure to search for the killer, Tom. Meanwhile LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) who happens to be a Texas ranger arrives on the trail of Chaney. LaBoeuf has been pursuing him for another crime concerning the murder of a Senator in Texas. He agrees to work with Cogburn, who is more familiar with the terrain where Chaney is hiding. Mattie did not like the idea because her intension was to make sure that Chaney is hanged for killing her father and not for the crime in Texas. Mattie was left behind even though Cogburn agreed to travel with her and instead left with LeBoeuf to track down Chaney. One point that was questionable to me was when Mattie was refused passage on the ferry that conveyed Cogburn and LaBoeuf, Mattie crossed the river ridding at the back of her horse. LaBoeuf showed his displeasure by whopping Mattie with a switch rod, Cogburn to my surprise waited for too long as if he was enjoying the action being taken before he finally stopped him. The transition on the pace of the film as a whole was based on one of the traditional transitional devices, after critically observing the film; I found that the editor used vertical line to move across the screen to wipe the previous images away. It also show that the slow cut method was often used and this type of cutting more often stimulates the feeling of a tranquil observer which to me is a way to attract a particular group of viewers. The pace was good and calm for viewers especially the application of sound to aid some sections of the transition. I also realized that at certain points the cutting speed changes because the rhythm needs to correspond with the pace of the action. I haven't seen the 1969 version "True Grit" but I think there is no need going to see that, this movie will be recommended to others and I hope they will all like it. Kudos to the directors (Coen Brothers), the editors and the producers for the great sound, lighting and picture angles.

reviews.review_title: Great movie - Not the same as the original - but as good
reviews.content: A great deal has been written about this movie so I will not try to analyse, it has probably all been done. The inimitable John Wayne played this movie as expected, if you have watched other John Wayne movies. This version, although the same story, has a flavour definitely different. Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn in this movie is somehow grubbier, less likable, but more credible than the original. Mattie Ross is unbelievably bright and savvy (she cannot be 14 yrs old!) but still feels the same character as the old version.Matthew Damon disappears entirely into LaBoeuf. I would have preferred Barry Pepper as Tom Chaney because I could have hated him. For me, Josh Brolin seemed misplaced. The frequent full use of not instead if 'nt I found irritating. The film for me is as good as the original, although poles apart. In this case, the remake is not a rehash but a viable, alternative take.

reviews.review_title: True Grit shows that it is a worthwhile remake
reviews.content: I recently watched this 2010 remake of True Grit which was directed by Joel and Ethan Coen. Normally this is not my type of movie to watch but I decided to go out of my zone and try it. The storyline and main idea of the movie is somewhat typical for a western, all about seeking revenge for a wrong, but what makes it different is that it is coming from 14year old Mattie Ross portrayed perfectly by Hailee Steinfeld. She wants to hire a U.S. Marshall, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) and a Texas Ranger, LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) to bring justice to Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) the man who killed her father over a couple of gold pieces. Mattie and Rooster have such a tumultuous relationship that it is hard to imagine them having anything other than a business relationship. She is constantly trying to keep him sober enough to keep him on track with finding Chaney and shows such control that we tend to forget that she is only 14. Thus the movie title comes in to play with Mattie, Rooster and LaBoeuf always facing some challenge to their own "grit" and to see if they have what it takes to continue on.This film reminds me a little of Unforgiven starring Clint Eastwood who is hired to track down a man who cut up a prostitute or whore as they were referred to back then. While there is different elements to the story in Unforgiven, the same hire someone to find the bad person and bring them to justice is still a huge part of it. They both have their showdowns with the bad guys.The cinematography is done well with so much attention to detail. I can still picture the smoke and sun-filled courtroom when we are first introduced to Rooster Cogburn. The lighting was done well too. The sun coming in through the windows of the courtroom was so blinding that you're sure it's hot outside. And the night shots were done so that the audience can still see what is going on without taking anything away from it being at night. The scenery for the west was outstanding in this film. From the mountains and wide open ranges to the river every shot taken made one feel as if they were right there in the old west.This is one of the better remakes of movies I have seen in quite some time. While no one could ever come close to replacing John Wayne as Rooster Cogburn, Jeff Bridges did an outstanding job. I was equally impressed by the performance of Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie. For a movie of this type that I usually don't go out of my way to watch these days, I am glad I took a chance and watched this one. It is definitely one to watch and now I am ready to go back and watch the original one too.

reviews.review_title: Hard to match the original film
reviews.content: Remaking True Grit was a great idea that doesn't pan out in the long run. I am a big fan of the Coens and I absolutely loved "No country for old men" but this remake lacks the humor of the original. Some hinted that it wasn't as entertaining as the original and I would have to agree. Honestly, the first time I watched it, I fell asleep. For me personally it is not that much of a stretch to fall asleep during movies, you can ask my friends, but I guess this one is a little long in the tooth at certain points. As for the cast, Jeff Bridges is a good actor but his portrayal of Rooster is too overdone and (pardon the pun) too gritty. He is not as animated as John Wayne and that is one of the missing elements. The girl(Haylee Stanfield) is very good but I still like Kim Darby better. Darby was much more spirited in the role IMHO. Matt Damon is good as LeBoufe, much better acting than Glen Campbell in the same role but still Glen did a fair job and was just there as a means of fodder for the Duke anyway. The guy that plays Lucky Ned Pepper was probably the best in the whole movie but in too short of a role. As for cinematography, it is a beautifully shot film. The Coens do excel in this area for sure.****possible spoiler**** The pace of the movie is better after the first 30 min is over as opposed to the original version which was a laugh riot especially the exchange between Mattie Ross and Stonehill played by Strother Martin in the orig. The guy who plays Stonehill in the 2010 version is a bit too dry and humorless.He is probably not a bad actor in other roles but this portrayal is a little too stiff. ****possible spoiler**** A minor point for those offended easily language wise, there is only one minuscule instance in the orig of cussing but in this one Rooster says one too many of a certain word compared to the original, however, it was not that profuse.****possible spoiler**** I have heard some complain about the ending but the Coens are generally by the book about such matters so the ending didn't personally bother me.

reviews.review_title: Don't see what the fuss is all about
reviews.content: So, I watched both True Grit films this week, the first being the new version...The story is good...a girl who's father is killed is determined to find him and make him pay. She uses her wits and resources to convince an old cranky Marshall to help her while a Texas Lawman is also willing to get the bad guy, but for different reasons...he wants to bring him back to Texas to be hanged...Now...after seeing the film I went "meh"...like I said, good story, everything looks good, the snowfall in particular really pops. As for the performances...well, here we go: Bridges done just fine although there's really nothing outstanding about him. He plays a drunk old cranky lawman, so picture that..OK, that's it....Matt Damon is odd in this. He's playing it serious one moment, then smirks and acts like he's in a comedy. He's very mis-cast here. Josh Brolin, well, he's OK for the few minutes he's on screen, but he speaks so oddly I didn't know what he was saying half the time, same as every guy in the film really. It was annoying.When it was over the girl did a good job, probably the best of the bunch but the ending was really lame, trying to go for depth and emotion and really it's a standard ending and it didn't leave me feeling much of anything. Certainly not worth all the nominations and awards, but given them probably because people think the Coen's can do no wrong or something. Overall I wouldn't recommend it. See Tombstone or The Proposition instead.Oh and as for people saying "It's totally different from the original"...No..even the dialog is the same in a lot of scenes. The only differences are in the ending, otherwise it's the same movie.

Terrible. People didn't speak like that in the late 19th Century. I have early recordings from around the turn of the century, and except for an Eastern accent, people actually spoke in contractions just like we do today! They wouldn't be that hard to understand. Some dialog coach decided that every word should be spoken without contractions in a robotic manner. I tried to keep it out of my mind, but the delivery of almost every actor was so stilted that I couldn't continue after 20 minutes of "See Dick run. Run, run, run. See Jane. See Jane run. See Spot run, run run run." It ruined the movie for me. I don't care what happened in it. I deleted it from my queue.

reviews.review_title: Great to look at and well performed, but largely a slavish remake!
reviews.content: I look forward to Coen Brothers movies but this was something of a disappointment. Beautiful to look at, and with wonderful performances all round, especially from Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld, this should have been a film to savour, so why the overall negative impression? The problem is that the movie is almost entirely a line by line, scene by scene remake of the original, itself no more than an average western. This remake contributes some nice performances but adds nothing of consequence, except perhaps for an almost unpleasantly downbeat and unnecessary epilogue. Moreover, the original was played with far more humour and heart, leaving behind it a pleasant memory, not a bitter aftertaste. I am truly surprised that this movie has attracted so much critical acclaim and that it should even be in the running for the Academy Award for best picture.

reviews.review_title: I was told you had True Grit
reviews.content: I love a movie that has a good story. True Grit (2010) is one of those movies. The Coen brothers did a fantastic job on this movie. The setting was appropriate for the time in which the movie takes place. I thought the costumes and makeup were very well done. Each person looks like how you would picture someone to look during that time. The cast is top notch. I am a big fan of Jeff Bridges (Rooster Cogburn) and Matt Damon (LaBoeuf). Everyone acted their parts very well but Bridges is the star in this film. He does an amazing job portraying Rooster Cogburn. Hailee Steinfeld (Mattie Ross) is also one of the bright spots of the film. True Grit (2010) is about good vs. evil. It is a movie about justice prevailing. Mattie's father is killed by a man named Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). She goes into town to try and find someone that will help her avenge her fathers death and bring justice to Tom Chaney. Mattie hears of Rooster Cogburn and decides to enlist his help. She says that she heard he is a man of "true grit' and hires him to help her find Tom Chaney. LeBoeuf is also looking for Tom Chaney so he joins them for the manhunt. The most compelling part of the movie is the relationship that develops between Rooster and Mattie. As they are searching for Tom Chaney they form a bond with one another. I enjoyed watching their relationship develop as the film progressed.One of the better aspects of True Grit (2010) is the dialog. Taking place in Arkansas the characters have the typical accent one would expect to hear from that state. The way that people spoke back then is different than most people speak now and that was evident in the movie. The women spoke very properly in the film much like one would have expected to hear in that time. Laboeuf is from Texas so his diction and manner of speaking are different than that of Rooster's. The film did a good job of recognizing that and it was evident each time they spoke to one another.I was impressed with the way they used camera angles during the film. There were quite a few scenes that made you feel like an observer. In the beginning when three men were being hanged, the camera was down in the crowd looking up at the men. That gave the sense of actually being there and watching it happen. When LaBoeuf was surrounded the camera was up high, giving the feel like you were there with Mattie and Rooster watching what was going to happen to LaBoeuf. Overall I thought True Grit (2010) was a fantastic movie. The story was very compelling and kept me watching and wanting to know what was going to happen. The classic good vs. evil western where justice prevails never seems to get old and True Grit (2010) is one of the better films in this genre.

reviews.review_title: Jamstervision: Never was shooting food so much fun! True Grit reviewed
reviews.content: So your pappy was killed by a marauder and you're a tween in the 1800's, what would you do? Obviously go out for revenge by looking for someone with True Grit to take them out! Here's my take:* Captain Jack Sparrow has found his lifemate! Pirate patch..check! Unique, grisled voice..check! Gun...check! Sounds like a match made in heaven, because watching Rooster in action was a real treat. This guy's seen it all, and you can tell by the way he carries himself. But seriously, what's with the corn muffin shooting contest? If anything, you think someone with the amount of experience Rooster's had would want to save the food for survival and save his A- game for the task at hand, but I guess there must've been a guilty pleasure in 1800's shooting foodstuffs contests (that and drinking a bottle of mighty fine whiskey)...jamstervision.blogspot.com

reviews.review_title: I don't blame the Coen's for the "no ending" ending
reviews.content: It's not their fault. It just isn't fashionable any more to end things in a way that smacks of some bigger narrative, as though there is some greater purpose to things.The acting was superb, as everyone says. I enjoyed the dialogue, and am grateful for the Coen brothers in trying to preserve it. I often wonder how much we, as those who never lived it, can say, "It was authentic". But it sure SEEMED as though a good amount of research went into the dialogue. If so, I am grateful to the Coens for this. If not, I am bothered to be misled, because the dialogue indicates we as a race may really yet have such a capability.But it was the ending that disappointed me. It was just a big let-down. Maybe the philosophy behind what is entertainment has changed, or maybe what people find entertaining has changed, or maybe what the movers-and-shakers think WE should think is entertaining has changed. Anyway, I found the "no story here" ending kind of nullifying as to the rest of what I had seen.I do feel sympathy for anyone trying to make a "good" movie these days, though. If it ties up everything in a bow, it is seen as trite and naive. Perhaps because this movie looks back around an age of American prosperity on an era that in some ways matches our own for bleakness, it could be said to have captured something for today.The decorum of the people as represented in this movie, to me that was what informed me (or entertained me, whatever that term may mean).

reviews.review_title: Coens Brothers still at the top of their craft
reviews.content: The word "grit" will now be in my everyday vocabulary. For TRUE GRIT, the Coen Brothers have written a screenplay of such articulation and cadence that if it does not win an Oscar, then the award should be abolished. I chose not to see the John Wayne version of the film, which is against my custom, but I am very glad I went into the Jeff Bridges version fresh, not knowing the fate of the characters at the end. However, I have heretofore not mentioned the fools that populate movie theaters in 2010, as I did not want to put that illness into my reviews, but this time my viewing experience was so interrupted at the start by punk teens and their DAMN mobile phones, that it did effect me the entire film, though they left five minutes into the movie. Despite that extraordinary bane of modern society, I was still mesmerized by the dialogue and the performances. I will once again declare that if Hailee Steinfeld does not win the best actress Oscar, the award should be abolished. Whoever cast her in the role of heroine of TRUE GRIT deserves an Oscar as well. She was absolutely perfectly cast and delivered the complex Coens Brothers dialogue with skill and gravity so that it did not seem absurd that a 14-year old girl of the old west would speak in sentences just below tongue twister level. Matt Damon did a great job as well in his delivery, as did Jeff Bridges, although his dialogue was of a whole different sort, but no less witty. The adults in the theater laughed often at his quips, and I of course ha-ed. I sincerely wish those punk kids had not robbed me of maximum enjoyment of this film. The Coen Brothers are truly master filmmakers. They just command the screen like few other writer/directors can. They cut no corners. Every second of film time is maximum creativity and pure cinema. It would be my pleasure one day to shake their hands and offer my humble appreciation of their skill. TRUE GRIT reminds me once again how much I, personally, still yearn for the opportunity to be a Man. In the days TRUE GRIT was set in, you were either a Man or a damn fool, literally. And you were free to be a Man. I do not necessarily believe in a soul, but I feel inside of me my spirit thirsting to be a Man out on the land in an organic world that is real and tangible. So much of the 2010 world has no meaning, no physicality, and it all just serves to sissify men. Just the fact that at least half the men my age go around wearing flip-flops! Is there any greater sign of the sissification of society? My footwear of choice? Waterproof Goretex XCR trail running shoes, footwear suitable for any environment from sea level to 4,000 meters (I summited Mt. Fuji in such shoes). Like the gas station scene in NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN, TRUE GRIT had scenes of dialogue that were aural candy and so exceptionally interesting I strained my ears just so I could hear what comes next a picosecond sooner. Hailee as the young heroine Mattie Ross was a character of utmost class and high ethical standards with great sympathy and compassion, even for those who deserved little. If I were the parent or guardian of a teenage girl, I would use Mattie as an example of what a young person is capable, and to show what the power of having class, ethics and intelligence is because 2010 society is almost completely devoid of both. For example, Mattie speaks to two men during one scene, only one of them rises to talk to her about a serious matter. She gives a warm good-bye to the standing man, and in an articulate dart speaks to the other, "Trash! Enjoy your seat." This may be a very small thing most viewers would not care about, but to me it was a detail and further display of what burns inside the character of Mattie, and what makes her memorable. If my movie experience was not sabotaged by those punks early on, I may be using the word "masterpiece" in this review. I still will long think about TRUE GRIT, and its characters. This is a classic modern western and deserves any praise it gets. P.S. — I requested a refund,but accepted free tickets since the registers were already closed.

reviews.review_title: Great Western Sure to Be a Classic
reviews.content: When you see a movie with actors like Jeff Bridges, Josh Brolin, Matt Damon and Barry Pepper in it you know it is going to be a good one. When you add in the talented newcomer Hailee Steinfeld playing Mattie Rose it is not only a good one but a bona fide hit. From the start this revenge themed western classic has a darker air about it than the original movie starring John Wayne filmed in 1969. With the movie starting with a narration by Mattie retelling her story, you feel the focus of the movie has shifted from a story about a drunkard US Marshal as in the 1969 version, to be truer to the novel. Do not mistake this focus on Mattie to take away from Jeff Bridges excellent portrayal of Reuben J. "Rooster" Cogburn. With Mattie's willingness to sleep with the dead in the mortuary you can get the sense that she is sure of herself and will not be put off. Mattie's dealing with Colonel Stonehill (played venerable character actor Dakin Matthews) is something to behold, and the quintessential scene where she proves she is not a girl to be trifled with. After this early verbal jousting the tone is set for the rest of Mattie's conversations. At the onset of any conversation with little Miss Mattie you are drawn to the edge of your seat gleefully awaiting her victory of her thoroughly thrashing her opponent. She employs words like razors and her lawyer (J. Noble Daggett) like a cannon. Rooster Cogburn moves from indignant to Mattie to admiring her gumption. Her failure to yield from the very start of their quest to find her father killer and the many attempt that follow earns his respect. Not many 14 year old girls would ford a river on horseback to be spanked on the other side for the troubles that is where Mattie proves yet again she is not an ordinary young lady. Her interactions with Matt Damon's character Texas Ranger Laboeuf are as fun to watch as the thrashing she gave the Colonel. Laboeuf is a more believable character than from Glen Campbell's portrayal form the 1969 movie. Laboeuf's character is not the only one that stands out against the original. Josh Brolin playing Tom Chaney (the antagonist) and Berry Pepper as "Lucky" Ned Pepper (the gang leader) both stand out during every scene they are in. From start to finish there is no scene that you find yourself wishing along or waiting for action. The Coen brothers have not only remade the movie bringing it in-line with the novel but have brought the book to life. Taking the focus from the Marshal that won John Wayne an Oscar to refocusing it on the original heroine adds realism and a True Grit to the film.

I haven't seen any western movie before. But I really enjoyed the movie. The acting from Jeff Bridges is excellent as the aged US Marshall Rooster Cogburn. I think the movie mainly describes about Mattie Ross (Steinfeld) who hires someone to hunt down the murderer of her father one Tom Chaney (Brolin), her acting is pretty good for a little girl. The acting from Matt Damon as Texas ranger LaBoeuf is not bad. Overall, this movie describes to us a different thing about western movie. The visual appearance of this movie is great. It has the setting that the places in that time setting would have. You feel like you were actually watching something that could be from that time era instead of a modern movie.The movie was very well done

True Grit is one of the best Western movies. It was a story about a retired sheriff who helped a girl to find her father's murderer. There were many scenes that showed her struggle to find someone to kill the murderer. Although there were many problems but her believe made her met someone who can help her. Jeff Bridges could play well as Rooster Cogburn. I didn't realize La Boeuf was Matt Damon, his beard made him different. Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross also play well, she is a great actress. I think it's really amazing. Places, plot, story, and the acting from the actor and actress are really cool for me. This movie was a remake. But it's still worthed to watch.

reviews.review_title: Why ruin a good movie (spoilers maybe)
reviews.content: Why do these idiots that want to remake a great movie always want to ruin it. Do we have to have a crappy sad ending to a movie that originally had an uplifting happy ending? I mean is that how they show their directing/writing/producing talent.I mean really WTF? We have to kill her horse? We have to separate her and cogburn? BTW very few people bitten by rattle snakes die. If you didn't like the original why remake a-hole. The whole thing that made the original great was the relationship built between the 3 people and the happy ending and you take the majority of the good stuff out. You people are stupid. Who wants to pay 20 bucks and leave a theater feeling like s h i t. Dumb asses

The story: Don't worry about the plot. We've seen it in the 1969 original, or read the book, or seen dozens of other westerns of the same ilk. The story is there. The movie, True Grit, is an interpretation of fine western literature. This is primarily a comparison of Hathaway's (1969) and the Coen's (2010) interpretations of a novel. To compare a 1969 interpretation with one from 2010 is a bit unfair. The difference in the two interpretations is more of some story telling changes and technical change than a brilliance of the Coen's vs. Hathaway. I saw Hathaway's version of True Grit twice. Once in 1969. I was not a John Wayne fan. I left the theater liking the movie – John Wayne and all. The Cast: I saw the 1969 True Grit again, about three hours after seeing the Coen's interpretation. Both films had some terrific and some mediocre actors – Glenn Campbell (LaBoeuf) could sing but not act. Hathaway's interpretation made up for Campbell with too brief encounters with Robert Duvall and Dennis Hopper. In Coen's interpretation, Matt Damon has received rave reviews for his portrayal of LaBoeuf. I was underwhelmed. He does provide counter-point to Bridges' Cogburn. He was straight, law abiding and clean. I was put off by Brolin as Chaney (killer of Mattie's father). He was much too pretty for a member of a gang led by the likes of Lucky Ned Pepper. The characters of Cogburn (Bridges) and Mattie Ross (Hallie Steinfeld) nail their roles. Wayne and Darby are weak in comparison. Wayne delivers lines as Wayne, walks like Wayne, and dresses like Wayne – never dirty or in need of a pressing or a bath. This might reflect the time – in 1969 heroes were clean guys. Bridge's Cogburn not only looks like he slept in his cloths, you can practically smell him. Darby's Mattie was sentimental at times – a character trait all but lacking in Seinfeld's Mattie. Darby was 20 when she played the role; Steinfeld was 13. The Dialogue: Some of the lines from both interpretations are identical – I assume they are from the Portis text. A funeral director tells Mattie (who is looking at her father's corpse) "You can kiss him - - if you like (she doesn't, thank Portis)." Or, Cogburn's line "Fill your hands you son-of-a-bitches." And, many more. The Coen's consistently use what sounds like a more formal language. Contractions in speech are used, but less apparent that in Hathaway. This may be the way Portis wrote the material, or the Coen's dialogue may be based on a more formal language of the time. It seems very appropriate. The Story (2): When Mattie takes her horse across the river to join the search, Cogburn turns and watches her. He has attempted to leave without her. At that point, Mattie has hired Cogburn because he has "true grit." In Coen's version of this scene we see that Mattie, too, has true grit and that Cogburn recognizes it without saying so. In the 1969 version, John Wayne says, "She's a lot like me." Was this because 1) In 1969 movies needed to say what they wanted audiences to know and today movies seem to believe that we can figure it out, or 2) the Coen's could structure the scene and Bridge's could act it to show his regard for Mattie, and Wayne could not act anything but Wayne and had to say it. Toward the end of the film, we see that Mattie's situation has set the stage for Cogburn to be as he once was. The guy who could hold the reins in his teeth, yell, "Fill your hand you son-of-a-bitches." Charge four armed me and kill them all (well, at least three of them). In taking Mattie to the doctor, he shots her horse then carries her the rest of the way. Falls once. Says something to the effect that he's not as young as he once was. Then gets up and carries her the rest of the way. In the effort, he has learned what he once was, he still is. The endings of the two movies differ dramatically. In Hathaway's version Cogburn lives on for a sequel, in Coen's he dies. Ala Coen, Mattie is invited to and shows up at the Wild West show where Cogburn is participating. She's an adult 25 years later (she's 38) Cogburn is has 25 additional years of smoking and drinking. Mattie learns that Cogburn has died. We certainly don't want to see him as a washed up cowboy legend. We want to remember him charging the bad guys with the reins in his teeth, or carrying Mattie through the snow. He has to be dead. As for Jeff Bridges, where could have he gone from Crazy Heart? Did we want to see him in a suit as a Wall Street Banker? (No.) Do we want to see him in "Grandfather Focker"? (Hell, no!) Cogburn is his 2010 role, just as Cogburn was Wayne's role in 1969. The Directors: A single Coen film will never stand alone. It will always be part of a collective works. Let us accept True Grit for the western it is, the novel interpretation it is and it is terrific! Photography! I was absolutely chilled by the snow scenes in the Indian Territory and the scenes of Cogburn racing to the doctors. The land was sometimes beautiful, often foreboding. Unlike the 1969 Technicolor version, cinematographers have become able to shot in the dark. It certainly makes a huge difference. The sound tracks were also striking difference. Hathaway used the orchestral sound of Bernstein – sounding like Bonanza's theme. Coen's version used hymns like "What a friend we have in Jesus" and "Leaning on the everlasting arms." They were much more like the music of the era.

reviews.review_title: "Two thirds of it are either horse-traveling montages or excess dialogue"
reviews.content: From the directors of movies such as No Country for Old Men, The Big Lebowski, and Fargo comes a movie called True Grit. Wait, did you say "from the directors of No Country for Old Men, The Big Lebowski, AND Fargo?" It ALSO currently holds a 95% Fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes? This True Grit must be one amazing movie! 2 Hours Later.What a let down. Dare I say it, but True Grit was kind of...boring.For those of you who don't know, True Grit is a movie about a young girl who hires a U.S Marshal to track down the man who murdered her father. While it doesn't sound like a boring premise, it gets dull pretty fast when there are long stretches of the movie where the main characters are traveling by horse and pony. There's also too much talking, if I may be so crass.Sometimes Jeff Bridges' character has something funny to say, that is, when you can understand him. There are also some great bits of dialogue that come out of the young girls quick-witted mouth, like when she haggles stubbornly with a man with whom her father had previously made a deal with. But there's too much talking when I start zoning out of people's conversations and waiting for the next scene. And no, I'm not some brain dead 11 year old who only wants to watch things blow up; but that doesn't mean that I'm entertained by a movie when two thirds of it are either horse-traveling montages or excess dialogue that I don't feel is necessary.As most people have already said, Hailee Steinfeld (the young girl) delivers a strong performance - as do Bridges, Damon and Brolin. When Steinfeld's character is first introduced she comes off as a sharp yet stubborn little girl. At first I was charmed by her character, but then she outstayed her welcome and I started getting really annoyed with her fast-talking and overly clever dialogue. Is it bad that I actually sympathized with Damon's character when he started spanking and whipping her? Let me note that there are some very good, though few, action scenes scattered across this movie. In particular the last act is very entertaining. Unfortunately though, the movie ends with a very unsatisfying and hurried conclusion - which I won't spoil.I am very disappointed to be giving True Grit just three stars. All signs indicated that this may have been one of my favorite movies of 2010; but just like Black Swan, this movie was hugely overrated. It was praised so high when in reality it's just an average movie albeit a movie by the Coen brothers.Read all my reviews at www.jasonthecritic.com

reviews.review_title: A Western for People who have never seen a good Western
reviews.content: Again, the Coen brothers do show their uncanny talent of telling stories about people who are utterly unlikeable. It is a mystery to me what happened after "Fargo" - as this was the last movie where it was possible for the viewer to at least care A LITTLE BIT about the characters. No doubt Jeff Bridges does a good acting job with his mumbling drunkard "Rooster" Cogburn, same for Hailee Steinfeld's dead-serious little smart-ass Mattie Ross - but really NOBODY CARES. None of the characters have any depth, and therefore, the viewer is left with shrugging and waiting for the end titles to roll. The action goes along without any real surprises, the directing is Hollywood standard, the cinematography is okay. And until the final 15 minutes, the viewer has the impression of watching a so-so Western: nothing special, nothing original. - And then, the Coens pull the worst out of their hats: an endless scene where you wish for either one of the characters (or both) or the horse to die immediately. It DRAGS along, with cheesy music, cheesy cinematography - and it's a pain to see this movie being ruined. Whereas the final sequence starts with the remarkable voice-over line: "25 years is a long time." - And boy, 110 minutes can be a long time, too! - What is left is a stale taste in your mouth, even the impression of having wasted almost two hours of your life for a Western that requires new vocabulary - as "overrated" doesn't capture the disappointment in the slightest way. Go watch "The Outlaw Josey Wales" instead, an underrated gem.

I am am not going to write a review of this excellent film. I am going to tell what happened in the theater after the film ended. No one moved. Through the entire credit sequence not a single person in the theater spoke or got up to leave. A lot of sniffles but absolutely no movement to exit by the nearly packed house. Usually someone has to pee so bad that they get up and exit. But not today. Im 61 and have watched many many films in theaters all over our great country and I have rarely if ever seen such a thing! I hate to predict and am usually wrong but Haille Steinfeld, Jeff Bridges and the Cohen Bros should be Oscar winners for this one.

reviews.review_title: You better die in the summer, because no graves are getting dug in the winter!
reviews.content: I've never been a real western fan, of course I've seen most of the Clint Eastwood' films, the last one I remember watching though, could be seen as the surrealist of them all and that was Alexandro Jodorowdsky' 1970 cult classic "El Topo".However, being a fan of the Coen brothers and knowing what their renowned for, I had a feeling that I wouldn't be surprised, but throughly enchanted by a new take on what I know now is a remake of an old western classic.What got me hooked from the beginning was the dialogue between the characters and I'm sure you'll think and feel the same.At times,It was just A constant barrage of put downs and comebacks, quite similar to those you'd expect between friends at a bar.The first that got me was the bartering scene between Mattie and Col Stonehill ,then, her second meeting with the Rooster and his quip about fairy tales and her surprise encounter with Labouef and her last words about the state of his cow licked hair.Anyway, it was these and many others that kept me keen to hear what would be said next throughout the film, but the overall story, action, suspense and setting made this movie a really good watch from beginning to end and for anyone who's never really been into westerns before, should definitely give this one a try, you won't be disappointed, but pleasantly surprised.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, not great middle of the road.
reviews.content: If your going to remake a film- rewrite it entirely or do it justice. This is just a yawn fest of a film. THE GOOD: Hailee Steinfield. nailed it. timing,delivery and connection. some of my friends that joined me in the cinema felt she overacted but she has that "it" factor that will see her on the SAG nominee list someday I can guarantee it. Josh Brolin is wasted in this film. His character could of been so much more.THE BAD: The music just doesn't work for this film. Sounds petty but it was so off putting for me. The score itself is not bad just its use.On its own its a beautiful piece of music and nicely composed but it just seems like its selection was an after thought.It didn't elevate the mood of the film or punctuate the emotion of scenes effectively. *****SPOILER ALERT!!!!!***** THE UGLY: The script is flat, plods along and doesn't really go anywhere or have enough peaks to retain interest for the movie viewer. where are the villains with depth? Matt Damon as a US Marshall? cmon! why are there only two decent shootout scenes?? Hate to say i but Hollywood just fails to make good westerns anymore. Rent it or get the original. Its not just John Wayne and the cast that make it a true western classic its the production and how the story is told that bring it all together, sadly the Coen Brothers haven't quite delivered.

reviews.review_title: Brothers Coen have delivered a worthy western movie with a Coen-character
reviews.content: Its been a wile since I've seen a western with characters like these. Everyone in this picture could have their own movie. Its really fantastic how every person has so much details in their characters that you could watch this movie over three times or more and still noticed something else in every person.It's a classic storyline about a 14-year-old farm girl Mattie Ross sets out to capture the killer of her father. Hailee Steinfeld sets a perfect eager young girl that will do everything that her father learned her to get to her goal. To get there see gets help from Jeff Bridges as Cogburn a truly drinking bastard but a hero and Matt Damon as Texas Ranger LaBoeuf with an ego as France as his name.

True Grit: An excellent American novel, by Charles Portis. I've seen every film version, and read the original book.Story: Mattie, a young woman, travels far from home to claim her father's remains, and hire a bounty hunter to bring her father's killer to justice. Mattie, in this movie, is characterized perfectly: She is independent, humorless, businesslike, brave to a fault, and very direct in manner and speech (criticizes others without hesitation), but impeccably honest. And, she expects the same from others.Rooster (Bridges), the man she winds up hiring to capture her father's killer, is shabby, careless and crude in habits and mannerisms. He often takes liberty with the truth, even under oath in court. But, his reputation as a killer of men impresses Mattie enough to override any personal distaste she has for him.What follows, turns into a legitimate adventure. When Rooster catches up with the killer of Mattie's father (Josh Brolin, as Tom Chaney), he is in the company of a gang of Desperadoes, including Barry Pepper (also wanted by the law). Rooster and his Texas Ranger partner are unfazed by being outnumbered and outgunned. To grizzled veteran Rooster, it's just another day at the races.Much excitement follows, in the grand surroundings of the American West. Close encounters in the woods ensue, with the upper hand changing sides several times. Mattie becomes a hostage. Now, Rooster's bounty hunt turns into a rescue mission as well. An excellent performance is also turned in by Barry Pepper. His countenance and mannerisms flesh him out as an intelligent, deadly adversary. Josh Brolin correctly depicts the character of Tom Chaney - a man who might have once been intelligent, but who has descended into alcoholism, murder and theft. He tries to speak eloquently, but his articulation is slow and almost painful to listen to....he is a ruined man. Many people, myself included, will question: why was this movie even made? After all, John Wayne really covered it well in the 1969 version (one of the best performances of his career). I would say that this movie, in some of the details, is more faithful to the original book - especially in the depiction of Mattie's character and ultimate fate. There is just a tinge less "Hollywood" in this version, compared to the Duke's. It's a tad more gritty and realistic, which I always seek in a Western movie. It is an excellent re-make, up to date, which if nothing else, will appeal to younger viewers. Those younger viewers may be more able to relate to this version of True Grit, simply because it was not filmed decades before they were even born....and, they get to see actors in this movie that are still alive and making movies today. That alone justifies the making of this movie.If this movie were not a remake - if this was an original screening of a written story; the first effort - I would have rated it a "10".

I'll open with this; I did not realise before watching this film that there was an original. I have not seen the original and therefore this review is based solely on this iteration.To begin, this film is beige beyond belief, dull. Boring. I found this movie to be slow moving, yet lacking any meaningfulness and/or depth to keep me as a viewer engaged. I wasn't expectant of a fast moving action flick, nor am I adverse to taking in and enjoying a slow burner, however this film fails at all points.The acting, pretty much all round, is as wooden as a saloon door, other reviews have rightly called that the delivery of dialogue does indeed feel like the actors are stood there with scripts in hand merely reciting their lines - devoid of emotion and delivery. As pointed out by others too, Bridges feels miscast in the role and his accent is incomprehensible - detracting from what little is happening on screen.There is little to save this film from a harsh criticism from myself. My default is to fall back on cinematic and scenery shots to revive a poor score, however this film is shot mostly at night eliminating such scenes. The wardrobe varies little for the main characters across the film too meaning there is little to appreciate about this picture.To sum up, if you haven't seen the original and wish to sit down and take this in, I'd recommend to save your effort and watch something else. And, going by reviews of those whom have seen the original, save your effort of this and watch the original.

reviews.review_title: Loved it - up until the end
reviews.content: I was anxiously awaiting this remake of the John Wayne/Glenn Campbell/Kim Darby 1969 classic. Of course I could not help but compare the two movies. I really liked this 2010 Version - Loved Matt Damman as LaBoeuf and Jeff Bridges was great as Rooster Cogburn - the girl playing Mattie was wonderful as well, although I had not heard or seen her before, so I'll check out some of her other films. I wondered how Mr. Bridges was going to handle that 'awesome' Cogburn scene against Ned Pepper and he did great- no overacting, just natural and to the point. Not enough of Josh Brolin though :) Even if he was the bad guy.I loved this film up until the end that is. The Cohn Bros. completely changed the ending and I don't know why - it seemed so weak. Maybe that's the original story ending, but I didn't like it. Who wants to see a wrinkled up 40 year old Mattie? It just seemed like they ran out of time or something and quickly slapped something together to end the story and it was purposely done or else they would have just gone with the classic 1969 ending.But all in all it is well worth a watch and maybe even an Oscar nod. I'd also suggest watching the original.

reviews.review_title: A radical western that will keep you entertained.
reviews.content: Characters: 4 Screenplay: 4 Cinematography: 2 Emotional: 2Overall: 3.5It was very refreshing to see such a strong young female role. She brought back memories of Natalie Portman in Leon: The Professional, except with a more prominent role. Steinfeld does a stunning job on screen.
