At only 14 years, she fills the boisterous snarky shoes extraordinarily. And her character is rounded out quite well with the more natural undertones of her character as the stories goes on. Cogburn is a great as the drunken headstrong fool. Sprinkled with silly antics and one liners, his character is less fleshed out, but provides a great deal of entertainment when interacting with Mattie and Laboeuf. LaBoeuf rounds out the trio well, with the logical and structured side, albeit a bit odd. The interplay between the characters is priceless.The film starts of strong. The introduction scenes are entertaining and memorable. The short caricature introductions each match the flavor of their characters exceptionally. The pacing is well done, with nice downtime scenes between. The film does a good job of rewarding careful viewers: little tidbits of foreshadowing that are followed through. Interspersed throughout the film are bits of comic relief between the trio, and it is well timed and fresh. Thankfully the film rewards logic over brash courage in the end. My only concern is the ending. It's a bit anticlimactic, which initially is a letdown. But there is a bit of appreciation for an unorthodox ending for an unorthodox story. It leaves you high and dry, which one may not always appreciate Following the clichés of westerns, True Grit begins looking like standard fare. With a slow fade in scene, silhouettes, and warm tones, we're pleasantly surprised when the film strays from the beaten path character wise. Some scenes are very well shot, such as the ending frame. The only problems I had with the cinematography were the stereotypical traveling fades: a bit too much. Yeah, I presume they were trying to mock westerns, but the cuts were too fast and short.While the film attempts to build up the sympathy for Mattie, the emotional investment of the story is diluted by the unorthodox humor. It wouldn't suit this film to become too invested in the film, it's more akin to something you just sit back and watch. At the climax points of the film, I just didn't find myself caring all that much. But it was still highly entertaining and the ending was unique in a good way, once the initial dissatisfaction fades away. A radical western that will keep you entertained.You can read the review with encoded spoilers here: critical-eruditass.blogspot.com /2011/04/true-grit-2010-usa-western.html

"True Grit" was truly gritty indeed.While the Coens have created many period pieces before (likely just as many as they have modern films), this film seems like their most elaborate and detailed to date. The costumes, the sets, the accents – everything is impeccably created to deliver a sense of gritty realism and authenticity. It may be a western made now, but it could easily stand beside any number of westerns made over a half century ago. The camera's attention to detail is unsurpassed, and the sweeping vistas of the mountains and forests are simply gorgeous. Coupled with the rather magnificent score, the look and feel of the film may just be their most ambitious work yet. I have never been one to be a fan of westerns, but this film easily makes me have a greater appreciation for the genre.The script is fairly well done as well. Everything we have come to know the Coen Brothers for is here: plenty of light and dark humor, a script filled with a wealthy amount of exposition (almost too much), a rather tightly knit story revolving around an odd cast of characters (and even more bizarre supporting characters), and a surprising amount of graphic violence. You know you are in the hands of master filmmakers the moment the production company logos disappear, and easily forget this is a "re imagining". The blatant western setting does not deflate any of the usual Coen traits. Instead, it enhances them, and brings to light where their styles and ideas have been inspired from.

True Grit was a very good movie. The movies is a remake. With the exception of the epilogue, this is a better movie than the original. Mattie is a fourteen year old girl seeking revenge in the wild west. A period piece, True Grit does not shy away from themes that are controversial such as the accepted misogynistic treatment of women. Hailee Steinfeld holds her own brilliantly in every scene that she's in. She is especially impressive since she has several of her scenes with Academy award winning actors.In many of those scenes you almost forget about Bridges, Brolin or Damon. Yes, Hailee Steinfeld is that good!The movies is well paced. The movie sustains a high level of suspense. Because you bond very early on with Mattie, you care about her and want her to exact her revenge. I wish the best for Hailee Steinfeld and hope she chooses great roles because she already is a great actress. But then again I love old fashioned themes. Lord I remember when times were less complex. meeks lewis

John Wayne will be turning in his grave. This is a lazy, unimaginative boring take on a classic western. It fails to have any charm or excitement that the original captured so well. The great Jeff Bridges fails to live up to expectations and gives a lazy performance with an accent that almost impossible to understand.

The Coen brothers did a good job recreating the 1969 John Wayne film "True Grit." When you recreate a film that was a classic, your going to be held to high expectations and deal with a lot of criticism. The stage was set perfectly, the location, buildings, costumes, historical elements, etc. Everything worked together to give it that old western feel and make it seem like it was filmed in the old west. The only thing that reminds you that it isn't is the picture quality.Jeff Bridges did a good job playing Rooster Cogburn, he's no John Wayne but he did good. I have yet to see the original John Wayne version, but now its on my top list of movies to watch. Over all I give the movie an 8 out of 10, I thought this film was great for a new western. Now I just need to borrow the original from my grandpa.

True Grit was an OK movie but it could've have been way better. The actors were convincing in their roles, but they could have had more emotion. There was something this movie was lacking. I cant really put my finger on it , but I know something is missing. The director could have done a better job at telling the story. Ethan Coen's choice on lighting and camera angles were OK. In the dramatic scenes the lighting was dark, and in the some what calm scenes the lighting was brighter. The use of camera angles were OK, could have been used in a way better manner. i would have done a lot of things differently, I would have added more drama, more emotion, things that would make you feel for the characters. The best scene in this film wads the ending scene where Ruben Cogburn saves Mattie Ross from a rattle snake bite. Overall the movie could have been way better. I would recommend this movie to families that have children and a younger audience.

reviews.review_title: Good movie but you can't replace a legend
reviews.content: This was a good and entertaining movie. However, you just can't replace a legend like the Duke. And with all due respect to Mr. Impossible's review, Jeff Bridges is no John Wayne. The part of Rooster Cogburn was made for Wayne. And while Bridges is a very good and competent actor, he is not in Wayne's league. NOBODY could make a western like the Duke. He should have won an Academy Award for the Searchers. And I do agree with Mr. Impossible when he correctly states Hollywood makes to few westerns anymore. And that is a shame. I also liked Kim Darby's performance better in the original True Grit. Again, Darby was made for the role of Mattie Ross. The scenery was also better in the original. I loved the location scenery in the original where the "dugout" was located. That is the same location used in the movie "North to Alaska", also starring the Duke. But I really did enjoy this movie and I do recommend it. I just do not think it measures up to the original, which would have been very difficult to do.

The remake of true grit by the Coen brothers was a great film and the coen brothers are one of my favorite directors in film right now. My favorite part of the movie would have to be the climax when Mattie kills tom Chaney and rooster kills Ned pepper's gang. The acting was great with Jeff Bridges as Rooster Cogburn who i thought played his character perfectly. Hailee Steinfeld played Mattie Ross perfectly in her first major role that kicked off her film career. Matt Damon was good as Labeif who i thought played well off of Jeff Bridges Rooster Cogburn. True Grit was way better then the original in every single aspect like acting,directing and the film was actually filmed on location unlike the original.

reviews.review_title: A good movie, not as close to the book as the Wayne version
reviews.content: 1st, I must say I am highly perplexed that some say this version is closer to the book than the John Wayne version. That is simply not the case as the 1969 version is very close to the book while the Coen's verions strays quite a bit... and not always for the better. Why would anyone who has actually read the book say that this version is closer... it isn't... in word and definitely not in spirit.As for this movie... it is VERY good, worthy of viewing whether you have seen the original movie, read the book, or any combination. Matt Damon and Hailee Steinfeld do a much better job than Cambell and Kim Darby. Interstingly, to me anyway, is how Berry Pepper did what seems an obvious choice- instead of reworking Lucky Ned Pepper's 'character,' he stuck to Duvall's interpretation.If you read a review that says the 2010 copy is closer to the book than the 1969 copy-read the book, watch both movies, and you too will wonder why the reviewer says otherwise.

the remake of true girt wasn't as good as the original i think that the original was better like when Maddie in the new one she lost her arm but in the original she didn't lose it it was a complete sham a fake Jeff bridges could have done a better job and so could have Matt Damon but Hailee Steinfeld did a good job but in the new one she was a little more bossy and i didn't really like it it was just a boring piece of garbage it should have been better i wished it would be better but i do like the special effect in it it was pretty good i didn't think that could be that good so yeah thats what i have to say about this movie so goodbye

reviews.review_title: Exceptional cinematography, but that's about it.
reviews.content: I had high hopes for this movie - the Coen Bros, Jeff Bridges, a remake of one of my favorite movies. The trailers looked promising. Early on in the film, the recreation and detail of the courthouse was astoundingly authentic, and this was carried through the entire film. But for me, many scenes were way too lengthy while others crawled at a snails pace. Character development was lacking with the slight exception of Rooster Cogburn. A solid performance by Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross was a treat. Even younger than Kim Darby in the original, Steinfeld's performance was much more believable, even as a 14 year old. Overall, an entertaining disappointment...if there is such a thing.

reviews.review_title: Humanity corrupts, with the accidents abundant; can life go on?
reviews.content: "Life can still continue" is not the type of ending Coen brothers' films will let audiences take away with, and there are always surprising tweaks of story development, so did "True Grit", even as a re-make, 40 years apart. Consider this is the first re-make by Coen's.The re-make presents a paradox explicitly displayed, inherent with power of black humor. Audiences are caught into all possible disturbances, to carry with them after the end of the film – a Coen Brothers' trade mark.Unlike most of the re-makes, the difference does not lie in the advance of technology but different styles. We can appreciate fairly two makings primarily on the ground of craftsmanship – this is the most extreme fun of seeing movies to watch the same story line presented by two distinguished (groups of) great artists. Won't get bored.

reviews.review_title: More moral depth than most viewers notice
reviews.content: Chaos-rampant from Greece wrote a very fine review that set me thinking that he doesn't appreciate the epilogue with the older Mattie enough. He appreciates it, certainly, and everything he says is true. But in addition it ties-off one of the novel's great themes, rarely noticed by viewers and readers alike amid the laughter and excitement.The story, in cliché terms, is that of a young girl who sets out on the vengeance trail for the robber who murdered her father. At the end she is damaged goods because of it. Note her physical disability in the epilogue. She remains a spinster as well. People all through the film keep telling her that what she's doing is not fit for a woman. The truth is that an obsession with vengeance is not a good thing for anyone, male or female, but she persists to the point where she drops into a hell of snakes only to be rescued by the most improbable of God's angels, so to speak. Head and shoulders better film than the 1969 film, more serious, just as funny, and very thoughtful.

Nothing comes to fruition in the movie. The built up in tension between the main character and villain falls flat. Pointless, empty movie. Lots of pointless scenes, superfluously drawn out scenes.Not enough action to even merit calling it a western.Main character starts out strong and interesting but quickly loses her character.

reviews.review_title: Believe the hype, and don't believe the haters.
reviews.content: This film is great. The Coen brothers hit it out of the park with this film.This film is getting a lot of unnecessary hate for being a remake of a John Wayne classic. These people do not know what they are talking about. These films are two different masterpieces that really shouldn't be compared to each other. Both are great in their own right. Yes, they are based off the same book, but this is more faithful.Jeff Bridges, while not quite as memorable as the Duke, does a wonderful job here. He put his own, "Dudeish" spin on it. Don't compare Mr. Bridges to Mr. Wayne. It accomplishes nothing. A film is a film.The direction and acting is top notch. The young actress who plays Mattie Ross is brilliant, and a great find by the Coen brothers. Matt Damon is also great, he's a perfect ***hole. The film is beautifully shot. And it sounds great. My hat goes off to the cinematographer and composer.9/10

The movie "True Grit," is a remake of the original 1967 version which starred John Wayne. This remake includes actors Jeff Bridges (as Marshall Rooster Cogburn), Hailee Steinfeld (as Mattie Ross), Matt Damon (as LaBoeuf), and Josh Brolin (as Tom Chaney) ("True Grit," 2010). They are the main characters in the movie. This document will review the plot of the movie, the theme, techniques used which support the theme, and an overview of the overall feelings with which the viewer is left.The movie starts with a girl on a train. That girl is Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld), whose father (Frank Ross) was unnecessarily murdered. The viewer is able to gather that Mattie loved her father very much and that he was someone who stood up for what was right in the face of adversity, even to death, which unfortunately was his demise. The movie is about Mattie avenging her father's death. From the beginning of the movie, the viewer can tell that Mattie shares the same qualities as her father, boldness and tenacity. At the very beginning of the movie, there is a Bible verse that appears on the screen, it is Proverbs 28:1: "The wicked flee when none pursue . . ." (Coen & Coen, 2010). This verse sets the tone for the movie, as the movie is about Mattie's pursuit of justice by seeking out Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), the man who killed her father. She realizes that she needs to hire the best possible person for the job of avenging her father's death, as she cannot do it alone. As mentioned, Mattie is bold; which is very fitting to the remainder of the verse in Proverbs that is completed by the statement that "but the righteous are as bold as a lion" (Proverbs 28:1, 2011). She finds that Marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) is someone with "True Grit" (2010) and tenacity and that is exactly the type of person she needed to ensure that justice could be served. She recruits Rooster and they set off on a journey together.The theme of "justice" is portrayed in a variety of ways throughout the movie. The first and most obvious, is the Bible verse in the beginning of the movie. This is indicative of the theme. Next, Mattie herself stands for justice. Not only does she strive for attaining justice for her father's death, but she stands for all things right. She is bold enough to go to the man who sold her father ponies and ask that he make things right, by giving her what was rightfully her father's. Additionally, later in the movie, she reminded Rooster that they promised the kid in the house who was killed, a decent burial; although they would not be able to fulfill that promise.Often in order to achieve justice, one must have tenacity and boldness. This type of boldness and tenacity is seen in Mattie (Hailee Steinfeld) and Rooster (Jeff Bridges). This type of tenacity was also represented in the movie "Friday Night Lights" as the football team continues to get "pummeled" and hangs in there and continues to fight ("Friday night lights," 2012). Mattie exhibited this type of tenacity throughout the movie. Despite naysayers, having to sleep among corpses, etc she continued with her pursuit for justice. She was left by Rooster (Jeff Bridges) and LaBoeuf (Matt Damon) and she used her pony to cross a raging river to catch-up. Her tenacity is also demonstrated when the viewer sees the implication that all these years, she's gone on living despite the loss of her arm. Rooster also demonstrated this tenacity in his willingness to take on a fight with the odds of five to one (him being the one), and when he saves Mattie from the snake bite and goes for miles on the horse until the horse collapse then carries her for miles in his arms.Next, various techniques used within the movie tie back to the theme. Main techniques that were used to show tenacity and the means to justice were camera shots, and transitions. The Camera shots used showed how evil the wicked could be, for example: the scene when Mattie faces Chaney, it shows that Chaney really is evil when it zooms in closer and we can see that he is going to take Mattie. In addition, the camera angle when he takes a knife to Mattie shows how evil he is. This shows us just how evil is, and demonstrates why it cannot be allowed to prevail. In addition, the camera shots show that Mattie is not really a killer, when she pulls a gun on Chaney, but rather, she is prepared to do what she needs to do to ensure that justice is served. Next, the transitions between the scenes are used to show tenacity and the gall needed to ensure that justice was served. The transitions indicate the passage of time, the length of time that the journey took. The transitions made the journey seem very long, especially after Mattie had been hurt, when Rooster was carrying her in his arms. At that point, they had taken revenge on Chaney; however, Mattie was injured as a result, and in order to ensure that she (the righteous) was not killed by her pursuit for justice, we see that Rooster carries her in his arms to safety.The movie was very well done. The theme of justice and the tenacity required to achieve it, is very well portrayed. In closing, the main take-away from this movie was essentially, when the righteous do nothing, the wicked prevail. Though it is often easier and to cower in the face of adversity, look the other way (do nothing), or remain the victim, this movie shows us that even though justice may come at a price to the pursuer, there is great satisfaction that accompanies the attainment of justice and comfort in knowing that justice has been served.

The Coen brothers team up again in this remake of the 1969 film and manage to make an audience think during an "action" movie once again. Advertised like a western gunslinger's tale it will leave action fans wanting more. In traditional Coen fashion the movie ends just as it feels like the pace is finally starting to pick up. However, what makes this movie great is not the story itself, which is rather straight forward and dry, but the acting. Bridges and Damon make this movie a fun watch, and seem to always put on a stellar show. Many will leave the movie wondering what the real point was as it feels the Coen brothers were being too subtle, but Bridges and Damon make this film live up to some of the expectations.

reviews.review_title: They don't know how to make Westerns anymore
reviews.content: Unfortunately, I grew up reading western novels and watching western movies made by the true masters of the genre. True Grit 2010 is proof that the making of a western is now a lost art.The Coen brothers unfortunately did the movie world a disservice with their poorly executed version of what is a great western story. True Grit 2010 plods its way through and never builds up to - well - much of anything. The acting by Bridges and Damon is sub-par, along with much of the rest of the cast, and maddeningly ho-hum throughout. Hailee Steinfeld actually performed better in many respects than they did, although many of her scenes should have been re-shot due to misdirection. She and Barry Pepper (who unfortunately only had a relatively small part in comparison) were the only two who even came close to keeping the script alive. If a plodding script and dispassionate acting are your cup of tea, then by all means True Grit 2010 is for you. If not, read the book, or rent the original.

reviews.review_title: A really good movie totally ruined by the ending.
reviews.content: This was a really good movie that was totally ruined by the ending. Jeff Bridges, Hailee Stienfeld and Matt Damon gave outstanding performances. It was so well put together that I don't know why the Coen's let the movie fall apart in the ending. Mattie is bit by a rattle snake and Rooster rides her to get medical attention. In doing so he rides her horse to death. When he first took off with her there was another horse just standing there by the men he'd just killed that he could have taken and swapped out when the horse got too tired. Any man with the experience he had in the country at that time wouldn't have ridden a horse to death, especially if another was available to take along as a relief. Even with as great as this movie was up until that point, I left the theater with a bad feeling. The Coen's really managed to mess up one of the best movies they've ever put together.

I have read a number of reviews drawing attention to the dialogue and saying how like Portis'novel it is - and how different from Hathaway's 1969 version. Such critics should revisit the 1969 original. In many instances both films are word for word the same. The Cohen Brothers' take on 'True Grit' lacks the narrative pace and drive of the original and,generally, has poorer performances. Bridges looks as if he must have spent hours watching John Wayne's Oscar winning role and has not got anywhere near it. Quite apart from being rather unconvincing in the role, he is sometimes incoherent and makes one wish for sub-titles. ( A feature of many US movies today is that actors have poor articulation and recording techniques are also poor - there were never these problems with Ronald Colman, C Aubrey-Smith, David Niven, Errol Flynn, Cary Grant, Stewart Granger or James Mason).While the film's ending may be true to the novel, it is less satisfactory than the 1969 ending. It doesn't always follow that adherence to an original source makes for a better film: read 'Double Indemnity' if you do not believe me; the book's ending is silly.

I never enjoyed the 2010/2011 version of True Grit,basically there was no grit in it. Bridges speech was slurried and hurried as was Matties,and the movie seemed to be so hurried. The 1969 screenplay was far more superior than this version...Like all or most remakes it just does not do it for me...Even the music was way out west...John Wayne is Rooster Cogburn maybe the film makers should leave it at that. ...Bridges made some cracking westerns when he was younger,but i find him very disappointing in this movie....Reading other reviews you might think that i am talking about a different movie,but if you have not already seen the original True Grit,then go see it before you see this version,its much more gutsy,and less hurried,the scenery is more breath taking and the all round acting is just so much better. You just cant beat the original cast,Wayne,Duvall,Hopper,Darby,Campbell,etc.
Great movie!!! Great story and well shot. Enjoyable characters, a movie with real heart. Hailee Steinfeld is great and so is Jeff Bridges.

reviews.review_title: An interesting remake but oddly cold
reviews.content: This 2010 version correctly tells the story through the eyes of Maddy Ross and has a similar ending to the book; the John Wayne version more accurately depicts certain scenes from the book but changed the ending. The Coen brothers version is, pardon the pun, grittier and as a result probably more realistic but that is how things have to be these days yet, for all the realism, I think their version lacks tension. Certainly the ending appears to have been cut short; there is none of the pain, discomfort and tension that there is in the book and the John Wayne version managed to portray several parts of the film in a more suspenseful manner. I feel slighted cheated by the Coen Brothers film, it was good but could have been far better. It should have been made longer and contained more detail - the scene where the two outlaws are captured in the hut is oddly succinct and superficial, obviously foreshortened for whatever reason is just one example so, for me, the John Wayne version remains superior.I suggest that anyone who hasn't read the book buy a copy, it's a terrific read.

reviews.review_title: Must see this (sure to be) Classic Coen
reviews.content: There is just something special about a movie with dialogue that actually makes you think about the punchline and then look over to the person you are with and say, "did they just say that?" I would call this a better, even more polished version of "O'Brother Where Art Thou".This movie will make you laugh out loud. There is suspense, there is a little bit of gore, and even a moment that will make you jump out of your seat. How many other Westerns can you say that about? Superb acting with top notch direction! Not many movies deserve a 10/10, but I have no problem giving this one a perfect score.

My parents wanted to see True Grit and asked if I wanted to come. My first thought was "No way hose" but then i realized that there were no other good movies that i could get into out at the time, so i went along with them. all i can say, is that i was glad i did. the movie was wonderful. i enjoyed every minute if it. it was a movie that was great for my family with just enough action and adventure but not enough that we were bored to death. when i left the theater that day i talked about it all day. i give it a 10 out of 10 being one of the best movies i have seen in a long time. it is really hard to find good movies for the family that everyone will enjoy but this one was perfect. i would say that you could see it if you are at least 10 years old. after i saw this movie i saw the original and am reading the book. it is very similar, especially the dialogue. i thought that it was a very good movie.

John Wayne and other actors in the original movie,make are of such stature that this remake should never have been done. John Wayne and actors of that era show that expletives and other four letter curse words are not necessary to make a movie great.,,anyone can curse, only good actors can act without the vowel language, they demonstrate how bad and cruddy people who are evil can be. Long live the memory of John Wayne

reviews.review_title: Brilliant. The best thing the Coens have done so far
reviews.content: I have come away with mixed feelings about a lot of their work. Some of it I like and some of it I don't but, I have to say, I think their True Grit is wonderful! I felt it was simultaneously a real, gritty Western, in and of itself, as well as being a homage. I thought the acting was flawless, especially from the two leads, the setting and cinematography was breathtaking and the dialogue could be quick, witty and very moving. I could not stop looking at Hailee Steinfeld. What great casting! She had the perfect look and attitude for this role. It stirs such deep emotions in me and while I was watching it, I was reminded of watching Badlands for the first time. Of watching The Shawshank Redemption for the first time. The themes are universal, the narrative very simple but I think it's a rare thing and will hopefully become a modern classic. I LOATHE John Wayne and never ever want to see or hear from the original ever again. True Grit is one of my newer favourites and I do NOT have many of those.

reviews.review_title: How to mess up a great concept
reviews.content: (First I have to say that I've never had any relation to the True Grit story before.) This movie left me very disappointed. I don't know it actually was possible to mess up such a great concept and story, but the Coen brothers certainly did. Not only did they rush in a lot of action scenes without any connection to the story but they let something that could've been such a great relationship and story between the young Mattie Ross and the marshal Rooster Cogburn go completely missing. Hailee Steinfeld as the brave but innocent girl Mattie made me happy and I really enjoyed her character, therefore I found it extremely stupid when the Coens decided to take the innocent away from her by making her shoot the film's bad guy in such a rushed, confusing and very unsatisfying way.The scene where Rooster is trying to save her life after she'd been bit by a snake, which I would call the climax of the film, was also extremely rushed and with no satisfying feeling to the audience what so ever. I feel like they've rushed all the scenes that actually MAKES the story in the place of stupid happy violent shooting scenes, a random guy hanging in a tree, too much whiskey and a poor development of the characters.It left me with a sad feeling that they managed to spoil what could've been a thrilling, heartbreaking and epic story. The only reason I'm not giving this film the bottom rating is because of the lovely Hailee Steinfeld and the wonderful Jeff Bridges who both acted excellent and deserved more developed characters.

The dialogue (and almost everything else) is almost identical to the 1969 original. Aside from small differences to make it appear more 'authentic', this movie is a copy. Not a re-make. Why did they bother?

reviews.review_title: I liked the movie but I expected more.
reviews.content: I have watched previous works of coen brothers and i had always loved it but here something was lacking, except that i love the the acting ,cinematography , cast .

So, I went to see TRUE GRIT last night. Just had to see for myself. You know you shouldn't judge movies until you pay the price of admission. Anyway there were some surprises that internet reviewers neglected to mention. It's a musical!?!? Man, was I shocked when Rooster burst into song singing. "Oh, Lucky Ned Pepper!/I shot you in the upper lip/But I was aiming for the lower!" Then there was this whole fantasy ballet involving Mattie and LaBouef(?).Anyway, it all ends up that Mattie Ross was really Dorothy Gale, and she wakes up in her room in Kansas. And now Jeff Bridges is a character called Hunk, Matt Damon is Zeke and Josh Brolin is Hickory. The Dorothy character tells about her dream and says, "You were there Hunk. You too Zeke! And Hickory."They all begin to sing "We got True Grit! True Grit is what we got!/If you don't think we have True Grit we will tie you in a knot!"Then the scene fades out to the roar of the MGM lion.

I found the film enjoyable, the story entertaining and the scenery very nice. However, I didn't think the film was brilliant, mainly for the following reasons. Firstly, Jeff Bridges should have taken lessons from Colin Firth, and learned how to speak audibly for the cinema audience whilst playing a character with a speech impediment. Secondly, the young girl in the film reminded me far too much of Anne of Green Gables, with her braids and staged voice, which was simply too bizarre. Thirdly, the concept was not at all original, being a remake of an old film. Overall, an OK film to watch, but it had none of the originality or uniqueness of "No Country for Old Men".

True Grit is based on a solid story, clearly the original book reveals an honest depth of 19th century life in the mid west. The Cohen Bros have taken the rough hewn ore that was made into the 70s film and polished it into a precious gem. Spielberg casts his usual stuff, but what succeeds here most are the performances - far and away this is Jeff Bridges best performance, eclipsing the Duke by leagues, when you compare the two characters JW is little more than a cardboard cutout, despite his commanding stature and voice and the acclaim he received for this role; Hailee Steinfeld is incredible, she breathes life into her huge character so powerfully and convincingly, the viewer is transported to 1880, amongst the dirty, seedy wild west. - incredibly this was only her first big screen role, she is definitely an actress to watch for. True Grit is not going to suit all tastes, its not your typical popcorn action spaghetti western, its a classical journey story - truly enjoyable and refreshing.

I recently saw True Grit, and was very impressed! The story line was amazing and I was thoroughly entertained. I was not aware the story was a re-make of an earlier film until after I watched the movie. I did not compare this to a lot of other movies seeing as I was under the impression it was an original before I was informed otherwise. The strong dialog and characteristics of all the actors and actresses in this movie were very impressing. Although the main character is a little girl, she brings the heat!! She has no trouble keeping up with the men in the movie, and does not shy away of what she came to conquer. The men didn't think that she would help out, but they end up working together as a team to take charge of the problems they face! This movie has a lot of different emotions tied in. You will find yourself on a roller coaster through the lives of others implying that women can conquer just as much as men! This film is very inspirational and will make you want to take charge of your life and achieve anything you set your mind to.

reviews.review_title: A young girl is bent on avenging her father after an outlaw by the name of Tom Chaney murders him in cold blood.
reviews.content: I'm not a huge fan of Westerns. I'm the first to say their Southern drawl annoys me. Keep this in mind as you read this review because I went into this movie knowing no matter how amazing it was I would never want to own it. Saying this though I must admit that the acting was phenomenal. Usually when there's an A-list actor in a movie all I can think about is who they really are. That never happened once throughout this whole movie. The story and plot were sound too. There were no huge surprises though. The whole movie was monotonous to me. Nothing stood out. I would also say the ending was very abrupt. That's how they intended it to be but in my opinion it was too abrupt. Overall this movie was good. To me the acting was the highlight of the film. I do not personally think that this movie was Oscar-worthy though. I would probably watch it again but I would not buy it.

I think this was a great movie. I was going to rate it nine stars, but when I thought about why I would rate it nine stars I couldn't find why I would. Well the reason I voted ten stars is because I couldn't find anything wrong with this movie. There is humor, action, and drama. I am not really a Matt Damon fan, but his part in this movie was very well played. I think all the characters were great and played the parts that were right for them. I highly recommend this movie. I hope that people realize on how great this movie was and I hope that they watch it when it comes out on DVD. I can tell you that as soon as it comes out I'm defiantly getting it.

First of all, I enjoyed all of the 2010 True Grit (well, the guy with the bearskin was a silly added bit). I still enjoy the 1969 True Grit, feeling most of the performances there are also very good (well, Glenn Campbell leaves a bit to be desired). I attribute my enjoyment to the original novel True Grit by Charles Portis, one of America's great writers.Both movies, not only 2010, used Portis' dialogue extensively. Both Matties speak as Portis had her speak during the 1878 period. She is one of the most unusual book heroines ever written, and Hallie Steinfield is better than Kim Darby. The cast and cinematography are great, and the plot stayed fairly true to the book. Matt Damon was excellent in the part of La Boeuf, and the character parts true to the novel.I recommend this movie as a very good addition and timely upgrade for today's audiences to the '69 film, but I still have the '69 DVD which I treasure.

reviews.review_title: This story has already been told.
reviews.content: Why does hollywierd feel the need to retell the same story. This happens often. It's lazy. The main characters, Rooster Cogburn and Mattie Ross, surely have other adventures that could be told. Instead it is almost verbatim from the original. Don't get me wrong, the actors were good, but the story has already been told.

reviews.review_title: Good movie to wait and see on DVD.
reviews.content: My wife and I saw the movie yesterday. Although Hailee Steinfeld gave us an incredible performance, we thought the overall movie pales in comparison to the original film. Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon were very good in their roles. Their banter was "laugh out loud" funny at times as they played well off of each other. We couldn't quite put our finger on it, but we felt the overall film was lacking. It felt like much of the movie was building up to a climatic ending that never really happened. Having loved the first film, maybe we were expecting too much from this one. The scenery was fantastic! Good movie to wait and see on DVD.

reviews.review_title: Very Good Movie, bordering on Great
reviews.content: I am not a professional reviewer so I admit to certain ignorance's regarding the technical aspects of films and I lack the verbiage to fully explain myself. I can only report my feelings for the movie. I was extremely excited to hear that True Grit was being made by the Coen's with Jeff Bridges in the role of Rooster Cogburn. The addition of Josh Brolin and Matt Damon was icing on the cake. But let's face it, the girl almost stole the show. I say almost because she was almost as good as Bridges. This is a good thing by the way, not a criticism. OK the good first. The writing and directing are always fantastic in Coen Brothers movie. The cinematography was spectacular and far out-did the original movie. The acting was excellent (possible Oscar nominations?) and I think Bridges added a depth to the Cogburn character that John Wayne could only dream about. I say that as a John Wayne fan, but let's face it, he didn't have a lot of range. The Cogburn Character was somewhat different in as much as he talked and talked and talked. Most of it was funny though. Steinfeld was a surprise and I felt she also was a step up from the Kim Darby version. Damon's version of Laboeuf, was way different than the Glen Cambell version. There was more of a tenderfoot quality to the character, yet he was supposed to be a tough Texas Ranger. There was a lot more humor in this one than the original and the classic Coen dialog was pleasing. The not so good.I think this movie suffers a little bit because it is a remake. While it wins almost all comparisons to the original, it is still compared to the original. If this movie was alone in the world, it would have been seen as groundbreaking. But it is not the ORIGINAL. To do a remake I think you need to distance it so far from the original that you almost can't make the comparisons. This movie followed the ORIGINAL too closely. I kept hearing that this follows the book, not the original. I din't read the book, but I saw the original and this didn't seem to be that different. Yes the characters were deeper and darker, but still not that much different. While the dialog was a lot different, the plot and even the scenes seemed to be almost identical to the original. Too close perhaps. I was just expecting something way different and it wasn't that different. Probably it is that I was just expecting something else. The Brolin and Pepper (Barry Pepper, who played Ned Pepper) characters were not in this movie for very long. The last part of the movie was like it was on fast forward compared to the original. I would have enjoyed seeing more of these characters, especially Ned Pepper who seemed to be a truly despicable person. Loved the teeth...The movie seemed to stall at some points. I think the dialog was intended to fill these up, but it seemed to me that the scenes were slowed down specifically for the dialog.I know that much of my criticism for this movie is only because I was expecting something else and that is my fault, not the movie makers fault. But even with my criticism I give this movie 8 out of 10 because it is a very good movie. I just don't think I can say it is great. I should go down as one this years best movies though and I highly recommend it for anyone who likes a really well made western.

The film is about a girl, Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) who seeks to avenge her father's death, who was killed by a bandit Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). She hires a marshall, Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) to track him down and bring him to justice. A Texas ranger (Matt Damon) also wants to get Chaney as of a crime he committed in Texas.Onto the review. Oh I'm not going to ramble I loved this film. I've never really seen any westerns before and this introduction to the genre was fantastic. The cinematography is gorgeous, rolling plains and the wild west – it's all stunning. Roger Deakins was totally snubbed at the Oscars lazy year. The direction is spot on and they're interpretation of the book is great, granted it is a rather straight forward plot they execute it brilliantly.Hailee Steinfeld, oh well you're just magnificent aren't you? You fall in love with her when she begins to barter with a man about horses, she is the heart and soul of the film. I don't think there's a scene where she isn't present, obviously apart from when her character is older. For me she was the standout of this film, if I had it my way I'd give her all the awards. Jeff Bridges is good as the marshall and he deserved his Oscar nod, but half the time I couldn't understand what the hell he was saying?! I was unable to figure out his ramblings for parts of the film. The supporting cast is equally good, Matt Damon was great along with Josh Brolin. Barry Pepper stole his scenes as the creepy leader of Chaney (Brolin)'s gang. Some fine acting on display here.The music is lovely and fits perfectly, all I can say about that!I do love this movie, and my only criticism is the understanding of Jeff Bridges' dialogue! 10/10 In my opinion, one of the best films of 2010.

Sure, it was a good movie. But I don't think it had enough emotion to it. It was touching how the U.S. Marshal was emotionally attached to the child (he was fighting desperately to save her life). However, I saw many people cry (especially around the part where the horse was shot). I don't think this is worth crying about, it wasn't that emotional. The horse was of no use to him at the time. Other than that, the last parts were, below standards. The actor who played the young girl 25 years later was WAY different then she should have looked. It was hard to really get into the story and feel sad when she was informed that the Marshal has passed away because she just looked so different. It was as if I changed the channel and there just so happens to be another one of these films on, playing at a similar scene.However, the first part was amazing. It was set up really well and I LOVED it. If only they were to work on the last part some more...

I expected a classic western - the way they were 50 years ago - but this movie felt more like a modern action/adventure set in a western environment. For example the hero is very typical; at heart a good man with decency, yet still he is cool as he is a bit of a bad-guy and have very rough voice. The movie felt too much like a fairytale, both the good and the bad guys were too nice. Also, the girl had a little bit too strong character for me to find it believable.But of course, even if it was not a classic western it could still be a great movie, in a modern way. But unfortunately I can't say it was very exciting in that aspect either. The presentation of the bad guys were very brief and shallow which made the plot weak as you didn't really care if they were brought to justice or not.Also, there is a "horse scene" towards the end which you might find very disturbing, at least I did.

reviews.review_title: Not Just a Western, way more than just a Film
reviews.content: I am not really a big fan of Coen Brothers and not really a guy who wanna watch Western movie in a weekend when there are other movies in my bucket too, but my brother caught this movie a while ago and his only comment was "you will be laughing till the last half of the movie." Frankly, I was confused, none of the promos actually portrayed anything remotely funny, instead the film rather depicted a darkness (as most of the westerns) and grittiness of the old wild wild west. SoI decided to give it a shot, and man was I surprised. Yes, the movie has a dark undertone; yes, the movie is pure western; yes, the movie is depicts realism and very realistic characters; but, for almost two hours I had forgotten I was actually watching a western. This movie depicts a journey not just of revenge, but also what self-respect and retribution means for a man (no matter what the age); it not only focuses on darker sides, but also expresses a glint of light in every character, no matter how bad ass. This movie is an ultimate classic, and should be watched by all ages, of course children will definitely want some guidance, and people like me (belonging to Asian Region) may also require use of subtitles because of Jeff Bridges' awesome western accent (Hats off, and hands down to this guy for stealing the show), but it still worth every penny you spent on it and every moment you had with it.And even if this does not persuade you, then understand this, I have never written a review for a movie, but this time I just couldn't stop myself. Hope you enjoy the film!

reviews.review_title: This is a very good western movie and the technical aspects are well done.
reviews.content: As a long time fan of John Wayne movies, with one of my favorites being True Grit, I was apprehensive of this version before viewing it. By I must say that the Coen brothers did an excellent job with their adaptation of the story and their selection of actors to play the roles was excellent. Jeff Bridges is his own version of Rooster Cogburn and while their are similarities he does not attempt to be John Wayne. Hailee Steinfeld brings Mattie Ross to life. Pluses of this film from the original are the technical improvements in camera, lighting, and sound effects. Certain scenes are sure to make you jump. Additional aspects of the film that should be appreciated are the scenery and the costumes utilized. From the background scenery, to the dusty streets, to the lighting from the camp fires, will help an audience feel as if they have gone back in time. The costumes and clothing are well done and fit the era well. It is apparent that much research was done to make the time period as realistic as possible.Well done and my recommendation to other fans of the original movie, go into this with an open mind, avoid comparison to the original, and enjoy a good western! I was not disappointed and I hope that you will not be either.

Okay, first thing's first... If you watched the old John Wayne flick you will definitely end up comparing both: the old and this here new.This version seems rushed in. The character of Mattie Ross is not well written and we never get to understand her nor the reason for her 'grit'. (Can't blame the actor for successfully failing at creating a good impression)John Wayne playing Rooster stands out definitely as compared to Bridges.Even the handling of the guns is not "west-like" as we have been led to believe by myriad westerns in the past.Lucky Ned was played very well, but Chaney just disappointed to the core. (But again, the movie seems rushed-in and the character was not well written so can't really blame the actors there)Only the scenery got the feel of Old West, not the accent (and even the dialogue was pretty straight forward as compared to other westerns we have been led to believe..)The only good thing about this version is the End.. It is much better than the old movie's end.

True Grit is not just another western that deals with gunfights and a damsel in distress, this movie goes much deeper than that. It takes the viewer on a ride with a 14 year old girl seeking revenge for her father's murder, a Texas Ranger that is pursuing the same man for a different reason, and a colorful U.S. Deputy Marshal that helps the young girl. Mattie Ross is the 14 year old girl that wants revenge for her father's murder. She was played by the actress Hailee Stienfield who does an amazing job in drawing the viewer into feeling like they are right there on the journey. The Texas Ranger La Boeuf is depicted not so well by Matt Damon who in my opinion could have been portrayed better; I feel that he tried a little too hard to act like he was in a western instead of just acting. The murder they are pursuing, Tom Chaney, is played by Josh Brolin who I feel did a really good job in portraying him in the way that he was a criminal but wasn't really the brains of the operation. The Marshal Rooster Cogburn was played by the actor Jeff Bridges who in my opinion did an amazing job in portraying the many faces of Rooster to their fullest.This film was given a rating of PG-13 which I feel was a good rating for this movie for the fact that it isn't just a lot of fighting and swearing but it did have some in it. The visual appeal of this movie is great it has the setting that the places in that time setting would have. You feel like you are actually watching something that could be from that time era instead of a modern movie. All together I believe that this is a superb film not just for the western genre but an all-around great movie.

I thought it was a really good remake. The acting was top notch throughout, the sets were well done.... I loved the original and enjoyed this almost as much. Look, I totally understand the original is a classic western- I love westerns. I also LOVE John Wayne. But guess what? This movie is good too. They didn't try to reinvent the wheel - just retold the story, and did a very good job in the process. If you like westerns, check it out! If you are so set in your ways that no one can ever, ever remake a movie that you liked 50 years ago, may as well pass it up because you pretty much already made up your mind... Relax, enjoy a good western!

This was a cinematic experience for me. The Coen brothers are classic and they should remain same. let it Barton Fink,THE HUDSUCKER PROXY AND TRUE GRIT. Their diversity of ideas in every film are different and unique. I value them on the same level with Stanley Kubrick,Ingmar Bergman and Andrei Tarkovosky.Academy Awards are a bunch of deep little thinkers who thought it should not win. For me it was bigger than Kings speech,but should have won best Picture but who cares about the faith of people who are manipulated by the Oscar ceremony. "Time just get away from us"-the quote and music it hits u harder than anything.People say Pulp Fiction is new age cult cinema but i believed it was a just a structure around things.A good cinema no doubt.
