A few days ago my father and I watched the original True Grit with "The Duke", John Wayne. This was the only John Wayne movie that I have been able to stomach as a whole, because most of the time, I found his movies to be bland. That being said, the original left me in love with a film for the very first time. I thus then needed to see the new one directed by the Coen Brothers.In the theaters I had plenty of laughs because of the great dialogue included in the film. The Coen Bros. did a great job incorporating some of my favorite lines from the original into their work. In my opinion Jeff Bridges played a better Rooster Cogburn than "The Duke". Bridges has really improved in my eyes because of his acting in this film.The Coen Bros and Jeff Bridges have provided me with a new favorite movie! It's a must see!

You can tell this is in the olden days by the sepia , it has a double purpose here . It is both artsy AND fartsy .
Jeff Bridges is a great actor but ain't a patch to the original Rooster .
All of the actors in this are probably better at their "craft" that the original except Robert Duvall , but the humanity and likability of the characters is missing .
The Coen bros. did not make an exact copy of the original , they tried to make it their own . The classic western as art , but it is a swing and a miss to me .

When I first started watching the movie, I expected six-shooters, shootouts, revolvers, betrayal, deceit and corruption - what more would you expect from the Wild West and Western? This movie is not your regular western flick - this one has a deep story depicting a woman telling a flashback story of her greatest adventure - avenging her deceased father. This film is exciting, thrilling and every single minute of it is worth watching. Ten minutes before the ending, I expected a happy ending, but it eventually turned out to be bad for the characters - Mattie lost her arm due to the snake bite, Cogburn died and there's not a sign of LaBoeuf. Luckily, Mattie got her revenge and accomplished her only goal of killing Tom Chaney, a fugitive on the loose who murdered her father. True Grit is an amazing experience and I recommend it to everyone.

reviews.review_title: "Even to the over-the-top PG-13 violence, the Coen Brothers' adaptation of "True Grit" amazes me!"
reviews.content: True Grit comes from a Western novel written by Charles Portis and has been made into two different movies. The first one that comes out was released in 1969 starring John Wayne as Reuben J. "Rooster" Cogburn. The second one that comes out was released in 2010 starring Jeff Bridges as Cogburn. From my perspective, the 2010 version can probably never be passed.The Coen Brothers created Oscar-winning pictures such as No Country for Old Men and Fargo. However, they turn into the Western side of film-making and creates one of the greatest modern Western films of all time! True Grit (2010) is directed by Ethan Coen and Joel Coen. The film involves Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) swears to take revenge on Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin) for killing his father. She gets help from the toughest U.S. Marshal around named Rooster Cogburn and a Texas Ranger named LaBoeuf (Matt Damon). She creates a sudden relationship with the two lawmen, but they go on a searching trip that can take them anywhere.True Grit (2010) is an amazing Western film with many great performances in acting, direction, and score. Jeff Bridges shows his great determination as Cogburn that also includes his pretty hilarious voice. Matt Damon and Hailee Steinfeld also provided great performances throughout. However, I noticed that the violence was a little bit over-the-top and shown in some sequences. With the PG-13 rating, it can go too far. Even with the rating, this movie is absolutely fantastic considering the Western genre. While I was watching True Grit (2010), I saw great messages including the act to stick right by someone through terrible events. The story was absolutely fantastic!True Grit has always been a great Western story throughout many movie adaptations. However, I don't think any other version can overtake this one. Including certain understandable messages, I loved the Coen Brothers' adaptation of True Grit! I give credit to the brothers for their absolutely amazing direction throughout the Western film. Also, I give credit to Bridges and the rest of the cast for their performances. This Western film was absolutely amazing! I give True Grit a 10/10 for its outstanding direction, soundtrack, and acting. I would definitely give this movie a recommend!True Grit was nominated for 10 Academy Awards including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Actor (Bridges), Best Supporting Actress (Steinfeld), Best Art Direction, Best Cinematography, Best Costume Design, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Sound Editing.

This movie pale's in comparison to the original. With a run a time only 18 minutes less than the original it feels like a good 30 to 45 minutes less, because of how much is cut or rushed. Now making the remake shorter in and of itself is not necessarily bad, but the parts they did put large and important holes in the story and character development. The acting is generally terrible, particularly Bridges and Damon who overact so much its makes their characters seem comical and nearly incomprehensible. Honestly I couldn't understand half of what Bridges said because he mumbled so much, and Damon's character is barely in the movie and is never developed like in the original. Only Steinfeld did a comparable job, which was fairly true to the original, but with her touch to the character. Brolin is completely wasted in this film as he literally had only 5 minutes of screen time. The Coen brothers would have been well advised to have completely reworked the story so as to avoid the comparison's (which are fair considering they tried to keep it as close as possible), and put their own touch on the story.

reviews.review_title: Just added True Grit to my list of favorite westerns.
reviews.content: Just returned from seeing True Grit and have to say this movie was like having a good meal. You leave full and satisfied. I even give props to Matt Damon for what he did with Glen Campbells old Texas Ranger part. I only wish Josh Brolin and Berry Pepper could have had more screen time. I love westerns and can usually tell where they were filmed but in True Grit it was totally unique locations. I especially enjoyed the town set, I kept wondering where it was, I wish I could walk the streets. Jeff Bridges knocked it out of the park with his adaption of Rooster and Hailee Steinfeld was awesome and has a great future in motion pictures.I can't wait until this comes out on DVD.

reviews.review_title: More than just another "eye for an eye" Western movie
reviews.content: What an excellent film about a teenage girl who is willing to stop at nothing to avenge the murder of her father. After hiring Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges), who is a U.S marshal that is full of "true grit," the young Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) finds herself on a journey of lifetime while trying to track down and capture Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin), the man who killed her father. On their quest to bring Chaney to justice, a Texas Ranger by the name of LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), who has been tracking Chaney for months, joins their party.Rooster, Mattie, and LaBoeuf are a dynamic trio that performs some of the best acting I've seen in a Western movie in a long time. The characters of Rooster and Mattie are stupendous. Each character has a unique personality that seems to hilariously rub each other the wrong way throughout the entire film; however, by the end of the movie a great deal of respect is shared between all of them. This special bond is formed as a result of the trials and tribulations incurred on their hunt for Chaney.A common theme of the movie is "an eye for an eye," which Mattie certainly makes clear in her relentlessness to keep Rooster and LaBoeuf on his trail. This is a typical theme found in many Western movies. The ways of the Wild West forced individuals to deal with their problems on their own. However, this film has many more themes entwined within in it. True Grit delves deep into a theme dealing with basic human compassion. Rooster Cogburn is as rugged and as rough as they come on the exterior, but even he proves to be affectionate and ultimately to have a heart of gold.From the perspective of cinematography, the shots of the countryside were absolutely beautiful. The camera pans and the extreme long shots of the various types of landscape bring the Old West to life. The lighting in each scene is suburb. Several scenes use lighting to draw attention to a specific character; for example, the scene of Rooster in the courthouse with sunlight shining on him from the window at his back. Perhaps such shots are foreshadowing Rooster's benevolence? Nonetheless, this is a must see film; especially, for those of you who enjoy a good Western movie.

reviews.review_title: Although it is a remake, this film is sure to become a new classic.
reviews.content: Spoiler Aler..... True Grit is a memorable Western about a young girl who hires a tough US Marshall to hunt down her father's killer who also stole his horses. She decided to join the hunt despite the Marshall's orders for her to stay behind. The hunt is joined by a Texas sheriff who also wants the killer for other reasons and crimes he committed. The three then head to Indian lands to find the killer, but they face harsh realities on their journey. The main Character is Mattie Ross played by (Hailee Steinfeld) who is the protagonist in the film. She is filled with the need to avenge her father's murder committed by the outlaw Tom Chaney played by (Josh Brolin). She enlists the help of a US Marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges) who is a ruthless individual with deep mental scars and a itchy trigger finger. At first Marshall Cogburn is hesitant, but gives in after she persists in having him work for her. The two are also joined by LaBoeuf (Matt Damona) a Ranger from Texas who is intent on bringing in the fugitive.The main themes deal with revenge and redemption. Other sub themes are mentorship and determination. The theme of revenge is evident because Mattie is intent on killing her father's murderer without regard for her own life. The theme of redemption surrounds around Marshall Cogburn's character that seems to be in search of a purpose in life after killing so many people throughout his lifetime. The theme of mentorship is visible because the relationship between Mattie and Marshall Cogburn is that of a mentor and student as well as father figure. That is because Mattie doesn't really have good memories of her own father especially after he left her with the burden of avenging his life. There is also a love story between LaBoeuf and Mattie that never blooms. Mattie is wise for her age and is frustrated because people won't take her seriously. She manages to find some respect among equals who happened to be the ones aiding her in finding her father's killer.Character development is what makes the theme relevant. The character of Mattie Ross is a complex and at times stubborn and we learn that she is amazingly smart for her age which occasionally gets her into trouble with both Rooster and LaBoeuf. She is determined to catch her father's killer, but never considers turning him to the authorities. She is intent on exercising her eye for eye philosophical rights. On the other hand, the LaBoeuf character is set on bring Tom Chaney to Texas to face consequences. Just like another western called, "3:10 To Yuma" where the main character is intent on bringing a fugitive to justice and face trial. Mattie and LaBoeuf are both committed to their ideals, but they just happen to be on two opposite sides of the law. They are similar in many other ways because they are articulate, smart, and persistent. Because of their differences, they happen to be attracted to each other. The character of Rooster Cogburn is a drunk with many bad memories of his previous life and doesn't enjoy being a US Marshall very much. He views this hunt for Tom Chaney as his last chance for redemption and doing something worth doing. He and LaBoeuf have a strange somewhat uptight relationship and argue about everything. He takes to passively mentoring Mattie and is willing to sacrifice his life for her dangerous mission. Their undertaking is justified as the film progresses and each character states motives for embarking on such a operation. The dialogue in the film helps the believability of the characters and makes the theme come alive.The film uses incredible cinematic techniques such as lighting, costumes, and sound effects. The film also uses narration to speed the continuity and stays at a steady pace throughout. The lighting in the film is appropriate and adds an element of controlled chaos to the film. For example, some shots are done with full lighting takes advantage of outdoor lighting and sunlight while other shots are done with three dimensional shadows. The film is superbly edited and coherence is extremely calculated. The film is directed by the Cohen brothers Ethan and Joel who also directed a similar film called "No Country for Old Men" which explores the world of revenge and a US Marshall's search for a killer. True Grit is a film that speaks to the heart of revenge, redemption, and willingness to continue when odds are stacked against an individual. The film employs unbelievable cinematic techniques and is driven by powerful dialogue and spectacular acting by Haille Steinfeld, Jeff Bridges, and Matt Damon. Although it is a remake, this film is sure to become a new classic.

reviews.review_title: Filled with action, suspense and comedy, True Grit tells the tale of a young girls search for revenge.
reviews.content: Filled with action, suspense and comedy, True Grit tells the tale of a young girls search for revenge. Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) is a young, but very wise, strong and intelligent girl who has left her home to find the man who murdered her father. She employs the assistance of U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges). Although Cogburn is hesitant at first, eventually he agrees to assist Mattie in capturing her father's murderer Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Joined by LaBouef (Matt Damon), a Texas Ranger also in search of Tom Chaney, the 3 set off into the wilderness on a wildly entertaining man hunt. The Coen brothers did an amazing job in both the direction and editing of the film. Scenes were setup perfectly, and the transitions between scenes were clean and non-obtrusive. Particularly enjoyable were the action sequences. The camera follows the characters and switches back and forth between the people shooting and the people being fired upon. This sort of camera work goes a long way toward making the viewer feel like they are part of the action and the viewer also isn't stuck staring at a boring and static objective camera point of view. The lighting of the film works for the setting and feels very natural. The glow of campfires, the blazing sun, and the soft flickering light of candles all seem very realistic. The lighting is yet another example of how this film draws its viewers into the setting.The story of the film itself moves along at a quick speed, but not so quick as to confuse the viewer. The drunken and often humorous comments made by Marshall Cogburn often give the film a lighter and less serious vibe. In other words, the movie doesn't seem to take itself too seriously, and that is what makes this film so entertaining. Perhaps the most enjoyable aspect of the film is the characterization and story development. Although Marshall Cogburn, Mattie Ross, and LaBouef have different pasts and different personalities they are all searching for the same man for one reason or another. The characters types of the lead actors play very well off of each other even though each character's motivation seems to clash with the others. The story develops in such a way that the viewer develops a solid emotional attachment to the characters even though the film is relatively short. We learn a lot about each of the characters and in the end, we want to see them succeed in their task.Overall, True Grit is a fantastic western style film that shows a true passion for film making. The relatable story, the memorable characters, the realistic scenery, and the action packed gun fights make True Grit an extraordinary remake that is truly better than the original.

reviews.review_title: True Grit- more than just a summary
reviews.content: A young girl Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfelf) wants to go on a wild goose chase for her father's killer who she firmly believes is Tom Chaney (Josh Brolin). Mattie uses her stern tone and unwillingness to give up to get her way with whomever she comes across in order to get help to chase down on obtain Tom Chaney. Mattie is able to save up some money and gather information on the Marshal with the most "grit". This marshal is Rueben Cogburn (Jeff Bridges). Mattie visits Cogburn and hires him to help her fine Chaney, but with the stipulation that she must be able to come along. Before going out on this adventure Mattie is approached by Texas Ranger LaBouef (Matt Damon) who also has interest in finding Tom Chaney. Mattie has no interest in the Ranger LaBouef's assistance because Mattie wants Chaney all to herself to being into justice in her hometown. Mattie has no intentions of letting Chaney go to Texas to be returned to justice.Texas Ranger LaBouef and Marshal Cogburn head out to find Chaney without Mattie. Mattie catches up to the Ranger and the Marshal advising that she will be going along with them regardless of what the two men say about her not coming along. LaBouef is appalled about a young girl traveling along with the two men and being exposed to the roughness of what the chase for Chaney could bring. Cogburn knows that it is not a good idea either, but he lets Mattie come along. Cogburn seems to have an attitude knowing that the young girl cannot keep up with the two men, but he will let that be proved to Mattie because she's too stubborn and determined to find out any other way.The theme of this movie is focused on the plot. The plot being that Tom Chaney is a killer that needs brought to justice and Mattie, Ranger LaBouef and Marshal Cogburn are determined to make that happen. I am not much into Western movies and most likely would not have watched this movie if it had not been a selected movie for my movie analysis class. It actually turned out to be a really good movie and contained many more areas of focus than that of finding Tom Chaney. This movie was about proving a young girls determination to find the person that killed her father and proving to everyone that she could do what a grown man could do. This movie was also about Cogburn caring about someone more than himself. Cogburn was a stubborn, self-centered, and boastful drunk. He did not have time for anyone but himself, his alcohol and the target of who he was to kill. In this movie Cogburn grew to care about Mattie and was willing to protect her and help her at any cost. This movie reminds me of The Land Before Time movies. (I just spent the weekend watching several sequels of these movies with my niece). The plot of The Land Before Time movies is that the baby dinosaurs are determined to be grown up and to fight nature and other dinosaurs just like the grown-ups. Mattie's determination to find Tom Chaney and hunt for him like a grown-up reminds me of the baby dinosaurs and their determination to show that they can be grown up too. In the movie there are a lot of shots that the camera angle is high above where the action is happening. The area in which the camera is at is usually with Cogburn, Mattie and LaBouef looking down on the Tom Chaney and his posy. This happens several times in the movie and it gives an impression that Cogburn, Mattie and LaBouef are people of a higher value than that of Chaney and the men that ride, support and kill with him. The film angle giving this impression goes along with the attitudes of the Marshal and Ranger as they are the law, they bring in justice and no one can be above the law. Also the camera angles being high above Chaney and his posy also provide support to the self-assured attitudes of Mattie and Cogburn. Mattie and Cogburn were a lot alike with their stubbornness and boastful attitudes.The movie ended with Mattie, Cogburn and LaBouef getting what they wanted most, Chaney getting what they felt like he deserved. The movie jumped about twenty five years ahead at this time Mattie was looking to meet up with Cogburn again, but missed him by just a few days as he passed away from a health issue. Mattie never saw or heard from Ranger LaBouef again. Mattie stated at the end that she never married as she did not have time for bothering with a man, though she did not say why. My guess is that Mattie was too stubborn for a man and she found it less bothersome to handle life how she wanted rather than worry about her and someone else. Showing Mattie at this age and Mattie stating why she did not marry supported my earlier assumption that Mattie and Marshal Cogburn were very much alike than not with their stubborn and boastful ways.

reviews.review_title: This is how you do a remake!
reviews.content: While not the Coen brother's best film, this remake just works! It has a darker and more somber tone to it as well as an improved leading cast than the original. It's shot beautifully with viewers being given a chance to take in the expansive scenery as they follow Mattie Ross and Rooster Cogburn deep into the Indian Territory to track down the murderer Tom Chaney. I love that the run-time is just short of two hours long and that's all it needs! It's a straightforward film plot-wise(but it's not at the same time when you think of how deeply drawn these few characters are!), doesn't involve that many main characters, is short and sweet in some ways and yet still feels epic! You really get into it and feel like you've gone on this big adventure with these few characters that you've gotten to know. And when the characters don't speak, it's mainly to allow the actual backdrop and vast setting of the movie (which is like another character in itself thanks to the very talented cinematographer Roger Deakins, who made almost every frame of this film beautiful!) to speak to the audience, whether it's accompanied by music in some places or none in others. Having grown up watching westerns as a kid (thanks to my Dad's influence), this genre of film always has appealed to me in it's many different forms. I've always liked how a lot of the films could share similar(sometimes identical) plots, settings, characters and still feel different to the viewer. One can compare the early John Wayne westerns and even westerns like 'The Magnificent Seven'. A lot of these were classics that for the most part shared a lively and cheerful tone to them, even while containing gun violence and what would normally be considered dark themes. Compare these to when director Sergio Leone came out of nowhere with 'The Dollars Trilogy'! He took the genre by storm! The amazing music of Ennio Morricone, the hard-ass Eastwood and the much more gritty violence all made people change the way they thought about what a Western was! They had their playful moments for sure in their own way, but these were no longer the good old' jolly westerns the whole family would watch on a Sunday! They brought such an enormous contrast to the genre and laid down the foundations for so many more westerns that would even go an extra mile in darker tones! Back to True Grit! This remake I think successfully balanced the optimistic tone and sense of adventure from the original film (without being hokey! I know. I'm sorry John Wayne! It was good for it's time.), while also being gritty, more realistic and actually leaving a real emotional impact on viewing. And like a lot of other Coen Bros films, it's main heroine is unique and really surprises audiences. It may not be an all-out Coen Brother's film, but it has enough of them in it to be noticed and have a new twist while also being one of their more accessible films for wider audiences.

True Grit (2010)The Cohen brothers take on True Grit was simply great. They took a movie and novel and did not do the traditional "remaking" they turned it into something better in my opinion. The story of True Grit is about a 14 year old girl Mattie Ross, played by the very talented actress Hailee Steinfield, that takes matters into her own hands to try and avenge her fathers death by going after his killer Tom Chaney played by Josh Brolin. She enlists the help of Rooster Cogburn played by Jeff Bridges and is accompanied on the trip by another traveler Texas Ranger LaBoefu played by Matt Damon. The theme of the movie to me is Mattie must learn to accept that in the world, there are crooks and outlaws and we just have to accept that we are not always going to have everything our way.The actors and actresses in this movie did and outstanding job. Jeff Bridges take on Rooster really made it his own character. After seeing John Wayne play this part, I thought it would be very hard to top it. I believe Jeff thought this too and instead of trying to top it or make it better he took the character and made him his own. Actress Hailee Steinfield also made her presences known on this film. For a fourteen-year-old girl in this movie she really steals almost every scene she is in. Her stubbornness and perseverance are impeccable and you cannot help but watch the film in awe as she actors with actors who have been doing this far longer then she has even been alive. The Cohen brothers use several techniques in the film to help tie in their themes such as lighting, and angles. One scene they use great lighting in is the cabin scene where Rooster and Mattie stumble upon the true outlaws waiting for Tom Chaney and his gang to arrive. This was an intense scene and they use the lighting to give it that feel in those scenes. In addition, angles were important to the film to help give those scenes of them traveling or having the shoot out with Tom Chaney and his gang a more dramatic feel. This was a great film and I would recommend it to anyone because of how versatile it really is.

This movie, while entertaining, has too many drawbacks, I'm surprised it was nominated for academy awards.. First of all, the dialogue is poor. Jeff Bridges is hard to understand, and the screenplay itself made the dialogue difficult to follow. Maddie was the only one I could understand. The screenplay adaptations from the original were poor, with random characters such as a man in a bear suit in the wilderness who has no relation to the story. the ending was poor also, showing two random cowboys who give news of Roosters death and an older spinster type Maddie who turned out to be a crotchety witch of an old woman, nothing near true grit. Matt Damon was too old to be the Texas Ranger, a weak dichotomy between Rooster and LeBouef. Entertaining, but a weak remake of an original.

Never read the Charles Portis novel.Saw the original film when I was 11.41 years later, I saw the re-telling of the novel.Yes, I too questioned the decision to remake a John Wayne classic. But, it is the Coen Brothers. And they deliver a wonderful film that should have no difficulty existing in the same world as the first.Trivia ~ In 1969, The Duke's patch was on his left eye; in 2010, The Dude's patch is on his right eye. The 1969 Tom Chaney's powdermark is on his right cheek; in 2010 it is on his left cheek. In 1969, Mattie slides to the river on the left bank; in 2010 she slides down on the right bank.What other mirror opposites will you find? Coens... Gotta love 'em.

reviews.review_title: True Grit is worth seeing; maybe twice.
reviews.content: I'm a true fan of the original True Grit movie of 1969; so to best that movie would be a tall order. True Grit of 2010 delivers. This may well be Jeff Bridges's best role ever. I'd like to think that he would be Acadamy Award material for this movie. My hat's off to the Coen Bros. for their details and portrayal of the old west the way I think it really was. Once Mattie opens her father's trappings to a beautifully blued 2nd model Colt Dragoon and his Masonic Square and Compass I was totally sucked-in. When Mattie confronts her father's murderer she unleashes the wrath of that Dragoon only to land on her backside from the recoil. Now her Dragoon is wet and prone to misfire. Beautifully portrayed here but not so in the original 1969 version. The shoot out on the open flats below has to be exactly right; true grit without fears. When Matt Damon off loads the 45-70 Sharps you see the dirt fly on the other side of it's intended target. That's the kind of details only a shooter would know. True Grit of 2010 is a must see and a must own movie.

The film is obviously brilliant in many ways, but I have no interest in listing them here because everyone who has already read the reviews has come across lavish praise. Rather, I would like to add two observations, one wide-reaching, and one incidental.1. Dialog: The Cohen brothers seem to have carved out a nice little niche for themselves that allows them to write dialog that is completely over the top, time and time again. Most characters "sound" the same in terms of their word choices; as such, they lack individual personalities in this regard. Vocabulary is a huge part of character building in any film or a written piece of literature. It is a mystery to me why the Cohen brothers overlook this factor, to a large extent. Why? In my opinion, they like to "show off" their fifty dollar words. It started out as a need to "prove" themselves and now it is the millstones around their necks that allow critics to overlook this glaringly amateurish aspect of typical Cohen Bros dialog. I, myself, love language and words, but never at the expense of character building. The Cohen Bros proclivity for verbose and prolix dialog grows tiresome as the years wear on, especially when critics lavish them with awards for films that consistently showcase this glaring problem. Nobody will tell these "emperors" that they are buck naked in terms of their word choices. As William Blake would say, "enough or Too much!"2. Casting--specifically eye color and facial structure: Elizabeth Marvel looks nothing like Hailee Steinfeld. The most obvious problem with casting is eye color. Marvel has steely blue eyes and Steinfeld has dark brown eyes. On a large movie screen, this glaring inconsistency is unforgivable. Also, Ms. Steinfeld has multi-racial features owing to her exotic mother and Marvel looks like Pilgrim stock (emphasis on the "grim"). That severeness of appearance would have been fantastic if the Cohen brothers had cast a WASP for the young Mattie's role. But they did not, so why the heck did they cast Marvel? What were you thinking Cohen brothers? Dumb, dumb, dumb. This said: The choice to cast Steinfeld was brilliant. The choice to cast Marvel was anything but Marvelous. In short: this film should have been Marvel-less. There are plenty of multi-racially striking and brilliant actors who look more like Steinfeld. My choice would have been Jenette Goldstein. Her performance in Aliens back in 1986 was quite liberating, and she has the face and manner to pull off the tough/spinster roll of Mattie in 1903, sans arm. In short: She also looks enough like the young Mattie to be believable.

Awesome movie. Just watched it for the fifth or sixth time and my eyes stayed glued to the screen as if it were my first time. Stellar performances, witty dialogue, amazing cinematography.. Adapted from a novel, yes, but all so original. Highly entertaining, highly recommended. Thumbs up! In my opinion Hailee Steinfield deserved that best supporting actress Oscar over Melissa Leo. I personally didn't..couldn't't, appreciate her acting over Hailee's outstanding performance. Nothing against 'the fighter', it was a nice movie but that award certainly deserved to go home with Hailee that awards night. True Grit certainly showed true grit!

I told my wife that I wanted to stay and watch the movie again before we were fifteen minutes into it, so this review is not about whether I liked the movie or not. This review is a comparison of this movie to the original version.When there is a remake of a great movie, the obvious question is always why was it done.In this case, the obvious answer is that the makers of the new movie thought that the original True Grit was not gritty enough. "Gritty" is a somewhat amorphous term, but generally seems to mean that it's realer. It was apparently felt that a movie that was essentially a tragedy shouldn't look so pretty, and that it shouldn't have a country western singer in a starring role.Therefore, it was taken out of the California Sierra in Autumn, and put in Texas in Winter, and the serviceable performance by Glen Campbell in the original is replaced by the usual polished performance by Matt Damon.The overall level of acting in the movie is diminished, even by casting Damon as LaBoeuf, when Robert Duvall is replaced in the role of Lucky Ned Pepper by an actor whose last name happens to be Pepper. This tepid irony seems to be the only Coenism that I detected in the movie.There were unexpected plot turns, but none that seemed quirky and intentional. It seemed more like a Scott Rudin production than a Coen brothers production.The unexpected, and inexplicable, plot twists came mostly at the unsatisfactory ending of the film. Why didn't LaBouef die? If he wasn't dead, couldn't he have helped in getting Mattie to medical attention? Why did we need to know that Mattie never married, or that she lost her arm. What was that gratuitous snub of Jesse James at the end about? My daughter feels that the Academy committed a crime when the 1969 Best Actor Award was not given to Dustin Hoffman for playing Ratso Rizzo, and instead was given to John Wayne for playing John Wayne. It just so happened, though, that John Wayne was just right to play Rooster Cogburn, and Jeff Bridges didn't play John Wayne as well as John Wayne did.Making a movie more real is interesting and sometimes important when telling a true story, but True Grit was a made up story. There is no reason for a patron to feel sad at the end of a movie instead of happy if one is as real as the other.As I said, I enjoyed the new version of True Grit, but it wasn't as satisfying as the original.This doesn't mean True Grit should not be made again. The only failing of the original version was that it wasn't made in 3D.

reviews.review_title: The film was OK, but the original made it work for me.
reviews.content: The original "Duke" made the film for me, the remake is OK as it's takes a different slant on the story viewpoint. I know you should not really make a comparison, but it's hard not to when the original is still familiar. The John Wayne movies (especially the cowboys) were in a class of their own, this remake does have qualities that the original didn't for sure. Such as the language used, I would be interested in knowing if the take "type" had been researched. Understandable language traits have moved on considerably, but I could not get used to how polite everyone seemed. There was also a dirt factor that worked for me, the original Duke only ever looked dusty at best and never just plain filthy.

Of all the Westerns I have seen this was my favourite. The pacing is brisk and while I hate remakes 99% of the time this is that 1%. It was astounding and the performances were all top notch. I know there are some issues with Bridges dialogue being hard to understand, I did not find it bothersome after the 3rd or 4th minute.This movie is worth the price of admission and has not suffered at all upon a 2nd watching. An old west tale of vengeance is nothing new, but when done right it is still a workable model and this was brilliantly executed.To my viewing eye originality is crucial, but if a new story is not the way you are going it has to be stunning, this fits the bill. The casting was impeccable. Damon as the Ranger was curious but effective, Bridges following in the Duke's footsteps was brilliant, he brought something a little different so he was not just aping Wayne's iconic turn as Cogburn.

If I was writing a school report for this movie I'd say, 'Fair, but could do better.' Being a fan of the Hathaway version, in which Wayne - a limited actor but a great screen presence - gives a truly iconic performance, I wondered just how this would measure up. It's not bad but it is, I think, a missed opportunity to put an authentic reading of Portis' novel on film. In view of the Coens' insistence that they had gone back to the novel I was surprised at some of the deviations from the book, not to the script's advantage. The cast is fine, with Bridges wisely not trying to out-Wayne Wayne, but trying something different - perhaps nearer to the Cogburn in the novel. This is a really good acting performance. Damon is good (as always) and the young Mattie is fine, although not always being quite assertive enough as Kim Darby was. What I found missing was the droll humour of the first movie. Don't get me wrong, this is an enjoyable movie. It's just that I think it could have been better.

reviews.review_title: a nice western revenge drama with good fun played by excellent actors
reviews.content: Movie starts off as a revenge drama like many other western movies but this time it's a 14 yr old girl seeking the revenge. The girl's father is killed by Tom Chaney. She goes out and hires a tough marshal, Cogburn , played by Jeff Bridges to catch Chaney.Jeff Bridges is hilarious in the first scene when he is on trial in the court for murder. He is the kind of tough marshal who takes law into his hands and does not accept failure. He is getting old but has seen enough in his life time to trace out a fugitive in the desert.Matt Damon's character, Labeiff, a Texas ranger, starts out as a ranger who is out to do his job of catching Tom Chaney and joins the girl and marshal. He is good cop but not a tough one at it like the Marshal. Defensive at first but more mature and out to prove what he is capable of. You see Cogburn and Labeiff hesitating to proceed ahead sometimes and withdrawing their efforts, Cogburn terminating contract with the girl and Labeiff going back to Texas. It's the girl with the "True grit" having the motiviation and hunger to stick it out, no matter what. The girl's wit and innocence and childish sense of responsibility and ignorant braveness and her stubborness played out perfectly. It's what brings Cogburn and Labeiff back to save her.Overall, a nice western revenge drama with good fun played by excellent actors. I did not see the original movie but i enjoyed this one very well. A perfect movie for winter times!!

I wont bore you with the story, as you can read that in the description above, so I will make this review short and sweet. If you are interested in watching this movie, then please watch the original instead. John Wayne brings far more character to the role of Reuben (Rooster) Cogburn than the mumbling grumbling incomprehensible version that the otherwise wonderful Jeff bridges brings to the role. For some unknown reason they decided to make Bridges dialogue almost impossible to understand without subtitles, it's as if he had a mouthful of chewing tobacco the whole way through the film. However, there is one shining star of this movie, and that is Hailee Steinfeld.

Yesterday I bought a Blu-Ray edition of this movie, and after movie has ended I was really satisfied. This movie is NOT a remake of an John Wayne movie from 69'. It's not an actual remake, it's more to dedicated the book than Hathaway version.Acting is superb. Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon and little Steinfeld brought a movie to a whole new level. I admire Hailee Steinfeld's acting because she was really into the part she was given, and I was amazed. Jeff Bridges, on the other hand, was playing a cold, fearless sheriff who was almost always drunk. It was really entertaining to see him in that kind of role. Music was very good too, it was composed by Carter Burwell (The Big Lebowski, Fargo..)This movie is really good, Coen brothers made it again.

reviews.review_title: It's like a western Tarantino would have made. They just can't shut up.
reviews.content: True Grit though long winded it may be is an excellent character study, immersed in the environment of the old wild west. The cinematography is a work of art the shots look like paintings with falling snow and well lit cabin sets. Yet despite what it has going for it seems the writers can not get past their own perceived brilliance, often dragging out a 10 minute scene with issues that could have been resolved in 3.Jeff Bridges of Big Lebowski fame plays Rooster Cogburn a U.S. Marshal with an itchy trigger finger who is nagged into going on a man-hunt by a manipulative young girl who's father was murdered by a bumbling out law named Tom Chaney. The film itself is not so much about the hunt though as much as it is about the relationships between the characters. This is part of the Coen's style. They use characters as archetypes to get the point across; the bratty girl, the drunk trigger happy U.S Marshal, the half witted outlaw who is possibly using it as a act to appear less dangerous. Seeing them interact and go through one crazy scenario after the other is the major bulk and focus of the film, not the western brutality, or the hunt for Tom Chaney. The problem is the duration. Was it necessary to hear Rooster ramble on about his wives, or to see him get into it with LaBouf over his Texas heritage? No it wasn't but it's the Coen's trademark so don't expect that to change soon. Inexplicabe characters will show up then disappear never to be expanded on (the man in the bear skin), and some will receive a anti-climatic demise (really that was the fate Tom Chaney?).However script complaints aside this was a good experience to feel taken back to the era of cowboys and revolvers. Few times has the presence of the west been filmed so convincingly, and the dialog is spoken beautifully using words people don't normally speak these days, at least not like that. It's a shame it was over done. You see dialog is like oxygen molecules fusing with carbon... too much makes it poison.

reviews.review_title: Give it a rest with the remakes already!
reviews.content: OK let me start by saying that this is less a review on this movie and more an assault on all these pathetic remakes. Granted this particular remake was far superior to the original but its the coen brothers with there gigantic budgets and grade A cinematographers so thats no surprise. I actually found the original true grit to be pretty terrible in almost every way. But I would like to take this opportunity to plead with the "people" of earth, Please stop supporting all these stupid remakes. We all know that the studios are just trying to manipulate more demographics. Its bad enough when no name directors do this but its escalated to where a lot of the industry giant directors are wasting there time and credibility doing these pathetic remakes. I will summarize by saying that they are only making these because for some stupid reason there is a demand for them, and I truly feel that this is the beginning of the end of film as we know it ( more so in north America) so if anyone cares about the future of film please be a little more selective, don't go see something just because its out, go because you think it is original or well done. Lets take the power back!

The movie was interesting,but mostly violent.It was slow moving at times.I would not recommend it because of some language. Specifically the irreverent use of God's name as a curse word 3-4 times.Although it had verses of scripture here and there,and some background hymn music it did not stand true to Christian virtues. Vengeance, as outlined in the brief movie summary is the direction of the movie. So overall I say a rating of three.Some funny elements at times,and also a few touching moments,but mostly swings around in all directions. It did not seem like a true western at all, but had the dressed up feel to it.Very incomplete dialog.Fractured at best.

reviews.review_title: Excellent acting, more humorous than I thought
reviews.content: Its the use of the original language that makes it! a little like Shakespeare cowboy style, with all the nuances and hidden humour that style can provide. Excellent acting performances all-round although bridges is humorously impossible to understand, he gives a rounded performance that blows John Wayne's socks off. Will now search the Coen's catalogue to see if other titles lie this that nod to the original source- great fun Ending though doesn't somehow fit with the feel of the film I thought?? Matt Damon too having a blast a a slightly camp Texas ranger and looking slightly scarily like Robert Redford at the start.

reviews.review_title: Great performances and a solid story!
reviews.content: The Coen brothers delivers again, this time with a classic western story and it is fun, engaging and entertaining. The best part is the marvelous performances by the great actors, especially veteran Bridges and newcomer Steinfeld. And Matt Damon as the somewhat fragile Texas Ranger is a good counterpart to the strong leads. Josh Brolin doesn't have a big role even though he is up there with the others on the posters, but what he does is solid. True Grit is a movie filled with great dialogue and effective humor. The cinematic experience lives up to the expectations as you are drawn into a totally believable world. My only complaint is that this world, and the characters portrayed here sometimes is a little bit too stereotypical, but that is also part of the fun. Great movie!

We are treated to a series of episodes and vistas rarely seen in recent Westerns. Here is a movie that gives us the feeling of taking a virtual trip to the Old West, a place full of the stereotypes so prevalent in this film, but exquisitely and masterfully presented and shot through the eyes of Roger Deakins outdoing his previous work. Here are desolate vistas, births of new towns, a palpable depiction of the tough, lawless early days of the Western frontier. We see the recreation of the growing settlements, the restrictive gender situations and social differences. No detail has been left out or spared. It takes almost a documentary feel, but this is contrasted with the realistic approach and the attention to the speech of the times. Yes, the words and their delivery was different. People went beyond "see ya" or "talk 2 u, 2" back then. They knew specific terms for particular emotions and items, and though a bit unsettling at first, it's very impressive how the young Hailee Steinfeld completely commands the screen whenever she is in front of the camera and must speak her part.

reviews.review_title: A Shadow of the John Wayne Epic
reviews.content: This movie pale's in comparison to the original, and seemed a lot shorter too. With a run a time only 18 minutes less than the original it feels like a good 30 to 45 minutes less, because of how much is cut or rushed. Now making the remake shorter in and of itself is not necessarily bad, but the parts they did put large and important holes in the story and character development. The acting is generally terrible, particularly Bridges and Damon who overact so much its makes their characters seem comical and nearly incomprehensible. Honestly I couldn't understand half of what Bridges said because he mumbled so much, and Damon's character is barely in the movie and is never developed like in the original. Only Steinfeld did a comparable job, which was fairly true to the original, but with her touch to the character. Brolin is completely wasted in this film as he literally had only 5 minutes of screen time. The Coen brothers would have been well advised to have completely reworked the story so as to avoid the comparison's (which are fair considering they tried to keep it as close as possible), and put their own touch on the story.

I loved the original True Grit and was looking forward to this remake, especially with Jeff Bridges playing Rooster Cogburn. However, I found that throughout the film the script attempted to make the actors repeat almost the exact lines from the original film. This made me focus on comparing John Wayne with Jeff Bridges and Bridges was a pale imitation of Wayne in my view. Couldn't the scriptwriters have varied their script from the original? Same for the character Ned Pepper, originally played by Robert Duvall. Some of the acting appeared a little stilted possibly because they seemed to be speaking their lines almost verbatim from the original film. Josh Brolin in particular seemed a little uncomfortable with his lines. Just my opinion but disappointing. However, Hailee Steinfield was superb as Mattie.

The original was made in a different time. A time when realism and true grit, we're things not desired in a movie. John Wayne got his Oscar for this movie as a gift. While he did a great job portraying Rooster, he was still The Duke, playing a character. Enter the modern version, detailed down to the ink staining the store owners fingers. Pure historical fiction and a beautiful rendition of the old west. This is the movie I gained respect for Matt Damon as well. In short, he let himself go in this movie and showed he was more than just a one dimensional actor, but a true genius of his trade. I give this a 10 because only a few movies have ever compelled me to watch through the end of the credits. This one was among them. You have to let this movie take you to another time or you will miss what it's trying to show. The end.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest work of coen brothers.
reviews.content: Coen brothers as always done a great job. I loved the heart breaking performance from Heilee Stenfield as well as Jeff bridges. Matt give his small though significant role. The narration is simple yet powerful. Soundtrack and cinematography was equally great.

In comparison to the John Wayne original, this fails in every way. Sure this version has great costumes, invokes nostalgia for the westerns of old and features some big names, to boot. The Coen's make great movies. This is not one of them – possibly they just had too hard a task at hand and it all feels a bit lack-lustre as a result. From the off, it lost the little nuances (from the original) that draw you into the characters, the dialogue felt wooden and there were just too many irritating bits in the film to break the flow. Without any comparisons (to the original), it's just long and dull....a 6* rating at best. Great film for a long plane journey - it'll send you off nicely.

I am a fan of the Coen brothers and was really looking forward to this film. There are no heroes in their films, and I went in expecting a darker interpretation of the novel. I was not disappointed - the interpretation was indeed darker and the film was better for it. It's the acting that really brought the film down. Is Jeff Bridges a good actor? Of course he is. But he had big boots to fill, and his feet simply aren't large enough to fill them. In fairness, it would be tough for anyone to follow an icon. Berry Pepper was good too, and maybe he will grow into a Robert Duvall some day - but not yet. Hailee Steinfeld plays the Mattie role more stiffly than Kim Darbie, but both did a great job. This is still a great story, and this version will be a good movie to rent. But it's tough to beat an original, and that's the case this time around.

reviews.review_title: 2 hours of my life I can't get back
reviews.content: Really?! Half the time I couldn't understand Jeff Bridges. Yes, I appreciate he was 'in character' but the dialogue was strained. And after many cuts of trailing across the wilderness, a chance bit of action and it's all over.

reviews.review_title: A poor remake of a classic film
reviews.content: The film is nearly a word for word remake but with inferior acting and interpretation. The humour that was in the original is still in the script but delivered so badly that it practically passes you by. Jeff Bridges tries his hardest to have a grittier persona than John Wayne but only succeeds in boring the pants off the viewer. The girl playing Mattie is about as exciting as a piece as wood and the actor playing LeBoueff brings nothing to the table. While the original had a great supporting cast who all brought something to a great story this remake has no memorable performances by anyone apart from the snoring grandmother. I can see why someone who has not seen the original would enjoy the movie but all I wanted to do after watching it was shout out to the audience that if they watch the original they will see everything they have just seen but with better acting, better screenplay and even better music.

OK, OK, Hailee Steinfeld is excellent, Matt Damon was surprisingly good and Jeff Bridges was not bad -- but to me the Coens lost interest about half the way through. I don't know if it was the editing, the script or just the rhythm of the story that just went haywire and it started to seem a bit sloppy. Mattie Ross falling in the cave with those ridiculous CGI snakes? Why? It was totally incongruous to me - the rest of the cinematography is quite stripped down and and then we suddenly get bonkers effects. Sorry, but that let me down as did the clunky script for the second half.

reviews.review_title: Not up to Par for the Cohens
reviews.content: Very disappointing movie. I expected more from the Coens. Terribly slow to the point of being ponderous. No much of a story, really. Pretty predictable, too. Steinfeld as Matty was not believable as a 14-year-old. Didn't read the book but the Matty character had to be exaggerated as no one 14 has such a grip on the law coupled with such negotiating skills. Especially in the latter 1800's in Arkansas. Jeff Bridges was pretty good as Cogburn but he seemed to be trying too hard. Came off more as a caricature than a role. Matt Damon's portrayal of a Texas Ranger didn't fit in at all. He looked and acted like a 20th Century cowboy rather than someone from the rough and tumble frontier. Some of the scenes were far-fetched. For instance, why Cogburn, a seasoned horseman, would ride his mount into the dirt is inexplicable. Can't say I would recommend this flick to anyone. The Coen's missed on this one.

Coen brothers present a western which is pure film. I believe that westerns have got some main features. westerns are always simple film. I mean that their stories are not so complicated. furthermore, their budget is not high-priced. western films express to us past living that were poor and simple. that is reason why westerns should be simple. In my opinion, Coen brothers created a very successful western world in true grit.when we look scenes of true grit, we can see how they are simple. for example; the scene of sheriff Cogburn's judgment include simple dialogs and simple decor. moreover, when sheriff Cogburn and Mattie Ross trail in pursuit of tom Chaney, there is not complicated. their target is certain and, their lifestyle are simple life.In my opinion Jeff Bridges played very well, he played such as a real sheriff. moreover, Barry Pepper played very well as a lucky Ned. maybe his scenes are not so much , however he played very well. this film is the very good example of the westerns.

reviews.review_title: True Grit will win tons of Awards!
reviews.content: This is a movie which people will really enjoy regardless of whether they normally like Westerns. The acting is as good as it gets for a female lead, especially a 14 year old. Jeff Bridges nails his character as the past his prime gritty, selfish Marshall! Matt Damon puts in the only sub-par performance of the film. Damon doesn't seem to understand how to capture the soul of a 1800's Texas Ranger. He seems quite uncomfortable in that role. Overall its a wonderful movie full of Oscar level acting. The back drop and scenery is completely believable as you feel swept back 150 years. The tension between the gruff Marshall and the headstrong girl keeps you enthralled. You never quite know if she loves him or loathes him.

reviews.review_title: It Required True Grit to Attempt This Remake
reviews.content: Liked it better than I thought I would. I'm a big fan of the earlier film and the novel, still, this movie holds its own. I'm not a huge Jeff Bridges fan, but he did a fine job with his version of Rooster. So, too, did Hailee Steinfeld as Mattie Ross.Matt Damon did his best as the Texas Ranger...but that character is a third wheel in the novel, the first movie, and, now, in the second. Don't mean to blame Damon...the Texas Ranger is an odd character. Didn't much care for the action as it played out when the Texas Ranger encountered Ned's gang. The writing slipped at that point.The setting was probably truer to the novel's as was the ending, and using that ending was to the movie's detriment. I don't think it has the satisfaction of the first movie's ending. And I didn't like the new version of Tom Cheney's demise which deviated from the novel and the first film.Even so, hat's off to all involved in attempting a movie remake of a film (and from a novel) some of us regard highly. Not an easy task, but they put together a very good movie here.

This film captures everything I was hoping for it to have. It was funny, scary, suspenseful, well written, beautifully shot and so on. I find no fault in the film and i have been trying to for some time now.There was no sex in the film to speak of and the language can at worst be described as salty. At first I read this as being weak and the Coen brothers trying to get the film out to a more accepting audience. But as i reflected on the film further, i came to a realization of sorts. If Cogburn had been shown leaving the room of a prostitute at one point while he was in town, and there was some nudity or sex, it would have added nothing at all to the film. We learn exactly what kind of a man he is without sex or nudity. As for the language, it didn't need to be any worse. Not everyone in the west had to drop the f- bomb at the drop of a hat. Nor did women have to be called horrible things. Cussing can work well in a film. Tarantino and Scorsese use it well. But this film simply stands on it's own and needs no artificial aids.

reviews.review_title: The Coen Brothers deliver some "True Grit"
reviews.content: True Grit was in fact a very well made movie, starring Jeff Bridges as a badass U.S. Marshall who is helping a young girl who's father has been killed by a murderous Josh Brolin. Along the way in the story Jeff Bridges encounters a remarkable Texas Ranger in which Matt Damon plays. At first Jeff, and Matt don't exactly have "the same morals" but the two are great together, depicting their characters perfectly. In the story there are a few very boring parts in which they are practically telling you to fall asleep, but this happens very rarely leaving the viewer wanting more of the movie. The end of the movie is not exactly what I expected, it disappointed me ending very abruptly. All and all I must say that the Coen brothers painted a great picture of the old west, and, other that a few minor parts, did a great job on the movie.

reviews.review_title: Serious or funny? A little bit of this and that Coen-film
reviews.content: I like this movie, allot really but you will not know what is gone a come at your face (*haha*). Coen brothers are one of those filmmakers that make a movie after movie and they are good, but not brilliant (but good). They made: No Country For Old Men, Burn After Reading, A Serious Man, three very great films that made me laugh or blew my mind, this is the movie that wasn't like those three, but still good. Jeff Bridges is very love-able as the Marshall (But you can't hardly understand him) and Hailee Steinfield was awesome as Mattie Ross. Mat Damon was really good too, i just thought he was not at all in the movie. He showed up, then left, he showed up again, then he left again. There are two problems in this movie and they are Big: 1. It's PG-13, not enough awesome violence like in No country for old men (I mean, it's a western. It only got a one big scene with some blood in it, like allot of blood) 2. It's only 110 minutes, the movie doesn't got enough time to do some fun, it only showed some depressed scenes, allot of long dialog scenes and Bridges and Steinfield running on horses. reviews.review_title: Pointless pile of pony droppings (opinions may vary on whether this contains spoilers, but don't put any pony droppings in your coffee)
reviews.content: Does nobody who wrote such glowing reviews of this depressing pile of pony-droppings remember the original "True Grit" with John Wayne, and that razor-witted firecracker who played opposite him (Kim Darby)? I'm not even old enough to have been there, but it's still widely available, and cheaper than the price of a movie ticket. The 1969 movie was as fun to watch as it was shocking, without all the depressive realism which destroyed the point in spending two hours of your life watching a movie. While it's a valid point that too little realism is insulting to modern, educated viewers, how many have so little pain in their own lives, and so much time that they can stand to watch movies of the trend set by "No Country For Old Men" and "The American" - movies which are only painful to watch, and always end on a depressing note?John Wayne and his directors struck a reasonable balance between entertainment and realism. The 1969 movie showcased an acerbic wit in both Wayne's Cogburn and Darby's rendition of Mattie Ross. Wayne portrayed a functional drunk, who could still manage to shoot strait, even if he was in the process of losing that. There's nothing funny about watching the Cogburn played by Jeff Bridges, an old man who can't even speak, kill himself with hugely exaggerated drunkenness. Honestly, it was less believable than Wayne's drunken hero Cogburn to see Bridge's much older, and much too exaggeratedly drunk act. Considering the hypothermia-inducing conditions, animal and firearm dangers of the territory which he was supposedly on, nobody would expect him to pick himself off the ground in the morning. Anyway, if the Coens want to preach Prohibitionist politics, then it should be the appropriate political parties who pay them, not the viewer. Ross was not all childish virtue when portrayed by Kim Darby in the original movie, and the remarkable cunning which she displayed was entertaining, inspiring, and her script was more honest in light of what she was up against.The movie, when made in 1969, also paid far more actors, and more interesting scenes, while treating the viewer to much stunning outdoor footage, accuracy to the location or season notwithstanding. Many of the scenes in the 2010 rendition were done in the dark, which besides making it more painful to watch, saved the Coens much money on set and footage detail. Altogether, the 2010 remake, for those who know better cinema, stunk worse than a rotting corpse in a snake pit of cheapness, and the re-tooling of the dialogue served only to completely remove all of the fun. It's a waste of time to watch if you've seen The Duke, and all who played in the 1969 movie, and it's a ten-dollar movie ticket wasted.

reviews.review_title: Very little difference for all the hype.
reviews.content: I am a big fan of both John Wayne and Jeff Bridges and see very little difference in their performances except for the scruffy beard. For the Coen's to say Wayne didn't deserve an Oscar and then make Bridges practically the same is absurd. To say they wrote the new version is as ridiculous. I sat through the film quoting dialogue along with the characters from the original, so that couldn't have taken long, or cost much. Due to the lack of westerns nowadays this was a very good effort but I thought the ending was lame compared to Wayne's fence jump. As far as Retribution goes it must mean the Coen's are getting even with their dad for making them watch too many John Wayne movies. The part where Rooster kicks the Indians around was unnecessary.

I am frustrated that the trailer didn't say anything about a snooty little kid that goes around down talking everyone she meets - no doubt - each person is male.Possible replies to this comment include: "It's empowering to women" and "men and women are equal"Well I'm not saying that they aren't. But think of it this way, if the kid was a boy instead, the older men would have torn him to bits already. Such disrespect is ridiculous.Lol, I love how at the end her excuse for not getting married is "I never had time for it"AHHA, well of course in 1880 she must have been busy with her career, or raising the children she didn't have. Also, what excuse does she have for treating the guy at the end of the movie like trash? She is so sexist towards men. She has this preconception that all men are scum so she treats them so.

reviews.review_title: Cracking Western, very real, excellent acting.
reviews.content: Excellent acting throughout the film, obviously not just the main stars but especially for the actors playing Mattie and Ned Pepper characters. They stood out for me, but they were all very good.Set in a time and a vast place,1880s Mid West, that we can only try and somehow imagine now. Just imagine riding for days and days in the wild in unbelievable cold and dangerous conditions, danger from people, animals, the weather and disease. It seems like everyone you came across could either be a friend and helper or the person that takes your life without thinking!Amazing how 25 years transformed the true wild west into a show-time wild west. But the real wild west as shown was Cold, hard and a complete unsparing wilderness - one brilliantly portrayed in the film! Now going to change my vote from 8 to 9 on the strength of Hailee Steinfeld's acting, so strong.

reviews.review_title: A Short And True Review For Western Fans
reviews.content: I am going to try to keep this review short and to the point. Focused for people that are fans of Westerns and have seen the original True Grit.If you are watching this film hoping to see a better version of the original, you will leave your seat with nothing but thoughts on how they went wrong with this flick. We all knew going in there was no chance in competing with one of the best John Wayne movies, and it will take this knowledge and giving this movie the chance of being 'its own' to have a good experience.Hailee Steinfeld plays a great 'new' Mattie. Quick witted, she provides a great mix of crude comedy and intense determination.Jeff Bridges has the unfortunate task of replaying John Wayne. Given this impossible job to start with, I would have to say he does a pretty great job of following the original, yet bringing this character into his own.Overall, this is a good film. If you wait for it to come out on disk, you wont be missing anything, but if you find yourself bored with some time, seeing it in the theaters will not hurt anything.

reviews.review_title: A surprisingly traditional western-that's not a bad thing though.
reviews.content: The Coens have crafted something very worthwhile here. They have made a fairly simple western revenge thriller, without any of the usual ironic distance in previous their films, instead consentraiting on story telling. The difference here being that the language used is highly sophisticated-it has a rugged beauty which reflects the landscape around it. It also boasts excellent performances from the two leads.I've said it's a traditional western-that's true in the sense that it has a much more black/white morality to it than those of the Eastwood/Leone school (not to the discredit the latter). However it does give the viewer some space to reflect on the action-it's clear who is in the right but are they doing the right thing? In the context of the Coens' previous work this is not their best, it is up there, though without the quirky humour and irony it might disappoint fans-but it is a very good, well executed, compelling film. With all these traits in mind, does it need the personal touches of the directors in question?

reviews.review_title: A Pulp Fiction rip off, so to speek
reviews.content: A very entertaining movie based on a genius dialogue. But it's hard not to compare the overall impression to that of Tarantinos Pulp Fiction in terms of genre-crossover-experiments. In this perspective, True Grit positions itself as a post-modern production, where Monty Python-like dialogue meets ultra violence. The Cohen brothers does their best to tender the audience with twisted anecdotes of the west, masters as they are. But the sole appearance of a fall into a pit of snakes á la Spielburg leaves you wondering if this is a standalone masterpiece or a clumsy remake of more than one movie. I'm entertained but I long for a non-Hollywood Cohen production.

reviews.review_title: A carbon copy waste of time!
reviews.content: I am a European and a huge fan of American westerns so when I rented the new much vaunted True Grit DVD last night I was waiting with eager anticipation. How disappointed I was this 'new' version is a frame by frame remake of the Duke's classic of 1969.It reminded me of the pointless color remake of Psycho- the Hitchcock classic- some years ago.True the new movie is more gritty and realistic, but thats to be expected in a modern movie, particularly made by the Coen's. Although Jeff Bridges tries very hard to avoid an impersonation of the Duke he doesn't quite succeed, in fact he largely reprises his Wild Bill Hickok character from a few years ago. The photography is good but the lethargic pace and lack of action make this production a meaningless process, and a greatly over-hyped one at that. Stick to the Duke's original and save on the popcorn and rental fee!

I feel asleep 4 times during this movie. No matrix-like special effects or camera techniques. Looks like they wanted to make something fast and cheap. How expensive is it to film some horses out on a dusty trail? I'm no film expert, but I'm sure it's pretty cheap.Some classics need to be left alone. Next they're going to remake Starwars with Justin Timberlake playing Luke Skywalker.The "4" that I gave was very generous and is based on the actors doing a great job.All in all, avoid this movie at all costs...

A first-class western, solidly entertaining and rich in fine craftsmanship. The Coen brothers went back to the harsh terrain of West Texas, where their Oscar-winning masterpiece 'No Country For Old Men' was set and shot, to film this epic quest of justice. It's a decidedly straightforward exercise in genre filmmaking, lacking the quixotic touches Joel and Ethan usually bring to their films. To be honest, were their names not in the credits you could suggest this film was made by any good filmmaker. They pair up with cinematographer Roger Deakins once again, and he shot this beautifully--strikingly lit scenes, winter nights that look as cold as they are, lovely scenic vistas that recall the visual glory of the best movies in this genre. The brothers have stated with persistence that this is not a remake of the 1969 Henry Hathaway film which won John Wayne his Oscar. They stick more closely to the Charles Portis novel both films are based on. The film's most savory asset is the pitch-perfect period dialogue, rich in local color and cadences. The great Jeff Bridges tackles the Duke's role, growling/grumbling his lines, relishing playing drunk and craggy but terrific in suggesting the hard-bitten intelligence his Rooster Cogburn has. Matt Damon has superb timing and makes an intriguing, chatty Texas Ranger all too ready to get defensive about his job title and his home state. Josh Brolin, despite getting third billing, only actually appears on screen for a limited amount of time in the third act. But his chiseled face and menacing eyes instantly suggest the rattlesnake lurking beneath the guise of a slow-witted man. He's so good you wish he had more screen time. Barry Pepper, a superbly sturdy character actor in role after role, shows up as another villainous outlaw thug. But the real standout is Hailee Steinfeld, who is a knockout in her first role. At only 14 she nails the part, able to suggest her character's beyond-her-years wisdom and resourcefulness, her "true grit" as it were. But she also conveys the understandable fear a young girl would feel when she walks into a situation and comes to understand she's in over her head. That first-timer Steinfeld more than holds her own with Bridges, Damon and Co. is one of the great movie-going pleasures of the holiday season. The film's meandering pace will test some viewers, but the shocking bursts of violence, the dark, dry sprinkles of wit, and the thrilling confrontations of the third act are enough--along with the performances and direction--to make this one of your best bets for entertainment at the cinema right now

Like all the Coen Bros movies, True Grit is beautifully shot, the scenery is stunning and there are some typically quirky moments in the cinematography. The story is compelling, and the dialogue is surprisingly droll which enhances the bleak atmosphere even more. The direction is superb, Carter Burwell's score is wonderfully atmospheric, the pace is more secure here and the final shoot out which stood out in the 1969 film is glorious. The performances are also really good. Jeff Bridges had the great John Wayne to compete with, not an easy feat at all, and while he is a more monotone Rooster Cogburn he is a revelation charisma and performance wise. Matt Damon impresses too, and Hailee Steinfeld is a big improvement on Kim Darby and comes very close to outshining her co-stars.

More importantly, Hailee Steinfeld shines as Mattie Ross, the wise-beyond-her-years, smooth-talking girl who is intent on avenging the murder of her father, outshining Kim Darby from the earlier version.
